item.title: Shaka Bahadu Class of ?96
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
When Shaka Bahadu was three years old, his parents took him to a local preschool to be tested for admission. Unfortunately, the toddler was not accepted. "I was supposed to put together a puzzle but I refused," Shaka explains nearly twenty years later. "I?m not exactly sure why. I guess I wasn?t in the mood at the moment."

A friend steered Shaka?s parents in the direction of the Academy, where either Shaka was in a better mood during his admissions test or Molly McDermott, the admissions director, saw beyond the recalcitrance of a three-year-old to Shaka?s immense potential. Shaka began his GPA odyssey in the Early School and ended as student council president his eighth grade year. He became interested in student government in fourth grade and served as a student representative every year until his eighth grade year, when he ran for the office of president.
In addition to student government, Shaka was very active in athletics at the Academy, participating in soccer, basketball and tennis every year during middle school. He performed well academically, although he describes himself as "a late bloomer." When he was in third grade, his mother passed away, and Shaka went through a rough two years. "I didn?t pull myself out of it until about half way through fifth grade," he recalls, ?but the teachers were very understanding. I could talk to them about how I felt and they were totally cool with it."

Shaka went on to University Liggett School for high school, where he felt "tremendously prepared. I walked into Liggett and got into every advanced and honors class I could get into. I really wanted to continue the work ethic I had learned at the Academy. I worked hard, and when I got to high school I kept going. I wanted to continue everything I had done at the Academy."

When it came time to apply to college, Shaka originally had his sights set on Stanford. Harvard "was supposed to be a long shot," he says. When he got in, it was a tough decision. Ultimately he decided on Harvard. "You don?t say no to the big ?H?!" he jokes. Harvard also offered him a financial aid package he couldn?t refuse. As far as his college experience is concerned, Shaka says "it was rough at first, but it was exactly where I needed to be. I?ve learned how to think independently, which is the most important part.? While at Harvard, Shaka was elected First Class Marshal of the Class of 2004, which essentially makes him class president for life. He majored in Biological Anthropology, studying the evolution of human nature, and, as a pre-med student, took a heavy load of science courses. This latter has aptly prepared him for his current endeavor. Upon graduating, Shaka signed up for Teacher America, a non-profit organization that selects recent college graduates to teach at inner city schools where they are most needed.

"Science was by far my favorite class at the Academy," Shaka says. "Now I am teaching eighth grade science to inner city youth in Miami." Shaka truly believes in the mission of Teacher America, which is "for every child to have the opportunity to receive an excellent education. The concept behind it is to give emerging leaders of this country - future politicians, business people, lawyers and doctors - practical experience in our educational system to see where the flaws and benefits are, so that one day when we are in the position to make changes, we can."

Following this two-year commitment, Shaka plans to apply to medical school, where he will continue the educational experience that began at the Academy Early School. Says Shaka: "The Academy prepared me academically, socially, emotionally, and mentally. It was by far the best educational experience I?ve had so far - including Harvard."

item.title: Emily Liggett Class of '04
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
To go away to boarding school for her freshman year of high school was Emily Liggett's choice. It was a difficult and scary decision, but not one she has regretted, not even during those occasional moments of homesickness. Up until last year, her only experiences away from home were trips to Black River Camp and going on the Academy Adventures camping trip to central Ohio the summer after her fifth grade year at the Academy.

"The first week was a blast," Emily says of her freshman year at the Lawrenceville School in New Jersey. "And then the work came."

While she found the first trimester very difficult, she got her "act together in the second trimester," she reports. "I remembered what I had learned at the Academy, the techniques for studying. These really helped me organize my thoughts."

Clearly these techniques - along with hard work - have paid off. She finished her third trimester with a 3.8 grade point average. And in spite of a rigorous year of core classes required of freshmen at Lawrenceville, she still found time for extracurricular activities. For example, she joined the tennis team in the fall, played basketball in the winter, and ran track in the spring. She also worked backstage for plays and joined a number of clubs, including the Fellowship of Christian Athletes and the Lighthouse, both student organized Christian clubs. In addition, she was involved in the Young Republicans' Club (although she admits her interest in debating members of the Young Democrats' Club waned a bit after the election), and helped raise money to send to third world countries as part of Operation Smile - an organization that helps pay for operations for children born with cleft palates.

Emily was used to being busy and active while she was at the Academy, too, in spite of ambitious academic standards she set for herself. She not only consistently received High Honors while in middle school, but she maintained over a 4.0 grade point average throughout her middle school career. On the athletic front, she was the #1 singles tennis player for two years, and played varsity basketball for three years and varsity volleyball for two years. "I loved the volleyball season!" she says, in particular the mentor program, in which varsity players work with JV players on such skills as bumping and spiking. Favorite experiences at the Academy include the Washington, D.C. trip in fourth grade. "It was the best trip I ever went on," she says. "It really opened my eyes to the world."

All of Emily's former teachers at the Academy would be proud of the confident, poised young woman she has become. With a summer spent rejuvenating at home, traveling with her family and at camp with her two sisters, she is ready for the challenges of her second year away. She looks forward to expanding core course offerings and taking ceramics in the winter term and a class on the Bible in the spring. She also looks forward to participating in some of the school's traditions for sophomores, such as getting a big sister. She herself will be a big sister for real to her own younger sister, Marjorie ('05), who will be joining her at Lawrenceville this fall.
item.excerpt:encoded: To go away to boarding school for her freshman year of high school was Emily Liggett's choice.

item.title: Academy Names Athletes of the Season
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy eighth graders Bennie Fowler and Chloe Kirchner were named Athletes of the Spring Season at a closing assembly for Middle School students. Each was chosen for this honor based on his or her athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship.

Bennie Fowler was the co-captain and leading scorer of the boys? varsity basketball team, setting a new school record for points in a season. For his strong offensive leadership he was named Most Valuable Player and Bulldog by his teammates. Bennie, an all-around athlete, also played on the lacrosse team in the spring and is on the school?s citizenship list.

Chloe Kirchner was a member of the varsity volleyball team and received awards for best setter and best digger. She was also named co-MVP of the girls? varsity soccer team. In addition to being a scholar athlete, Chloe is a member of the National Junior Honor Society and is on the school?s high honors roll, citizenship list and Head of School list. Chloe also plays on the girls? tennis and basketball teams in the fall.

item.title: Eighth Graders Cut Loose in Footloose
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy eight graders cut loose in a spirited rendition of Footloose on June 9.

Each of the 28 students in the graduating eighth grade class was involved in every aspect of the production, from building the elaborate sets (there were numerous scenes that need to be staged, including a town hall, a school, a burger joint and a church) to creating the choreographies.

Each student also took the spotlight while acting, dancing and singing. Songs and choreographies included such favorites as Footloose, Holding out for a Hero, Dancing in the Streets, and Let's Hear it for the Boys.

item.title: "Learning Bridges" Link Academy Teachers to Experts
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy teachers will have a unique professional development opportunity this school year in the form of audio seminars offered by the Independent Schools Association of the Central States (ISACS). The seminars will offer expert presentations on a variety of education-related topics. The October seminar, "Homework Practices that Really Work," will launch the series. Harvard University professor Grant Wiggins will present two seminars: "Writing Essential Questions" in October and "The Role of Questioning in Teaching and Learning" in March. Carol Ann Tomlinson of the University of Virginia offers "Differentiated Instruction: What Matters Most?" in November. Other topics include "The Power of Mindsets: Nurturing Motivation and Resilience in Students" by Harvard Medical School psychologist Robert Brooks and "Discipline Strategies for Developing Responsible Students" by Madelyn Swift. Through PowerPoint presentations and a conference call set-up, these seminars will enable teachers to connect with national experts and benefit from the latest research without leaving the school. Teachers will meet after school from 4 to 5 p.m. to participate as a learning community and discuss applications for the Academy.

Visit www.isacs.org to view program outlines, registration information and current additions.

Media Contact:
Mary Anne Brush 313-886-1221 x172
item.excerpt:encoded: Academy teachers will have a unique professional development opportunity

item.title: Caitlin Munn ?03
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Caitlin Munn '03 is, by her own admission, a shy person. It is not easy for her to talk about her accomplishments as a sophomore at University Liggett School or the successes of those formative years that began when she was a preschooler at The Grosse Pointe Academy. However, she does credit the Academy with helping her overcome her shyness at critical times. For example, says Caitlin: "Being in the eighth grade play really helped me feel more comfortable in front of a crowd." She also recalls having to present her eighth grade heritage project in front of her classmates.

Other experiences at the Academy also helped Caitlin come out of her shell, meet people and make friends. For example, she went on three Academy Adventures trips with Mike Fultz during the summertime. "Those trips were a lot of fun," she recalls. "They taught you a lot about working together, teamwork and independence."

Caitlin's years at the Academy gave her the confidence to pursue the toughest schedule and course load possible at ULS. In addition to such advanced classes as Spanish III Honors (her favorite class), Honors Algebra II Trigonometry, and Honors Chemistry, she is required to play three sports. She opted to play field hockey in the fall and ice hockey in the winter, and is conditioning for the spring season.

While at GPA, Caitlin played #3 doubles tennis and played on the varsity volleyball team in both seventh and eighth grade, and was instrumental in helping the team continue its winning streak over two seasons.

 "Caitlin had a serve we called the 'Munnster,'" says her former coach, Mike Fultz. While on the varsity team she won awards for most improved overall, most improved digger, and most improved server. Her eighth grade year she was the starting first server, and ended the season with the highest serving percent (95.74) and the most aces. In addition to holding a number of all-time records, Caitlin was, according to Mr. Fultz, "one of our best all-time servers."

This summer Caitlin plans to return to the Academy for her third consecutive year as a counselor at Blue Streak Camp. She was among 350 high school students invited to participate in the National Youth Leadership Forum on Medicine. If she decides to go, she will be sent to one of the participating hospitals and have the opportunity to shadow a doctor. She is interested in pursuing a career in medicine, and volunteers four hours every Sunday at St. John Hospital, where she fulfills a number of tasks - from holding newborns to reading to children to pushing a candy cart around to the nurses' stations.

Caitlin's advice to this year's graduates is to "get involved and take advantage of things that Middle School doesn't offer, such as different sports and clubs. This is a great way to meet people and make new friends." To younger students who still have a few years ahead of them at the Academy, Caitlin points out that: "Teachers at the Academy give a lot of advice. Follow that advice. They give it for a reason. Work hard and challenge yourself as much as possible, because it will pay off."
item.excerpt:encoded: Caitlin Munn is, by her own admission, a shy person.

item.title: Steve Stanton '94
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
"My pursuit of higher education unquestionably began at the Academy," says Steve Stanton '94, who is now in his second year at the University of Michigan working towards a Ph.D. in Psychology.

Steve came to The Grosse Pointe Academy as a first grader. "I was an only child and my parents wanted to give me a good start," he explains. "They looked at a variety of schools in the Grosse Pointe area. I think one thing that impressed them was the long period of tenure so many of the faculty members had. All the teachers were very established and my parents were impressed with their dedication. Many of them were at the Academy for their entire careers. This was something my parents grew to appreciate."

Steve developed strong relationships with many of his teachers during his eight years at the Academy and recalls some of his fondest memories, like beating then Headmaster Sid DuPont in golf by one stroke when he was in eighth grade ("I still have the score card," Steve says. "I considered it one of my greatest accomplishments of my young life!") and racing honors math teacher Scott Tily in completing a quiz.

Steve still keeps in touch with many of his teachers. During a recent visit, he planned a holiday dinner with Marion Chrisner, who was not only his music teacher for eight years, but also gave him private piano lessons. He also helps out with Mike Fultz's Academy Adventures summer trips whenever possible. "I didn't go on the trips when I was a student," Steve admits, "but I have more than made up for it with the number of trips I have gone on since!"

Steve refers to Mr. Fultz as "a good cheerleader in all aspects. He gets kids enthusiastic not just about science, but about sports and his outdoor trips as well." Steve enjoyed six years of science with Mr. Fultz, culminating with sixth grade biology.

 "The Academy is incredibly good at fostering interest in academics," Steve affirms. "I am in a field now that is firmly rooted in science, and it all started in sixth grade biology and eighth grade honors chemistry."

Steve believes that his teachers "fostered the idea that it's okay to be pushed hard, and that when you are pushed and do well, it's all the more rewarding. Learning to be pushed to that extreme has carried over into the rest of my educational experience as well."

Upon graduating from the Academy, Steve went on to attend Grosse Pointe South High School. "I can say with certainty that when you graduate from the Academy, you are prepared for high school," Steve says. In fact, while the honors classes at South were challenging, particularly in the upper grades, "it was nothing like the challenges I faced at the Academy." He went on to attend the University of Michigan, where he received a B.A. in Psychology and Economics.

 "The Academy is a wonderful place to get eight plus years of being nurtured academically but in a way that really cultivates a desire to challenge yourself," says Steve. "I can vouch for myself and other people I know from my class and other grades that it is something that really does last."
item.excerpt:encoded: Upon graduating from the Academy, Steve went on to attend Grosse Pointe South High School.

item.title: Back to School Picnic
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Spirits were high during the Back to School Picnic on Wednesday evening. Over 450 people gathered on the Academy lawn to enjoy the beautiful weather, eat a picnic dinner catered by National Coney Island, and catch up with friends. The children enjoyed the Moonbounce and 18' giant slide, while a DJ provided music and dancing for all ages.

At the "Welcome" tent, new families met up with ambassador families; Auction co-chairs Mary Kosmalski and Tom McCarren modeled GPA polo shirts that sported the Action Auction logo, "Set Sail for the Future"; and an architect from Fanning-Howey was on hand to show interested parties plans for the new music annex.

As always, the Back to School Picnic provided an opportunity for the students to shed their back to school jitters, meet their teachers, and make new friends.

item.title: GPA Community Responds to Hurricane
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
When we opened the school doors on Wednesday morning we did so with all the enthusiasm that is associated with a new school year. We also began the year with heavy hearts as we grieve for the people of New Orleans, Louisiana, the surrounding communities and the gulf coast from Gulf Shores, Mississippi to the Florida border.

As a former resident of New Orleans, my family has a special connection to that community. Our son Judd was born there in Baptist Hospital, a hospital on Napoleon Avenue that today is under eight feet of water. As we watch this drama unfold, we pray for the safety of the people, the future of the region and our nation itself.

All of those associated with the Academy will be organizing our efforts to help the survivors of this tragedy. As with 9/11 and the tsunami, we will respond with open hearts and minds to support relief efforts.

There are over 5,000 people from the devastated area coming to Detroit. They will need housing, food, jobs and schools for their children. My family has contacted the United Way and Neighborhood Service Organization (800-241-4949) and has offered to house a family.

The Academy will be working to raise funds for the Red Cross. I urge all of you to help in any way you can.

On Monday, September 12 at 8:45 a.m., we will commemorate the events of 9/11 on the front circle of the main school building. At that time we will also pray for the people affected by the hurricane. Shortly, we will also announce plans for contributing to the Red Cross.

Please join us on September 12 and in our efforts to restore the stricken area and provide hope for the future.

Phil Demartini
Head of School
item.excerpt:encoded: When we opened the school doors on Wednesday morning

item.title: New Faculty Profile: Wendy Jewett
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Wendy Jewett has faced some challenging moments in her life. She has taught high school science in an inner city school in Minneapolis, where poverty was a harsh reality and the only recourse was one's own innovation and ingenuity. She has jumped out of airplanes during her training at Airborne School at Fort Benning, Georgia. (She describes the experience as "absolutely terrifying" and jokes that it will come in handy this year when she is teaching laws of motion and gravity to her seventh grade science students. "I have definitely tested the limits of gravity!" she says.)

However, Wendy herself would probably describe one of her most scary moments as coming back to the school she graduated from in 1987 and having to address some of her former teachers - now colleagues - by their first names.

Wendy attended the Academy from first through eighth grade. During that time, she had Mrs. Wolney in third grade, Mr. Fultz for biology, Mr. Tily for computers and math, Mrs. Johnson for social studies, Mrs. Chrisner for music, and Mrs. Ream for math and science. Karen Ream retired last June after 26 years of teaching at the Academy, and it is filling her shoes that Wendy finds the most daunting challenge of all.

"I feel so blessed to be back at the Academy," says Wendy. "My daughter and I moved back here [from Minnesota] to be with my family, and now we have the Academy family too. I have to keep pinching myself. But what grounds me - and reminds me that I better keep working on those lesson plans - is knowing the shoes I am filling. That is a sobering thought. But it is a wonderful opportunity, too."

Wendy is well positioned to face the challenge. She comes to the Academy equipped with seven years of experience teaching high school science, three years in North Carolina and four years in Minnesota. She received a Bachelor of Science in Genetics and Cell Biology from the University of Minnesota School of Biological Science, and has dual teaching licenses in life science and chemistry. She prides herself on creating a classroom atmosphere that is motivating and positive. She is an advocate of using technology in the classroom to enhance learning and promoting scientific inquiry and problem solving through experimentation.

In other words, Wendy jokes, "We'll drop things out the window and blow some stuff up."

In all seriousness, she has made creative use of the mirrored panels in a storage cabinet in her classroom to include the class agenda for the week. For the first day of school the panels were filled with such inspirational quotes as the following one by Allen Bloom: "Education is the movement from darkness to light."

In addition to being an alumna of the school, Wendy is also the parent of a first grader, Ellie, who is in Kelly Beke's class. "I must be the first Academy triple crown!" she says. "I'm an alum, a teacher and a parent, all at the same time!" Ellie is adjusting well to the transition to a new school, but she misses her friends in Minnesota and especially her father, a captain and medical service commander of the largest deployed medical unit in Iraq.
 
"With all these changes in her life," says Wendy, "what softer place to land than here."
item.excerpt:encoded: Wendy Jewett has faced some challenging moments in her life.

item.title: September 11 Observance
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Remarks by Phil Demartini, Head of School
September 12, 2006

Welcome to all of you on this beautiful morning.

We are here today to commemorate the events of September 11 and pay our respects to the victims of that dreadful day. Normally, our flag is raised to its rightful and highest position and we proceed with the program. However, this year, because of the catastrophic effects of Hurricane Katrina, we have placed the flag at half-mast as requested by President Bush. We will also take time to pray for the survivors of that horrible occurrence.

Throughout its history, the United States has been put through very serious challenges and always has survived. There have been wars, serious illnesses like polio and tuberculosis, terrible accidents and dangerous storms - none, however, as devastating as Hurricane Katrina. I imagine it will take decades for the Gulf Coast to recover. I imagine it might be impossible for the victims to ever fully recover. It is our task and obligation as American citizens to help wherever and whenever we can. We at the Academy - faculty, students, administrators and staff - will do our part to help heal the survivors and give them a future of hope. Our plans will be announced in the near future. As part of the Academy Family, we will ask all of you to help us reach all of our goals. Together, along with millions of other citizens, we will take what has become America's greatest tragedy and turn it into America's greatest show of compassion. President Bush has declared that Friday, September 16 be a day of recognition and prayer for the hurricane victims. We will observe this in each classroom.

I would like all of us to have two moments of silence: one for the 9/11 victims and survivors, and another for the victims and survivors of Hurricane Katrina.

Thank you - We are all so proud to be Americans, and we are so proud of our wonderful country.
item.excerpt:encoded: Welcome to all of you on this beautiful morning.

item.title: McMillan Lecture Series Features Brain Researcher
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Renowned brain researcher Eric Jensen is The Grosse Pointe Academy's featured McMillan lecturer this fall. He will speak on "How the Child's Brain Works" in the Academy Fieldhouse on Tuesday, October 11 at 7:30 p.m. The lecture is free to the community.

The first thing to know about Eric Jensen is that he is a former teacher with a real love of learning. While most of his experience is with middle school students, he has taught at every level, including three universities. His academic background is in psychology, and he is a member of the Society for Neuroscience and the New York Academy of Sciences.

Eric co-founded the first international brain-based learning program in 1982 and has authored 20 books on the brain and learning, including Teaching with the Brain in Mind. Many Academy teachers have attended Eric's workshops and have received Learning and the Brain Certifications. Eric comes highly recommended by GPA faculty and school counselor Sean Hogan-Downey.

Bring your friends to this not-to-miss lecture. It would make a great outing for a book group, for example, and is geared to educators and parents of children of all ages.
item.excerpt:encoded: Renowned brain researcher Eric Jensen is The Grosse Pointe Academy's featured McMillan lecturer this fall.

item.title: Set Sail with the Power of Math!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The curricular school-wide theme for the year is "Set Sail with the Power of Math!" Throughout the year we will host a variety of activities to promote math and all of its powers. On March 8, 2006, we will have a Math Fair that is similar to the Art Fair of last year. Each student will have several math projects or samples on display. During the day of the Fair, the author/illustrator David Schwartz will host small presentations for the students, and that evening he will host a larger presentation for students and parents. He has written many books that celebrate math, including How Much is a Million, If You Made a Million, If You Hopped Like a Frog, and many more. We are very excited about his visit!

We are also excited that students in grades 2-8 will be participating in the Continental Math League. This League is a national competition that involves several "meets" per year (the number of meets depends on the grade level). A meet is a thirty-minute time period in which each student independently attempts to solve six word problems. Each correct answer is worth one point; the top six scores are submitted to the League as a GPA team score. Students prepare for these meets during portions of math class. Some classes solve a problem a day. Others work on several of the problems at one time. The League provides over one hundred practice problems. Each student's problem sheets will become part of his or her math portfolio.

We participate in the Continental Math League for a variety of reasons: 1) students' problem solving capabilities improve; 2) students learn many different problem solving strategies; 3) students are motivated to achieve; and 4) we are able to compare our results with over 400 schools from around the country.

If you have any questions about this article, please contact Wendy Demartini, Curriculum Coordinator, at wdemartini@gpacademy.org or call 313-886-1221.

item.title: Collecting Leaves: A Sixth Grade Science Project
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
"Every year I am asked by kids, 'Why do we have to do this?'" says science teacher Michael Fultz of the sixth grade leaf project, a well-known staple of his science curriculum. "They want to know why it's important to be able to identify all of the trees on campus. I tell them that trees are the most dominant organism around them. Step outside - there are trees all around you. You should be able to identify them."

Mike also believes that the leaf project is a great way to start off the year. "It's not abstract," he explains. "It's right in front of you. It's doing science. If you follow the key and make careful observations, you'll come to the correct conclusion. That's what this is all about - getting kids to make careful observations and to look for subtle differences in order to discover the correct answer. This is the scientific method."

There are four steps to the process. The first step is learning how to use a dichotomous key and make good identifications based on the characteristics of the different trees. For example, does the plant have needle-like or scale-like leaves? Are the needles more than one centimeter long? Do they occur in bundles or in groups along the twigs?

The second step is identifying and collecting leaves. The students preserve their leaves in books until they are ready to place them in a photo album. Once this step is completed, they will have collected and learned to identify 41 different types of trees on the school property.

"There are even more trees on campus," Mike says, "but many of them are exotic and the kids will never see them again. I concentrate on the more common trees they will see everywhere." The students learn some interesting facts about the trees along the way. For example, they learn that bowling alleys are made out of sugar maple. Baseball bats are made from ash, because it is lightweight and strong, and absorbs shock well. Hardwood floors are often made out of oak, and furniture may be made out of woods like cherry, maple and walnut.

In identifying the trees, the students will use terms like "opposite simple" and "alternate simple" and look for such characteristics as the color, lobes and teeth of the leaves and the texture, color or peel of the bark. For example, the bark on a locust peels sideways, and what Mike calls "the give-away" to identifying a white cedar is that it is the only tree on campus with tiny scales rather than needles. An astute observer trained to use several of his or her senses might also comment that the scales smell like grape bubblegum. 

The students are finished collecting their leaves during the first few weeks of the fall, but their fieldwork is still not done. The next step is for them to answer the question: What is the most important tree on the school's property?

In the experiment, the importance value of the trees is based on size and number. "This is when they start to learn about the scientific method," Mike says. In order to answer this question, the students must first be able to identify the trees (a process they have of course mastered in the leaf collection phase). After measuring and counting a survey of the trees on the property, they head indoors with their compiled data - to the computer lab, to be exact. There they learn how to record their data, make graphs and charts, and write an interpretation.

"It is all part of the discovery process," Mike says. "If they take it step by step, follow the key, make good observations, and record good data, they will discover. This is what science is all about."
item.excerpt:encoded: "Every year I am asked by kids, 'Why do we have to do this?'"

item.title: Professional Development Keeps GPA Faculty on Cutting Edge
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Professional engineers, designers and architects routinely congregate in seminars and workshops to share best practices, conduct research, and study trends and issues as part of their continuous career improvement. The teaching vocation is no different. Those charged with educating our children also get together often for professional improvement, and school-sanctioned professional development (PD) days are an important part of that activity. As inherent learners themselves, teachers use PD days to stay on top of trends and technology that affect the work they do with students. That is especially evident at The Grosse Pointe Academy, where a combination of on-campus and off-site PD days, seminars and classes contributes to making its faculty one of the most well-qualified and innovative teaching staffs in the state. In fact, as GPA students enjoyed the last day of their spring break on April 6, their teachers were in the middle of another day-long PD session, one of seven days of professional development scheduled for the school during this year. We have one main PD day in the fall and one in the spring, said Jennifer Kendall, the Academys assistant head of school for institutional advancement and early school education. We also use three days for professional development before the students return in the fall and two after they leave at the end of the year. Quality of instruction Research has proven again and again that the quality of instruction is the most important factor that parents look for when choosing a school for their children. According to Learning Forward, a Dallas-based association advocating for educators, when parents of students are asked what they want for their children, there is overwhelming agreement that they want the best teacher possible in every classroom. The most important factor contributing to a students success in school is the quality of teaching, the organization said in a report titled Why Professional Development Matters. While parents may not be familiar with this research, Learning Forward says they are united in their desire to ensure great teaching for every child every day. Claudia Leslie, a French teacher and library specialist in GPAs Early School, is the chair of the schools professional development committee. She said the on-campus PD events for teachers on April 6 included "a teachers ed camp, tech/STEAM presentations and a Mini-Maker Faire." Innovation grants Off-campus, there also is plenty of opportunity for GPA teachers to gain additional knowledge and skills. During the year, six of our teachers visited schools across the country to gather and share ideas, Kendall said. She said the Academys Innovation Grant program, which was largely funded by the school's auction last May, is intended to provide faculty and staff with the opportunity to visit and learn from cutting-edge programs at other independent schools across the country. GPA Head of School Lars Kuelling said the schools teachers are always seeking innovative ideas to make their classrooms more vibrant for their students. We were so fortunate to have had this additional [Innovation Grant] funding to support new ways to make The Grosse Pointe Academy the best learning environment possible.

item.title: Montessori program highlighted at the Academy on a special night
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Erik Brynjolfsson, the author of The Second Machine Age: Work, Progress, and Prosperity in a Time of Brilliant Technologies, says there is a disproportionate number of Montessori-educated people founding and managing many of todays successful tech companies. Googles Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Amazons Jeff Bezos, musician Yo Yo Ma and Wikipedias Jimmy Wales, to name a few, he notes. Brynjolfsson thinks its a direct result of the Montessori classroom environment that emphasizes self-directed learning, hands-on engagement with a wide variety of materials (including plants and animals), typically occurring in a very deliberate sensorial school day. Add Wall Street Journal blogger Peter Sims who says, the Montessori educational approach might be the surest route to joining the creative elite, to the many, many proponents of a education philosophy that is centered in nurturing the uniqueness of each developing child.  
  Interested parents found out recently about these advantages when The Grosse Pointe Academy held its annualMontessori Information Night on November 11on the Academys campus in Grosse Pointe Farms. During the session, parents observed demonstrations from Academy Early School teachers highlighting the Montessori method's child-centered, individualized approach to education, specifically geared for children 2-1/2 to 5 years old. The event detailed the areas of the classroom, learning experiences, and benefits of the Montessori program for those interested in enrolling their children in Michigans longest continuously operating Montessori program. item.title: Another class heads to high school with the Academy advantage
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
GPA's newest graduates will be attending some of the finest secondary schools in the country, including Deerfield Academy, University Liggett, Cranbrook, Choate Rosemary Hall and the International Academy. Alum tells newest graduates that the Academy gave them"gifts that will carry you throughout your life; gifts that will get you through difficult and challenging experiences." When commencement speaker and Academy alum Megan Bonanni told the newest class of graduates from The Grosse Pointe Academy last evening that among the many pieces of advice they will get before heading to high school, one of the most important is to be kind, it may have been met with a little bit of nonchalance from those on the stage. But, Bonanni said, the truth is when you live a life where you are kind, like-minded people will come to you. It was simple, yet powerful advice. She told them that high school can be tricky. Its awkward. New high school students are trying to figure out who they are and frankly they are very emotional, she said. So be kind and surround yourself with like-minded people who lift you up instead of tearing you down. [caption id="attachment_25930" align="alignright" width="350"] Commencement speaker Megan Bonanni, who graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy in 1980, is a partner at Pitt McGehee Palmer & Rivers PC, a Royal Oak, Mich., firm specializing in employment law, civil rights, personal injury and criminal defense.[/caption] Bonanni, who graduated from GPA in 1980 and currently is a partner at Pitt McGehee Palmer & Rivers PC, a Royal Oak, Mich., firm specializing in employment law, civil rights, personal injury and criminal defense, spoke to the class and their family and friends as part of the Academys 2016 commencement ceremony, which was held Tuesday evening in the schools Tracy Fieldhouse. Head of School Lars Kuelling also addressed the new graduates, who now journey to high school with arguably a very distinct advantage over most other eighth graders in the area the Academy advantage is what school officials typically say. Graduates, you have learned a great deal while at GPA, and now we ask that you take that knowledge and use it for the good, Kuelling said. You are more than ready for the challenges and responsibilities of high school, and we know that, but we will miss you nonetheless. Kuelling also told the grads that they have accomplished much as a class. Youve distinguished yourselves in the classroom and the arts, on the athletic field and in community service and you have been the best big buddies that our first graders could have hoped for, he said. In the process, your teachers and I have seen that theres not much that fazes you as a group. You always impress us with your camaraderie and willingness to jump right in, no matter the situation. And, thats why the phrase Hakuna Matata, which means no worries, is the perfect motto for your class. Youve learned how to enjoy life while facing challenges head on. Academy alum Bonanni also recounted for the 2016 grads that even though she herself went throughmany of the same challenges they did when she was their age, her own GPA experience was both profound and dynamic, and that even though she graduated 36 years ago, they all share in something special. We share gifts that this school gave to us and they are gifts that will carry you throughout your life; gifts that will get you through difficult and challenging experiences, she said. She mentioned two gifts in particular. It is here at the Academy where I was taught a love of learning. And it is here where each individual and their uniqueness is celebrated by teachers, by administrators. The Academy always made me feel unique, special, worthy, Bonanni told the grads. And you will see that there is an indelible mark left on you a mark that only comes from spending so many years in a place that promotes such inclusion, tolerance and respect for others. So it is without question that this years talented class of 29 students, who are heading to some of the finest high schools in the country including Deerfield Academy, University Liggett, Cranbrook, Choate Rosemary Hall and the International Academy are leaving 171 Lake Shore Road with an advantage an advantage that comes from experiencing at least eight years of the best uncommon education available in southeast Michigan. Congratulations to The Grosse Pointe Academys Class of 2016: Shekinah Aho, Justin Ambris, Cesar Arreguin, Katie Bagby, Weston Brundage, Trey Chennault, Angelo Cracchiolo, Isabella Cubba, Timmy Donaldson, Megan Driver, Maria Fields, Haleigh Howard, Noah Humphries, Tierney Janovsky, Dakota Jones, Oliver Jonsson, Will Jonsson, Aiden Kuelling, Brooke Popadich, Blake Pradko, Josh Roberts, Nafi Sall, Christopher Scupholm, Sade Shaw, Ian Shogren, Emma Smith, Isabella Tomlinson, Matthew Valente and Molly Woods.

item.title: Sixth Annual CATCH Fun Run
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Friday, October 7th, all first through fifth grade students will participate in The Grosse Pointe Academy's sixth annual CATCH Fun Run. The CATCH organization was founded by Sparky Anderson in 1987. CATCH stands for Caring Athletes Team for Children's and Henry Ford Hospitals. The organization provides sick children and their families with items and services that are not covered any other way.  The following are examples:

  • While a child was suffering through a fatal illness, his father wished to spend as much time as possible with his son.  To do so, he was forced to take an unpaid leave of absence from his job.  CATCH funds were used to pay for one month's rent during the father's leave. 
  • An 8-year-old girl with paraplegia and numerous other physical disabilities demonstrated great social skills, but was limited in her interaction with peers due to her disabilities.  CATCH helped pay for a bike with special back support that now allows the child to play and socialize with her friends.

The Fun Run will take place here at school around the perimeter of the soccer field. The run will begin at 2:00 p.m. (Please note that this is a change in time.) We are asking each child to please donate $5. All donations should be in to your child's classroom teacher by October 5th.  Students in first through third grade should wear their intramural uniforms to school.  Sweatpants and sweatshirts are encouraged in case the weather is chilly. The fourth and fifth grade children will change into their PE uniforms before the event begins.

Feel free to come watch and cheer on our great student runners! For more information regarding CATCH, visit their website at www.catchcharity.org.  If you have any questions about the Fun Run, please e-mail me at sovshinsky@gpacademy.org.

Thanks for your support,

Sasha Ovshinsky

item.title: GPA Fourth Graders Capture History with Technology
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy fourth graders participated in the fifth annual AT&T/MACUL Student Technology Showcase on September 28 at the State Capitol Building in Lansing. The students demonstrated to elected members of the Michigan State Senate and the House of Representatives how technology is being used in the classroom to facilitate learning.

Accompanying fourth graders Gabriella Colonna, Karstan Minanov and Allison Mobley were third grade teacher Debby Wolney, Early and Lower School French teacher Claudia Leslie, and Director of Technology Robert Rochte.

The students presented projects they completed last year as part of the third grade curriculum. Last year in Mrs. Wolney's class, the students created a digital photo documentary of The Grosse Pointe Academy. Using historic maps, blueprints and pictures from GPA Archives, records provided by the Grosse Pointe Historical Society, and the publication Know Your Grosse Pointe by the League of Women Voters, they learned about The Grosse Pointe Academy of the past in order to capture some of that history using the technology of today.

The students toured the property and its building, researching all they could find out about its history. Then, each student selected an area that he or she thought was most interesting to preserve with a photograph. Using a digital camera, they photographed each other by the areas of interest. Returning to the classroom, each child wrote a factual paragraph detailing his or her photo. The research was then word processed in a Microsoft Word document.

In an interdisciplinary twist to the project, the students, with the help of their French teacher, Claudia Leslie, translated their works into French. The students displayed both versions of the journal to visitors during the MACUL conference.

"Our students represented us very well at the MACUL Technology Showcase," says Mrs. Wolney of the experience. "We were one of the very youngest groups, but our children didn't seem to be aware of that at all. They shook hands, explained in great detail about their project, and raved about their school to curious onlookers. As a result, they had their picture taken with many dignitaries."

The Student Technology Showcase is sponsored by AT&T and the Michigan Association for Computer Users in Learning (MACUL), an organization dedicated to bringing educators from all levels together to share their knowledge and concerns regarding educational uses of computers and technology.

item.title: Celebrating Community Spirit
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
What a week of community spirit it has been. It was kicked off during the second annual Academy Tailgate Party on Saturday, a marathon of fun for attendees, some of whom remained from morning till night. The children present took advantage of the soccer field for impromptu soccer and football games, while adults enjoyed a casual afternoon of football viewing and socializing.

Tuesday featured the first buddy event and the third annual Fall Spirit Night. First and eighth grade students had already become acquainted with their buddies last Friday during their trip to the apple orchard, but the remaining students in grades 1 through 7 got acquainted on Tuesday afternoon. They gathered around the flagpole to hear brief remarks by Phil Demartini, then paired off with their buddies to complete a "Getting to Know You" sheet. Pairings were as follows: Grade 2 with Grade 5; Grade 3 with Grade 6; and Grade 4 with Grade 7. Special thanks go to third grade teacher Jeanette Stepanek for organizing the buddy event. The next event will be held on October 21 and the theme will be Halloween.

On Tuesday evening, the community came out in full force to cheer on GPA sports teams while enjoying fun, food and friendship. Present at the event were Kensington School, who faced the boys' soccer team; and Greenhills, who matched up with the Lady Bulldogs in tennis. Competing against GPA in a cross-country meet were ULS, Greenhills and St. Joan of Arc.

item.title: October Sets Sail with the Power of Math
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The topic for math for the month of October is probability and data analysis. The middle school math team has put together three activities involving probability and will use the data collected to create graphs that can then be used for data analysis and discussion.

The activity for this week is coin flipping. Given ten flips, students are to predict (and record) how many times the coins will be heads and how many times tails. Then they are to actually flip a coin ten times and record their results. These results will be placed into a box at the math booth in the cafeteria or given to math teachers Michelle Roberts or Wendy Jewett. The middle school students will graph the data as it is collected and share the results with the school.

item.title: "Learning Bridges" Audio Seminars
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The new face of professional development, using technology to access quality presenters at affordable costs, has come to Academy teachers. On Wednesday, October 5, through distance learning, the entire faculty was able to hear author and educator, Rick Wormeli, talk about "Homework Practices that Really Work." This is the first of a series of six seminars for faculty through a subscription offered by the Independent Schools Association of Central States (ISACS).

Through these one hour audio conference/visual PowerPoint seminars, faculty are able to learn about current research and best practices first-hand from experts in their fields, but share the cost with dozens of Midwest independent schools. Another advantage for faculty is being able to discuss ideas presented and how to implement them since everyone is able to "attend" without travel costs. Other topics in the series include "Writing Essential Questions" and "The Role of Questioning in Teaching and Learning," presented by Grant Wiggins of Authentic Education, and  "Differentiated Instruction," by Carol Tomlinson of the University of Virginia. Madelyn Swift will present "Discipline for Developing Responsible Students" and Robert Brooks, Harvard Medical School Psychologist, will discuss "The Power of Mindsets: Nurturing Motivation and Resilience in Students."

Teachers are able to e-mail or ask questions directly during the presentation. They may also submit evaluations for each seminar online.

item.title: Meet New Early School Teacher Kate Kingsley
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Kate Kingsley has the distinction of working with the Academy's very youngest children: the two and half and three year olds in the Early School's 3-day program. This is the perfect environment for a young woman who has worked with children all of her adult life. A graduate of the University of Michigan Dearborn, Kate has worked as a nanny, run a summer camp at Pier Park for children ages 3 to 7, and operates a play group for two-year-olds on Tuesday and Thursday mornings (the days she is not at the Academy). She also worked as an assistant in the junior elementary room at The Giving Tree.

 "Everyone has been wonderful," Kate says. "The parents have been very helpful and supportive." To ease the transition of being the "new kid" at the Early School, she has also relied on the nine years of experience of classroom assistant Eula Hankins. "Eula has been awesome," says Kate. In addition, Kate will be rotating among the kindergarten teachers five afternoons a week. She is on a 21-day rotation schedule, and will spend time in every kindergarten classroom twice.

It is the children themselves who have made the transition easiest for Kate. "They are hilarious," she says. "They surprise me with how much they want to do."  She is pleasantly surprised by how independent they are at such a young age. "I am finding out their personalities and what materials I should put out to reflect that," she says. "I enjoy watching them come out of their shells while their individual personalities emerge. I'm amazed how smart everyone is."

She has opted to make a lot of materials, something she enjoys doing, to best match the children's growing intellects and curiosity. She has themes for the month, such as Manners and Families in November and Holidays of the World in December. In addition, the children will study the continents, and she hopes to have parents come in the classroom to cook food from that continent.

 "In keeping with the Montessori philosophy, I want to expose the children to a wide range of the world," Kate says. "At the same time, I need to keep it basic. It is a young class, but I hope to give them some exposure to prepare them when they go into other classrooms next year."

Says Kate: "My main goal is for them to have fun and enjoy school so that they look forward to coming for five days next year."

item.title: Meet New Trustee Ben Warren
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Ben Warren brings a strong financial background to The Grosse Pointe Academy's Board of Trustees as one of three new trustees appointed this year. This will be his second year on the Finance Committee, and he served on the Development Committee a number of years ago.

Ben, who is currently in the private investment business, has been involved in a number of family businesses throughout the years. In addition, he has a background in fund-raising for non-profit organizations, including Henry Ford Health System; he has raised capital for several upstart businesses; and he has worked for Merrill Lynch. He has also served on a number of boards, including Cottage Hospital, of which his grandmother was a founding board member, the Henry Ford Health System Hospice Board, and the Farms Foundation Board.

 "I feel it's important to volunteer your services," says Ben. "It's also important to be involved in your child's education. Serving on the Board allows you to be active and involved in what's going on. You can be part of the solution and help make a difference."

Ben and his wife, Carol, chose the Academy for their eldest child, Streeter, when they moved back to the area from California because they had heard a lot of good things about the school from friends whose children attended it.

 "The main thing that drew us to the Academy was the emphasis on values and respecting others," says Ben. "This was what distinguished it from other schools in the area. We also liked the size and the feel, and the warmth of the campus."

Streeter, who began as a first grader, graduated in 2005. His younger sister, Chandler, is currently in the fifth grade in Mrs. Teetaert's class.

Ben and Carol appreciate the values that have been instilled in their children throughout their years at the Academy. Ben was particularly impressed with Streeter's graduating class. "There was great camaraderie in that class," he says. "The kids were never afraid to help a fellow student. It's not a competitive, cutthroat environment. One of the things the Academy fosters in the students is to be a helper. I think that's what the world needs - kids who are willing to pick each other up when they need it."

Ben also appreciates the accessibility to administration and faculty. "You can pick up the phone and call Phil [Demartini] any time with a question or a problem," he says. "Carol and I enjoy the open door policy. You don't have to go through layers of bureaucracy to reach someone."

Ben also cites the buddy program and the fact that "there is a place for every child" as two unique aspects of the school.

Streeter is currently attending Eaglebrook School in Deerfield, Massachusetts. When his father asks him what he misses most about home, Streeter's response is: "I miss school. I miss the Academy."

Says Ben: "I think he misses the culture here that is very special."

item.title: Sean Hogan-Downey Leads Parent/Child Book Group
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
"Has anyone here ever felt like a loser?" asked Sean Hogan-Downey, A.C.S.W.

Hands went up around the room. Present were parents and students in Wendy Demartini's fifth grade classroom. They were participating in a book group discussion facilitated by Sean, who is a licensed marriage and family therapist and the Academy's school counselor and staff consultant.

The book being discussed was Loser, by Jerry Spinelli. Parents read the books with their children and attended a breakfast/book discussion on Thursday, October 27. The central theme of the book involved social issues surrounding friendship.

"I need to draw a lesson for these fifth graders in this room," said Sean. "You are past the stage that everything is sunshine. There is a way you can be like Zinkoff [the protagonist of the novel]. You don't have to let people get to you."

Sean cited her favorite line in the book as follows: "Big-kid eyes replace little-kid eyes." A discussion followed to clarify what this means. "You need big eyes to see the meaning behind things," explained Sean. "That's what we're doing today, looking at the meaning behind this book. Big eyes also often make us critical, and when you get critical, you start to separate yourself from people. For example, name calling starts when you get 'big eyes.'"

The students talked about what it means to be accepted socially and how it feels to be bullied or not picked for a game. Strategies were discussed for how to deal with those moments when one does feel like a "loser."

"Sometimes I cry," said Giovanna Posselius.

"You have to step back and define whether you really lost or whether you can get back up and keep trying," added Jeff Smith, parent of Gerard Smith.

Other suggestions included learning to use your "big eyes" to look at the big picture and learning how to laugh at yourself.

"You may never call someone a loser yourself," said Sean to the students, "but I sure hope you'd be active if you heard someone else called a loser. I would hope you wouldn't be what I call a bystander. Why should someone have to cry without arms around him or her? Why would you turn down someone who wants to play? There's no reason in fifth grade why big eyes have to be only critical. They should also see beyond themselves. Little kids with little eyes see and think about themselves. You're at the age when you should start to consider other people."

Sean also had a message for the parents present: "We tend to put our kids in a box, but sometimes the box doesn't fit."

Michelle Schaller, parent of Lauren Schaller, agreed. "The character [of Zinkoff] was odd, but so true to himself that the bully ended up respecting him." The students made the point that it is important to stand up for yourself as well as others. The final message of the book was that by remaining true to himself and not changing who he was, Zinkoff changed the people around him.

"Zinkoff may not have had a best friend," pointed out Marsha Goan, parent of Conor Tily, "but he sure knew how to be one."

Sean Hogan-Downey is on campus for both parents and students on Mondays from 10:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. and Thursdays from 10:30 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. Please contact Michelle Alt at malt@gpacademy.org to schedule an appointment. Sean's office is located on the first floor of the Lakeshore Building.

item.title: Grade 2 Studies the Human Body
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy second graders, along with Mr. Lapadot and Mrs. Demartini's fifth grade science class, enjoyed a special visit on October 27 from Dr. Pam Hammel, a forensic odontologist and grandmother to second grader Katherine FitzSimons. The timing of Dr. Hammel's visit was perfect; not only did it coincide with the second grade unit on the human body, it also came shortly before Halloween. Accompanying Dr. Hammel was a woman who has been dead for over 80 years.

Thanks to the efforts of Dr. Hammel, the children had the rare opportunity to see an actual human skeleton, in this case the skeleton of a woman who lived in the late 1800s and donated her body to science in the 1920s. Dr. Hammel also brought along several human skulls.

The students learned interesting facts from Dr. Hammel, including the fact that doctors can tell a male skeleton from a female skeleton by the shape of the skull and the pelvis, and that the sturdiest bone in a human body is the femur.

"Your body is the most incredible machine ever," Dr. Hammel told the children. "Your eyes are better than the best camera. Your brain is better than the best computer. So take good care of your bodies."

Dr. Hammel explained that a forensic odontologist is "just a fancy word for dentist" and that her job is to identify people from their teeth. In fact, she was headed to New Orleans the next day to assist in the ongoing effort to identify the remains of victims from Hurricane Katrina.

The children were delighted when Dr. Hammel gave them the opportunity to name the skeleton. The winning suggestion was Bonita Bojangles.

item.title: Nutritionist Visits 4/5 Students
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Nutritional oncologist Dr. Cynthia Browne, M.D., Ph.D., gave a presentation to the 4/5 students in the Lake Shore Parlor on Tuesday, November 1 on practicing good nutrition. Dr. Browne is the Director of Cancer Care in Radiation Oncology at the Van Elslander Cancer Center and is a national speaker in the field of nutritional oncology.

Dr. Browne discussed nutrition in our world today, the importance of nutrition in the children's development, connections between pesticides and cancer, the benefits of eating organic food, and nutritional supplements for a healthy immune system.

Visiting the day after Halloween, Dr. Browne gave the children concrete reasons why they should avoid consuming too much sugar. "Your brain doesn't feed on Milky Ways," she said. "Your brain feeds on the sugar in your blood - it's called glucose." In addition, she made the statement that a can of pop decreases the immune system's ability to fight infection for up to six hours. Pop - or rather the phosphoric acid put in it - is also the leading cause of what Dr. Browne referred to as an epidemic among teenage athletes. These athletes suffer from stress fractures due to the fact that the phosphoric acid leeches calcium from their bones. "So drink your milk," Dr. Browne advised.

Dr. Browne brought in organic apples to share with the students and conducted an experiment in which sliced apples that were sprinkled with vitamin C turned less brown than those left unprotected in the air, illustrating the importance of this vitamin in helping repair damage from oxidation.

"If you left a Twinkie under your bed for two years, what would happen to it?" Dr. Browne asked the students. Everyone agreed that it would remain exactly the same due to chemicals and preservatives. On the other hand, Dr. Browne pointed out, an apple left under a bed would eventually rot due to the bacteria that would feed on it. The moral of this tale? "If the bacteria don't want it, you shouldn't want it either," said Dr. Browne.

The 4/5 study on nutrition, an integral part of the science curriculum, was greatly enhanced by Dr. Browne's presentation. Special thanks go to parent Pam Yates for making the arrangements. Dr. Browne's visit will be followed up by the Grade 4/5 Nutrition Fair on December 13.

item.title: Alumni History Day: A New GPA Tradition
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday, November 10, students in first through eighth grade experienced a taste of what it would have been like to be a student at the Academy prior to 1969, when the school was operated by the Religious of the Sacred Heart as a day and boarding primary, middle and upper school for girls.

Back in the Academy of the Sacred Heart days, it was a tradition for the nuns to surprise the students with something called a cong?. A cong? was defined for the students as ?a formal or authoritative decision to depart; an abrupt dismissal; a leave taking; a day of celebration for the entire school.?

This ?celebration for the entire school,? sponsored by the Academy Alumni Association, began when Head of School Phil Demartini and Director of Advancement Paul Harrell rang a bell up and down the hallways, as the nuns used to do. Surprised students poked their heads out of their classrooms to discover what all the commotion was about. Their teachers quickly ushered them up to the auditorium, where Alumni Association President Roselie Posselius gave a brief introduction and told them what was in store for the afternoon during Alumni History Day.

First the students viewed a PowerPoint presentation entitled ?The Grosse Pointe Academy Journey Through Time: Then and Now.? Archival photos of historic buildings, landmarks, interior scenes, events, activities and even people were juxtaposed against present day photos. The students were especially pleased to see such familiar faces as Miss Camille, Mr. Tily, Mrs. Chrisner, Mrs. Johnson, Mrs. Wolney and Mr. Lapadot ? both ?then? and ?now.?

Following the slide show, the students broke into groups for a scavenger hunt that took them all over the school and the campus in an historical romp. They were guided in their hunt by such clues as ?Way back in time, there were plants and beasts / On which daily the nuns would feast! / Little by little, the apple trees were cut, / Now we are left with this mysterious hut!? (Answer: the Barn) Another clue was: ?There?s a historic lane / Leading up to a glass pane / Shaped in a heart / Look for the small stones for the place to start.? (Answer: Pillars and Heart Entranceway)

At each stop along the hunt, students were greeted by adult ?ambassadors? who provided historical information about that particular site. The sites included the Lakeshore Parlor, faculty lounge, orchard farm, chicken coop, St. Madeline Sophie statue, and, finally, the Nun?s Walk: ?I?m long and narrow, a pathway to pray / It used to be quiet, now a place to play / Come walk down with me, and look at my trees / This famous walk is known for its breeze!?

At the conclusion of the hunt, students headed back to their classrooms for another Sacred Heart tradition, the gouter (snack). At that time they were given a packet of information containing facts on each historical site to bring home and share with their families.

?Part of the purpose of this event was to integrate some of the tradition back into the school,? said Mary Alice Mecke, who wrote the clues for the scavenger hunt and prepared the fact sheets for the alumni volunteers and other adults who served as ambassadors. ?Highlights of the afternoon for me were watching the children?s faces when they saw Phil Demartini walking up and down the hallways ringing a bell, and seeing Peggy Baer dressed as a nun and Ellen Krease dressed in Carole Peabody?s old school uniform.?

The afternoon ? a true surprise and delight for the students ? would not have been possible without the efforts of many alumni, chief among them Roselie Bellanca Posselius ?73, Mary Alice O?Brien Mecke ?74, and Robin Locniskar Hartnett ?82. Special thanks go to resident historian Carole Peabody ?51 for her expertise. Students, faculty, staff and administrators alike hope the cong? will become a new Academy tradition.

item.title: Early School Students Give Thanks
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Students in Charlene Murray?s Early School classroom got a taste of Thanksgiving early this year. On November 16, parents brought in family favorites for a Thanksgiving feast. The students had prepared some of the fare beforehand: they made cornbread muffins and churned their own butter. Prior to the feast, parents and students alike enjoyed a performance by kindergarteners (from left) Kristofer Grandison, Olivia Yates, Tommy Van Pelt, Karina Minanov, Nicholas Harrell, Chase Clark, and Ashleigh Hale. The children told the story of the Pilgrims? journey to the New World by describing specific things for which the Pilgrims were thankful: the Mayflower (?it rocked and rocked but didn?t sink?), a rock they could stand on, housing, corn, wild turkeys, and new friendships.

item.title: Meet New Director of Finance Angie Granata
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Angie Granata comes to The Grosse Pointe Academy as the school?s new Director of Finance with a strong background in public accounting. As a staff auditor at Plante & Moran, PLLC since 2001 and a Certified Public Accountant since 2002, she has experience in managing all aspects of financial needs for health care, non-profit, private schools, and public school district clients. She also has audit experience with pension plans and municipalities. In addition, she worked as a tax preparer for Jackson Hewitt Tax Service and has a Bachelor of Business Administration with a major in Accounting from Western Michigan University.

 ?I love it here,? Angie says of her first four months at the Academy. ?Everyone is so awesome. Pat [McCarthy] keeps me in stitches. It?s a nice place to work in terms of community - and who can beat the view??

Angie has quickly immersed herself in getting to know people and learning the job. ?I really enjoy the variety of projects, from human resources to the finance piece, which I?m used to. And whoever thought I?d be doing fire drills? You never know from day to day what might come up.?

Angie?s goal for her first year is to go through the process and observe for herself what happens on a daily basis. After a full year?s cycle, she believes she will understand the policies and procedures in place. ?While ultimately there may be changes,? she explains, ?things are done in a certain way for a reason, so I believe it?s best to understand that before making any changes. This school year is about educating myself in addition to getting to know the school community and the policies and procedures.?

One of the procedures she has looked at recently is the school?s emergency plan. She and Patti Boynton, the school nurse, attended a school preparedness meeting put on by the Red Cross. This meeting coincided with Phil Demartini?s conversations with the principal at St. Paul School regarding a reciprocal evacuation. While it had always been the school?s plan to use the St. Paul gym in an evacuation (and, in turn, for St. Paul to use the Academy gym), the Academy had yet to practice the process. On November 3, the students had their first evacuation drill to St. Paul School, successfully evacuating the Academy campus in under five minutes.

In addition to changes in her professional life, Angie has announced a change in her personal life as well. She was recently engaged to John Boyle, a pediatrician in private practice in West Bloomfield. The first person to know about the engagement was not a member of Angie?s family or a long-time friend; it was Phil Demartini. John was visiting the Academy for the first time and Angie decided to take him on a tour. On his first visit to the Chapel, John got down on one knee and proposed. The couple ran into Phil on the way out and shared their news. Angie hopes to show John more of the school the next time he comes to visit - when she is less distracted!

item.title: A Tribute to Native Americans
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy welcomed a special guest for this year?s Thanksgiving Assembly, which was a tribute to Native Americans. David Nighteagle, a Native American from the Lakota tribe, traveled from his home in the southwestern corner of Colorado to share his talents with Academy students from the Early School through grade 8.

David?s grandfather introduced him to flutes and helped him make his first flute fifty years ago. Since then, David has hand carved over 9,000 of these beautiful instruments, some of which are on display in the Smithsonian. He has played them all over the country, including concerts in the southwest, Disney World and at the opening ceremony of the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.

Prior to David?s presentation, Early School students recited a poem, ?Indian Children,? and all of the students performed a Cherokee Lullaby and a Native Dance of the Kiowa under the direction of Early and Lower School music teacher Roshell Chuhran.

David interspersed the playing of his flutes with stories of his culture. He told the children that Native Americans believed that because one takes the heart of the wood out of the flute by carving out the center, one must put back one?s own heart while playing. ?Flutes are thought to have healing powers,? he said. ?The next piece I play goes out to people in your community I understand are healing right now, like Mr. Demartini, Miss Denise and Mrs. Chrisner?s son John. While I am playing, please keep them in your thoughts and prayers.?

At one point, David played two flutes at one time. He also invited several groups of students to come up on stage with him and accompany him with some percussive instruments in an improvisational manner. Pictured are (from left) David Nighteagle, Joseph Cavataio (grade 3), Allison Mobley (grade 4), Libby Watson (grade 5), and Charlie Milligan (grade 6).

Special thanks go to Janice Sturm for all her efforts in bringing David Nighteagle to The Grosse Pointe Academy.

item.title: Parent Led Book Groups
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Fostering a love of reading is a prime goal of the language arts curriculum at The Grosse Pointe Academy. Teachers today have a bigger challenge than in the past, however. There are many other activities besides reading that compete for children?s time and attention.

4/5 teacher Cheryl Teetaert has come up with a solution that has proven effective with her students. Her theory is that while book reports are a staple in language arts classes, sometimes they can be a chore. On the other hand, there has to be accountability that a child has actually read a book.

In lieu of requiring a book report, Cheryl has organized parent-led book group discussions for the children. Gretchen Woodward, parent of fifth grader Katherine, can attest to the success of this program.

?I?m amazed by the children?s insights into these books,? Gretchen says. ?Their love for the book comes out in their discussions. I?ve seen a big difference in some kids who I?ve known since they were young and they didn?t really like to read ? and now you can tell how much they love reading.?

The books selected for the book group discussions deal with individuals having to survive alone in the wilderness or confront a difficult situation. The first book talks were based on two prolific young adult authors, Gary Paulsen and Jean Craighead George.

?The kids end up learning survival skills as well as life lessons,? says Gretchen. ?I?m surprised at how well they grasp these concepts at such a young age. They are so enthusiastic about reading. This is Mrs. Teetaert?s philosophy ? she wants them to love to read for reading?s sake. This was the biggest revelation to me: how much these children love to read.?

According to Gretchen, there are no specific requirements or limits to how many books the students should or can read; they simply read as many books as they can, at a pace that is comfortable for them. Once they finish a book, they meet with a group of students and a parent who leads the group discussion. The parent will ask such question as: What did you enjoy about this book? What are some of the major themes? What do you think the author was trying to accomplish with this novel? What is stronger in the book: plot or character development? The students will discuss their favorite characters, or what the main character believes in and what he or she is willing to fight for. They relate their own experiences to events that occur in the novel. They also discuss the writer?s style and whether there are any flaws in the book.

?They do a lot of writing in Mrs. Teetaert?s class,? Gretchen explains, ?but the focus here is on reading.?

Other parents and classroom friends who have participated in the book group discussions are Jocelyn Cieszkowski, Linda Heidt, Alex Miziolek, and Nina Tocco.

item.title: A Journey Back in Time
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
To enrich their adventure of learning about Michigan history, Academy fourth and fifth graders will have the privilege of reenacting and experiencing a day in the old-fashioned one room school at the Provencal-Weir House in Grosse Pointe Farms. This opportunity, which is part of the 4/5 social studies curriculum, is sponsored by the Grosse Pointe Historical Society. Students will travel back in time to the 1880s to the old-fashioned Provencal School dressed in attire appropriate to the late 1800s. For example, the girls will wear long skirts and a blouse with a shawl while boys may wear cotton shirts and long pants stuffed into their socks to resemble knickers.

To prepare for their journey back in time, the girls have sewn bonnets and the boys have sewn vests. Over the past week, many parents have come into their classrooms to assist the children ? and perhaps relearn for themselves how to thread a needle!
