item.title: Meet New Trustee Charles Becker
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Chuck and Michelle Becker looked at a number of different schools in the area when searching for a kindergarten for their son Charles. They debated the merits of public versus private and ultimately chose The Grosse Pointe Academy.

?We were immediately impressed by the Academy,? says Chuck. ?We especially liked the Christian teachings and the quality of the education.?

They remain very satisfied with their decision. Charles is now in the third grade, while Elizabeth is a three-year-old in the Early School three-day program. Michelle is active with Action Auction and the couple has opened up their lovely home and hosted a number of social events for the Academy community.

Chuck, who is an investor in real estate and hospitality, started his own firm, Becker Ventures, in 1998. He served on the Finance Committee of the Board of Trustees last year, but when he was asked to join as a trustee he was forced to decline due to a  business commitment. This year he was asked again and accepted. Chuck will continue to serve on the Finance Commit-tee and will spend his first year getting acclimated.      

 ?The time is right now for me to give the time commitment that is necessary,? Chuck explains. ?I only joined the Board two meetings ago, but with time I hope to offer some of my background and experience and work with the school to make it stronger.?

item.title: A Behind-the-Scenes Look at AIMS Conference XV
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
It may not be as complicated an event to plan as Super Bowl XL, but the Association of Independent Michigan Schools (AIMS) Conference is a major undertaking, especially when the event occurs on your own home turf.

No one knows this better than Barbara Karle and Mary Jo Johnson, The Grosse Pointe Academy?s AIMS representatives and organizers of this year?s conference, co-hosted by the Academy and University Liggett School on October 24. Barbara and Mary Jo started the planning process for this biennial event after the last conference ended two years ago.

 ?It?s like the Auction,? Barbara said. ?No sooner is it over than you start planning for the next one.?

Of the two-person team ? ?Camille [DeMario] called us ?the AIMS queens,?? Barb jokes. ?All we needed were crowns? ? Mary Jo was the veteran. Having chaired the 1999 conference on her own, she is happy to have Barb as a partner this year. Says Mary Jo: ?It was so much more enjoyable and less stressful to work with another person. It was a joy to work with Barb.?

The key to a successful conference, according to Barb and Mary Jo, is finding good speakers, including a keynote speaker who appeals to a wide range of teachers and is well known in the education field. Barb had heard about this year?s keynote speaker, Benjamin Zander, through an AIMS contact, and worked in conjunction with a number of people to pursue him for the AIMS 2005 Conference. Zander, who is the conductor of the Boston Philharmonic Orchestra, spoke on ?Experiencing the Art of Possibility.?

 ?He delivered a great message,? said Barb. ?You can live in two different worlds: the downward spiral of negativity, or the world of possibility.?

In addition to the keynote address, the conference offered 20 workshops at the two sites. The Academy sessions were designed to appeal to early childhood and elementary teachers and staff, while the ULS sessions were geared to upper and middle school participants. Featured speakers at the Academy included Sean Hogan-Downey, the Academy?s staff consultant and school counselor, who addressed dealing with difficult parents ? ?Sean got rave reviews!? said Mary Jo ? Barb?s sister Trudy McSorley, the Dean of Students at Siena Heights University, and John Badalament, who spoke on engaging fathers in students? lives and the school community. John Badalament also presented an evening lecture for parents at ULS that was open to the public.

 ?I think what impressed us most about the conference was how our whole Grosse Pointe Academy community came together to work as a team,? Barb said. ?Administrators, advancement staff, kitchen, maintenance and housekeeping staff, and faculty members all made it happen. Every facet of the school was involved, from initial planning meetings with Phil Demartini and other administrators to the participation of every faculty member the day of the conference. For example, every workshop was hosted by an Academy faculty or staff member. The series of meetings at the beginning really helped because everyone heard the same message at the same time. From there, Phil basically empowered us and supported us every step of the way.?

The day would not have flowed so smoothly without the help of Director of Technology Robert Rochte, for example, who managed the technology involved, or Food Services Supervisor Jodi DeVee, who provided box lunches and refreshments. Also critical were improvements in the sound system in the Tracy Fieldhouse thanks to the efforts of Director of Advancement Paul Harrell, and countless other people who pitched in and helped where most needed.

 ?Peggy Baer from the Advancement Office was a huge asset,? said Barb. ?She was so willing to help.?

The students were also a welcome addition. ?People liked to see the school and they also liked to see the kids,? said Mary Jo. ?They really stepped up to the plate.?

Serving as student guides (and giving up a day off from school) were sixth graders Rebecca Broderick, Henry Brophy, Anne Flick and Michael McCuish; seventh graders Taylor Bell, Walter Bridgforth, Libby Krueger, Gigi Wells and Sarah Whitaker; and eighth graders Will Basse, Ian Flick, Imani Mixon, Chanel Nichols-Geter, Nicole Smith and Matt Stanley.

The fifteenth AIMS Conference was an unmitigated success, but Barb and Mary Jo are not resting on their laurels. They are already starting to plan for the AIMS Conference XVI, to be held in 2007. In fact, in early November Barb attended the ISACS Conference in Kentucky in search of speakers, and returned to the Academy with a list of promising prospects. Apparently the Rolling Stones is not among them, but then again, this isn?t exactly the Super Bowl ? it has far more impact on the daily lives of Academy teachers and their students!

item.title: Middle School Students Compete in Forensics Meet
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The 2005 Academy forensics team competed in the 7th/8th grade Eastside Catholic Forensics League meet on Saturday, December 10 with outstanding results. The team earned a record six first places: Chanel Nichols-Geter (2) and Michael Leahy in the challenging category of impromptu, Alex Parker and Adam Smith in storytelling, and Nicole Smith in declamation. Chanel also earned a plaque for overall points in impromptu.

Second places were earned by Taylor Bell, who read her own original poetry, Alex Parker in storytelling, Robert Stanley (2) in storytelling, Nicole Smith in declamation, and Michael Leahy in impromptu.

Emily Skau earned a third place in poetry, Imani Mixon two third places in drama, and Alex Parker earned one third place in storytelling while Adam Smith earned two. The multiple interpretation team of Kendall Dixon, Samantha Fitzpatrick, Anne Flick, Susie Stefani and Samantha Sternad earned two third places. Nicole Smith earned a third in declamation, Michael Leahy a third in impromptu and Sarah Whitaker and Julia Rose O'Hara earned a third in duo interpretation. We are also especially proud of our other sixth graders who competed against seventh and eighth graders and we look forward to their returning next season: Somers Brush, Will Callewaert, Elizabeth DiMauro, Danny French, Michael McCuish, Anna Ochylski, Elizabeth Penman and Grace Rentschler. Eighth grader Laura Flowers competed strongly in declamation also.

Special thanks to all the parents who helped our team in many ways: judging, coaching, supplying lunch and snacks, organizing, car-pooling and providing general moral support. Thanks also to Walter Mosley, an Academy alum and recent law school graduate who volunteered to coach the impromptu category students, and to Early School assistant Katie Couture, a St. Thecla graduate and high school forensics veteran who spent many hours before school, after school and at lunch expertly coaching and encouraging the students. Her help during practice and at the meet was invaluable. New moderator Harriett Whitaker brings fresh energy to the job and former moderator Mary Jo Johnson now assists. It was truly a team effort and the enthusiasm and team spirit made the competition an awesome experience. We are fired up for next year. Look for a Forensics Night in the spring!

item.title: Grade 4/5 Nutrition Fair
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The 4/5 Nutrition Fair, held every other year as part of the science curriculum, took place on December 13. The fair started with three stations years ago and has grown to eight stations.

In ?Inside My Pyramid,? students learned about the new nutrition released by the government. In ?Choose Sensibly,? they learned how to read labels on food products and make healthier choices. ?Dish Out Proper Proportions,? true to its name, taught about ?super sizing,? and ?Blast Off to Planet Power? was a computer game in which students fueled their rockets with healthy food choices. The goal of the game was for the players to take their rockets to Planet Power to earn a certificate. ?It wasn?t easy,? says organizer and school nurse Patti Boynton, ?but everyone can play. All you have to do is go to www.mypyramid.gov on the Internet.?

In ?Shout It Out,? students answered various questions about nutrition and were rewarded with delicious smoothies (the recipe provided by Mary Kosmalski, mother of fifth grader Jeffrey Woolstrum, along with a smoothie recipe booklet). ?Breakfast Helps You Grow and Learn? provided information on nutrients our bodies need to grow, with a concentration on carbohydrates and suggestions on breakfast cereals. ?Tips for Families? concentrated on additives put into products, from shampoos and deodorants to a variety of foods. It also emphasized the importance of family dinners.

Finally, the students conducted two experiments prior to the Nutrition Fair. In ?Building a Healthy Base,? they soaked chicken bones in coke, vinegar and coffee, observing over two weeks how the bones lost calcium and became rubbery. In ?Aim for Fitness,? they discovered the importance of drinking fluids and staying hydrated, using grapes to represent the cells in their bodies. The dried out grapes became - you guessed it - raisins!

item.title: Third Annual Celebration of Gospel Music

item.content:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy welcomed Preston Brown for the third consecutive year as a guest conductor in a celebration of gospel music on Tuesday, March 14. Mr. Brown is the musical director for the Fellowship Chapel Praise Team as well as for East Middle School in Farmington Hills. Vocal students from East Middle School joined with Grosse Pointe Academy students and alumni in rousing renditions of ?Glorify Him? and ?He?s Never Failed Me Yet,? among other gospel favorites. The evening featured solo performances by members of the Fellowship Chapel Praise Team and a finale of ?I Need You? by the full ensemble that rocked the rafters of the auditorium.

item.title: The Difference the Performing Arts Make
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
When Marion Chrisner first came to teach at The Grosse Pointe Academy in 1969, the auditorium was bare except for a single piano. She literally started from scratch in developing a music curriculum for Academy students. That summer, she began her Orff training (a three-year process) and purchased the used instruments from the Orff workshop for a grand total of $369 - the price of a single instrument today! At that time, the Orff program, founded in Germany by Carl Orff, had only been in the United States for three years, and the Academy was one of the first schools in the country to initiate its use in its music curriculum. Carl Orff developed these xylophone style instruments specifically for teaching music to children.

?Orff instruments are based on the pentatonic scale,? Marion explains. ?In other words, you can play any combination of notes together, and everything sounds good. This is very musically fulfilling for the children.? In addition, the Orff method promotes improvisation along with refinement of the ear.

Since the introduction of Orff instruments nearly 40 years ago, The Grosse Pointe Academy?s music curriculum has come a long way in promoting the school?s goal of educating the whole child. The main components of the curriculum are singing, movement and drama, music history and literacy, and rhythm and instruments. Through singing and performing, students develop their skills, participate in and enjoy music. Through movement and drama, they develop an innate confidence and interpretive use of their bodies and voices. Music history and literacy for the younger children exposes them to a variety of music and begins to develop their appreciation for music. As the children grow older, they are made aware of the development of music through the ages and assess its effect on life. Finally, rhythm and instruments provide a musical experience that involves both sides of the brain and awareness of accompaniment to music.

The Early School students? first musical exposure begins with Early School through Grade 3 teacher Roshell Chuhran, who introduces them to different types of music, including patriotic, folk, seasonal, sacred, multicultural and nursery rhymes. ?This helps them find their singing voices,? explains Roshell. Roshell is an advocate of exposing children to music at an early age due to the link between music education and increased intellectual ability, sequencing, right-to-left progression and hand-eye progression.

?In our curriculum, we build auditory skills,? says Roshell. ?Singing songs helps children with their speaking. For example, elongating vowels gives them a chance to connect sounds.? The children also work on developing a sense of pitch, memory, appropriate use of both sides of the body, the ability to distinguish between rhythm and beat, and an introduction to Orff instruments. This latter aids Roshell in getting the children to work as a group, develop a beat, find a pitch, and use their hands independently. She uses a variety of other rhythm instruments as well, such as hand drums, rhythm sticks, finger cymbals and boom pipes.

Music provides a supportive environment where children are free to be risk takers. A music curriculum creates what Roshell refers to as constructivism in teaching, which encourages free thinking, a sense of ownership, a guide to developing thoughts, active involvement in the process, a real world concept, thinking and understanding, and the ability to transfer these skills to other disciplines.

Marion Chrisner, who teaches music to grades 4-8, agrees with this philosophy.  ?The most important thing to me is the child,? says Marion. ?Music is a love, but the growth of the child is key and what drives the curriculum. We teach children through music with the whole child as the most significant product. That?s why I give the students opportunities to try all these different things so that they are comfortable and find a niche that brings them joy.? Critical to every element of the 4-8 music curriculum is 100% participation, with every child trying and working to his or her individual level or ability.

?Yes, every music teacher wants to put on a show where everyone sings on pitch and dances to the same beat,? says Marion. ?But here I like to look at the bigger picture. Here is the place where you learn to work together to put something together. Here is where you feel you can do something and no one will make fun of you. Here is where you are not judged by your God-given talent alone.?

Following the grand opening of the new performing arts wing on February 22, Mrs. Chuhran and Mrs. Chrisner have resumed their unique styles of teaching in a brand new facility complete with state-of-the-art equipment and instruments. It is a far cry from that empty auditorium Marion encountered in 1969. Still, it is not the surroundings that have kept her hard at work all these years: it is the students that fill those surroundings. ?It?s been one heck of a ride here. When I see our kids go on to become class leaders, I know I had some part in that,? Marion says. ?It makes me feel good.?

item.title: Academy Opens New Arts Wing
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Parents, past parents, faculty, staff, trustees and alumni attended the grand opening of the new performing arts wing on Wednesday evening. Live entertainment was provided by Spanish teacher Brian DeMaggio, a classical guitarist, and a brief video was shown that showcased the performing arts at GPA since 1993. item.title: Meet Ron Seykell
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Ron Seykell has only been teaching creative movement at The Grosse Pointe Academy for a week, but already he is enthralled with the place. Looking around at the Early School gym with the sun streaming through the high windows, he says, ?What an amazing building this is!? He refers to the facilities themselves as ?incredible? and the location as ?perfect.?

As far as the students are concerned, Ron has worked with second and third graders and several Early School classes so far and is clearly impressed. ?The kids are so well behaved and really bright eyed,? he says. ?You can see the tangible results of good parenting manifest itself in these children. You can tell the difference.?

Ron is filling in for Denise Szykula while she recovers from surgery. He recognizes that her dance shoes are large ones to fill, but looks forward to carrying on the program she has created while giving it his own individual spin. ?I will definitely follow Denise?s program,? Ron explains. ?I?m not sure everyone realizes exactly how brilliant it is. It?s very methodical, building in a layering and very age appropriate way.?

However, at the same time he hopes to incorporate in the curriculum what he refers to as ?Broadway magic? ? i.e., theatre arts, theatre history, theatre games and character work.

?The arts are so important in a child?s education, and it?s obvious here that this is recognized,? Ron points out. ?Statistics back up what we have always known intuitively: that by exposing children to certain aspects of the arts, other talents might be discovered. Some of these children may never dance again after they leave the Academy, but dance may open a window into something else. For example, a child might be exposed to an artist through the expression of movement and discover a love of color.?

Moreover, as Ron points out, the arts reduce stress, improve speaking and listening skills, and (as statistically demonstrated) result in the likelihood that students will get better grades in school, go on to higher paying jobs, and achieve leadership positions.

For now, however, Ron, who is a veteran Broadway actor who has performed in Cats, Les Miserables and Jesus Christ Superstar, to name a few, is content to begin by getting acquainted with the children and sharing with them his unique brand of energy and his enthusiasm for the performing arts.

The school-level bee, at which students answered oral questions on geography, was the first round in the 18th annual National Geographic Bee.

Ian and Gordon were among nine finalists who qualified for the bee based on a written exam. The other finalists were sixth graders Henry Brophy, Will Callewaert, Gregory Jolly and Robert Stanley; seventh grader Michael Leahy; and eighth graders Kat Fitzgerald and Matthew Stanley.

Ian Flick is now eligible to compete for a spot on the national team in the state competition. One person from each state moves on to compete in Washington, D.C. for a $25,000 scholarship and a lifetime membership in the National Geographic Society.

item.title: Academy Honors Top Athletes
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Eighth grader Ian Flick and sixth graders Emmy Boccaccio, Somers Brush and Grace Rentschler were named Athletes of the Fall Season based on their athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship.

Ian Flick was co-captain of the cross-country team and winner of the Bulldog and Spirit awards. In addition to being a scholar athlete, Ian is a member of the National Junior Honor Society and is on the school's high honors roll, citizenship list and Head of School list.

Emmy Boccaccio and Grace Rentschler vied all season for the #1 singles spot on the girls' tennis team this fall and were co-recipients of the Most Valuable Player award. The leading runner on the girls? cross-country team, Somers Brush was named Most Valuable Runner by her teammates and coach. The three sixth graders all participated on the girls? JV basketball team and were given the MVP award (Grace), Bulldog award (Emmy), and Sportsmanship award (Somers).  All three are scholar athletes and are on the high honors roll, citizenship list and Head of School list.

Generally a boy and a girl who excel in one or more sports are named Athlete of the Season in the fall and spring. ?While sometimes two girls or two boys might be named in a given season, it?s rare for three athletes to share this distinction,? said Athletic Director Michael Fultz. ?It?s also rare for this award to be given to a sixth grader. These three young ladies distinguished themselves athletically in their respective sports but were so evenly matched that the coaches thought all three deserved to be recognized."

item.title: Preparing for Success in a Multicultural World
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The 2005-2010 Grosse Pointe Academy Long Range Plan issued this fall makes the following statement: ?The Academy recognizes that in order to provide the finest educational experience for its students and to prepare them for success in a multicultural and global world, we must strive to create an inclusive, diverse community that will challenge them to make reasonable and moral decisions and teach them tolerance, appreciation and respect for all races and religions.? One of the implementation strategies outlined in the Long Range Plan is to ?maintain a strong Diversity Committee to oversee diversity initiatives throughout the school.?

That Diversity Committee, which grew out of a Diversity Task Force established in 2001-02, has been in existence for several years under the leadership of Rosi Triano.

 ?Promoting diversity has long been a love of mine,? explains Rosi, who teaches K-3 art and also serves as the Academy?s representative on the Southeast Michigan Diversity Committee (SEMDC). This group meets four times a year at different locations (most recently at the Academy), with members taking part in a round robin sharing of activities and planning such events as the Teacher of Color Job Fair, the Middle School and High School Symposiums, and the Bi-Annual Teachers? Workshop. The Job Fair furthers the committee?s goal to recruit faculty and staff members of color. Rosi has attended the past several years, oftentimes accompanied by Phil Demartini.

As the SEMDC rep, Rosi shares activities that have proven successful at the Academy and also culls ideas to bring back to colleagues. Another favorite aspect of her committee work is reading and discussing books on diversity.

Says Rosi: ?The Academy provides an environment that encourages and promotes the concept of valuing the similarities and uniqueness of each person. The goal of the diversity committee is for GPA to become a beacon in the community to teach children to understand, appreciate and treasure the differences and similarities of different races, ethnic backgrounds, learning styles and points of view.?

One of the charges of the Diversity Task Force was to define diversity. Seven specific characteristics of diversity were established: ethnicity, race, religion, culture, gender, geography and economics.

 ?Part of the difficulty I encounter is communicating effectively how many different ways we approach diversity at this school,? explains Rosi. ?I can talk about specific classroom activities we do for Black History Month, for example, but that?s just one month out of the school year. We do so much more than that, such as the international parade we held last year as part of the Journey Around the World theme, hosting David Nighteagle this year during our tribute to Native Americans, or having Carla Jackson (the Multicultural Coordinator for Cranbrook School) conduct diversity awareness workshops for our faculty.?

Finally it comes down to the children?s awareness of each other?s differences. Subtle messages can be delivered even in art class. Says Rosi: ?I handed a child a peach-colored crayon and he said, ?That?s skin color.? ?Well, it might be your skin color but there are many skin colors,? I replied.?

 ?The children we are educating today are the leaders of tomorrow,? Rosi says. ?If they can work inclusively and collaboratively today with all different types of people, imagine what they will do tomorrow as our future leaders.?

item.title: Children's Author Speaks at Math Fair
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy families enjoyed a celebration of math during the Math Fair on March 8. Colorful displays showcased the problem-solving abilities of students in Early School through Grade 8, and young attendees enjoyed a variety of games and activities. A highlight of the evening was a presentation by David Schwartz, author of How Much is a Million and If You Hopped Like a Frog, among many other award-winning children's books. Mr. Schwartz shared his love of numbers and literature, engaged the audience with his storytelling abilities, and, in the conclusion of his presentation, involved the children in demonstrating truly "how much is a million."

On Thursday, Mr. Schwartz gave a series of workshops to the students. Says David, "Children love big numbers in the same way they love big animals like dinosaurs and whales, and for that reason big numbers are the perfect way to get kids excited about math." David used a variety of visual aids to make numbers come to life, including producing a bag filled with 100,000 kernels of popcorn!

Since publication in 1985, How Much is a Million? has become the classic children?s book on large numbers. Illustrated by Steven Kellogg, it has won several awards and has been featured on Public Televisions ?Reading Rainbow.? Schwartz?s recent book, Q is for Quark: A Science Alphabet Book, is a zany, brainy, mind-boggling and amusing romp through the world of science. It is written at the upper elementary and middle school level, a higher reading level than his other books except for its companion, G is for Googol: A Math Alphabet Book, which was published to numerous accolades in 1998. His latest book, Millions to Measure, also illustrated by Steven Kellogg, does for measurement what How Much is a Million? did for big numbers: it renders the subject accessible, mind-boggling, and fun.

As a speaker, Schwartz is entertaining and informative. His presentation makes math and science fun in ways that many adults never thought possible.

item.title: GPA Welcomes New Coaches
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Please welcome the Academy's new lacrosse and girls' soccer coaches, John (Chip) Russell Fowler III and Cheryl Piccione.

Chip Fowler is a native of Grosse Pointe and attended University Liggett school from elementary through high school. He played lacrosse at ULS, where he was coached by John Fowler (who, despite the same name, is not related to him). He then went on to play club lacrosse at Purdue University. Chip served as the assistant coach for ULS's high school varsity football team this fall. He is currently taking graduate classes at Wayne State University in History and Public Administration and plans to apply to law school.

Soccer has been a big part of Cheryl Piccione's life for many years, and only this past year did she officially hang up her cleats and retire from her women's league team. Having grown up in St. Louis, she played on a travel team as well as for her high school and college and was named all-state in high school. She has lived in Michigan for 14 years and has two daughters: Nicole, who is a freshman at Grosse Pointe South, and Emily, who is a third grader at Trombly. Cheryl has coached soccer for the Neighborhood Club and the Grosse Pointe Soccer Association.

item.title: Academy Chess Team Brings Home Trophy
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the second consecutive year, The Grosse Pointe Academy chess team came home with a third place trophy in the 2006 Michigan Elementary Team Reserve (K-5) division of the Michigan Chess Association state championship held on Saturday, February 4 at Michigan State University in East Lansing. Accompanying the team were parents, coach Dr. Ed Mandell of All the King?s Men in Warren, and faculty advisor Wendy Demartini, a fourth grade teacher at the Academy who is also the curriculum coordinator.

Several players also earned individual medals for their performances. Third grader Jared Dempsey and fifth grader Jeffrey Woolstrum won silver medals, while fourth grader Karstan Minanov and fifth grader Steven Ragland shared a silver medal. Finally, third grader Joseph Cavataio received a bronze medal.

The Academy formed an after school chess club for kindergarten through fifth grade students five years ago. The club has grown in popularity over the years, in particular with younger students. During the past three years the school has invited local elementary schools to participate in a K-6 chess invitational, in which individual trophies are awarded. The first invitational for this year was held in December, with a second one tentatively scheduled for May 24. Due to the success of the chess club and the burgeoning interest in chess in general, Demartini decided last year to form a chess team. The team meets on Friday mornings from 7:30 to 8:30 a.m. under the direction of Dr. Mandell.

For information on The Grosse Pointe Academy chess invitational in May, please contact Wendy Demartini at wdemartini@gpacademy.org.

This year marked The Grosse Pointe Academy's second annual 4/5 Science Fair, which culminated in an evening event on March 15 when parents had the opportunity to view the display boards in the front quad and library while the young scientists were on hand to explain their methods and procedures.

4/5 teachers Wendy Demartini and Bob Lapadot led the project during science classes. They began by teaching the scientific method (stating the problem, forming a hypothesis, listing the materials and procedures, recording observations, and forming a conclusion). Work for the projects was completed both at home and at school.

Middle school science teachers Michael Fultz, Wendy Jewett and Michelle Roberts and director of technology Robert Rochte judged the projects, awarding ribbons to the top five projects in each grade.

The fourth grade winners were (front row from left) Robbie Triano, Samantha Perry, Kara French, Allison Mobley and Karstan Minanov. The fifth grade winners were (back row from left) Julia Kaiser, Libby Watson, Conor Tily, Nicholas Morley and Jeffrey Woolstrum. Not pictured is fifth grade winner Gerard Smith.

Said one fourth grade parent about the Science Fair as a learning experience for both her and her child: "We enjoyed the process, appreciated the spirit, and grew from the experience. Thanks for the learning!"

item.title: Top Continental Math League Scorers Recognized
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
During a Chapel assembly on Monday, April 10, The Grosse Pointe Academy recognized the second through eighth grade students who received the top scores in the Continental Math League competition. 

The Continental Math League (CML) is a nationally sponsored mathematical competition. Students are challenged to solve six difficult problems in thirty minutes. Each correct answer is worth one point. The problems are designed to encourage students to use a variety of problem solving techniques in the areas of mathematical and visual problem solving.

This was the first year at the Academy that students in grades 2-8 participated in the Continental Math League competition. Grades 2 and 3 have three meets while grades 4-8 have five meets. The top six scores at each grade are sent in to the CML headquarters in New Jersey.

Special recognition was given to fifth grader Dylan Demkowicz, who received a perfect score of 30. According to fifth grade teacher Wendy Demartini, who coordinates the CML competition for the Academy, Dylan received one of approximately 40 perfect scores across the country among fifth graders who participated in the competition this year. A special plaque will be hung in Dylan?s honor in recognition of this achievement.

The top scorers for their grade in the Continental Math League competition are as follows (pictured clockwise from front row, far right): Alexander Minanov (Grade 2), Jared Brush (Grade 3), Caleb Cimmarrusti (Grade 4), Dylan Demkowicz (Grade 5), Grace Rentschler (Grade 6), Somers Brush (Grade 6), Evan Schwartz (Grade 7), and Matthew Stanley (Grade 8).

item.title: You Make a Difference Fund
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
October 16 through 20 will mark the kickoff for this year's You Make a Difference Fund Drive. This annual fund helps the school fund the many programs that make up the Academy experience. Whether it is providing salaries for the outstanding faculty, purchasing supplies for the many educational activities, or maintaining the athletic facilities, dollars are required so that the students' experiences are outstanding in all areas of their education.

The introduction to the fund will come through the mail the week of October 9, so that those who wish to pledge immediately may do so. For others, our parent volunteer team will begin making calls during "You Make a Difference" Week. (Make your pledge early, and you can avoid the call!) New parents will be invited to a cocktail party on November 9 so that they may meet other new parents and learn more about the Academy.

This year, parents will have the opportunity to designate their gift to one or more of the following areas that you are most interested in supporting.

General Fund
Unrestricted support allows the school the most flexibility in directing funds to areas where they will have the greatest impact.

Technology and Classroom Support
Technology is an increasingly powerful tool that can be used to enhance student learning.

Faculty Support
Independent schools need to attract and retain highly competent, qualified and caring faculty members to lead academic, arts and athletic programs.

Character Development
Whether it is spiritual enrichment through Christian life classes and special Chapel assemblies, community service programs that expand the boundaries of the classroom, or involvement in afterschool athletics, the Academy emphasizes moral and ethical character development in young people to help prepare them to assume leadership roles later in life.

item.title: Reed Harris, Class of 1994
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grade 4/5 teacher Cheryl Teetaert enjoyed a special visit in April from a former student, Reed Harris ?94, and his parents, Inge and Reed. Reed was home visiting from Santa Monica, where he works for KUD International, a program management and development company that specializes in the development of large-scale public-private projects. These projects include aquariums, museums, professional football and baseball stadiums, and educational facilities. Reed is currently Assistant to the President.

What prompted the visit was a special fondness Reed and his parents share for GPA. The timing was particularly appropriate, as it came during Mrs. Teetaert?s final year of teaching before retirement. Reed was one of her first students at the Academy.

Reed came to GPA as a second grader while his sister, Tiffany ?99, began in the Early School. The family lives in New Baltimore, and for eleven years Mrs. Harris made the commute back and forth to school, dropping the children off at 7 a.m. so she could arrive on time for her teaching job at Lake Shore High School in St. Clair Shores.

Says Mrs. Harris: ?Everything at the Academy was the best. I don?t regret a minute of it. There were times my husband and I struggled financially, but we decided to make an investment in our children?s education, and we don?t regret a penny. We can?t say enough about the teachers. They are topnotch with Master?s degrees and above.?

Reed agrees with his mother?s assessment. ?The quality of the instructors at the Academy was a defining characteristic that sets that school apart from any other school in the country.? Reed has special memories of his second grade teacher, Mrs. DuPont, who made him ?feel at home right away,? his third grade teacher, Mrs. Thomas  - ?What a fun person! Class was never dull and her fun and easy going personality put a smile on my face each day!? -  and, of course, 4/5 teacher Mrs. Teetaert. She was the teacher Reed felt closest to. ?She treated each of her students like one of her own children. She truly cared about us and our future. After fifth grade, I hated to move on and leave her.?

Reed did in fact move on to the Middle School, and after graduating he attended De La Salle High School. It was there that he first noticed how his hard work at the Academy had paid off. ?I was ahead of everyone,? he says. ?As a freshman, I was put into honors and AP classes with sophomores and juniors. This was strictly a credit to the Academy. All the students had this opportunity. Everyone was brought up together and pushed to the same degree to go the extra distance and learn the material.?

Reed went on to the University of Michigan, where he received a B.S. in Industrial and Operations Engineering. Once again his hard work paid off, and he has enjoyed two years at a company that he says is one of a kind in the industry. But most importantly, he enjoys his memories of the Academy, from competing for a piece of candy from Mrs. Teetaert?s infamous ?jolly jar? to the critical role his teachers played in molding his study habits and work ethic.

item.title: GPA Students Participate in AIMS Literacy Conference
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
?Literacy makes for a stronger democracy,? stated author Anna-Lisa Cox to the middle school students assembled at a panel discussion of her recent book, A Stronger Kinship. On May 3, a day decreed ?AIMS Literacy Day? by Governor Granholm, middle school students from six Association of Independent Michigan Schools gathered at Friends School in Detroit to discuss the book in the presence of the author. Students used the book to study positive multicultural relations in mid-19th century Covert, Michigan. Detroit Free Press books writer Marta Salij stated in a recent review: ?The book has enormous value in reminding us that prejudice doesn?t have to be the default setting on human relationships.?

Representing The Grosse Pointe Academy were seventh graders Libby Krueger, Michael Leahy, Rachel Ochylski and Evan Schwartz, and eighth grader Chanel Geter. The other participating schools were Cornerstone Schools, Dearborn Heights Schools, Detroit Waldorf School, Friends School of Detroit, The Roeper School, and University Liggett School. All of the students participated in a panel discussion facilitated by Friends Head of School Dwight Wilson. Also in attendance were AIMS Director Richard Halsey and Literacy Project Manager Kathy Long. The students addressed questions within the context of the book that also related to their own lives, such as whether they or someone they knew had ever been in a situation in which they were denied service, or what actions their parents had taken to make them more accepting of the differences among people. Many students responded that their parents had made a positive step in this area by choosing an independent school.

?Color blindness is not the goal,? stated Ms. Cox. ?It is natural and human to recognize differences in people ? differences in clothing, hair style or skin color. It is getting beyond those differences and getting to know a person as an individual that is important.?

According to Michael Leahy, the book ?showed how children who are raised in an integrated society grow up to be integrated people.?  Said Evan Schwartz: ?We have to talk to each other to create stronger kinships.? Rachel Ochylski believed that the discussion ?opened up my eyes to how racism isn?t something from long ago and that it has to do with more than the color of a person?s skin.?

The question of what makes a leader came up during the discussion. Dwight Wilson responded: ?A leader is the first person to stand up and do the right thing.? This statement seemed to resonate with the Academy students. Said Libby Krueger: ?Leadership is all about choices. You have to have the courage to stand up for what is right.?

?Even if your friends are against it or make fun of you for it,? agreed Evan.

Echoed Rachel: ?Even if you?re standing alone.?

item.title: Sixth Graders Celebrate Poetry
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Sixth graders have immersed themselves in poetry in language arts class over the past several weeks. After studying a volume by a favorite poet and completing a poetry wheel as a book report, the students set to work writing poetry of their own. To celebrate completion of their poetry journals, language arts teacher Harriett Whitaker organized a "Poetry Caf?" on Tuesday. Students brought in refreshments and sat on pillows and beanbag chairs to listen to their peers' selected readings from their journals. The next day the classes convened outdoors on the old basketball court on the Lakeshore lawn to incorporate art into their poetry through the use of a new medium: sidewalk chalk. The result? Sidewalk poetry!

item.title: "Envisioning a New World Through Multicultural Eyes" Conference
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Wednesday, May 10 and 24, The Grosse Pointe Academy is honored to participate in a conference at Friends School in Detroit called ?Envisioning a New World Through Multicultural Eyes.? It is a two part conference including five groups of Metropolitan Detroit middle schools. The subject of the two part conference is a child imagining the construction of a new world. Without adult guidance they will look at such questions as:

? Building an equitable educational system
? Improving the health care system
? The proper role of fine arts
? The role of the military
? Improving the justice system
? Supporting our less fortunate citizens
? The role of sports

Eight Grosse Pointe Academy students attended on May 10. They were seventh graders Taylor Bell, Walter Bridgforth, Jess Martinelli and Julia Rose O'Hara, and eighth graders Ian Flick, Chanel Geter, Gavan O'Connor and Emily Williams.

item.dc:creator: costellodg

The Academy's French program was on display at Services for Older Citizens during their "Food and Friendship" luncheon on May 15. Accompanying Early and Lower School French teacher Claudia Leslie and Middle School French teacher Judyth Stayton were Debby Wolney's third grade class and a group of seven seventh graders. The younger students presented interesting facts about France and its landmarks, then recited a poem and sang a song, both in French. The older students performed an original skit in French called "Money Can't Buy You Happiness."

The theme for the month at SOC was France, so the timing of the visit was perfect!

item.title: Sixth Graders Host Medieval Feast
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: As a culminating activity for their unit on the medieval period in social studies class with Harriett Whitaker and Mary Jo Johnson, sixth graders staged a medieval feast on May 19. Present at the "manor on the lake" were the king and queen, lords and ladies, knights, squires, a priest, pages and jesters. Serving wenches (i.e., parents) served the three-course banquet of soup and bread, chicken legs, saffron rice and peas, and cookies. A food taster sampled each course before it was approved for consumption by the king and queen. During the course of the four-hour banquet, knightings were performed, the royal court was entertained by original dances, juggling, a magic act, piano solos and poetry readings, to name a few, and justice was served when several wrongdoers were brought before the court for judgments. Several were pardoned for their criminal acts, while others landed in the dungeon.

item.title: GPA Appoints New Board President
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
With a business and law background, Bret Wacker brings a great deal of experience and knowledge to the Academy?s Board of Trustees. The 2006-07 school year marks his sixth year on the Board, where he has chaired the Technology Committee and the Educational Policy Committee, sat on the Finance Committee, and chaired last year?s Christian Task Force. This year Bret follows Michael Fisher?s footsteps as President of the Board. Michael stepped down from the Board in June following nine years of service to GPA, the last three as President.

Bret and his wife, Sharon, moved to Sharon?s hometown of Grosse Pointe Farms in 1996 for a job opportunity at Compuware. Bret served as senior counsel at Compuware for ten years, but this past April took advantage of an opportunity to develop and lead a business when he joined Adecco Group North America as Senior Vice President, Government Solutions. Bret?s role at Adecco, the world?s largest staffing company, is to craft and execute the company?s federal contracting strategy. At any point in the week he may be found in his home office in Grosse Pointe Farms, in his office in Washington D.C., at the company headquarters in New York, or at a U.S. Government customer site anywhere else in the U.S.

Born and raised on the East Coast, Bret received a bachelor?s degree in journalism from Penn State University and his law degree from Vermont Law School. Bret combines strong communication and analytical skills, attention to detail and keen business acumen with something equally powerful to his role as Board president: a deep affection for the school. This affection stems from his years not only as a trustee and volunteer, but as a parent as well.

As Bret describes it, the Academy is committed ?to creating a total child with a love of learning. After that, the child?s natural talents will take over. Our job is to establish the academic foundation for them to be successful lifelong learners. We also support their physical well being and spiritual lives by creating an atmosphere that fosters both.?

?Like a business, our ?product? is all we can measure ourselves by, and I think the Academy produces a first-rate product in its graduates. We are uniformly told by the high schools that our students are poised and prepared, as well as being curious and active learners,? says Bret. ?As an independent school in this area, we are asked all the time: why should a parent spend the money when there is a good public school system in the community? It is the total child commitment that distinguishes a school like the Academy. The whole child is what an independent school focuses on.?

Bret, as Chair of the Christian Task Force, has played a key part in the school?s efforts to further define and articulate the spiritual component of its mission. ?The Academy?s role in the spiritual part of our students? lives is to support the foundation established by their parents. Our parents are responsible for making choices of faith for their children, and the Academy supports those choices by reinforcing community service, teaching respect for others, and its commitment to family.?

The Wackers first looked at the Academy when their oldest child, Kate, was a preschooler. They explored all their options, including public, private and parochial, but were swayed toward GPA by a particular person they met during their tour.

?A remarkable young lady led us around,? Bret explains, ?and I think she was the deciding factor. Naturally we were impressed by the curriculum, the buildings, and the enthusiasm of the teachers, but it was the tour guide who flipped the switch for us. When Sharon and I walked out afterwards, we looked at each other and said, ?If our little person turns out like that young lady, it will be well worth the investment.??

Bret and Sharon trusted their instincts with their first child and have not regretted their decision since. Their experience with Kate, now in sixth grade, and later with son Thomas, who joined the Early School last fall, has merely reinforced their impression that the Academy produces poised and confident young people like that eighth grade tour guide. They have also never had a teacher they ?can?t speak highly enough of - and I don't think we've just been lucky,? says Bret. ?I think that?s just the nature of the faculty.?

Bret is looking forward to the start of this school year. His goals for his tenure as President include working with the other members of the Board, as well as Phil Demartini and his team, successfully completing the current Phase II construction of the classroom building and the Capital Campaign, and making continued progress on achieving the objectives of the Academy?s current Long Range Plan.
item.excerpt:encoded: With a business and law background, Bret Wacker brings a great deal of experience and knowledge to the Academy?s Board of Trustees.

item.title: Fifth Graders Bring Romeo and Juliet into the 1950s
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
?But, soft! What light through yonder window breaks?? It is the performance of Romeo and Juliet by Mrs. Demartini?s fifth graders in the Academy auditorium!

Set not in ?fair Verona? but in Fat City, U.S.A. in the 1950?s, this version of Romeo and Juliet told the story in a vernacular that the audience, made up of students and parents, could understand. The tragic overtones of this tale of woe were offset by such comic touches as the Nurse on roller blades, Juliet in a poodle skirt, an Elvis-style king, and a cast of characters in shades delivering deadpan lines.



The fifth graders participated in every aspect of this student-directed play, from set design to choreographing the fights (which involved switchblades in lieu of swords), and were involved as both actors and stagehands during the performance. The class will take their show on the road to St. Paul Catholic School on May 31, ULS on June 1, and Services for Older Citizens on June 6.

item.title: McMillan Lecture Series Features Parent Educator
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Nationally known clinical psychologist and parent educator Dr. Wendy Mogel, The Grosse Pointe Academy?s featured speaker in its annual McMillan Lecture Series, will speak on October 10 at 7:00 p.m. in the Tracy Fieldhouse at 171 Lake Shore Road in Grosse Pointe Farms. The lecture, which is free to the community, is entitled "The Blessing of a Skinned Knee: Raising Self-Reliant, Optimistic Children in a Nervous World."

Publisher?s Weekly gave Mogel's best-selling parenting book, The Blessing of a Skinned Knee, a starred review saying, ?Impassioned, lyrical and eminently practical, this volume is a real treasure. In 2006, The New York Times Magazine ran a profile of her life and work highlighting the crossover success of The Blessing of a Skinned Knee in Jewish, Christian and private school communities across the country.

Dr. Mogel has been a keynote speaker at the annual meetings of the National Association of Independent Schools, the National Association of Principals of Schools for Girls, the Educational Records Bureau, the National Association of Episcopal Schools, and the American Camp Association.

A graduate of Middlebury College, Dr. Mogel completed an internship in psychology at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. She is co-founder of the Los Angeles Association of Independent School Counselors and serves on the boards of the Center for Early Education and the Counsel for Spiritual and Ethical Education, a century old inter-faith organization serving private schools. She contributes articles to Independent School Magazine, Camping Magazine, and the Jewish Telegraphic Agency. In the coming year, Scribner will publish her new book about everyday ethics for parents of teenagers: The Blessing of a B-.

There will be refreshments and a book signing immediately following the lecture. For more information, please contact Peggy Baer at pbaer@gpacademy.org or call 313-886-1221.

The William Charles McMillan III Lecture Series is a gift from Thayer and Gioconda McMillan given in memory of William in the interest of emphasizing the importance of elementary education.

Academy sixth graders, under the direction of language arts and social studies teacher Harriett Whitaker, are spearheading a recycling program for the school as part of their community service. After much anticipation and excitement, the recycling truck arrived on Friday, September 22 to deliver the drop-off bins.

Paper may be dropped off on the first and third Thrusdays of every month during morning arrival. Students will be available to assist in removing recyclable paper from parents' cars. The first collection will be on Thursday, October 5. Parents may also drop off paper in the "Paper Retriever" bin at any time. Bins are located in a variety of places, including the school offices.

Magazines, catalogs, junk mail, newspapers or any similar type of paper will be accepted. The company will not accept construction paper, bound books, cardboard, telephone books or anything laminated.

item.title: GPA in the Community
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Community service is alive and well at The Grosse Pointe Academy. In fact, it occurs almost on a daily basis as a naturally occurring part of the curriculum. In the span of one week, students in a range of age groups performed four examples of community service activities.

On October 27, following the Halloween Parade, the entire fourth grade class took the haunted houses they had made earlier that week to share with seniors at Services for Older Citizens at the Neighborhood Club. The students arrived dressed in their Halloween costumes and reprised the parade for the benefit of the seniors.


On October 29, a team of cross country runners and seventh graders joined up on behalf of the Detroit Institute of Ophthalmology to participate in the Detroit Free Press 5K Fun Run/Walk, a family event planned in conjunction with the Detroit marathon. After either walking or running the course, the participants crossed the finish line at Ford Field!



On November 1, eighth graders raked leaves on the Academy campus as part of their community service requirement. And finally, sixth graders greeted parents during car pool drop-off on November 2 to collect paper as part of their ongoing recycling program.

This is just a small sampling of the way The Grosse Pointe Academy makes service to the community a part of daily life.

item.title: Feliz Dia de los Muertos!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Brian DeMaggio?s Spanish students in grades 6-8 studied Dia de los Muertos (the Day of the Dead) in early November. Brian introduced the students to such customs popular in Latino communities as making an ofrenda, or shrine, for dead loved ones. Typically an ofrenda would include a picture of the person, marigolds, fake skulls or skeletons, food and drink, and objects that represent what that person enjoyed while on earth. This Friday was the culminating event of this weeklong study. To make the celebration as authentic as possible, Brian ordered Pan de Muertos (?Bread of the Dead?) from Mexicantown Bakery and calaveras (sugar skulls) from Algo Especial Market for his students to sample. ?The bumps (on the bread) signify tears and bones of dead loved ones,? he explained to the students. He also made a traditional drink from Ecuador called colada morada. While many of the ingredients necessary for this drink are not available in the United States, such as berries that are indigenous to Ecuador, Brian replicated it as closely as possible using blueberries, blackberries and pineapple and mixing it with cinnamon and cloves to give it the proper flavor and corn syrup to give it the proper thickness. The punch is served warm and, authentic or not, the students seemed to enjoy it. ?It tastes like Kool-aid!? said one.

On November 1 and 2 there was a walking tour in Mexicantown where the public could visit various ofrendas and exhibits in Southwest Detroit. Brian encouraged his students to attend.

item.title: Sixth Graders Study Scientific Method on Campus
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Every year I am asked by kids, ?Why do we have to do this??? says science teacher Michael Fultz of the sixth grade leaf project, a well-known staple of his science curriculum. ?They want to know why it?s important to be able to identify all of the trees on campus. I tell them that trees are the most dominant organism around them. Step outside ? there are trees all around you. You should be able to identify them.?


Mike also believes that the leaf project is a great way to start off the year. ?It?s not abstract,? he explains. ?It?s right in front of you. It?s doing science. If you follow the key and make careful observations, you?ll come to the correct conclusion. That?s what this is all about ? getting kids to make careful observations and to look for subtle differences in order to discover the correct answer. This is the scientific method.?

There are four steps to the process. The first step is learning how to use a dichotomous key and make good identifications based on the characteristics of the trees. For example, does the plant have needle-like or scale-like leaves? Are the needles more than one centimeter long? Do they occur in bundles or in groups along the twigs?

The second step is identifying and collecting leaves. The students preserve their leaves in books until they are ready to place them in a photo album. Once this step is completed, they will have collected and learned to identify 41 different types of trees on the school property.

?There are even more trees on campus,? Mike says, ?but many of them are exotic and the kids will never see them again. I concentrate on the more common trees they will see everywhere.? The students learn some interesting facts about the trees along the way. For example, they learn that bowling alleys are made out of sugar maple. Baseball bats are made from ash, because it is lightweight and strong, and absorbs shock well. Hardwood floors are often made out of oak, and furniture may be made out of woods like cherry, maple and walnut.

In identifying the trees, the students will use terms like ?opposite simple? and ?alternate simple? and look for such characteristics as the color, lobes and teeth of the leaves and the texture, color or peel of the bark. For example, the bark on a locust peels sideways, and what Mike calls ?the give-away? to identifying a white cedar is that it is the only tree on campus with tiny scales rather than needles. An astute observer trained to use several of his or her senses might also comment that the scales smell like grape bubblegum.

The students are finished collecting their leaves during the first few weeks of the fall, but their fieldwork is still not done. The next step is for them to answer the question: What is the most important tree on the school?s property?

In the experiment, the importance value of the trees is based on size and number. ?This is when they start to learn about the scientific method,? Mike says. In order to answer this question, the students must first be able to identify the trees (a process they have of course mastered in the leaf collection phase). After measuring and counting a survey of the trees on the property, they head indoors with their compiled data ? to the computer lab, to be exact. There they learn how to record their data, make graphs and charts, and write an interpretation

?It is all part of the discovery process,? Mike says. ?If they take it step by step, follow the key, make good observations, and record good data, they will discover. This is what science is all about.?

item.title: Seventh Graders Conduct Eggstraordinary Experiment
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Science teacher Wendy Jewett had an unusual experiment - or what she calls an "eggsperiment" - planned for her seventh grade physics students. The students were to engineer a contraption designed to protect an egg dropped to the ground from a great height. (Originally the eggs were to be dropped from a window of the Lake Shore building, but the weather proved uncooperative and Wendy quickly enlisted the help of the maintenance crew to drop the eggs in the fieldhouse from a cherry picker raised to the height of the ceiling.)

First the students completed their control work, including measuring the distance from the cherry picker to the ground, and dropping a few sacrificial eggs to test velocity, momentum, impulse and force on impact. The following day the actual contraptions were dropped. Ideas for protecting the eggs ranged from innovative and ingenious to just plain tasty. Eggs were cushioned in cotton balls, jello and marshmallows, hidden in stuffed animals and pillows, and dropped on a sheet, just to name a few of the students' ideas. Next week the seventh graders will analyze their data and write their interpretations.

The event proved particularly entertaining for younger students, who interrupted their gym class to observe this "eggciting" event!
item.excerpt:encoded: Science teacher Wendy Jewett had an unusal experiment - or what she calls an "eggsperiment" - planned for her seventh grade physics students this week.

item.title: Sixth Graders Bond at Camp Storer
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
There are many concepts that sixth graders bring home with them from their time at Camp Storer, but perhaps the most important one is ?total team.? Traditionally the sixth grade goes to Camp Storer in early fall to bond as a grade for their remaining years at the Academy, and a big part of that is learning how to work together as a team to solve problems.


Camp Storer begins and ends with team building, and the concepts learned are ones applied throughout each activity. For example, during the first night, the students, along with faculty members Brian DeMaggio, Michael Fultz, Lucia Hu, Ellen Krease and Harriett Whitaker, participated in a re-enactment of the Underground Railroad. Camp Storer staff members served as slave owners and other characters, such as abolitionists, while the students were slaves and the Academy teachers their guides into freedom. In the beginning of the reenactment, the students were sold into slavery.

?It was a very intense, powerful experience,? said language arts and social studies teacher Harriett  Whitaker. ?The kids still talk about the Underground Railroad. Parents have also talked about the impact that it had on their children.? One of the most memorable parts of the experience occurred to a group of ?slaves? led by Christian Life teacher Ellen Krease. ?We got lost in the woods for over an hour!? said Ellen. ?It was pretty scary.?

During the second day, the students studied the power of water, in which they built a river and learned about erosion and glaciers. Another unit was on Native American life. A Camp Storer staff member cooked stew and flatbread, and the students studied Indian sign language, played Indian games, invented Indian names and learned about trading.

On the third day, the group learned about reptiles and amphibians in a unit entitled ?In Cold Blood.? A final activity, which expanded on the ?total team? concept, was called ?The Incredible Journey? and involved a low ropes course in which the students had to work together as a team to reach success. ?The main lesson they learned was that there are some things you can?t do by yourself,? said science teacher Michael Fultz. The students also learned about ?zero waste,? which ties into the sixth grade recycling program initiated this year by Harriett Whitaker as part of the students? ongoing community service efforts.

One of the purposes of the trip to Camp Storer is for the sixth graders, who are making the transition into middle school, to bond as a class. ?They are going from two fifth grade classes to one sixth grade class,? explained Mike. ?By spending time together they get to know each other. They also get to know the teachers as people and vice versa.? Some of the activities at Camp Storer, such as singing silly songs and square dancing, helped to break down the barriers between students and faculty members. During the square dance on the last evening, Mike Fultz and Spanish teacher Brian DeMaggio played guitar and Mike even joined the counselors as a caller for the dances.

While at Camp Storer, the students learned about respect, responsibility, honesty and caring. ?These are the core values we teach at the Academy,? said Mike. Upon their return, they brainstormed as a group about these values and created a sixth grade covenant that each of them, along with the teachers who make up the sixth grade advisory team, had to sign to show their commitment. ?They take the covenant seriously,? said Mike. ?Some of them even put it on their lockers.?
item.excerpt:encoded: There are many concepts that sixth graders bring home with them from their time at Camp Storer, but perhaps the most important one is ?total team.?

item.title: Academy Teacher Inducted into Denison Hall of Fame
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Physical education teacher Cheryl Carroll was inducted into Denison?s Hall of Fame in October. Cheryl was a four-year letterwinner in tennis, swimming and diving.

?Cheryl was one of the most outstanding divers in the history of our athletic program,? says her former diving coach, Lynne Schweizer. She captured the AIAW one meter Ohio diving championship in 1979 and 1982 and was the three meter champ in 1982. Cheryl advanced to the MAIAW regional as a diver and placed 13th in the three meter event. On the court she was a three-time state champion at third singles and captured a pair of state doubles championships.

Says Cheryl: ?Sports have always been and always will be a big part of who I am. Now having a career as a physical education teacher and coach, I am able to share with others my passion for athletics.?

Cheryl was recognized during a formal ceremony as well as during half time at Denison?s homecoming football game (pictured above).

item.title: Eighth Grade Attends Stratford Festival
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: After reading Shakespeare?s Twelfth Night in class, the eighth graders got the chance to see the play performed live at the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Ontario. The day began with lunch at a local restaurant followed by some free time to explore the town. All the students came together for a quick picture in town before making their way to the theater. In an interesting twist, the director chose to set the play in Victorian India so many of the costumes and characters exhibited an Eastern flair rather than a traditional Western European setting. Despite the setting change, the students impressed the teachers with their in-depth understanding of the play?s themes and plot structure. Before heading back, the students enjoyed a light dinner in a local park where they discussed their opinions of the production.
item.excerpt:encoded: After reading Shakespeare?s Twelfth Night in class, the eighth graders got the chance to see the play performed live at the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Ontario.

item.title: 4/5 Students Have a Blast in Science
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The week before the holiday break was a blast for Academy fourth and fifth graders ? literally! Students set off nearly 50 volcanoes on the nun's walk during science class. The volcanoes were made at home with the help of on-line tips, the creativity of the students and their parents, and some good old-fashioned baking soda and vinegar ? along with several secret ingredients. This is the third time in six years that 4/5 science classes have completed this project, and each year brings a twist. The popular chemical mixture for this year was Diet Coke and mentos, which produced mixed results.

One of the strengths of the project was the amount of flexibility given to each young scientist, allowing for endless creativity. ?Our philosophy is that the children don?t need kits,? said 4/5 science teacher Bob Lapadot. ?They have vivid imaginations. Why not let them run with it? And the results were spectacular ? volcanoes of every size, color and shape imaginable. We had one that could fit in the palm of your hand and another that was as tall as some our students!?

From the biggest . . . to the smallest.
item.excerpt:encoded: The week before the holiday break was a blast for Academy fourth and fifth graders ? literally! Students set off nearly 50 volcanoes on the nun's walk during science class.

item.title: Seventh Grader Wins GPA Geography Bee
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to seventh grader Henry Brophy, winner of the school-level competition of the National Geographic Bee. Sixth grader Meade Maxwell was the runner-up. The school-level Bee, which was held on December 22, was the first round in the 19th annual National Geographic Bee. The Bee is sponsored by the National Geographic Society.

Thousands of schools around the United States and in the five U.S. territories participate each year in the National Geographic Bee. Academy Middle School students qualified for the Bee by taking a written test, then ten finalists competed in the final round on December 22 by answering oral questions. Henry and Meade went on to the championship round.

Henry will advance to the next level of competition, a written examination to determine state competitors. All school winners are eligible to win the national championship and its first prize, a $25,000 college scholarship, at the national competition held on May 22 and May 23, 2007 in Washington, D.C. The program will air on television. Check local listings for dates and times.

Anyone can brush up on geography with GeoBee Challenge, an online geography quiz at www.nationalgeographic.com/geobee, which poses five new questions a day from previous National Geographic Bees.
item.excerpt:encoded: Congratulations to seventh grader Henry Brophy, winner of the school-level competition of the National Geographic Bee. Sixth grader Meade Maxwell was the runner-up.

item.title: Storyteller Visits GPA
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Storyteller La'Ron Williams paid a special visit to The Grosse Pointe Academy on January 12. He met with Early School students first in the Tracy Fieldhouse and then did a combined presentation for Grades 1-8. Mr. Williams' stories are based on folk tales from the African/African-American tradition. He led the audience to see the important lessons that have arisen from those traditions - lessons about self-esteem, self-reliance, perseverance in the face of great challenges, and the struggle to expand the American ideal of democratic inclusion. Mr. Williams, who was dressed in traditional African clothing, played a variety of instruments to accompany his stories, including the Mbira and Djembe drums from Africa.

In the afternoon, Mr. Williams led a discussion tailored specifically to the seventh and eighth graders. Using humor and song while weaving history lessons into his stories, he prompted the students to use their minds and imaginations to recreate the past. "It is through sharing our combined history and culture that we gain a greater understanding of one another," he stated to the students.



"What an excellent introduction to our eighth grade social studies heritage unit," commented Wendy Demartini, Curriculum Coordinator, who arranged Mr. Williams' visit as part of the school's celebration of the life and work of Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr.
item.excerpt:encoded: Storyteller La'Ron Williams paid a special visit to The Grosse Pointe Academy on January 12.

item.title: 4/5 Students Learn the Scientific Method
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: To prepare for the 4/5 Science Fair in March, students are learning about the scientific method in science classes with Mr. Lapadot and Mr. Nayak. Middle school science teacher Wendy Jewett gave a demonstration to the 4/5 students on January 18, showing them how to state a problem, formulate a hypothesis, gather materials to conduct the experiment, and collect data before drawing their conclusions. Ms. Jewett conducted an experiment on the effect of temperature on diffusion, producing data that supported the hypothesis that the warmer the water, the faster the rate of diffusion.

item.title: Fourth Graders Study School's Architecture
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The faculty is developing a curriculum that will ensure our students have an understanding of the history of this school and community. The focus for the fourth grade will be on architecture. This topic is particularly timely given the renovations to the main school building that are currently in progress.


A special visit by Theo Pappas, AIA, of Fanning-Howey in Novi, the architectural firm that is leading the renovations, brought the building?s architecture to life for the students on January 31 during their weekly Breakfast Club. Using presentation boards, Mr. Pappas gave the students a glimpse of their future once the building is complete in September of 2007.

The fourth graders had many questions for Mr. Pappas. For example, McCalla Mecke asked whether it was fun to be an architect.

?The best part about being an architect is seeing your dream become a reality,? Mr. Pappas told the children. He also described some of the challenges inherent in retaining the history and architectural integrity of a 78-year-old building while at the same time bringing the classrooms up to the 21st century. Finally, he emphasized how such a major endeavor involves teamwork by a range of specialists.
item.excerpt:encoded: The faculty is developing a curriculum that will ensure our students have an understanding of the history of this school and community.

item.title: On Your Mark, Get Set, Go!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Third graders studied energy in science class. They explored circuits and switches to see how energy from a battery (chemical potential energy) going through wires (electrical potential energy) makes the car move (kinetic energy). The children got a charge out of designing their cars and holding mini-races in the hallway and classrooms!

item.title: GPA Celebrates Chinese New Year
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
What is known as the Chinese New Year in this country is commonly referred to as the Spring Festival in China, says Chinese teacher Lucia Hu. According to the Chinese lunar festival, the new year celebration, which generally lasts 15 days, began this year on February 18.


Ms. Hu explained to the students the legend of the spring festival during a special presentation in the school?s field house on Wednesday, February 21. This special buddy event featured a parade in which students in pre-school through grade 8 participated.

?The spring festival is the most important and biggest festival in China,? she said. ?To the Chinese people, it is at least as important as Christmas is to people in the West. It is the first day of the lunar calendar and usually occurs somewhere between January 30 and February 20. This festival heralds the beginning of spring. It is also a festival of reunion. No matter how far away people are from their homes, they will try their best to get back home to celebrate a reunion dinner.?

The origin of the Chinese New Year festival can be traced back thousands of years. According to one of the most famous legends, in ancient China there lived a ferocious monster named Year. Year lived deep at the bottom of the sea all year round and climbed up to the shore only on New Year?s Eve to devour the cattle and kill the people. People in the villages would flee to remote mountains so as to avoid this disaster. One year, an old man offered the villagers an option to fleeing. His solution was to put bright red paper on all of the villagers? doors and to fill their homes with noise. That is why on New Year?s Eve each family sticks antithetical couplets written on red paper on their doors, blows up firecrackers, and keeps their houses brilliantly illuminated while they stay up late into the night.

The Academy students made plenty of noise in honor of this traditional Chinese celebration. In addition, they were treated to a dance of the dragon courtesy of dancers from the Golden Dragon on Mack Avenue. ?We really appreciate the authentic flavor that Yee Tom from the Golden Dragon was able to provide for the children,? said third grade teacher Jeanette Stepanek, who coordinates the school?s buddy program and organized the making of masks and paper dragons for the event.
item.excerpt:encoded: What is known as the Chinese New Year in this country is commonly referred to as the Spring Festival in China, according to The Grosse Pointe Academy?s Chinese teacher, Lucia Hu.
