item.title: Science and Engineering Fair at Cobo Center
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the first time in many years, Grosse Pointe Academy students submitted science projects to the Science and Engineering Fair at Cobo Center. The projects were completed in physics class under the direction of seventh grade science teacher Wendy Jewett. Congratulations go to the following students whose projects were recognized: Jeffrey Woolstrum (Blue Ribbon - Outstanding); Alexa Yates (Blue Ribbon - Outstanding), and Conor Tily (Red Ribbon - Honorable Mention). Conor's project was submitted in the ninth grade category, so he was competing with high school students.

There were over 1400 entries. The exhibits were judged on creative ability, scientific thought, thoroughness, skill and clarity. Jeffrey's project, submitted in the Earth and Space Science category, examined the salinity of water versus the penetration of an object. Alexa's project, submitted in the physics category, investigated how the temperature of a magnet is affected when subjected to different temperatures. Conor's project, also submitted in the physics category, tested how the length of the sling on a Trebuchet affects its distance and accuracy.

item.title: 4/5 Students Participate in Nutrition Fair
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The 4/5 students took an inside journey of "My Pyramid," visiting all seven bands. The first band was "Grains," where they learned about whole grains versus refined grain. After conducting a starch experiment on various foods, they were rewarded with the taste treat of a whole wheat bagel topped with nutritious apple-pear butter.


The second band they visited was "Vegetables and Fruits." The students
learned the difference between a vegetable and a fruit. For example, they learned that a tomato is really a fruit because it has seeds. They tasted guacamole with fresh vegetables and sipped on 100% fruit and vegetable juices.

Next they visited the "Milk" station. Here the students learned why calcium is so important for their bodies. They performed an experiment in which bones and eggs soaked in vinegar represented the acidic soda and caffeine drinks we put into our bodies that deplete our calcium levels. They tasted low fat natural yogurt topped with flax seed and string cheese.

Meat and beans was the fourth station visited. The students calculated how much protein their own body needs. They then read labels and chose five foods that would meet those requirements. The taste reward was pumpkin and sunflower seeds.

The "Fat and Oil" station was held in the cafeteria where the students learned about the good oils and fats to eat. They experimented by selecting various healthy foods from the cafeteria that meet the daily serving requirements. Here they sampled healthy fats and oils found in olives, along with whole wheat bread dipped in olive oil and balsamic vinegar.

The students then worked out in the lower gym by skipping for fiveminutes. This was the "Physical Activity" band. The importance of hydration was demonstrated in a fruit experiment. They learned to take their pulse and related it to their own basil metabolic rate. They were very shocked by how high their heart rates increased with activity. Thereward here was well deserved H20.

Finally they played "Pyramid Bingo." Everyone sampled granola that consisted of foods from the five food groups. (The granola was made up of Cheerios, dried pineapple, M&M's, sunflower seeds, wasabi peas, cranberries and currants.)

Says school nurse Patti Boynton, who organized the Nutrition Fair: "What really made the event such a success was the wonderful fourth and fifth grade parents who volunteered to man each station, teach the facts, and share their own everyday nutritional experiences with all of the students."

item.title: The Eighth Grade Year: An Experience of a Lifetime
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
?Until you have graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy, you have no way of knowing what a unique experience the eighth grade year is,? says Scott Tily, Grades 4-8 Principal. ?The year is chock full of experiences that our students remember for the rest of their lives. In fact, many of them come back and talk about their memories of the eighth grade play, or performing for senior citizens as part of the Bell Choir.?

In the past, the fall of the eighth grade year kicked off with a trip to Camp Storer, but Scott adjusted the schedule several years ago so that students now go to Camp Storer in Napoleon, Michigan during the spring of their seventh grade year.

?The purpose of the Storer trip is for the class to bond as a unit,? says Scott, ?and we feel that the sooner this happens, the better.?

During the Storer trip in the spring, the students engage in trust-building exercises with one another and build confidence individually with such activities as the climbing wall and the high ropes, achieving success with the encouragement of their peers. Prior to the first day of school, classmates reunite after the long summer for a pizza party and the bonding experience continues.

Another favorite tradition is the first and eighth grade buddy program. Eighth grade advisor Marion Chrisner and first grade teachers Barbara Karle and Renee Martin spend a lot of time planning monthly activities so that the students get to know one another throughout the course of the year. The buddy program kicks off in September with the annual field trip to Miller?s Big Red Orchard & Cider Mill, where the first and eighth graders pick apples together, pet farm animals, and go on a hay ride. ?The best part of the apple orchard trip or any of the buddy activities, as a matter of fact, is watching the eighth graders enjoy being little kids themselves,? says Marion Chrisner.

A trip to the Stratford Festival later in the fall is incorporated into the curriculum, as the students read and discuss the play (in the case of the 2007-08 school year, The Merchant of Venice) in class with language arts teacher Lawrence DeLuca before heading to Stratford, Ontario to see the play performed live. During the day, they enjoy lunch at a local restaurant and take in the sights.

Community service is another important part of the eighth grade year. In addition to the expectation to contribute to their communities independently, students are given the opportunity to perform service as a group, most notably when they perform at hospitals and for senior citizens as part of the Bell Choir.

In the spring, the students are treated to a trip to Cleveland that includes educational components, such as trips to museums and the symphony, and time for just plain fun, like hitting every roller coaster at Cedar Point. Shortly upon their return, it is time for final exams, which uniquely prepares them for the rigors of high school. Production of the eighth grade play begins at this point, and the day is broken up so that a morning exam is followed by a half day of play rehearsal. Once exams are complete, the students dedicate entire days to the play. This year, director Marion Chrisner chose ?Little Shop of Horrors? to fully showcase this group?s vocal, choreographic and dramatic talents.

Another class activity is preparing for the Baccalaureate service the morning of graduation under the guidance of Christian Life teacher Ellen Krease. The students select and read scripture, recite personal reflections, and perform musically, giving the service a personal flair unique to that class. That evening, of course, is graduation, followed by a reception on the Lakeshore lawn where a receiving line forms for faculty and parents to congratulate the students on achieving this milestone in their lives.

item.title: Academy Renovations Recognized for Outstanding Architecture and Design
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Last year at this time, The Grosse Pointe Academy was getting ready to open the doors of its renovated school building for students and faculty members to enjoy during the 2007-08 school year. This fall the school will open its doors once again, but this time to a building that has received a number of accolades and awards for outstanding architecture and design that focused on historic preservation as well as creating the best possible learning environment for students.

Most recently, the Academy was selected by School Planning & Management magazine as a winner of the 2008 Impact on Learning Awards. Scores of entries were received showcasing schools from all across North America.

Says Jerry Enderle, Editor-in-Chief of School Planning & Management magazine: ?This year?s winners represent a cross section of the best new construction and renovation projects in the U.S. The Grosse Pointe Academy project was among those recognized for solving real-world problems through innovative design, engineering, and technology solutions.?

All winning institutions will be honored at the 2008 Awards Banquet that will take place during the Council of Educational Facility Planners International?s (CEFPI) 85th Annual International Conference this fall in San Diego. The GPA project will also be published in the August 2008 issue of School Planning & Management magazine and included in a special ?Impact on Learning? Award Supplement. Receiving recognition in the historic preservation category, the Academy?s renovations will appear on the magazine?s cover.

?The vision of The Grosse Pointe Academy was to bring a modern learning environment to its historic Moran building, and to do so without impacting the school?s striking Gothic exterior,? explained project architect Theo Pappas, AIA, of Fanning/Howey Associates, Inc. in Novi. ?A phased renovations program ?unlocked? the building by rearranging program areas and reclaiming space for education.?

Classrooms are now 200 to 250 square feet larger and can support modern educational programs for grades 1-8. New computers and plasma televisions in each classroom, and a new computer lab on the second floor, create a technology-rich environment. Teachers enjoy ample storage space, and new lighting systems reduce energy costs. Preservation efforts brought new life to the 78-year-old building by restoring windows and doors as well as the original Welsh tile in the main lobby.

The Grosse Pointe Academy was also recognized for outstanding architecture and design in education and appeared as a ?Project of Distinction? in the June 2008 issue of School Planning & Management?s Education Design Showcase. Said Thomas P. McGinley, Special Projects Manager for the Education Design Showcase: ?Good designs don?t just happen. They are created due to the hard work of the district, the architect and the community. Each project may be unique, yet they all share one common goal: to provide the best possible learning environment for all students at all levels of education. The Grosse Pointe Academy?s project has achieved this goal.?

Finally, The Grosse Pointe Academy library was featured in the April 2008 issue of American Libraries magazine. The 2,800 square foot library renovation retained the original wood arches, historic pendant and sconce lighting, windows and wainscoting, while adding supplemental and task lighting and converting a former stage into a young children?s reading area.

Educational planning and interior design were led by Fanning/Howey Associates, Inc., with Frank Rewold & Sons serving as construction/project managers and Grissim Metz Andriese Associates leading the landscape architecture project. Lighting design was by Peter Basso Associates, Inc. and the historic preservation portion of the project was overseen by Gunn Levine Architects.

item.title: Farewell from the PCC Co-Chairs
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Webster definition of volunteering is as follows: ?One who performs or gives services of his own free will. To give or offer of one?s own accord.? The following is Jennifer Bojarczyk and Abby Wujek?s definition of volunteering, which Jennifer shared during the year-end PCC breakfast in May.

?Volunteering means going through more shampoo and conditioner in one year because you have so much on your mind while in the shower you can?t remember if you washed your hair yet so you do it again. It means when your husband asks what?s for dinner, your answer is ?Hot dogs, but by the way, in order to get that hot dog, you have to grill for three hours in the rain, make over 300 hot dogs and serve them all.? It means when you decide to throw a surprise parade for Camille DeMario, you have to have the biggest float and therefore enlist the help of your father who is an engineer, your mother who is a decorator, and your sister who just feels sorry for you.

Abby and I were honored during the final Board meeting of the year for our two years of service, but the biggest honor we receive is knowing we have made a small difference in our children?s world. Every day we roam the halls, whether as PCC chairs, room moms, ambassadors or chairs of some other committee. We have witnessed the joy and pride our children take in our steps to make The Grosse Pointe Academy a better place for them. Both Henry and Nicholas are at an age to understand what their mommies do for their school. Volunteering is not easy, not always fun, doesn?t pay and can be frustrating. However, it is the best job that the two of us have ever had. We know that we have had an impact on our children?s futures by being a part of their education through our volunteer service. Both of us have donated a lot of our time and money over the past six years and we will continue to do so because we believe in this beautiful school, its leadership, its character and its mission. I can only hope that our efforts will encourage others to step forward. It is not how big the job is but the effort that is put into the job that makes it worth it. We do not need rewards or thanks from others. The smiles and praise we get from our children is the only reward we will ever need.?

item.title: GPA Middle School Students Compete in National French Contest Exam
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the second consecutive year, Grosse Pointe Academy seventh and eighth graders participated in the National French Contest Exam (also known as Le Grand Concours) with outstanding results. This 60-minute national examination is developed and managed by the American Association of Teachers of French. Its purpose is to help stimulate further interest in the teaching and learning of French as well as to help identify and reward student achievement.

The exam is a multiple-choice test of approximately 70 items covering listening comprehension, vocabulary, grammar and reading comprehension. Students took the test that was appropriate for the French curriculum in which they are enrolled. Their scores were then ranked against students locally as well as nationally who are enrolled in similar curricula.

Competing against both middle school and high school students, the following Academy middle schoolers placed in the top ten nationally:  eighth graders Samantha Fitzpatrick (95th percentile with a #2 chapter ranking and #4 national ranking), Grace Rentschler (95th percentile with a #3 chapter ranking and #5 national ranking), Somers Brush (95th percentile with a #4 chapter ranking and #6 national ranking), Henry Brophy (90th percentile with a #8 chapter ranking and #10 national ranking), Robert Stanley (90th percentile with a #8 chapter ranking and #10 national ranking), and seventh grader Katherine Woodward (90th percentile with a #3 chapter ranking and #6 national ranking).

The sixth graders took the FLES exam, which includes a speaking section as well. Students are only ranked nationally for this exam. Kate Krueger ranked #9 nationally, and Caleb Cimmarrusti ranked #10 nationally.

item.title: Surprise Parade for Camille DeMario
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
It may have rained during the surprise parade for Camille DeMario on Monday, but the rain didn't dampen spirits, nor did it spoil the surprise. Miss Camille showed up for what she thought was a pep rally prior to GPA's annual Spring Spirit Night, only to find out that it was in fact a tribute to her 39 years at the Academy. Early School classes and lower and middle school grades created a variety of floats in her honor, then paraded around the Tracy Fieldhouse. The students selected themes for their floats that they felt best represented their memories of their Early and Lower School Principal, from "We Can Always Count on You" (Miss Kate's three-day class), to "You are My Sunshine" (grade 1) and "Golfing into the Future" (grade 5).

Special thanks go to PCC co-chairs Jennifer Bojarczyk and Abby Wujek and room parents for planning and organizing the event, as well as all the parents who assisted with float building and hosting float building parties.

item.title: Students Celebrate Academy History
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Every GPA family received a copy of "Reflections," a history of The Grosse Pointe Academy and the Academy of the Sacred Heart by GPA students from the 2007-2008 school year. This book was put together under the guidance of Early School teacher Peggy Varty, who worked with the curriculum committee and all of the teachers to coordinate this inaugural project.

"Reflections" includes work from every GPA student from pre-school through grade 8. Each grade level was assigned a project regarding the history, alumni, architecture, or grounds of the school.

As stated in the introduction to the book, "Our children and staff appreciate coming to such a beautiful facility each day to learn and we felt it was important for the children to study the history and background of their campus environment.... We hope you enjoy your adventure through the pages of this book and get a glimpse into the history of our campus." The history of the school has been added to the curriculum for yearly study at each grade level.

Special thanks go to the Architectural Salvage Warehouse of Detroit for the inspiration and partial funding to print the book. If you did not receive a copy of the book, please contact Peggy Varty at pvarty@gpacademy.org. Each family received a copy free of charge, and additional copies are available for purchase at $15 each. Please make out a check to The Grosee Pointe Academy and put "Reflections" in the memo section of the check. You may either pick up a copy of the book in Peggy's room or she will deliver it to your child's classroom. There are approximately 53 copies left so they will be sold on a first come, first served basis.

item.title: Students Spellbound at Spelling Bee
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the third consecutive year, middle school students Somers Brush and Alex Parker battled it out against one another in the final round of the annual Grosse Pointe Academy spelling bee. Somers was declared champion in 2005-06, with Alex winning his revenge as champion in 2006-07. Now eighth graders, they met for their final match-up, and, in spite of the violent nature of the two final words ? ?lacerate? and ?hemorrhage? ? the mood was congenial and good sportsmanship prevailed when Somers was ultimately declared champion for 2007-08. 

Fourth grader Jack Sheeren, a new student at the Academy this year, made it to the final three in his debut performance. ?This was actually the first year that fourth graders competed,? said 4/5 teacher Bob Lapadot, who has moderated the Academy?s spelling bee for 21 years. ?I was impressed with all of the students, but particularly the younger ones. It is not easy to get up in front of your peers and older students like that. It is a great opportunity for these kids to learn how to be poised and think on their feet in front of an audience.?

Congratulations go to all the top spellers in their grades who qualified for the bee based on two rounds of written tests. The other finalists were fourth graders Sara Anthony and Grayson Cieszkowski, fifth graders Charles Becker and Joseph Cavataio, sixth graders Karstan Minanov, Jennifer Vermet and Zachary Wood, seventh graders Ryley Maher and Ryan Rochte, and eighth grader Grace Rentschler.
item.excerpt:encoded: A school spelling bee seems an unlikely setting for violence, but the two final words in this year?s bee ? ?lacerate? and ?hemorrhage? ? might have conveyed otherwise. In all actuality, the mood was congenial and good sportsmanship prevailed when eighth graders Somers Brush and Alex Parker were declared champion and runner-up, respectively.

item.title: Sixth Graders Host Medieval Feast
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
A typical day at The Grosse Pointe Academy generally does not involve knighthood ceremonies, three-course meals or judgments, but then again Friday, May 16 was not a typical day at GPA. While the 4/5 students rested from their trip to Washington, D.C., the seventh graders tested their physical skills at Camp Storer, and the eighth graders took in the sights on their Cleveland trip, the sixth graders ruled the land with the annual sixth grade medieval feast.

Organized by social studies teachers Harriett Whitaker and Mary Jo Johnson, the event has become a popular tradition among the students. Parents, or "serving wenches," served a first course of bread, soup and pears, a second course of chicken, roast potatoes and baby carrots, and a final course of dessert. In between courses, King Scott (Tily) and Queen Harriett (Whitaker) and an assortment of guests that included a priest, lords and ladies of the manor, knights and squires, all seated according to their status, enjoyed a knighting ceremony, entertainment by musicians, dancers, jugglers, poets, jesters, and several judgments during which folks in the gallery decided whether an evildoer should be set free or sent to the dungeon. A special thanks goes to Huong Riley who did a phenomenal job organizing the parents and assisting Mrs. Whitaker with making additional costumes.
item.excerpt:encoded: A typical day at The Grosse Pointe Academy generally does not involve knighthood ceremonies, three-course meals or judgments, but then again Friday, May 16 was not a typical day at GPA.

item.title: Little Shop of Horrors
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
During the last week of school, while the rest of the students were busy finishing up classes, going on picnics, and enjoying end-of-year celebrations, the eighth grade was going full throttle in the production of an Academy tradition: the eighth grade play. This year the students put on "Little Shop of Horrors" under the direction of music teacher Marion Chrisner.

"As I think about the eighth grade play, I look carefully at the personalities of the class: what kind of humor do they have; what is their work ethic; how creative is their group imagination; how well are they able to support one another; and how much are they willing to share of themselves," says Mrs. Chrisner.

The next element is to cast the show in a manner that gives each eighth grader a part that showcases his or her unique personality, to make the parts as equal as possible, and then to provide a chance for each student to contribute to the overall production. For this year's play, this resulted in six trios, fourteen Audreys, eight Seymours, three dentists and three reporters.

The final criterion for the show itself is to divide the creative portion of the show so that each student takes responsibility for a particular area such as sound, lighting, costumes, construction, and "all the small details that bring success." According to Marion, "Ownership in the final product is a matter of pride and an outstanding lesson in learning."

The results, from the standpoint of those who attended the final performance on June 10, were spectacular.
item.excerpt:encoded: During the last week of school, while the rest of the students were busy finishing up classes, going on picnics, and enjoying end-of-year celebrations, the eighth grade was going full throttle in the production of an Academy tradition: the eighth grade play.

item.title: Welcome to New Principal Jennifer Kendall
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy announced the appointment of Jennifer Kendall as the new Early and Lower School through Grade 3 Principal beginning July 1, 2008. Kendall is currently Principal of Godwin Elementary School in Midland Park, New Jersey, a suburb of New York City. She is a graduate of Mount Holyoke College and holds an M.A. from Caldwell College in Curriculum and Instruction and an Ed.M. in Organization and Leadership from Teachers College Columbia University.

Jennifer brings with her a wealth of knowledge and ten years of experience in the educational field. In addition to her current Principal position, she brings perspective from previous appointments as a Director of Curriculum and Staff Development and a Technology Coordinator.  She has a thorough understanding of the Montessori philosophy and will be working closely in the transition phase with Camille DeMario, who is stepping down as Principal after 39 years of dedicated service, to further her understanding of Montessori applications for children in pre-school through Kindergarten at the Academy. 

Jennifer will be moving to Grosse Pointe this summer with her husband and two young children.  Phil Demartini, Head of School, is looking forward to the contributions Jennifer will bring to the Academy in her new role. As said by one of her references, ?Your school is so lucky to be able to hire such a tremendous person and committed educator. We already feel the void at our school.?
item.excerpt:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy announced the appointment of Jennifer Kendall as the new Early and Lower School through Grade 3 Principal beginning July 1, 2008.

item.title: Action Auction 2008 a Great Success!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The 41st Action Auction opened doors to another successful fundraising event for The Grosse Pointe Academy.  Held on the Academy campus on May 7 and 10, guests were tempted with a wide array of over 700 items as well as a first rate party. Catering was provided by Epoch Events Catering, well known for their restaurant group properties, Tribute in Farmington Hills, Forte in Birmingham and Latitude in Bay Harbor.

On Wednesday, May 7, 350 items were offered in a silent auction. The merchandise was artfully displayed to catch the bidder?s eye, with bids displayed on plasma screens to allow guests to move throughout the Tracy Fieldhouse.  Guests dined on a delicious strolling supper topped off by divine double shot desserts.

For the Saturday event, guests arrived on the red carpet and kicked off the night with a champagne toast in the school?s newly renovated library.  Many came in black tie to lend an elegant air to the evening.  The night showcased another 330 silent auction items to get the bidding started for the evening.



The Tracy Fieldhouse was transformed again into a lovely dining and event space with tables decked out with crisp, white and periwinkle tablecloths accented with a springtime array of gorgeous flowers. A sumptuous buffet dinner was served, followed by the start of the program. Emcee Paul W. Smith and the DuMouchelle auctioneers led the charge with a live auction, offering an exciting selection of 46 impressive items.  These included trips to Australia, Ireland, and Paris, beautiful jewelry, cars, parties and more.



Sponsors of Action Auction 2008 included Premier Sponsor ? St. John Hospital and Medical Center, Principal Sponsor ? Gallagher-Kaiser and Faculty Sponsor- National City, among many corporate sponsors and item donors who helped make the evening a success. Proceeds raised helped fund academic enrichment activities, scholarships and the preservation of the beautiful historic campus.
item.excerpt:encoded: The 41st Action Auction opened doors to another successful fundraising event for The Grosse Pointe Academy.

item.title: Grosse Pointe Academy Breathes Easier After Comprehensive Antimicrobial Treatment of the Facility
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Providing a safe and protected environment for students will always be a top objective for educators. Recently, the administration of The Grosse Pointe Academy took its commitment to creating an ideal learning environment to a microscopic level by treating the entire facility with the TriBan Antimicrobial System from Triton Technology Group, LLC.

The dreaded words of ?mold, mildew and bacteria? are rarely good news for any commercial property owner, especially a school administrator.  At a minimum, microbial contamination can cause stains, odors and property damage to facilities and at the extreme facilities have been condemned for poor air quality, ?sick building syndrome? and even found to harbor super-bugs like the antibiotic resistant MRSA bacteria.

?By their very nature, schools are an environment where germs can easily get passed around.  For us, children and faculty missing school days is a major concern in our efforts,? said Phil Demartini, head of school at GPA.  ?We believe it is our responsibility to do everything in our power to proactively make this learning environment as safe as possible.  Treating all of the Academy?s surfaces with the powerful TriBan Antimicrobial System gives us the confidence of knowing that we have done just that.?

According to the Indoor Air Quality and Student Performance study by the EPA, ?Evidence continues to emerge showing that poor indoor air quality (IAQ) can cause illness requiring absence from school, and can cause acute health symptoms that decrease performance while at school.  In addition, recent data suggest that poor IAQ may directly reduce a person?s ability to perform specific mental tasks requiring concentration, calculation, or memory.?  (Revised August 2003, 402-K-03-006)

?Microbes such as pathogenic bacteria like MRSA, and air quality issues caused by mold and mildew, are not what school administrators should be worried about,? said Art McWood, president of the Triton Technology Group.  ?They should be able to focus on the challenge of educating our kids in the best environment possible.  That confidence only comes with the continually active, comprehensive TriBan Antimicrobial System.?

?The key to the TriBan system is our durable antimicrobial application,? McWood continued. This EPA registered antimicrobial forms an extremely durable bond on a surface, killing all the microbes present on contact and essentially creating a molecular ?bed of nails? all over the treated area.  It makes the surface physically inhospitable to future microbial growth. To the human eye and touch, the application is invisible, but for microbes, it is an end-game.?

The Grosse Pointe Academy was treated from top to bottom with the TriBan Antimicrobial System, covering all the major surfaces of the building including the cafeteria, lockers, hallways, classrooms, athletic facilities.

Unlike most other antimicrobials that leach chemicals or heavy metals into the air and the surrounding environment, the unique technology controls microbial growth without leaching, making it an effective, ?green? alternative for schools.

?Part of our decision to choose the TriBan System was a concern for the environment. I didn?t want my preventative measures to only add more chemicals and toxins into the very environment I am trying to protect. Knowing that this was a non-invasive, green technology really made choosing TriBan easy,? said Demartini.

The TriBan Antimicrobial System is a comprehensive approach to microbial treatment and prevention.  It begins with extensive testing of the facility to determine what contaminants are present and what problem areas exist.  Then a customized treatment plan is created for a school that involves a deep cleaning with an EPA registered germ killer and fungicide and followed by an application of Triton?s continuously active antimicrobial to the surfaces.  Finally, post-testing by an independent lab and a long-term service plan covers annual re-inspections, retesting and service calls complete the process.

Located in downtown Detroit, Triton Technology Group is the exclusive provider of the TriBan Antimicrobial System.  Triton offers an extensive line-up of antimicrobial treatments and applications servicing a broad range of industries including schools, athletic facilities, marinas, new construction and health care facilities.  For more information about Triton Technology Group and the TriBan System, please call (313) 963-7979 or visit www.tritontg.com.

Recently, the administration of The Grosse Pointe Academy took its commitment to creating an ideal learning environment to a microscopic level by treating the entire facility with the TriBan Antimicrobial System from Triton Technology Group, LLC.

item.title: GPA Kicks Off Pennies for Peace Program
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Students in grades 1-8 attended a special assembly in the Tracy Fieldhouse on Monday to learn about Pennies for Peace, a service-learning program of Central Asia Institute (CIA). Dr. Alexia Minanov, mother of Alexander (Grade 5) and Karina (Grade 3), showed the students a brief video about the program and then explained how the Academy plans to participate. Each student, from Early School through Grade 8, is encouraged to bring in pennies to contribute to the penny jars available in each classroom. A friendly competition among classes will be held, and Ryan Marier, Assistant Vice President and personal banker at Chase Bank in Grosse Pointe, has volunteered to count the pennies free of charge and to keep individual class accounts. Stay tuned for reports of the students' progress! The program will run through early February.

Pennies for Peace is a service-learning program of Central Asia Institute (CAI). CAI is a non-profit that provides community-based education, especially for girls, in Pakistan and Afghanistan. Pennies for Peace invites students to broaden their cultural horizons and learn about their capacity to be philanthropists - one penny at a time.

For more information, please visit the Pennies for Peace website at www.penniesforpeace.org. You can also visit Central Asia Institute's homepage at www.ikat.org to learn about how CAI projects promote peace in these regions.

item.title: Leading Authority on Parenting Spoke at GPA
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Dr. David Walsh, one of the world’s leading authorities on parenting and the impact of media on children’s health and development, addressed parents and educators on October 28 at The Grosse Pointe Academy. The topic was “No: Why Kids of All Ages Need to Hear It and Ways Parents Can Say It.” Dr. Walsh was this year’s featured speaker in the Academy’s annual McMillan Lecture Series, which is a gift from Thayer and Gioconda McMillan given in memory of William Charles McMillan III in the interest of emphasizing the importance of elementary education.

The main theme of Dr. Walsh’s talk was self-discipline. According to Walsh, self discipline is a key character trait that leads to success in school and in life. Self-discipline helps kids stay on task, finish a task, stay focused, be engaged, take on a challenge, make better decisions and resist what Walsh called “the siren call of entitlement: ‘Gotta have it and gotta have it now!’” Parents who say “no” and use the parenting skills of No are re-discovering parenting strategies that work, said Walsh.

As an example, Dr. Walsh told what he referred to as the “Marshmallow Story.”

“Almost forty years ago, a group of scientists performed a very important experiment with children,” Dr. Walsh told the audience. “Parents brought three-and-four-year old boys and girls into a room one by one, where the scientist presented them with a choice. They could either eat a marshmallow that he gave them right away, or they could wait until he came back with a second marshmallow. Some of those little boys and girls gobbled up that marshmallow before the door was even closed; others did whatever they could to wait for that second marshmallow. The important thing about the experiment is that the scientists followed those children all the way through their growing-up years – through elementary school, the teenage years, into early adulthood. The conclusion of the experiment was that the ability to wait for that second marshmallow was an amazingly strong predictor of those children’s success and happiness through school and into early adulthood. That experiment was really a measure of a critical success factor: self-discipline.”

Dr. Walsh is the author of nine books, including the national best seller Why Do They Act That Way? A Survival Guide to the Adolescent Brain for You and Your Teen. His latest book, No: Why Kids – of All Ages – Need to Hear It and Ways Parents Can Say It, serves as the focal point of the Say Yes to No campaign, which teaches parents and educators how to instill self-discipline in America’s children.

Dr. Walsh has authored columns on numerous topics, including Internet addition and the dangers of MySpace.com. A frequent guest on national radio and television, he has appeared on NBC’s Today Show, Good Morning America, The CBS Early Show, The News Hour with Jim Lehrer, Dateline NBC, ABC’s 20/20, and National Public Radio’s All Things Considered and Morning Edition. He has received numerous awards, including the Council on Family Relation’s Friend of the Family Award.
item.excerpt:encoded: Dr. David Walsh, one of the world?s leading authorities on parenting and the impact of media on children?s health and development, addressed parents and educators on October 28 at The Grosse Pointe Academy.

item.title: Academy Graduate Performs for First Lady
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy alumna Regan Chuhran had the opportunity of a lifetime on Thursday, October 23. She was invited to perform before the First Lady during a luncheon at the Grosse Pointe Yacht Club honoring Congressman Tim Walberg.

?She didn?t miss a beat!? said her proud mother, Roshell Chuhran, who teaches music for Early and Lower School students at the Academy.

Regan was recognized before the guests by the Master of Ceremonies and again by Congressman Walberg. According to Roshell, the crowd was very appreciative of her efforts. ?Many of them commented privately on how nice it was to have a local talent play for them and how much they enjoyed her music,? said Roshell.

After her early beginnings at age six under her mother's tutelage, Regan is in her third year of studying piano under Laura L. Lindow. Regan is also an accomplished classical and Spanish guitarist. She sings with her church choir and is a member of the "Knighting Gails" choir at University Liggett School, where she is currently a freshman. A 2008 graduate of The Grosse Pointe Academy, she was voted "Most Likely to Win a Grammy" by her classmates in her eighth grade yearbook.

item.title: Yoga Ed. Comes to GPA
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Everyone, from young children to adults, should take time out of their busy schedules to stretch, breathe, and relax their minds and bodies, according to P.E. teacher Cheryl Carroll. As a teacher who focuses on the physical health and wellness of her students, Cheryl is a big believer that physical activity helps children relieve stress, focus in class, and perform better overall. A natural outgrowth of this philosophy is incorporating yoga into the classroom. Cheryl has invited Heidi George, a certified yoga teacher from Yoga Ed., to train Academy teachers in using simple yoga-based mind-body integration strategies for effective stress and behavior and classroom management. Heidi teaches students, teachers and parents in the Grosse Pointe community. Yoga Ed. is geared for pre-school through middle school.

After a preliminary session with faculty members, Heidi will hold weekly after-school sessions for teachers beginning in November. A pilot afterschool program for students will follow in December.

First graders in Barbara Karle?s class enjoyed a visit from Heidi earlier this fall. Heidi led the children in stretching exercises and taught them a variety of relaxation techniques.
item.excerpt:encoded: Everyone, from young children to adults, should take time out of their busy schedules to stretch, breathe, and relax their minds and bodies, according to P.E. teacher Cheryl Carroll.

item.title: GPA Honored for Restoration and Design
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy renovations to the main school building continue to receive accolades and awards locally, nationally and internationally. Most recently, the Academy received a 2009 Citation of Excellence Award from Learning By Design, a school and university leader's annual guide to architectural services published by Stratton Publishing & Marketing Inc. in Alexandria, Virginia.

From among a multitude of projects submitted throughout the country, the Academy's design project was deemed one of the best by a nationally recognized panel of architects and educational facility specialists. As a Citation of Excellence Award winner, the project will receive special editorial feature coverage and a free listing in the print and electronic Facilities Resources Buyer's Guide. The project and the Academy will also be showcased online at www.learningbydesign.biz.

"The Academy's selection as a Citation of Excellence Award winner from among this competitive field of entries is a genuine tribute to the school and the project," said project architect Theo Pappas, AIA, of Fanning/Howey Associates, Inc. in Novi. "I am particularly proud of this award, because the judge and jury were not just architects or designers, but educators and educational planners. This is a continuing testimony to all the hard work and effort of everyone who was so dedicated to making this happen."

The school will receive a commemorative plaque in recognition of this achievement. Head of School Phil Demartini has invited Theo Pappas to personally present this plaque at the Board of Trustees meeting in January.

The Academy also won a Preservation Wayne, Preservation Honor "Regional Neighbor" Award for the restoration of the main school building. Preservation Wayne is Detroit’s oldest and largest preservation organization dedicated to preserving, promoting, and protecting the neighborhoods and structures that define Detroit. The Academy will be recognized at the "Past, Forward" 2008 Preservation Honor Awards Dinner at the Colony Club Detroit on November 20.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy renovations to the main school building continue to receive accolades and awards locally, nationally and internationally.

item.title: Parent Guests Bring Expertise to Students
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
First grade and eighth grade students enjoyed some special visits from parents, who shared insights from their respective professions to enrich their studies.

Geoff Donaldson, an environmental planner and father of Bridget (grade 4) and Timothy (grade 1), visited Mrs. Martin's first grade class as part of their occupation unit to discuss how he helps to make the environment safe for everyone. Using a model and a spray bottle, he demonstrated to the children how rain washes pollutants into the sewers, which eventually carries pollutants to the waterways, and how building smaller, more curved waterways helps slow down the movement of water so that fewer pollutants get into larger waterways.

John Engstrom, a federal prosecutor and parent of Sophie (grade 5) and Miles (grade 2), spoke to eighth graders about the Constitution as part of their study of American government in social studies class with Mary Jo Johnson.
item.excerpt:encoded: First grade and eighth grade students enjoyed some special visits from parents, who shared insights from their respective professions to enrich their studies.

item.title: 4/5 Students Have a Blast in Science Class
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Science class was a blast for Academy fourth and fifth graders this week – literally! During what 4/5 teacher Bob Lapadot historically calls "V-Day," students withstood the cold outside to set off over 60 volcanoes. The volcanoes were made at home with the help of on-line tips, the creativity of the students and their parents, and some good old-fashioned baking soda and vinegar. Another popular ingredient choice was the particularly explosive combination of mentos and Diet Coke.

One of the strengths of this popular project, which the students do during either their fourth or fifth grade year, was the amount of flexibility given to each young scientist, allowing for endless creativity. “Our philosophy is that the children don’t need kits,” said Bob. “They have vivid imaginations. Why not let them run with it? And the results were spectacular – volcanoes of every size, color and shape imaginable."

Students were not shy about volunteering to set off their volcanoes!
James Raudabaugh's volcano successfully erupted before admiring bystanders.
Creativity was an important component of the volcano project.
item.excerpt:encoded: Science class was a blast for Academy fourth and fifth graders this week ? literally! During what 4/5 teacher Bob Lapadot historically calls "V-Day," students withstood the cold outside to set off over 60 volcanoes.

item.title: Eighth Grader Wins Geography Bee
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Eighth grader Meade Maxwell won the school-level competition of the National Geographic Bee and a chance at a $25,000 college scholarship. Seventh graders Robbie Triano and Allison Mobley were the finalist and third place runner-up, respectively. Held this Thursday, the school-level Bee, at which students answered oral questions on geography, was the first round in the 21st annual National Geographic Bee. The Bee is sponsored by the National Geographic Society.

Meade was the finalist two years ago and Allison was the finalist last year. As this year's champion, Meade will take another written test; up to 100 of the top scorers in each state will be eligible to compete in their state Bee in March.

item.title: Academy Students Have a Dream
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy students have a dream for America. They dream of "filling the world with peace and love." They dream that "we can do our part for world peace. That everyone can get a good education." They dream "to help kids go to better schools" and "to help the environment and the economy."

The students, with the help of their buddies, expressed their dreams in words and pictures after the special grade 1-8 assembly held on Friday afternoon in honor of Martin Luther King, Jr. The assembly, which was held in the Chapel, featured brief remarks from Phil Demartini, Wendy Demartini and Rosi Triano, the telling by eighth graders of the story of Marian Anderson, the first African American woman to sing with the Metropolitan Opera, the singing of "We Shall Overcome" by faculty members, and a solo vocal performance by eighth grader Giovanna Posselius.

Following the assembly, the students gathered in the classrooms with their buddies to write and illustrate their dreams for America. These letters will be mailed to President Barack Obama on Presidential Inauguration Day on January 20.

That everyone can get a good education." They dream "to help kids go to better schools" and "to help the environment and the economy."

item.title: Art Department Receives "Picturing America" Award
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy art department was awarded Picturing America, a free education resource of the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), distributed in cooperation with the American Library Association.

Picturing America award materials include forty images mounted on twenty double-sided, laminated posters for display and classroom use and a teacher's resource book. The school expects to receive these materials in March and April and will be able to keep them at no cost.

This exciting initiative of the National Endowment for the Humanities brings masterpieces of American art into schools and public libraries nationwide.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy art department was awarded Picturing America, a free education resource of the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), distributed in cooperation with the American Library Association.

item.title: GPA Names Athletes of the Fall Season
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy eighth graders Phillip Pierce and Gerard Smith and seventh grader Kara French were named Athletes of the Season for the fall of 2008. Each was chosen for this honor based on his or her athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship.

Phillip was the team co-captain and co-MVP of the Academy’s undefeated tennis team. He was undefeated in the #2 singles spot with a record of 14-0. A scholar athlete, he received high academic honors and is on the citizenship and head of school list. He is also a member of the National Junior Honor Society.

Playing in the #1 singles spot, Gerard had a record of 13-1 on the tennis team. He was co-captain and, along with Pierce, was voted most valuable player. He is a scholar athlete, received academic honors, and is a member of the National Junior Honor Society.

Kara, a first-year player on the undefeated varsity volleyball team, was named best spiker. A scholar athlete, she received high academic honors, is on the citizenship and head of school list, and is a member of the National Junior Honor Society.

item.title: First Graders Create Living Aquarium
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
This winter Grosse Pointe Academy first graders have been immersed in a cross-curricular study of sea life that incorporates language arts, science, art, music and French.

Each child selected a sea creature to research and write a report on. They studied the food chain, read different literature, conducted research on the Internet, and took part in an interactive lesson using the SmartBoard in the Fisher Library. First grade teachers Barbara Karle and Renee Martin worked hard to integrate the subject of sea life throughout their lessons in the classroom.

In art class with Rosi Triano, the students created large paper sea life puppets that they painted and stuffed. In French class with Madame Leslie, they listened to the story, The Little Mermaid, and learned the vocabulary for the most common animals that live in the ocean. In addition to creating a book that displays all the creatures they learned about, they expressed sentences with their newly developed vocabulary.

To tie all of these pieces together, music teacher Roshell Chuhran selected “The Aquarium” from the French composer, Camille Saint-Saens, to create a living aquarium using the artwork the students created along with their French studies.

The culminating activity for this program was when the students presented their work for parents on Friday, February 20  in the Tracy Fieldhouse. The presentation featured their artwork, introductions for themselves and their sea creatures in French, and a sea-inspired choreography.
item.excerpt:encoded: First graders dove into their study on sea life this year! This cross-curricular unit incorporated language arts, science, art, music and French.

item.title: Pennies for Peace - The Final Count!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Pennies for Peace fundraising drive concluded during a Chapel assembly on February 2, and the final results are in! The total amount raised was $2,417.57. Equally impressive is the weight (1335 pounds) and volume (46 gallons) of the pennies donated. The top five classes (in total dollars raised) are: Janice Sturm, Kate Banfield, Mary Jo Carrier, Wendy Demartini and Marsha Thomas.

The top five classes per capita are: Debby Wolney, Kate Banfield, Janice Sturm, Marsha Thomas, and Wendy Demartini. In both cases, Devin Mequio's second grade class and the sixth grade were close behind.

The Student Council raised $68.34 that was divided among the sixth, seventh and eighth grades. Dylan and Derek Demkowiz and Karstan and Nikolas Minanov earned tips at the Action Auction Legends Party that they donated to the program. This amount was divided among their respective class accounts. Other donations included a glass jug filled with pennies from past parent Chuck Begg totalling $263.02. This amount was divided among the classes.

"I want to thank all the teachers for supporting this cause and creating enthusiasm for it among their students," said Alexia Minanov, who spearheaded the effort. Denise Phelps, who served as faculty coordinator, gave special mention to second grader Danny Arkison. "Danny was a great help to me in keeping count of the penny jars and putting on stickers as the jars were submitted," Denise said. "I really appreciated his sincere and eager assistance."
item.excerpt:encoded: The Pennies for Peace fundraising drive concluded during a Chapel assembly on February 2, and the final results are in! The total amount raised was $2,417.57.

item.title: School Essay Contest Winners Named
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Three eighth graders from The Grosse Pointe Academy have been named local winners in the 40th annual America & Me Essay Contest, sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance.

The three students, who earned the first, second and third place awards for their school, are Shavon McSwine, first, Katherine Woodward, second, and Taylor Chuhran, third. All three received award certificates for their achievement. As the school’s first place winner, Shavon's name will also be engraved on a plaque for permanent display in the school.

The Grosse Pointe Academy’s participation in the America & Me Essay Contest was sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance agent Colleen Dyer of Grosse Pointe Woods (pictured below with the three winners, from left: Taylor, Katherine and Shavon). Started in 1968 and open to all Michigan eighth grade students, the contest encourages Michigan youngsters to explore their roles in America’s future. The students wrote their essays in language arts class with Lawrence DeLuca.

Shavon's first place essay now advances to the state level competition, from which the top ten essays in Michigan will be selected. The top ten statewide winners, who will be announced in April, will receive plaques, cash, and U.S. savings bonds valued from $500 to $1,000. In addition, the top ten essayists will be honored at a banquet in Lansing, meet with Michigan’s top governmental leaders, and be the featured guests at a Lansing Lugnuts minor league baseball game dedicated in their honor.
item.excerpt:encoded: Three eighth graders from The Grosse Pointe Academy have been named local winners in the 40th annual America & Me Essay Contest, sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance.

item.title: Blanketed with Love
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Sixth grade students joined forces on Monday, February 23 to help make fleece blankets for the homeless. The project was spearheaded by Sarah Blake, a Mercy High sophomore who partnered with a friend to create a non-profit business called "Blanketed with Love." Their blankets have gone to homeless people, pregnancy centers, abused women, soup kitchens and senior centers.



Thanks to the behind-the-scenes coordination of parent Mary Alice Mecke and the on-scenes help of community service coordinator Sasha Murphy, eighth grade volunteers and numerous parents, the students made over 30 blankets in support of St. Paul on the Lake's upcoming Homeless Week. Sarah and her sister, Lilly, and mother, Anne, were on hand to help with the project.

The Louisa St. Clair Chapter Daughters of the American Revolution of Grosse Pointe www.LSCDAR.com presented American History Calendars to The Grosse Pointe Academy for distribution to the history and social studies teachers and students. Celebrating the 200th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln, these calendars published by the United States Capital Historical Society feature pictures of American landmarks and an 1809 history fact for each day of the year. The DAR Chapter procures many of the educational items donated to the schools through the Riverbank Book Service of the Friends of the Detroit River www.detroitriver.org. 

LSC Chapter Regent Susie Scheiwe of the Louisa St. Clair Chapter Daughters of the American Revolution of Grosse Pointe is shown presenting the U.S. History calendar to 4/5 teacher Wendy Demartini and fourth grade student J'Von Tolbert.

item.title: Library Book Donated to GPA School Library by the Louisa St. Clair Chapter of the DAR
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Louisa St. Clair Chapter Daughters of the American Revolution of Grosse Pointe www.LSCDAR.com presented the book, The Constitution for Kids, by Cathy Travis, to The Grosse Pointe Academy school library. Written specifically for the 9-12 year old age group, this comprehensive book offers the text of the Constitution of the United States on a split page. On the left is the original, somewhat hard to understand, text and on the right is a modern English “translation” that makes it easier for students in fourth through seventh grade to wrap their minds around these laws. The book also contains Constitutional Amendments in easy to understand everyday English, a glossary of terms, and a summary section which helps the children process what they just read.

LSC DAR Chapter Librarian Mary Elizabeth Savage made the presentation in February, which has long been known as American History Month. The book is being donated to each public, private and parochial elementary school library in Grosse Pointe. The books were purchased from the Friends of the Detroit River Riverbank Book Service www.detroitriver.org with profits used for local community conservation education projects.

Mary Elizabeth Savage, Louisa St. Clair Chapter Librarian (at left), is shown presenting the book, The Constitution for Kids, by Cathy Travis, to GPA media specialist Karen French.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Louisa St. Clair Chapter Daughters of the American Revolution of Grosse Pointe www.LSCDAR.com presented the book, The Constitution for Kids by Cathy Travis to the Grosse Pointe Academy school library.

item.title: Moments from Dad's Day
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Many dads and special guests experienced a morning in the life of a GPA student - and it was busy! Whether challenging their intellect at chess or classroom games, testing their creativity drawing a picture, writing in a journal or building a model, getting a workout with a parachute in gym class, or simply enjoying a snack or a good book, GPA dads made the most of some precious moments with their children - and maybe gained a little more appreciation for all that their children do, learn and experience in a given day.

item.title: GPA Recognizes Top Continental Math League Scorers
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to this year's Continental Math League (CML) winners! The top scorers in each grade were recognized during a grade 1-8 Chapel assembly on Monday, April 6. The winners are (from left) second grader Margaux Schaller, third grader Elizabeth Sheeren, fourth grader David Scupholm, fifth graders Jack Sheeren and Alexander Minanov, sixth grader Jonathan Valente, seventh grader Joe DiMauro, and eighth grader Jeffrey Woolstrum.

Jack Sheeren and Alexander Minanov both had perfect scores and their names will join eighth grader Dylan Demkowicz's on a special plaque that recognizes all GPA students who received perfect scores. David Scupholm recorded his second consecutive win, while Jeffrey Woolstrum has been the top scoring student for his grade for the last three years.

The Continental Math League is a nationally sponsored mathematical competition. Students are challenged to solve six difficult problems in thirty minutes. Each correct answer is worth one point. The problems are designed to encourage students to use a variety of problem solving techniques in the areas of mathematical and visual problem solving. This was the fourth year at the Academy that students in grades 2-8 participated in the Continental Math League competition. Grades 2 and 3 have three meets while grades 4-8 have five meets. The top six scores at each grade are sent in to the CML headquarters in New Jersey.

“The world of math is changing,” said grade 4/5 teacher Wendy Demartini, who, as Curriculum Coordinator, brought the CML competition to the Academy several years ago. “It used to be that rote repetition of math facts was considered to be the goal of math instruction. In today’s world, math instruction focuses on understanding concepts and then applying those concepts to solving real world problems.”
item.excerpt:encoded: Congratulations to this year's Continental Math League (CML) winners! The top scorers in each grade were recognized during a grade 1-8 Chapel assembly on Monday, April 6.

item.title: Third Graders Welcome Churchill Expert
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Last week several Academy students were featured in the Streetwise Section of the Grosse Pointe News, where they were asked who they would most like to meet. Third grader Joseph Spica responded that he would most like to meet Winston Churchill. (Churchill was also the famous person in history whom Joseph chose for his third grade social studies research project.)

A gentleman named Jim Rauh, who is a member of the Winston Churchill Society, read Joseph's remark. Mr. Rauh then contacted the Grosse Pointe News, who contacted GPA, who then contacted Joseph's teacher, Mrs. Wolney, to arrange a special visit.

As a result, all of the children enjoyed a visit from Mr. Rauh, who regaled them with many stories about Winston Churchill. He also presented Joseph with an autographed book entitled Churchill that was written and signed by Churchill's granddaughter, Celia Sandys.

Mary Alice Mecke, mother of kindergartner Courtney and sixth grader McCalla, has paid regular visits to Mrs. Varty's classroom over the years to share her knowledge of the Japanese culture. Last week, Cherine Smith, mother of kindergartener Zakariya, visited Mrs. Carrier's classroom to teach the children about Egypt. item.title: Students Participate in China Quiz Bowl
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday, April 25, Academy seventh and eighth graders headed to Madonna University in Livonia to participate in the first Michigan China Quiz Bowl. As GPA is one of the only middle schools in the area to offer Chinese, our students competed with second and third year high school students from Cranbrook, the University of Detroit Jesuit and Troy High School. The quiz bowl consisted of three regulation rounds and a championship round.



“Our students did a wonderful job under great pressure,” reported Chinese teacher Lucia Crane. In fact, one of the eighth grade teams advanced to the finals, where they lost to Troy, which has offered Chinese for eleven years, in a tie-breaker. GPA came home with a second place trophy in Division IA, and a second place trophy in Division II.

item.title: Sixth Graders Rule the School
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Hear ye! Hear ye! While the fourth and fifth graders traveled to Mackinac Island for their Michigan trip, and the seventh graders headed to Storer Camps for some class bonding and the eighth grade to Cleveland for their end-of-the-year hurrah, let us hereby declare the sixth graders rulers of the school for their study of the Middle Ages! This social studies unit officially culminated, by order of the king, with the annual sixth grade medieval feast on Friday morning.

The event began with the grand entrance of the king, accompanied by squires and a priest. Queried the king: “Priest Omar! Have these squires spent the night in chapel praying for their souls?”

The priest responded: “Yes, Your Majesty.” The king then turned to the squires. “Have you, Squires, prayed to God asking for protection of your soul and to follow the Code of Chivalry

”Yes we have,” responded the squires.

"Do you promise to be brave in battle, honorable to your Lord and Liege, redress any wrong, protect women and children, help those in trouble, show mercy to the weak and defenseless, so help you God?”

“Yes we do!” trumpeted the squires.

During the feast, students were divided into manor groups with a lord or lady as the head of the manor. They competed for farthings, and the manor with the most farthings was granted the head table. Those who sat below the salt were seated according to their rank.

King William (Middle School principal Scott Tily) greeted the guests as they entered the “manor on the lake” – the Academy’s Lakeshore building – then conducted a knighting ceremony. The students played the roles of knights, monks, priests, lords and ladies of the land, and pages. They also provided entertainment as jugglers, jesters, dancers, magicians and musicians. There was even a duel! Several “serving wenches” (i.e., mothers of the sixth graders dressed in costume) prepared and served the food. The meal was presented in three courses: “first serve” was a bread bowl of soup; “second serve” consisted of chicken legs, saffron rice, carrots, and mead (apple cider); and “third serve” (dessert) was ginger cookies and pears. After each course was announced, two food tasters sampled the food to make sure it wasn’t poisoned. Judgments were announced for evil deeds, with the priest begging for mercy for the evildoer. The folks in the gallery decided whether that person should be freed or sent to the dungeon.

Contributing to the ambiance of the banquet were family crests and banners that the students created. Throughout the afternoon, students from other grade levels stopped in to observe the festivities.

Thursday of Medieval Week was "Monk Day." The students experienced the monastic life of the middle ages as they meditated in the Chapel, ate only bread and water, and slept in cells with only a single sheet of newspaper for a blanket. Any monks who broke the code of silence had to wear a hair shirt in penance.

The students were given a respite from their study of the Middle Ages on Thursday afternoon when they enjoyed a Poetry Cafe. While each student read from his or her poetry journal (a selection of free verse, limericks, haiku, acrostics and many others), classmates lounged on pillows and ate snacks while snapping their fingers to demonstrate their approval of their peers' work.

Special thanks go to Harriett Whitaker and Mary Jo Johnson for all their work in coordinating these events and to all the parent volunteers, in particular Mary Alice Mecke, who helped with costume fittings and who provided snacks and drinks for the Poetry Cafe and prepared and served food for the banquet.

While the fourth and fifth graders traveled to Mackinac Island for their Michigan trip, and the seventh graders headed to Storer Camps for some class bonding and the eighth grade to Cleveland for their end-of-the-year hurrah, let us hereby declare the sixth graders rulers of the school for their study of the Middle Ages! This social studies unit officially culminated, by order of the king, with the annual sixth grade medieval feast on Friday morning.

item.title: Lieutenant Colonel Homsy Visits in Honor of Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
In honor of Memorial Day, Lieutenant Colonel Sam Homsy visited his son Matt's sixth grade social studies class to talk about what it means to be in the Army.

Tying in what the students had studied about the American government, he was able to convey to the students a sense of what it means to be in the Army and to share some glimpses of his 22 years of experiences all over the world, most recently in Iraq and Afghanistan. With his prompting, the students came up with the following reasons why a nation needs a military: to keep us safe, to make a point, to stand up for what we believe in, to protect other countries, and to make the world a better place.

Lieutenant Colonel Homsy plans to return in early June to talk with his daughter Hannah's fifth grade class. His son, Ian, is a third grader in Mrs. Stepanek's class.
item.excerpt:encoded: In honor of Memorial Day, Lieutenant Colonel Sam Homsy visited his son Matt's sixth grade social studies class to talk about what it means to be in the Army.

item.title: Understanding Giftedness
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: What does giftedness look like and how is it different from being very smart? Why do gifted students need special academic programs? Dr. Cheryl Blau, Giftedness Programming Coordinator and a teacher at The Grosse Pointe Academy, will address these questions and more on Thursday morning, August 20 at 10 a.m. and again on Thursday evening, August 27, at 7 p.m. Both talks will be held in the parlor of the Lake Shore Building on The Grosse Pointe Academy campus, 171 Lake Shore Road, are open to the public, and are free. item.title: CRAZY BUSY: Speaker Offers Advice to Parents on How to Stay Sane in a World Gone Crazy
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Is your child running from one activity to the next? Are you juggling school, sports, extracurricular activities, homework, volunteering and friends? Come hear this year’s McMillan speaker at The Grosse Pointe Academy on Tuesday, October 6 at 7 p.m.  Nationally known speaker Dr. Edward M. Hallowell will offer groundbreaking advice on how to survive in a competitive, ultra fast, attention deficit society while remaining sane. A child and adult psychiatrist and author of fourteen books, Dr. Hallowell has been featured in the media including 20/20, Oprah, CNN, PBS, the Today Show, Dateline and Good Morning America.

 

The lecture is free to the public and will be held in the Tracy Fieldhouse at 171 Lake Shore Road in Grosse Pointe Farms.

 

There will be a question and answer session and book signing following the presentation. Refreshments will be served. For more information, please call 313-886-1221.

 

The William Charles McMillan III Lecture Series is a gift from Thayer and Gioconda McMillan given in memory of William in the interest of emphasizing the importance of elementary education.

item.title: Buddy Trip to Apple Orchard
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
First graders headed to Big Red's Apple Orchard on Friday morning with their eighth grade buddies. This annual field trip has become an Academy tradition and a favorite among first graders and eighth graders alike. The first of many activities the first graders will enjoy with their eighth grade buddies, it provides a great way for the students to spend a day together and get to know one another.

Accompanied by first grade teachers Barbara Karle and Renee Martin and eighth grade homeroom advisors Marion Chrisner, Lawrence DeLuca and Michelle Roberts, the students headed out bright and early to the apple orchard. First on the agenda was apple picking, followed by a hayride. After enjoying a snack of cider and donuts, the students went to the petting farm where they saw emus, llamas, cows, pigs, goats, sheep, chickens, turkeys and rabbits. They also enjoyed climbing on a hay stack pyramid.

On Monday, the first graders will make apple sauce from the apples they picked and will create a digital story about their day.

item.title: History Comes as a Surprise to GPA Students
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy students in grades 1-8 enjoyed a special surprise on Friday, October 2 courtesy of Academy alumni. At 1:15 p.m., Head of School Phil Demartini rang a bell up and down the hallways to announce a surprise known as a Congé - a tradition dating back to the Academy of the Sacred Heart days when the ringing of the bell signaled a surprise dismissal from classes. Many students may recall the Congé from four years ago when the school last celebrated its Alumni History Day, but for others it was brand new.

The students, faculty and staff congregated in the Tracy Fieldhouse for a special presentation of a "Then and Now" PowerPoint and comments from Mrs. Walter B. Robinson, ASH alumna, past parent and GPA founding trustee, who helped kick off the event along with fellow founding trustee Mrs. Carole Peabody, ASH '51 and Sr. Gail O'Donnell, ASH alumna and former ASH headmistress who was one of the nuns instrumental in the transition between ASH and The Grosse Pointe Academy. These special guests, who each played an instrumental role in keeping the school alive forty years ago, shared brief remarks with the students about their own memories of a Congé. Also present were Roselie Posselius '73, President of the GPA Alumni Association and past parent (Giovanna Posselius '09), and Mary Alice Mecke '74, current parent (Courtney Mecke, grade 1 and McCalla Mecke, grade 7) and chair of GPA's 40th Anniversary Celebration. Both Roselie and Mary Alice were students forty years ago when the school re-opened as The Grosse Pointe Academy.

The presentation in the Tracy Fieldhouse concluded with the singing of a traditional song, Donne, Donne-Nous un Beau Jour ("Give Us a Beautiful Day") and a special recognition of Marion Chrisner for forty years of musical excellence at The Grosse Pointe Academy. Marion, now in her 41st year, is the only teacher remaining who was on staff forty years ago.

The students then broke into assigned teams with group leaders for a scavenger hunt.  Students were given clues such as "I'm a larger room facing the lake / Visitors often will find cookies and cake / Come my way, and discover the past / It's an adventure guaranteed to be a blast!" (You guessed it - the Lakeshore Parlor.) Students would then go to that particular location where they were greeted by a parent, alumni volunteer or faculty member who would talk about the site and provide historical anecdotes. (Unfortunately, due to the inclement weather, all stations had to be moved indoors.)

The afternoon concluded with another ASH tradition - goutér, or snack. Ask your child to tell you about the special surprise and share the handout they were given on the history of the school!
