item.title: Meet Our New Teachers!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Kate Baudeloque is a familiar face at the Academy, in particular to Action Auction parent volunteers. She has helped out with the Auction on and off for over ten years. However, two years ago she came on board as a steady presence during the Auction busy season, and this fall she joined the teaching staff as the K-1 art teacher. (Rosi Triano, who previously taught K-5 art, is now teaching Grades 2-8).

It is a natural fit for Kate, who has a degree from the Center for Creative Studies in graphic design, with a minor in art therapy.

“The transition to teaching has been a pleasant surprise,” Kate admits, due, in large part, to the “incredible support” she has received from the faculty, in particular Rosi. Kate also enjoys her interactions with the students. “I love coming here, seeing the kids, starting a new project with them, witnessing their ideas and what each child has brought to the project. No two are ever the same.”

The K-1 art curriculum has included working with primary colors, using different line construction, creating 3-D paper collages, paper weaving, and studying the Lascaux cave drawings and Alexander Calder mobiles. Many projects are on display in the Early School, first grade wing and Valade Art Loft & Gallery.

Kate’s favorite part of the job? “I enjoy observing the process with the children, seeing it go from concept to final product. That is probably the most rewarding part of an art teacher’s day.”

New Spanish teacher Sarah Brown, a graduate of Notre Dame who received her Master’s degree from the University of Pennsylvania, has dedicated her nine-year teaching career to working primarily in an urban public school environment. Coming to The Grosse Pointe Academy has, therefore, been a big transition for her. The biggest difference, in her observation, is the class size.

“I really like the small class sizes,” says Sarah. “They enable me to do so many things I wasn’t able to do in my previous teaching situations.”

For example, when she taught Spanish for four years at a public high school in Seattle, she was responsible for five classes a day, with 30 students per class.

“With 30 students in a class you have 30 different learning styles. We practiced inclusion, so there were students at all different levels. The small class sizes at the Academy are amazing. I feel like I really get to personalize instruction for each student.”

Her class sizes vary, from three in her seventh grade class to 15 in her beginning Spanish class for grade 5.

“I really enjoy teaching the beginners,” Sarah says. “ I feel I can provide them with a foundation that they will carry with them for the rest of their language experience. The beginners are like sponges. They are so eager to learn!”

After graduating from Central Michigan University in 2007, 4/5 teacher Trevor Clor completed his student teaching in a fifth grade classroom in Grosse Pointe. He also did some long-term substitute teaching in Grosse Pointe, and last year taught sixth grade at a charter school in Hamtramck.

When comparing his last year of teaching to his first few months at The Grosse Pointe Academy, however, the differences are too numerous to count. The most important differences to Trevor, however, are the amount of parent involvement he enjoys, student motivation he observes, and administration and faculty support he receives at The Grosse Pointe Academy versus his experiences at the charter school.

“I love teaching here,” says Trevor. “The atmosphere is great, the staff are friendly and helpful, and the parents are more than willing to help in any way they can. And the students are courteous, eager to learn and enthusiastic. You also can’t beat the grounds! The last few days I watched the sun rise over the lake as I drove to school. It was so beautiful, I almost wished my drive to work took longer.”

In addition to his fourth grade class, Trevor teaches 4/5 science along with Bob Lapadot. In a current unit on force and motion, the students built connect cars. They will also be studying electricity and measurement.
item.excerpt:encoded: Joining the faculty this fall are Kate Baudeloque, Sarah Brown and Trevor Clor. Kate, a familiar face in the Auction Office, has expanded her role as a K-1 art teacher. Sarah is teaching Grades 4-8 Spanish, and Trevor has joined the 4/5 staff teaching grade 4 and 4/5 science.

item.title: Sixth Graders Present Comparative Lit Workshops
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the past several weeks in their language arts classes, GPA sixth grade students, together with Mrs. Whitaker and Dr. Blau, have studied myths, legends, folktales, fables, and fairytales from around the world. Students have read selections from each of these genres and have discussed at length the similarities and differences they have discovered within each genre as well as across various genres, time periods, and cultures. The roles of men and women in medieval times as portrayed in fairytales, the key elements of any hero's journey, and the qualities characteristic of heroes were among the topics explored in depth.

Following this in-depth study, each sixth grader was invited to select a subtopic within one of these genres to research so as to become a "specialist" on his or her specific, self-chosen topic. After an additional week of focused research, each student created a 10-minute workshop for presentation to the fourth and fifth grade students. Last Friday, October 30, the fourth and fifth grade students received a brochure listing all student workshop topics along with brief descriptions of each one. They were each allowed to select five workshops they would most like to attend. After careful planning and much cooperation from fourth, fifth, and sixth grade teachers alike, the sixth graders held their workshops on Wednesday, November 3 from 9:15 - 9:55 in the Tracy Fieldhouse. There were three sessions with multiple presentations of each workshop by the sixth graders so that the fourth and fifth graders were able to attend a total of three workshops of their choice.

Says Dr. Blau of the project: "The teachers and students alike were so impressed with the wide variety of topics, level of detailed knowledge, and creative presentation techniques that the sixth graders implemented when sharing what they had learned with the fourth and fifth graders."

item.title: Alum Shares Her Life as a Diplomat
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
“If you are good at a lot of subjects in school but don’t know how to choose just one, then a career in foreign service might be just the thing for you.” These were words of advice from Grosse Pointe Academy 1991 graduate Kate Van Til Rebholz, who spoke on November 9 to fourth through eighth grade students during their Monday morning assembly.

Kate, a 1999 graduate of Amherst College who majored in anthropology, decided to pursue a career in diplomacy after traveling through Europe on a Watson Fellowship. She was awarded the fellowship after graduating from Amherst and was given a year to do an independent study of her choosing abroad. Her study was on Neolithic remains (i.e., remains from the cultural period of the Stone Age beginning around 10,000 B.C. in the Middle East and later elsewhere, characterized by the development of agriculture and the making of polished stone implements). She discovered in her travels that she was far more interested in the people she met and the cultures she discovered than she was in looking at large rocks.

Kate started the process of applying for a job with the State Department while she was getting her M.B.A. at the University of Michigan Business School. After passing the foreign service test, completing the oral exam process, and undergoing extensive background checks (“They needed to make sure I was fit to represent the U.S.,” Kate explains), she was ultimately offered a job. Her first assignment was in India, where she met her husband, Jason, a foreign service officer on his second assignment after previously serving in South Korea.

After a two-year post, Kate and her husband were assigned to Indonesia, and the couple currently resides in Jakarta. Before beginning her assignment Kate underwent intense language training to become fluent in Indonesian. (Intense language training involves five days a week of nine-hour classes and an additional three hours of homework or lab for nine months.) Kate, who, by her own admission, is “an average language learner,” may ultimately learn as many as three languages over the course of her career.

In speaking with the Academy students, Kate emphasized how exciting her job is, with every day bringing new challenges, be it writing a speech for the Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton, or figuring out how to get a monkey out of her apartment. She is currently expecting her first child and is home in Grosse Pointe for the duration of her pregnancy before returning to Jakarta. Living overseas is “a fabulous cultural experience” that she and Jason hope to share with their children.

Kate enjoyed the opportunity to visit the Academy, meet with the students (in addition to her morning presentation, she spoke with eighth grade social studies classes), and catch up with former teachers. When reflecting on her days as an Academy student, she recalls music classes with Marion Chrisner and the Academy Adventures trips with Michael Fultz with particular fondness. Perhaps it was the summer camping trips that sparked some of her adventurous spirit! “The summer trips provided such a great opportunity to experience the natural world,” she says. She also had math with Scott Tily.

“I am really glad to have the opportunity to come back to the Academy and share my experiences," Kate says. "You don’t realize growing up that the world is as big as it is, and I hope to open the students’ eyes to that.” Kate also hopes to plant a seed in the minds of possible future diplomats. “This is finally a recruiting effort,” she admits. “I would love to have smart Academy students grow up and do diplomacy abroad someday. It really is a rewarding career.”

item.title: Third Graders Embark on Historical Tour
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday, November 12, the Academy third grade embarked on a historical walk that covered approximately 6,000 years, beginning when Native Americans came into this region from the Northeast. This tour, which is part of the students' social studies curriculum and includes a map skills unit, highlighted 15 points of interest, including the Nun's Walk, Grant's Castle, Joy Estate, Old Brook Lane, the Provencal-Weir House, and old farm houses and summer homes. The students learned about the establishment of Michigan as a state, the Native American tribes, ribbon farming, the heritage of The Grosse Pointe Academy, and business development of the Grosse Pointes.


The tour concluded at St. Paul's Cemetery, where parent Laura Jamieson, accompanied by an actor, “Mr. Renaud,” took the children to different headstones to discuss Grosse Pointe and family development in this area. The children made rubbings of some artwork on the headstones. These and their stories from the day are displayed in the hallway, and the experience will be captured on a DVD, complete with photos, video and voiceover, for the enjoyment of third grade parents.

item.title: These Little First Graders Go to Market
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy first graders were treated to an insider's view of Westborn Market on Wednesday. Mr. Anthony Anusbigian, a parent and owner of the Westborn Market, welcomed the classes for their personal visit. The students toured every department, from Michigan produce to the florist, bakery, meats, sushi, fish and seafood, dairy, breads and cheese.

When the tour was over the first graders enjoyed cupcakes that were made in the shape of a large colorful turkey and cider. All the children and teachers received a Westborn Market sweatshirt with the GPA logo on the sleeve.

"This was a perfect trip for our occupation unit!" said first grade teacher Barbara Karle. "A huge thank you goes to the Anusbigian family for making it possible."

item.title: 4/5 Students Create Native American Museums
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Fourth and fifth grade students, as part of their study on Native Americans in social studies class, created Native American Museums that were on display in the Fisher Library. Divided into groups of two or three, the students selected Native American tribes from a hat which they then researched. From their research they created artifacts on their tribe's culture, such as how they lived, what they ate, what their houses were made of, what kinds of things they made by hand.

Fourth graders Karina Minanov and Elizabeth Sheeren, for example, researched the Maidu tribe of California. They discovered interesting facts such as they made their moccasins out of one piece of buckskin and would stuff them with grass for warmth, that they lived in different types of houses depending on the season, and that one of these house types was built at least three feet into the ground. For their museum they made a cradle basket, moccassins, a woven basket, an earth lodge, and samples of foods that the Maidu Indians would eat, such as acorn, seeds, roots, rabbit, deer and fish.

item.title: Students Enjoy Thrilling Performance
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Sixth and seventh grade students have been working on Michael Jackson's "Thriller" choreography during music class for the past few weeks, and on Friday they had the opportunity to perform in front of an audience. After this visual treat, music teacher Marion Chrisner asked audience members to close their eyes for the next number. The seventh graders, directed by Jack Weaver, choreographed the sounds of a rainstorm, beginning with a soft sprinkle, escalating into a downpour, and then trickling to a close with intermittent raindrops. Those who peeked during the performance witnessed that this was all achieved through the simple use of clapping, rubbing hands together, drumming on knees - all, according to Mrs. Chrisner, a result of their own imagination, creativity and ingenuity. The performance ended to "thunderous" applause.
item.excerpt:encoded: Sixth and seventh grade students have been working on Michael Jackson's "Thriller" choreography during music class for the past few weeks, and on Friday they had the opportunity to perform in front of an audience.

item.title: GPA Shows School Spirit at Santa Parade
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the second consecutive year, The Grosse Pointe Academy participated in the Grosse Pointe Santa Claus Parade the day after Thanksgiving. GPA had a strong showing this year, with nearly 40 students and over a dozen parents marching. Taking part in the parade were Head of School Phil Demartini and Early and Lower School Principal Jen Kendall. Carrying the school banner, wearing Academy blue Santa hats, chanting "GPA!", and accompanied by the school mascot, the Bulldog, the Academy contingent demonstrated a lot of energy and school spirit to onlookers.

 

"Next year maybe we'll have an even bigger representation from our students," said Phil Demartini. "Our participation and support of this event definitely makes a strong statement to the community."

item.title: Students and Parents Participate in Book Discussion
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
“Has anyone here ever felt like a loser?” asked Sean Hogan-Downey, LMSW, LMFT.

Hands went up around the room. Present were 4/5 students and their parents. They were participating in a book group discussion facilitated by Sean, who is a licensed master social worker and a licensed marriage and family therapist as well as the Academy’s school counselor and staff consultant.

The book being discussed was Loser, by Jerry Spinelli. Parents read the books with their children and attended a book discussion on Thursday, December 10. The central theme of the book involved social issues surrounding friendship. The protagonist, Zinkoff, was perceived by his peers as a “loser” because, according to one student, “He wasn’t the best at anything so he wasn’t seen as important as someone who was the best at something.”

“But didn’t he try really hard?” countered Sean. “And he wasn’t a quitter.”

Sean cited her favorite line in the book as follows: “Big-kid eyes replace little-kid eyes. “You need big eyes to see the meaning behind things,” explained Sean. “With big eyes you notice more. You ask more questions. You become more critical and judgmental.”

The students talked about what they learned from the book and from Zinkoff. They also discussed what they would want to do differently as a result of reading the book.

“I can be happy when things are tough,” said one student.

“Even if the person is kind of different, I should still be nice to them because they could turn out to be a really nice person,” said another.

“I would be more open to people because Zinkoff was open to people,” said another.

Sean’s closing advice to students was as follows: “The next time you meet a person who is different, just think of Zinkoff. I think it might help.”

item.title: Giving the Gift of Books
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Julie Sheeren and her daughter, fourth grader Elizabeth, delivered books on Wednesday, December 8 to George Crocket Academy, a K-8 school in West Detroit. The books were donated in support of a project initiated by the students in Trevor Clor's class as a way to encourage the love of reading with those who are less fortunate.

Explains Julie: "Many of the students at George Crocket do not have books of their own at home, so our kids decided to donate a new or gently used book that they personally enjoyed." The children then made book marks, with statements like "I loved this book because it is an adventure" or "Enjoy this book! My favorite part was..." All of the 4/5 classes participated in the book collection and over 80 books with bookmarks were collected. In addition, four large bags of beautiful picture books and readers were donated by GPA families along with nine large boxes of non-fiction books from the GPA library. "Needless to say, our minivan was full!" said Julie.

Fifth grade teacher Ms. Dasaro told Julie that many teachers do not have adequate classroom libraries, so these books will be helpful to add directly to the classrooms. Her fifth grade boys helped to carry the books to their second floor classroom, and Elizabeth had a chance to meet the students and field some questions about her school and community.

Says Julie: "The students could not believe that other children gave their own books and the bookmark, too. They were truly moved by the love and generosity."

The books were donated by in support of a project initiated by the students in Trevor Clor's class as a way to encourage the love of reading with those who are less fortunate.

item.title: Sixth Grader Wins GPA Geography Bee
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Isabella Gierlinger, a sixth grade student at The Grosse Pointe Academy, won the school-level competition of the National Geographic Bee and a chance at a $25,000 college scholarship. Sixth grader Alexander Minanov was the runner-up. The school-level Bee, at which students answered oral questions on geography, was the first round in the 22nd annual National Geographic Bee. The Bee is sponsored by the National Geographic Society.



Thousands of schools around the United States and in the five U.S. territories participate each year in the National Geographic Bee. Academy Middle School students qualified for the Bee by taking a written test. In addition to Isabella and Alexander, the following finalists competed in the final round on December 18 by answering oral questions: eighth graders Karstan Minanov, Allison Mobley and Sheridan Reilly; seventh graders Nikolas Minanov, Jack Weaver and Sam Williams; and sixth graders Leonie Leslie and Jack Sheeren. Isabella and Alexander went on to the championship round.

The school winners, including Isabella, will take another written test; up to 100 of the top scorers in each state will be eligible to compete in their state Bee in on April 9, 2010.

The National Geographic Society will provide an all-expenses-paid trip to Washington, D.C. for state champions and teacher-escorts to participate in the National Geographic Bee national championship rounds on May 25 and 26, 2010. The first-place national winner will receive a $25,000 college scholarship, a lifetime membership in the Society, and a trip to the Galapagos Islands, courtesy of Lindblad Expeditions and National Geographic.

"Jeopardy!" host Alex Trebek will moderate the national finals on May 26. The program will air on television. Check local listings for dates and times.

Anyone can test their geography knowledge with GeoBee Challenge, an online geography quiz at www.nationalgeographic.com/geobee, which poses 10 new questions a day.
item.excerpt:encoded: Isabella Gierlinger, a sixth grade student at The Grosse Pointe Academy, won the school-level competition of the National Geographic Bee and a chance at a $25,000 college scholarship. Sixth grader Alexander Minanov was the runner-up.

item.title: GPA Names Athletes of the Fall Season
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Eighth graders (from left) Wade Penman, Kara French, Kate Krueger and Gordon Fisher were named Athletes of the Season for the fall of 2009. Each was chosen for this honor based on his or her athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship.


Wade was co-captain of the boys’ varsity soccer team and was the co-recipient of the most valuable defensive player award. He is a scholar athlete, received high academic honors, and is a member of the National Junior Honor Society. He is also vice president of the Student Council.

Kara, a second-year player and co-captain on the undefeated varsity volleyball team (29-0), was named best spiker with 195 spikes (a new all-time record) and co-best passer with 279 passes to the setter, also a new school record. She also had the most kills at 29. A scholar athlete with perfect attendance, she received high academic honors, is on the citizenship and head of school list, and is a member of the National Junior Honor Society.

Kate too was a second-year player on the undefeated varsity squad and co-captain of the team. She was named best server with 388 points served (a school record). She also had the most aces (37) and the highest spiking percent at 96.59%. She was named co-best passer and co-best setter and received an award for perfect attendance. A scholar athlete, she received academic honors, is on the citizenship and head of school list, and is a member of the National Junior Honor Society.

Gordon was the team co-captain and MVP of the Academy’s tennis team. He played #1 singles and had a winning record of 10-3. A scholar athlete, he received high academic honors and is on the citizenship and head of school list. He is also a member of the National Junior Honor Society.

item.title: Celebrating the Life of Martin Luther King, Jr.
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Students gathered in the Tracy Fieldhouse with their buddies on Friday morning for an all-school assembly celebrating the life of Martin Luther King, Jr.  Early and Lower School Principal Jen Kendall read a children's story called 'The Other Side," by Jacqueline Woodson, about two little girls who made a difference in the world by not letting a fence stand in their way. Students then got together with their buddies to draw a picture depicting what they would do to make a difference. After the buddy project, all gathered again to watch a 1963 newsreel on the Big March on Washington and to sing the battle hymn of the civil rights movement, "We Shall Overcome."

In the afternoon, Grades 4-8 reconvened in the Tracy Fieldhouse to watch Dr. King's "I Have a Dream" speech in its entirety.

item.title: Loose Change Campaign for Haiti a Success!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Students at The Grosse Pointe Academy were challenged to help with the relief efforts in the aftermath of the earthquake in Haiti by bringing in loose change to fill jars placed in every classroom. The final tally of the amount collected has not yet taken place, but students and faculty have rallied to the challenge, and all the money collected by the end of the week will be donated to the Red Cross.

Faculty and staff members enjoyed a "jeans day" in exchange for a $5 contribution, and students have been showing up at school all week with loose change jingling in their pockets. Homeroom advisors Wendy Jerome and Sasha Murphy issued a special challenge to seventh graders: If the students filled three jars with loose change in 48 hours, Mrs. Jerome and Mrs. Murphy would either clean lunch tables in the cafeteria for a week, or wear the school uniform, based on a majority vote.



The seventh graders not only met the challenge, they exceeded it, according to Middle School Principal Scott Tily. They managed to fill five jars. “Community service is a vital part of our program here at the Academy,” said Scott. “This is just one more example of our students stepping up to help others.”

The question remains, however: now that the students have met their challenge, will Mrs. Murphy and Mrs. Jerome be cleaning lunch tables next week, or donning the school uniform?

The final tally of the amount collected has not yet taken place, but students and faculty have rallied to the challenge, and all the money collected by the end of the week will be donated to the Red Cross.

item.title: Bee Spells Success for Sixth Grader
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Sixth grader Jack Sheeren was this year’s school spelling bee winner after battling it out many rounds with fellow competitors in grades 4-8. Mya Vogel, a fourth grader, became one of the school’s youngest runners-up. This was Jack's second consecutive win; two years ago, in his debut performance as a fourth grader, he made it to the final three.

Congratulations go to all the top spellers in their grades who qualified for the bee based on a preliminary qualifying test. The other finalists in addition to Jack and Mya were fourth graders Zoe Gierlinger and Karina Minanov, fifth graders Katie Fruehauf, Hailey McDonald and David Scupholm, sixth graders Jared Demkowicz, Isabella Gierlinger and Alexander Minanov, seventh graders Andrew Almasy, Charles Becker and Joseph Cavataio, and eighth graders Derek Demkowicz, Karstan Minanov, and Jennifer Vermet.

Jack will go on to compete at The Detroit News Spelling Bee at the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History on Saturday, February 27.

item.title: First Graders Create Living Aquarium
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
This winter Grosse Pointe Academy first graders have been immersed in a cross-curricular study of sea life that incorporates language arts, science, art, music, French and Christian Life.



In art class with Kate Baudeloque, the students created large paper sea life puppets that they painted and stuffed. In French class with Madame Leslie, they listened to the story, The Little Mermaid, and learned the vocabulary for the most common animals that live in the ocean. In addition to creating a book that displays all the creatures they learned about, they expressed sentences with their newly developed vocabulary. In Christian Life with Mrs. Baetens, the children read the story, Jonah and the Whale.

To tie all of these pieces together, music teacher Roshell Chuhran selected “The Aquarium” from the French composer, Camille Saint-Saens, to create a living aquarium using the artwork the students created along with their French studies.

The culminating activity for this program was when the students presented their work for parents on Friday, February 19 in the Tracy Fieldhouse. The children introduced themselves and their sea creatures in French and performed a sea-inspired choreography.

item.title: Middle School Students Show Their Spirit
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Middle school students have a cure for the February blahs: it’s called Spirit Week. Students showed their school spirit by dressing up in silly outfits for Clash Day, PJ Day and Twin Day and participating in a variety of fun competitions, such as the obstacle course, trivia challenge and talent show. (Unfortunately, due to the school closing on Wednesday, students were forced to wear their pj's at home.) 

During Twin Day on Thursday, middle school male teachers dressed as Mike Fultz and female teachers dressed as Michelle Roberts. The culminating event was the teacher vs. student dodgeball challenge on Thursday evening. In spite of heavy recruiting efforts on the part of the teachers to bring in basketball coach Jesse Jamerson and ringers from the maintenance staff, the students prevailed in the ultimate fighting challenge.

item.title: Helping the Homeless
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Seventh graders at The Grosse Pointe Academy had the opportunity to find out what it feels like to help others. On Tuesday, February 23 and Wednesday, February 24, the students participated in St. Paul's program for the homeless by serving breakfast beginning at 6:15 a.m. They also had the opportunity to talk to the guests before breakfast was served. One student even performed an impromptu piano recital!

"This is a wonderful chance for the children to meet and care for individuals who are experiencing difficult times in their lives," said Christian Life teacher Ellen Krease. "Hopefully this experience will help them develop compassion as they learn to see 'the homeless' as real people just like themselves."

The students prepared for the experience in Christian Life class. They also reflected on it after the fact by writing journal entries.

item.title: A Visit Back in Time at the One Room Schoolhouse
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Fourth and fifth graders culminated their study of the American Colonial period with a visit to the Provencal-Weir House in Grosse Pointe Farms. The children dressed for the day in Colonial attire. Having made vests and bonnets in class, they then completed their costumes at home. The girls wore long skirts and shawls with their bonnets, and the boys wore knickers, long socks and caps with their vests.

The students participated in a number of activities that helped prepare them for their visit to the one-room schoolhouse. For example, in art class with Mrs. Triano, the students learned about colonial crafts and used their imaginations to create their own versions of these crafts. They made cornhusk people and designed clothing and accessories for them. They also learned about tin punching and how it was used for functional items such as lanterns and foot warmers. Finally, they worked with types of Colonial claywork such as red ware and sponge ware. They each made a plate out of the red terra cotta clay, creating their own stencils and sponging a design in the center of the plate. For the sponge ware, students studied pictures of sponge ware plates, bowls and pitchers. They rolled out white clay and used cookie cutters to create Christmas ornaments that they then decorated with a sponge dipped in blue or green.

In addition, in social studies class, each student chose one of the thirteen original colonies to research and examine using information books, maps, encyclopedias, the class text book, and Internet sites. From their notes on the facts they gathered, the students prepared a brief oral description for their classmates. Aspects of the presentation included family life, clothing, food, houses, entertainment (toys and games), and education. Their study of Colonial school life particularly prepared them for what to expect in the day of a life of a student during Colonial times.

"One thing the children particularly looked forward to was experiencing the type of discipline teachers used back in those days," said 4/5 social studies teacher Marsha Thomas. "We taught them how strict teachers were in the one room schoolhouse. The rules were well known to everyone and enforcement of the rules was fair and firm." These forms of discipline included critizing a student, whipping with a hickory stick, or having the student sit on the dunce chair wearing a dunce hat.

Teachers and students alike enjoyed the role playing! Activities at the one-room school house included performing tongue twisters, participating in a spelling bee, reciting memory verses, doing arithmetic, practicing their penmanship, eating lunch, and playing games at recess.

The children dressed for the day in Colonial attire. Having made vests (for the boys) and bonnets (for the girls) in class, they then completed their costumes at home.

item.title: Happy Birthday Dr. Seuss!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Children in the Early School celebrated the March 2 birthday of Theodor Seuss Geisel, better known to the world as the beloved Dr. Seuss, in a number of ways. In a tradition she has been carrying on for many years, Mrs. Beth made green eggs and ham for her students, many of whom declared during their breakfast: "Say! I like green eggs and ham!"

 

Three-year-olds in Mrs. Kate's "Three Plus" (extended day) class also enjoyed a special celebration in honor of Dr. Seuss. The children donned their Cat and the Hat top hats and red bows and ate strawberries  and chocolate cupcakes with red and white frosting. "How old would Dr. Seuss be today?" Mrs. Kate asked the students. "One hundred and six!" replied one math whiz in the class. The students also named their favorite Dr. Seuss books and other facts they learned about the popular children's author, including the fact that his high school art teacher didn't like his drawings!

item.title: 4/5 Students Discover Scientific Method
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy fourth and fifth graders participated in the sixth annual Science Fair this winter, the culmination of which was a parent evening on Wednesday, March 10 during which attendees had the opportunity to view all the display boards in the library while the young scientists were on hand to explain their methods and procedures.

Grade 4/5 teachers Trevor Clor and Bob Lapadot led the project during science classes. They began by teaching the scientific method (stating the problem, forming a hypothesis, listing the materials and procedures, recording observations, and forming a conclusion). Working under the guidance of their teachers, students conducted some of the work for their projects in class and the remainder at home to meet specific deadlines throughout the process.

Fifth grade projects were entered into a competition, with middle school science teachers serving as judges. Special certificates of recognition were awarded to the top four fifth grade projects.

Congratulations go to winning scientists David Scupholm, Bridget Donaldson, Emma Andreasen and Markus Minanov. In "SuperBall Air Cannon," David addressed the question of how angle affects trajectory. He discovered that the lower the angle of trajectory, the farther a superball will launch. Bridget, in an effort to determine whether gas can be generated from waste, looked into which waste source releases the most natural gas: cow manure, cow manure and mashed bananas, or cow manure and vegetable peelings. Emma investigated whether a dog, cat or human has a cleaner mouth (the answer is that a cat's mouth has the most bacteria, and a dog's the least). Finally, Markus's burning question had to do whether the color of a candle's wax affects the rate at which it burns. He discovered that, in fact, the candles burned at the same rate regardless of color.

item.title: Vroom! Vroom! Seventh Graders Participate in Car Races
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
This March, seventh graders in Mrs. Jerome's physics class experienced a taste of the life of a car designer and a crash test dummy all at the same time when they participated in the 2010 Seventh Grade "Egg Crash" Race Car Competition.

The assignment was to design a car that could carry an egg down a ramp without the egg breaking. The criterion was that, with the exception of plastic wheels, the car was to be constructed entirely of paper.

The students conducted a series of time trials with their cars, first to determine the fastest car without an egg, and second to determine the fastest car that made it down the ramp with the egg still intact. There was also a design component to the assignment.

Awards were given out at the conclusion of the project for fastest car without the egg, fastest "crash test" egg car, and outstanding car design (as determined by an independent judge, art teacher Mrs. Triano). For the fastest car without an egg, the award went to McCalla Mecke. George Spica won the egg car crash contest, and Jared Brush received the award for outstanding car design.

The story picked up where the traditional Hans Christian Andersen fable leaves off: Hansel and Gretel have successfully done away with the wicked witch and are enjoying life in the gingerbread house. item.title: Famous People Come to Life at GPA
item.dc:creator: costellodg

Grosse Pointe Academy third graders stepped into the past this March to take a look at some famous figures as part of an ongoing research project. The students spent several weeks researching their chosen subjects. Dressing up in costume and delivering an oral report were the culminating activities of this popular social studies unit.

Walking the halls at GPA this week were, from Mrs. Wolney's class (pictured above with the models they made with their dads on Dads' Day): Harry Houdini (Danny Arkison), Neil Armstrong (Errington Belyue), Amelia Earhart (Stephanie Bloink), General Patton (Eben Bobby), Albert Einstein (Piero Cavataio), Charlemagne (Adrian Doan), General MacArthur (Henry Drettmann), Paul McCartney (Kaitlyn Fox), Abraham Lincoln (Adam Kuplicki), Sacagawea (Lily MacKrell), Milton Hersey (Henry Touscany), Leonardo da Vinci (Henry Whitaker), and Annie Oakley (Imani White). Not pictured is Susan B. Anthony (Margaux Schaller).

Visitors to Mrs. Stepanek's classroom would have caught sightings of the following famous people (pictured above): Eleanor Roosevelt (Elizabeth Acheson), Eleanor Ford (Elise Buhl), Albert Einstein (Isaac Cantin), Abraham Lincoln (Miles Engstrom), Harry Houdini (Patrick FitzSimons), Rosa Parks (Sydni Hall), Benjamin Franklin (Andrew Jamieson), Gordie Howe (Brandon Murphy), Cleopatra (Samantha Savage), Neil Armstrong (Thomas Wacker), and Ludwig van Beethoven (Blake Weaver).

item.title: GPA Named a Michigan Green School
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy is pleased to announce that it has been named a 2009-2010 Michigan Green School. In order to be accepted as a Michigan green school, the Academy had to submit a proposal that documented at least ten of 20 points of energy and environmental savings activities. These included the energy savings program achieved during the renovation of the main school building three years ago, the addition of a "GPA is Green" bulletin board outside the media center, our celebration of Earth Day starting at age 3 and continuing into lower school, the inclusion of an environmental unit in our middle school world languages curriculum, visits from guest speakers, such as the president of our local Audubon chapter, a sixth grade biology curriculum that centers on natural habitats and environments, an eighth grade science curriculum that has units covering alternative energy sources, nuclear energy, power plants and renewable energy, the adoption of endangered animals from The National Wildlife Federation, and our paper and battery recycling program.

item.title: GPA Announces CML Winners
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
During a Chapel assembly on Monday, May 3, The Grosse Pointe Academy recognized the second through eighth grade students who received the top scores in the Continental Math League competition.

The winners were Claire Sheeren (grade 2), Adrian Doan (grade 3), Ian Homsy (grade 4), David Scupholm (grade 5), Jack Sheeren and Alexander Minanov (grade 6), James Scott (grade 7), and Sheridan Reilly (grade 8).

The Continental Math League is a nationally sponsored mathematical competition. Students are challenged to solve six difficult problems in thirty minutes. Each correct answer is worth one point. The problems are designed to encourage students to use a variety of problem solving techniques in the areas of mathematical and visual problem solving.

This marks the fifth year that Academy students in grades 2-8 have participated in the Continental Math League competition. Grades 2 and 3 have three meets while grades 4-8 have five meets. The top six scores at each grade are sent in to the CML headquarters in New Jersey.

“The world of math is changing,” said grade 4/5 teacher Wendy Demartini, who brought the CML competition to the Academy several years ago. “It used to be that rote repetition of math facts was considered to be the goal of math instruction. In today’s world, math instruction focuses on understanding concepts and then applying those concepts to solving real world problems.”
item.excerpt:encoded: During a Chapel assembly on Monday, May 3, The Grosse Pointe Academy recognized the second through eighth grade students who received the top scores in the Continental Math League competition.

item.title: GPA Sweeps in China Quiz Bowl
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday, April 24, sixteen Academy middle school students, along with GPA Chinese teacher, Lucia Hu, headed to Madonna University in Livonia to participate in the second annual Michigan China Quiz Bowl, jointly sponsored by the Wayne State University Confucius Institute, the Confucius Institute and Center for Chinese Studies at the University of Michigan, and Madonna University.

Participating in the China Quiz Bowl were 43 teams from 13 schools. The five GPA teams competed in the middle school division, with four of the five teams advancing to the championship round and four teams bringing home first place trophies. The winning teams were made up of sixth graders Isabella Gierlinger, James Raudabaugh, Jack Sheeren and Evelyn Woodman (Division 1); seventh graders Joseph Cavataio, Matthew Homsy, R.J. McCarren and Michael Schaller (Division 2); and eighth graders Allison Mobley and Samantha Perry (Division 3). The two Academy eighth grade teams faced each other in the finals, with Mobley and Perry winning first place and Joe DiMauro and Robbie Triano taking home a second place trophy.

“The Michigan China Quiz Bowl is offered as an enjoyable incentive for students of Chinese language and culture to realize their accomplishments,” said John Brender, Director of the Wayne State University Confucius Institute. “Learning a foreign language – and especially Chinese – will bring many future rewards, but the initial thrill of putting together sentences and communicating in a foreign language is a milestone that we are extremely happy to acknowledge with this event.”

item.title: GPA Enjoys a Bit of Broadway
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
"Wouldn't it be loverly" if 42 sixth and seventh grade students could gather together for an evening's performance, each with a speaking part, each with a dancing part, each with a solo to sing? Had you been in the audience on Thursday evening for "A Bit of Broadway," you would "consider yourself" very lucky indeed and, in "reviewing the situation," might have concluded that director Marion Chrisner outdid herself in managing to pull off three plays in one evening - "My Fair Lady," "Oliver" and "Guys and Doll" (the missing "s" is intentional), adapting each in length and content to fit the particular cast of characters made of up GPA's sixth and seventh graders.

"In the middle school, it is especially important that kids develop a sense of self-worth and become more confident in their own abilities," explained Marion. "It is my personal philosophy that one of the ways that students can develop these attributes is by performing in front of others. Performing means trusting in others to support you and participate with you to create a worthy product."

item.title: GPA Celebrates Earth Week
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy, recently named a Michigan Green School, embarked on an especially ambitious celebration of Earth Day this year, expanding it into Earth Week 2010.

“This is a great opportunity for us to teach the students about what they can do to be green at home and here at school,” said Sasha Murphy, who spearheaded the school’s green program.

On Monday, April 19, every student and teacher was given an Earth Day sticker to wear. Grades 1-5 were given an on-line carbon footprint activity to complete followed by some “green” class discussions, and sixth through eighth graders were given the site to use in math class.

On Tuesday, teachers talked with their classes about how to conserve energy. “We asked the students to set a goal each day of the week as to what they would try to do,” explained Sasha. “Maybe they could turn lights off at home, or help their parents change light bulbs to CF bulbs. Maybe they could encourage their parents to do laundry with cold water, or only run the dishwasher when it’s full.”

Wednesday was walk, bike or carpool to school day. “At lunchtime, I heard the students plotting where they would meet and what route they would take to school,” said Sasha. Many teachers also participated, some carpooling, and others, like Christian Life teacher Ellen Krease, riding their bikes. According to Sasha’s count, there were over 60 bicycles in the bike rack, and approximately 20 students walked to school and another 20 carpooled.

On Wednesday during lunch, fourth through eighth grade students were surprised when they went to bus their trays. Rather than throwing their waste in the trash, students emptied their plates into buckets that were then weighed.

“We wanted to see how many pounds of food we are wasting,” explained Sasha. After the initial surprise, students had the opportunity during Thursday and Friday’s lunch to reduce their amount of waste, with the goal to reach zero waste.

 

On Thursday, the second grade enjoyed a visit from Arts and Scraps, a Detroit non-profit organization that uses recycled industrial materials to help students think, create and learn. The children created a variety of unique and environmentally safe forms of transportation out of scraps.

Earth Week concluded on Friday with a paper drive, the final day of measuring food waste after lunch, and the continuation of discussions and journal entries.

There were many other class activities prior to Earth Week and many that will follow. For example, Mrs. Stepanek’s third grade class discussed global warming and the greenhouse effect and conducted an experiment growing lentils in a hydroponic solution. They also made posters with recommendations to make the world a better place.

Beth Plotzke’s Early School students enjoyed a two-week discussion about how every day is Earth Day. Mrs. Beth gave each student a sugar maple sapling to take home to plant in honor of Earth Day. The class also planted a sapling by the Early School building.

“We planted it in the perfect spot,” said Beth. “We can see it from our classroom window, and many years from now it will provide shade and beautiful fall foliage for future Early School children.”
item.excerpt:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy, recently named a Michigan Green School, embarked on an especially ambitious celebration of Earth Day this year, expanding it into Earth Week 2010.

item.title: Janice Sturm Receives Selective Grant
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Early School teacher Janice Sturm was awarded a highly selective grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities entitled: “Seeking the Center Place: The Mesa Verde Cultural Landscape and Pueblo Indian Homeland.” It will take place in Mesa Verde, Colorado in August. Mesa Verde is one of the best preserved archaeological and cultural landscapes in the world. The session will focus on the deep history of the Pueblo Indian people who once occupied this region and reside in New Mexico and Arizona today. Janice will have the opportunity to explore thousands of years of Pueblo history as she interacts with American Indian scholars, excavates at the Goodman Point Unit of Hovenweep National Monument, conducts laboratory analyses with prominent archaeologists, and studies three important landmarks.


“This is a once-in-a-lifetime experience and I am looking forward to it,” said Janice.
item.excerpt:encoded: Early School teacher Janice Sturm was awarded a highly selective grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities entitled: ?Seeking the Center Place: The Mesa Verde Cultural Landscape and Pueblo Indian Homeland.?

item.title: Middle School Students Compete in National French Exam
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the fourth consecutive year, Grosse Pointe Academy middle school students participated in the National French Contest Exam (also known as Le Grand Concours), with fourteen students receiving medals for their high scores and achievements. This 60-minute national examination is developed and managed by the American Association of Teachers of French. Its purpose is to help stimulate further interest in the teaching and learning of French as well as to help identify and reward student achievement.

The exam is a multiple-choice test of approximately 70 items covering listening comprehension, vocabulary, grammar and reading comprehension. Students took the test that was appropriate for the French curriculum in which they are enrolled. Their scores were then ranked against students locally as well as nationally who are enrolled in similar curricula.

Competing against both middle school and high school students, the following Academy middle school students placed in the top 10 ranks both in the Metro Detroit Chapter and nationally: eighth graders Kate Van Pelt (#2 chapter ranking and #6 national ranking), Kara French (#3 chapter ranking and #7 national ranking), Jennifer Vermet (#4 chapter ranking and #8 national ranking), and Luiza Wasilewski (#5 chapter ranking and #9 national ranking); and seventh graders Nikolas Minanov (#1 chapter ranking and #7 national ranking) and James Scott (#2 chapter ranking and #8 national ranking).

Sixth graders took the FLES exam, which includes a speaking section as well. Students are only ranked nationally for this exam. All of the Academy’s sixth grade French students placed in the top 10 ranks, as follows: Sophia Engstrom (#5), Alexander Minanov (#5), Leonie Leslie (#6), Brynne Reilly (#6), Abby Kuplicki (#7), Rachel Lannen (#7), Anna Crane (#8) and Grace Drettmann (#8).
item.excerpt:encoded: For the fourth consecutive year, Grosse Pointe Academy middle school students participated in the National French Contest Exam (also known as Le Grand Concours), with fourteen students receiving medals for their high scores and achievements.

item.title: Sixth Graders Celebrate Medieval Times
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Hear ye! Hear ye! By order of the king, sixth graders ruled the school on Friday as they closed their study of the Middle Ages with the traditional sixth grade medieval feast.

The event began with the grand entrance of the king, accompanied by squires and a priest. Students were divided into manor groups with a lord or lady as the head of the manor. They competed for farthings, and the manor with the most farthings was granted the head table. Those who sat below the salt were seated according to their rank.

King Fultz greeted the guests as they entered the “manor on the lake” – the Academy’s Lakeshore building – then conducted a knighting ceremony. The students played the roles of knights, monks, priests, lords and ladies of the land, and pages. They also provided entertainment as jugglers, jesters, dancers, magicians and musicians. Several “serving wenches” (i.e., mothers of the sixth graders dressed in costume) prepared and served the food. After each course was announced, two food tasters sampled the food to make sure it wasn’t poisoned. Judgments were announced for evil deeds, with the priest begging for mercy for the evildoer. The folks in the gallery decided whether that person should be freed or sent to the dungeon.

Contributing to the ambiance of the banquet were family crests and banners that the students created. Throughout the afternoon, students from other grade levels stopped in to observe the festivities.

Thursday of Medieval Week was "Monk Day." The students experienced the monastic life of the middle ages as they meditated in the Chapel, ate only bread and water, and slept in cells with only a single sheet of newspaper for a blanket. Any monks who broke the code of silence had to wear a hair shirt in penance.

The students were given a respite from their study of the Middle Ages on Thursday afternoon when they enjoyed a Poetry Café. While each student read from his or her poetry journal (a selection of free verse, limericks, haiku, acrostics and many others), classmates lounged on pillows and ate snacks while snapping their fingers to demonstrate their approval of their peers' work.
item.excerpt:encoded: Hear ye! Hear ye! By order of the king, sixth graders ruled the school on Friday as they closed their study of the Middle Ages with the traditional sixth grade medieval feast.

Kindergartener Bode Neumeister was awarded the Camille DeMario Academic Scholarship, given to a rising Academy first grader who demonstrates a strong desire to excel along with academic promise.

Kurtz Trader Scholarship Award based on their success in academics and athletics with a strong desire to excel. As such, the award is reflective of the Academy’s core values and mission.

item.title: Action Auction 2010 Salutes the 60's
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy Action Auction celebrated the 60’s in high style on May 5 and 8. The “Salute to the 60’s” was evident in decorations, food and drink selections, and even the evening’s attire, from the wait staff to the attendees.

On Wednesday, May 5, over 300 items were offered in a silent auction. The merchandise was artfully displayed to catch the bidder’s eye, with bids displayed on plasma screens to allow guests to move throughout the Tracy Fieldhouse to enjoy the many offerings. The décor was a colorful throwback to the 60’s with mod seating arrangements, peace signs and lava lights in abundance. Delicious theme-inspired food stations allowed guests to dine and bid at the same time.

On Saturday, May 8, the night’s event showcased another 200+ silent auction items to get the bidding started for the evening.

A sumptuous buffet dinner was served, followed by the start of the main event - the live Action Auction. Kim Adams entertained the crowd as Mistress of Ceremonies and the DuMouchelle family served as auctioneers of the live auction, which offered an exciting selection of 42 impressive items, from once-in-a-lifetime adventures like an Alaskan family cruise, a week in a Tuscan villa or Paris apartment, or an exclusive Napa Valley wine tour, to exquisite jewelry, parties, original artwork, landscaping packages and even an opportunity to get a sneak peek at what happens backstage at a Caroline Herrera fashion show. The Tracy Fieldhouse was transformed once again into an elegant dining and event space, 60’s style.

Presenting corporate sponsors of Action Auction 2010 were Airfoil, Health Plan of Michigan and Woodworth, among many corporate sponsors and item donors who helped make the evening a success. The over $430,000 net proceeds raised at Action Auction 2010 help to fund academic enrichment activities, scholarships and the preservation of the beautiful historic campus.

item.title: Eighth Graders Produce West Side Story
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Eighth graders took on a variety of roles in the June 10 production of West Side Story. In the program, performers reflected on the meaning of friendship and loyalty based on the musical’s violent depiction of gangs and the results of racial dissension.

Students created the choreographies, designed sets, arranged costumes and experienced what goes into producing a play behind the scenes. They also took the stage, swapping lead roles.

“The goal is to give students an opportunity to work together to create a cohesive production,” explained Director Marion Chrisner. “The student is more important than the production and personal growth of each student is the main goal.”

Musical accompaniment was provided by Marion Chrisner (keyboard), Lawrence DeLuca (bass), and Joe Chila (percussion). Video production was under the direction of Lawrence DeLuca.

item.title: Academy Kids Run for CATCH
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy students in grades 1-5 raised a total of $577.52 for CATCH during the school’s tenth annual fun run on Friday, October 1. Students brought in $5 to participate, and ran by grade around the perimeter of the soccer field to the cheers of the other students.

This is the tenth year that the Academy has participated in the CATCH Fun Run, said Community Service Coordinator Sasha Murphy. “Every year we have participated, Jim Hughes, CATCH’s Executive Director, has come to cheer on our kids! He is very grateful for our support.” In fact, Mr. Hughes has been so impressed with GPA’s loyalty and commitment to the CATCH organization that once again, for the third consecutive year, two Academy middle school students have been asked to serve as emcees at the CATCH Night of Champions recognition dinner. This year sixth grader David Scupholm and seventh grader Anna Crane will have the honor of introducing hockey great Ted Lindsay, a former forward for the Detroit Red Wings.

The CATCH organization stands for Caring Athletes Team for Children’s and Henry Ford Hospitals. CATCH was founded in 1987 by Sparky Anderson.

item.title: New Teachers Settle into Life at GPA
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
With a few months’ experience behind them in the 2010-11 school year, new Grosse Pointe Academy teachers Didi DeBoer, Connie Irueta and Yandan Wang have settled into their daily routines and are now able to reflect on what the experience of teaching at the Academy has meant to them so far.

Didi DeBoer may be new to the 4/5 program at GPA, but she is not new to teaching. She comes to the Academy with seven years of experience as a substitute teacher in the Grosse Pointe public school system and three years as a second grade teacher at Great Oaks Academy in Warren.

Didi describes her three years at Great Oaks Academy, a charter school, as “a wonderful experience. I loved working there and I wouldn’t trade those three years for the world. It was a tough decision to leave, but when the opportunity arose here, I was so grateful. I was very excited to be able to teach in the community where I live.”

Didi has found the Academy to be “like a family. People really care about each other. Everyone knows one another. I love the small classes, the fact that you can work individually with students. We have all the tools here you could possibly want: intelligent, pleasant kids, supportive parents, fabulous staff and an incredible facility.”

In her first year here at GPA, Didi is jumping in with both feet. In addition to helping out with the after school forensics program, Didi will be coaching the girls’ basketball team this winter.

“I am basically a Detroiter,” says Spanish teacher Connie Irueta. Born in Cuba, she attended a Catholic school run by Dominican nuns from New Orleans, where she was taught English from the first grade on. When she was nine, her family came to the United States one month before the missile crisis. Like many other Cubans fleeing the Castro administration, her family initially came to Miami and then were relocated to Detroit as part of a family adoption program. There Connie attended the All Saints’ Catholic School on Ford Street.

Connie graduated from Holy Redeemer, then attended Marygove College in the 1970s before transferring to Wayne State University, where she changed her major from art to Spanish literature.
Her teaching background includes teaching Spanish as part of a bilingual program to middle and high school students. Most recently she taught at the Detroit School of Arts. “There was lots of drama in my classroom!” she jokes. After thirty years of teaching in the public school system, she retired last June. Her retirement was short-lived.

“I considered subbing or starting a Spanish club,” Connie recalls. “Then I heard about the opportunity here and I couldn’t resist.”

Connie too loves the small classes and her ability to individualize her lessons. She also appreciates the students’ eagerness.

“I like the fact that the students are giving. I enjoyed the sandwich making day. These are important traits that must be learned early in life and are reinforced here both at home and at school.”

Mandarin Chinese teacher Yandan Wang moved to the United States three years ago from Liaoning Province in the northeast part of China.

Says Yandan: “I never imagined I could teach Chinese to foreigners when I was young. English was very popular in China. All the students wanted to learn English at the University.”

Teaching Chinese to foreigners is exactly what she ended up doing, initially in China and now at Wayne State University and the Academy. She particularly enjoys teaching students about the Chinese culture. For example, fifth graders learned about Chinese fan dancing and seventh grade learned about Chinese brush pen painting. Eighth graders researched the mid-autumn festival in the library and then were able to discuss the holiday in class in Chinese.

Yandan has exposed the students to other native speakers, having invited visitors from the Confucius Institute at Wayne State to her classroom.

item.title: Sixth Graders Tour Recycling Plant
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
As part of our Green School certification, the sixth grade went on a field trip to Great Lakes Recycling Plant on Wednesday November 3. GLR is a state-of-the-art single stream recycling plant built in 2008, and located in New Boston, Michigan.

This was an excellent opportunity for our students to see “the bigger picture” since the sixth grade is in charge of GPA's paper recycling program. This field trip also served to reinforce responsibility (our October Pillar of Character) to our environment, as well as tie in with our science and geography units.

Students spent a couple of hours at the recycling plant, where they had a first-hand experience with the six main stages of recycling. They followed the recyclables from a big warehouse to the different sorting machines, all the way to the baling process.

Upon their return, the sixth graders made posters of the different recycling stages to share with the rest of the school. Make sure to stop by and take a look at the posters hanging in the second floor hallway!

Go to Flickr to view pictures from the field trip.
item.excerpt:encoded: As part of our Green School certification, the sixth grade went on a field trip to Great Lakes Recycling Plant on Wednesday November 3.

item.title: GPA Presents Free Screening of Documentary "Race to Nowhere"
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy Parents' Coordinating Council is proud to sponsor a private screening of the award-winning documentary "Race to Nowhere" on Wednesday, January 12 at 7 p.m. in the Tracy Fieldhouse.

The film examines the pressures faced by American schoolchildren and their teachers in a system and culture obsessed with the illusion of achievement, competition and the pressure to perform. "Race to Nowhere" points to the silent epidemic in our schools: students have become disengaged and stress-related illnesses, depression and burnout are rampant.
 
"Race to Nowhere" is a call to mobilize families, educators, and policy makers to challenge current assumptions on how to best prepare the youth of America to become healthy, bright, contributing and leading citizens. Check out the trailer or call 313-886-1221 for more information.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy Parents' Coordinating Council is proud to sponsor a private screening of the award-winning documentary "Race to Nowhere" on Wednesday, January 12 at 7 p.m. in the Tracy Fieldhouse.

item.title: Guest Performer Celebrates Spirit of Harriet Tubman
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Guest performer Leslie McCurdy gave a presentation on the life and spirit of Harriet Tubman during a special assembly on Friday, January 14 in honor of Martin Luther King, Jr. Day.

At 9 a.m., students in grades 1-3 gathered in the Tracy Fieldhouse to explore the theme of those characteristics that make Harriet a hero. The audience participated in recreating some parts of the story, including an imaginary trip on the Underground Railroad. Rag dolls were used to help tell the story and illustrate the various ages of Harriet Tubman.

At 10:15 a.m., Leslie McCurdy created a different experience for students in grades 4-8, using costumes and a barren stage. She told Harriet's story in her own words, from her earliest experiences as a slave, through her work on the Underground Railroad, to her continued commitment to others in her later years.

item.title: British Native Shares Experiences During WWII
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday, Jan. 6, in conjunction with their study of World War II, the seventh graders enjoyed a visit from a guest speaker, Mrs. Margaret Torp, who spoke to them about living just outside of London, England during the war.

According to Harriett Whitaker, who arranged the visit for the student, Mrs. Torp was about the same age as the students and experienced things like blackout curtains, sleeping in bunkers, as well has having the windows of her home blown out by a blast while she and her brother played “Snakes and Ladders” in the livingroom.  "Luckily, we ducked just in time and were able to avoid injury!" said Mrs. Torp. They had to have gas masks with them wherever they went, but never had to use them. Eventually some folks packed their lunches in them. Mrs. Torp’s brother was a prisoner of war, so she talked about how stressful it was not knowing his whereabouts for six months or even if he was alive. Her family listened to the radio every night because that’s how they got information about the war.

Mrs. Torp stressed to the students that there were good parts of the war as well, especially the camaraderie that developed within communities and time spent with family. Said Mrs. Whitaker about the visit: "It was a nice treat for the students to be able to hear first hand Mrs. Torp’s experience in World War II."
item.excerpt:encoded: On Thursday, Jan. 6, in conjunction with their study of World War II, the seventh graders enjoyed a visit from a guest speaker, Mrs. Margaret Torp, who spoke to them about living just outside of London, England during the war.

item.title: 4/5 Students Study Michigan Government
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Fourth and fifth graders traveled to Lansing on Friday, January 28 as part of their social studies unit on Michigan government. They enjoyed lunch, a tour of the Capitol building and a visit to the Michigan Historical Museum. While at the Capitol building they were greeted by representatives from the offices of Tim Bledsoe and Senator Bert Johnson. The visit to the Michigan Historical Museum, led by docents, included a time-line of Michigan's history from the Ice Age to the 1960s.

To prepare for their trip, fourth graders in Mrs. DeBoer's social studies class studied branches of the Michigan government and role played how to create a bill. With half of the students on the Senate and half on the House of Representatives, they debated on issues like how to get extra time at recess and how to earn free time each day. Neither bill was passed along to the governor, Mrs. DeBoer. "We had long debates but reached a stalemate. We plan to go back to session next week," Didi explained.

Fifth graders in Mrs. Demartini's social studies class, who had learned about the federal government in preparation for the trip to Washington D.C. last spring, compared federal laws to state laws and differences in state and federal government, including numbers of senators and representatives. The fifth graders were particularly eager to visit the Capitol building in Lansing and compare it to their recollection of the federal Capitol building.
item.excerpt:encoded: Fourth and fifth graders traveled to Lansing on Friday, January 28 as part of their social studies unit on Michigan government. They enjoyed lunch, a tour of the Capitol building and a visit to the Michigan Historical Museum.

item.title: GPA Students Show Their Spirit
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Middle school students at The Grosse Pointe Academy have a cure for the February blahs: it’s called Spirit Week. Students showed their school spirit by dressing according to a theme and participating in a variety of fun, challenging and just plain silly competitions. For example, sixth, seventh and eighth graders challenged their endurance and physical fortitude by scootering, hula hooping, and hopping their way through an obstacle course during Clash Day on Tuesday, tested their mental acumen during a trivia contest during Pajama Day on Wednesday, and battled it out on the basketball court in a game of lightning during Twin Day on Thursday. A culminating activity was dodge ball with students against the teachers.

The eighth grade was declared the Spirit Week 2011 champions, winning the obstacle course for the third straight year and sweeping the remainder of the events. Go to Flickr to see pictures from the week.

Middle School teachers wore purple on Twin Day in honor of Mrs. Whitaker!
item.excerpt:encoded: Middle school students at The Grosse Pointe Academy have a cure for the February blahs: it?s called Spirit Week. Students showed their school spirit by dressing according to a theme and participating in a variety of fun, challenging and just plain silly competitions.

item.title: First Graders Journey Below the Sea
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: First graders took a journey to the depths of the sea as part of their cross-curricular unit on sea life. Beginning in homeroom classes with Mrs. Karle and Mrs. Martin, students selected a sea creature to study, conducted research in library class with Mrs. Baetens, went into depth about their creatures in enrichment classes with Dr. Blau, then created three-dimensional puppets using fluorescent paints in art class with Mrs. Baudeloque. During the presentation to parents on Thursday morning, their research and knowledge shone through their art as they introduced their creatures in French and presented them on stage under black light to the music of "The Aquarium" by French composer Camille Saint-Saëns.

item.title: Eighth Graders Study Architecture
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: As part of their unit on architecture, eighth graders have studied six architectural styles in art class with Mrs. Triano: Classical, Romanesque, Gothic, Mediterranean, Islamic and Modern. Having completed a project in which they identified houses in a variety of architectural styles in Grosse Pointe, they have been busy in the art loft creating an architectural model that is a replica of a famous building or an original creation of their own. Using foam core, papier maché, tubes, tiles, cardboard or whatever materials they have at their disposal, the students have created a variety of structures, from a skyscraper with a viewable elevator and a castle with a moat, to a building with glass walls and a replica of the Eiffel Tower. Later the students will select a building in Detroit to research and present to the class.

item.title: 4/5 Science Fair Winners
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy fourth and fifth graders participated in the annual 4/5 Science Fair this winter, the culmination of which was a parent evening on Wednesday, March 9 during which attendees had the opportunity to view all the display boards in the library while the young scientists were on hand to explain their methods and procedures.

Grade 4/5 teachers Trevor Clor and Bob Lapadot led the project during science classes. They began by teaching the scientific method (stating the problem, forming a hypothesis, listing the materials and procedures, recording observations, and forming a conclusion). Working under the guidance of their teachers, students conducted some of the work for their projects in class and the remainder at home to meet specific deadlines throughout the process.

Fifth grade projects were entered into a competition, with middle school science teachers serving as judges. Special certificates of recognition and ribbons were awarded to the top sixth fifth grade projects.

Congratulations go to grand prize winner Karina Minanov and to ribbon winners James McCuish, Alex Johnson, Sophie Leonie, Elizabeth Sheeren and Spencer Warezak.
