item.title: The Academy Celebrates Earth Week
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
In celebration of its designation as a “Green School” for a second consecutive year, The Grosse Pointe Academy once again hosted a week-long observance of Earth Week, with a number of fun things planned in and outside the classrooms. Unfortunately, due to inclement weather on Tuesday, the plan to walk/bike/carpool to school day was postponed. However, the other activities took place as planned. This included each student and faculty or staff member receiving an Earth Day sticker.

Grades 1-5 worked on Earth Day packets throughout the week, while middle school students completed their carbon footprints during science class.

Grades 1-3 wrote about Earth Day for their daily journals, while sixth graders, who have been responsible for collecting recycling bins through the school buildings all year, weighed each of the bins they collected before dumping the paper for pick-up. This week the school recycled 42 1/2 pounds of paper. “This amounts to 42 and a half pounds of paper that will not be going into a landfill!!” said community service coordinator Sasha Murphy, who organized Earth Week for the school.

Sasha gave a special “shout-out” to the  third grade, which accomplished a rare feat during “Waste Free Wednesday” at lunchtime. The final weight of all their food waste was less than a pound.
item.excerpt:encoded: In celebration of its designation as a ?Green School? for a second consecutive year, The Grosse Pointe Academy once again hosted a week-long observance of Earth Week, with a number of fun things planned in and outside the classrooms.

item.title: GPA Sweeps in Michigan China Quiz Bowl
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday, April 16, sixteen Academy middle school students, along with GPA Chinese teacher, Yandan Wang, headed to the Birmingham Covington School in Bloomfield Township to participate in the third annual Michigan China Quiz Bowl, sponsored by The Confucius Institute at Wayne State University.

The competition features quiz bowl style questions that pertain to Mandarin language learning and Chinese geography. The six divisions comprised for non-heritage learners include first, second and third year middle-school divisions and first, second and third year high-school divisions. A record-number 46 teams joined the competition this year, representing nine schools from across southeast Michigan.

The Grosse Pointe Academy was represented by four teams competing in the middle school division, with all four teams advancing to the championship round and three teams bringing home first place trophies. The winning teams were made up of sixth graders Gabriela Cavataio, Carly Demkowicz, Jyen-ai Jones, Megan McCarren, Hailey McDonald and RaeAnne Woodman (Division 1); seventh graders Isabella Gierlinger, James Raudabaugh, Jack Sheeren and Evelyn Woodman (Division 2); and eighth graders Joseph Cavataio, Matthew Homsy, R.J. McCarren and Michael Schaller (Division 3). The two GPA eighth grade teams faced each other in the finals, with Joseph, Matt, R.J. and Michael winning first place and Charles Becker, Jared Brush, McCalla Mecke and Jack Weaver taking home a second place trophy.

“The Michigan China Quiz Bowl is offered as an enjoyable incentive for students of Chinese language and culture to realize their accomplishments,” said John Brender, Director of the Wayne State University Confucius Institute. “Learning a foreign language – and especially Chinese – will bring many future rewards, but the initial thrill of putting together sentences and communicating in a foreign language is a milestone that we are extremely happy to acknowledge with this event.”
item.excerpt:encoded: On Saturday, April 16, sixteen Academy middle school students, along with GPA Chinese teacher, Yandan Wang, headed to the Birmingham Covington School in Bloomfield Township to participate in the third annual Michigan China Quiz Bowl, sponsored by The Confucius Institute at Wayne State University.

item.title: 4/5 Trip to Northern Michigan
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The temperatures might have been a bit chilly in northern Michigan, but spirits were not dampened during this popular 4/5 trip that serves as a culmination of the students' study of Michigan and its history in social studies class.

To prepare for the trip (in addition to packing "lots of stuff," according to fifth grader Joseph Spica), each student chose a site to research from a minimum of two sources. Presentations to the class included a visual, and each student took notes on the presentations.

"They were very impressive with all their knowledge," commented fifth grade teacher Bob Lapadot. Fourth grade teacher Didi DeBoer pointed out that during their carriage tour of Mackinac Island, the tour guide allowed the students to share their knowledge. "She was very impressed with all that they knew!" said Didi.

Highlights of the trip included the Grand Hotel (which, according to Mrs. DeBoer's students, was built in three months), Fort Michilimackinac, the Soo Locks, Mackinac Bridge, Hartwick Pines and Historic Mill Creek. Regarding Hartwick Pines, fourth grader Jackie Mercier claimed that she felt like a lumberjack. Fifth grader Christian Ilitich enjoyed Historic Mill Creek - "It was really cool because we got to watch how a water-powered saw mill worked." Fourth grader Samantha Savage enjoyed observing the differences between Fort Michilimackinac and Fort Mackinac (the former is a reproduction and the latter is real, according to Samantha). Other favorites on the trip included shopping on Main Street on Mackinac Island (where fudge was apparently a favorite), walking around on their own at Fort Mackinac, and even spotting a ghost at the Grand Hotel!

Students in Mrs. Demartini's class are revisiting the presentations with their new knowledge and understanding. Said Wendy: "What once was unknown is now known and we can look at each site with fresh eyes and revisit and reinforce what we learned."

Highlights from the teachers' perspective included the Grand Hotel, the carriage ride on Mackinac Island, spending time with the children and observing how kind they were to one another, and the following quote: "I accidentally ate the fudge I bought for my mother!"

Click here to view pictures on Flickr.
item.excerpt:encoded: The temperatures might have been a bit chilly in northern Michigan, but spirits were not dampened during this popular 4/5 trip that serves as a culmination of the students' study of Michigan and its history in social studies class.

item.title: GPA Lacrosse Team Brings Home Tournament Trophy
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy varsity lacrosse team traveled to Bloomfield Hills on Saturday, May 14 for the Academy of the Sacred Heart Middle School Lacrosse Tournament. Four teams participated in round robin play, with the team with the best record at the end of the afternoon declared champions.
 
After defeating Greenhills (9-1) and the Academy of the Sacred Heart (9-2), the Academy Bulldogs faced Detroit Country Day, which also entered the third round of play with an undefeated record. The contest between the two teams ended in a 7-7 tie, with the tie-breaker being number of goals scored against each team. The deferential was two goals (GPA goalkeepers Clay Brock and McCalla Mecke let up a total of 10 goals, while ASH let up 12). As a result, GPA was declared tournament champions.

Head Coach Chip Fowler has worked with the varsity team for six years, while Head of School Phil Demartini has served as assistant coach for eight years. “Many of our players first discovered the sport here at the Academy,” said Demartini. “A good number of them go on to excel in high school. We have had players at University of Detroit, De La Salle, Liggett and Grosse Pointe South. In fact, currently one third of the varsity players at South are from the Academy. And these are impact players who start and contribute to the team’s overall success.”

item.title: Sixth Graders Host Medieval Feast
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Hear ye! Hear ye! By order of the king, sixth graders ruled the school on Friday as they closed their study of the Middle Ages with the traditional sixth grade medieval feast. The event began with the grand entrance of Queen Harriet of GPA Manor escorted by King Michael of GPA Manor and Queen Amal of GPA Manor escorted by King Scott of GPA Manor. Students were divided into manor groups with a lord or lady as the head of the manor. They competed for farthings, and the manor with the most farthings was granted the head table. Those who sat below the salt were seated according to their rank.

King Fultz greeted the guests as they entered the “manor on the lake” – the Academy’s Lakeshore building – then conducted a knighting ceremony. The students played the roles of knights, monks, priests, lords and ladies of the land, and pages. They also provided entertainment as jugglers, jesters, dancers, magicians and musicians. Several “serving wenches” (i.e., mothers of the sixth graders dressed in costume) prepared and served the food. After each course was announced, two food tasters sampled the food to make sure it wasn’t poisoned. Judgments were announced for evil deeds, with the priest begging for mercy for the evildoer. The folks in the gallery decided whether that person should be freed or sent to the dungeon.

Contributing to the ambiance of the banquet were family crests and banners that the students created.

Go to Flickr to view pictures.

The event began with the grand entrance of Queen Harriet of GPA Manor escorted by King Michael of GPA Manor and Queen Amal of GPA Manor escorted by King Scott of GPA Manor.

item.title: GPA Names Athletes of the Season
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy eighth grader Mac Carroll, sixth grader Emma Andreasen, and eighth grader Jared Brush were named Athletes of the Season for the spring of 2011 based on their athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship.

Mac, a two-year varsity basketball and varsity lacrosse player, was nominated for this honor by the coaches of both teams. He was named MVP of the basketball team and was co-captain and MVP of the lacrosse team. He is on the Academy’s citizenship list.

Emma, who was nominated by both her basketball and soccer coaches, was named MVP of the basketball team and was co-captain of the soccer team. She is a scholar athlete, received high academic honors, and is on the citizenship and head of school honor rolls.

Jared, a two-year veteran on the varsity basketball and varsity lacrosse teams, was nominated by the coaches of both sports. Voted co-captain of the lacrosse team by his teammates, Brush is a scholar athlete and was named to the academic honor roll as well as the citizenship and head of school honor rolls.

item.title: GPA Students Compete in National French Exam
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the fifth consecutive year, Grosse Pointe Academy middle school students participated in the National French Exam (also known as Le Grand Concours), with ten students receiving medals for their high scores and achievements. This 60-minute national examination is developed and managed by the American Association of Teachers of French. Its purpose is to help stimulate further interest in the teaching and learning of French as well as to help identify and reward student achievement.

The exam is a multiple-choice test of approximately 70 items covering listening comprehension, vocabulary, grammar and reading comprehension. Students took the test that was appropriate for the French curriculum in which they are enrolled. Their scores were then ranked against students locally as well as nationally who are enrolled in similar curricula.

Competing against middle school and high school students, the following Academy middle school students placed in the top 10 ranks both in the Metro Detroit Chapter and nationally: eighth grader and silver medal winner James Scott (#3 national ranking and #1 local ranking), eighth grader and bronze medal winner Nikolas Minanov (#5 national ranking and #2 local ranking), seventh grader and bronze medal winner Alexander Minanov (#6 national ranking and #1 local ranking), seventh grader and bronze medal winner Leonie Leslie (#7 national ranking and #2 local ranking), and sixth graders, who were ranked only at the national level: Katie Fruenhauf (#2 - silver medal winner); Stephanie Vermet (#3 - silver medal winner); Emma Andreasen, Antonina Cinnamond and Therese Drettmann (#4 and bronze medal winners); and Markus Minanov (#5 and bronze medal winner).

item.title: "Stand Up, Speak Out!"
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
GPA launched its "Stand Up, Speak Out!" (S.U.S.O.) Character Development Program on Thursday afternoon. This program is a follow-up to the school-wide Character Education Program that incorporated the following six pillars of character: respect, responsibility, caring, fairness, trustworthiness and citizenship.

"The goal of the Character Education Committee this year is to take our Character Education Program a step further by helping our students develop and utilize specific social skills and awarenesses," explained learning resources specialist Cheryl Blau, who serves on the Character Education Committee along with Interim Head of School Mike Kennedy, Grade 4-8 Principal Scott Tily, Early and Lower School Principal Jen Kendall, School Counselor Sean Hogan-Downey, and community service coordinator Sasha Murphy.

Individual classroom teachers ran activities within their own classrooms in grades 1-5 beginning at 1:20. Students in these classrooms engaged in a circle ball-toss activity that led students to discover and develop important communication, problem-solving, and team-building skills. Said Cheryl: "Discussions of 'inside' feelings, 'outside' feelings, and what we each need to feel safe and comfortable so we can do our best learning followed, culminating with each student writing what he or she most needs on a leaf and adding it to our school tree on the front office wall."

Middle school teachers ran an introductory slide show in the Tracy Fieldhouse, then students and teachers broke up into their homerooms for discussions of what they felt they each needed to make this an "awesome" year. This was followed by grade-level team-building/problem solving/communication skills activities in the field house. Sixth graders concluded the activities in the field house by participating in a unique game of kickball that helped them explore and develop their communication, problem-solving, and team-building skills.

The idea for the S.U.S.O. program came out of research that the Character Education Committee conducted to help GPA students develop and utilize specific social skills and awareness including assertiveness training, conflict resolution, defining and handling "normal conflict," defining and handling "harassment," defining and handling "bullying," understanding the bully/victim/bystander triangle and roles, tattling vs. reporting, and anger management. The afternoon's activities represented a kick-off of the program and will be followed up by individual classroom lessons at each grade level.

To see photos from the afternoon, go to Flickr.

item.title: GPA Announces New Partnership with Henry Ford Medical Center
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy is pleased to announce Henry Ford Medical Center - Cottage & Pierson Clinic as a school year partner and presenting sponsor of Action Auction 2012.

As Action Auction Presenting Sponsor, Henry Ford Medical Center – Cottage & Pierson Clinic will support the Academy by promoting Action Auction and our partnership, allowing the Academy to reach new audiences. Cottage will be a valuable resource on health topics of interest to Academy families, students and alumni. Academy students and parents will benefit from this partnership through community service opportunities, field trips and educational speakers and offerings.

This partnership was formed in response to parent volunteers’ desire to demonstrate the Academy’s commitment to giving back to the community.  A percentage of Action Auction item proceeds will support the new Henry Ford Center for Autism and Developmental Disabilities, the first of its kind on the eastside to offer comprehensive diagnostic and therapeutic services to families.

The Center for Autism and Developmental Disabilities, located at Cottage, offers children and families a multi-disciplinary team of specialists who provide expertise in the diagnosis and treatment of autism spectrum disorders. The treatments offered include speech and language services, social skills groups, behavioral interventions, occupational therapy and parent and family support groups.

"We are pleased to support the important work of this center for families in our community," said Interim Head of School Michael J. Kennedy.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy is pleased to announced Henry Ford Medical Center ? Cottage & Pierson Clinic as a school year partner and presenting sponsor of Action Auction 2012.

item.title: Academy Students Make a Difference
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy first through eighth grade students celebrated National Make a Difference Day on Friday with a variety of projects to benefit local organizations. Of particular emphasis this year was collaborating with our Action Auction 2012 Presenting Sponsor, Henry Ford Medical Center – Cottage & Pierson Clinic as part of our school-year partnership.

First graders made birthday cards for seniors at Services for Older Citizens; second graders made Halloween cards for the seniors; third graders made pine cone turkeys for display in the reception area of the The Center for Autism and Developmental Disabilities, located at Cottage; fourth graders made fleece blankets to be given out to patients by Henry Ford ER staff during the winter; fifth and sixth graders wrote Halloween poems to be displayed in frames at the Autism Center; and seventh graders raked leaves on the GPA campus. (Eighth graders will head off campus next Friday to rake leaves for seniors citizens as part of their year-long commitment to community service.)

"Even our six year olds understand how a birthday card can put a smile on an older person's face," said Community Service Coordinator Sasha Murphy, who organized the day's events.

Go to Flickr to see pictures from the day.

item.title: McMillan Lecture Addresses Internet Safety and Cyberbullying
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Leading Internet expert Parry Aftab spoke to a crowd of adults and middle school students in the Tracy Fieldhouse on November 9 on a topic paramount on many parents' and educators' minds: how to keep children safe in the uncertain and ever-changing world of high tech communications. Drawing on conversations and role-playing exercises she had shared with Academy students earlier that day, Ms. Aftab addressed the importance of understanding the technology first in order to prevent abuse and protect children from its dangers.

The future, according to Ms. Aftab, lies not with the parents but with the students. She offered some good news, saying that students are beginning to step forward to report cyberbullying issues.

"I have met with smart, involved kids across the world, from Singapore to New York City," said Ms. Aftab, "but never have I met with kids like I met with today. They want to understand. They want to help. They want to make a difference."

The William Charles McMillan III Lecture Series is a gfit from Thayer and Gioconda McMillan given in memory of William in the interest of emphasizing the importance of elementary education.

item.title: 4/5 Students Study Artist Andy Goldsworthy
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Fourth and fifth graders presented their studies and interpretations of the work of British artist and naturalist Andy Goldsworthy on November 15 under the direction of Creative Arts Movement teacher Denise Szykula. Each student participated in displaying small group studies and class choreographies representing the unique nature of the artist's work. The students amplified their understanding of Goldsworthy in art class with Rosi Triano. Bringing in objects found in nature, they created their own naturalist art, capturing the ephemeral quality so inherent in Goldsworthy's artistic philosophy. "I don't seek to mimic nature but to draw energy from it," said Goldsworthy. "Movement, change, light, growth and decay are the lifeblood of nature, the energies that I try to tap through my work."

Pictures of the Creative Arts Movement presentation are available on Flickr. The students' artwork is on display in the downstairs quad by the lower gym.

item.title: GPA Names Athletes of the Fall Season
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy eighth graders Grayson Cieszkowski and Robert Whitaker were named Athletes of the Season for the fall of 2011 based on their athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship.

Grayson, a scholar athlete, was a two-year captain and MVP of the girls’ varsity volleyball team. She also received awards as best server, best passer, and best spiker. Cieszskowski received high academic honors, and is on the citizenship and head of school honor rolls.

Robert was co-captain and Most Valuable Player for the boys’ varsity soccer team. A scholar athlete, he received academic honors and is on the citizenship and head of school roll.

item.title: Seventh Grader Wins GPA Geography Bee
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Seventh grader Sam Durno won the school-level competition of the National Geographic Bee and a chance at a $25,000 college scholarship. Eighth grader Alexander Minanov was the runner-up. The school-level Bee, at which students answered oral questions on geography, was the first round in the 24th annual National Geographic Bee. The Bee is sponsored by the National Geographic Society.

Thousands of schools around the United States and in the five U.S. territories participate each year in the National Geographic Bee. Academy Middle School students qualified for the Bee by taking a written test; ten finalists competed in the final round on December 21 by answering oral questions. Sam and Alexander went on to the championship round.

The other finalists in addition to Durno and Minanov were sixth graders Ian Homsy, Karina Minanov and Tristan Shogren; and eighth graders Rachel Lannen, C.J. Lemanski, James Raudabaugh, Jack Sheeren and Robert Whitaker.

Sam, along with other school winners in the state, will take another written test; up to 100 of the top scorers in each state will be eligible to compete in their state Bee in March.
item.excerpt:encoded: Seventh grader Sam Durno won the school-level competition of the National Geographic Bee and a chance at a $25,000 college scholarship. Eighth grader Alexander Minanov was the runner-up.

item.title: Fourth Graders Explore Early Michigan
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
As part of their study on Michigan, fourth graders in Mr. Clor's social studies class have been researching and discussing the arrival of Europeans in Michigan. Before Christmas break, they were given a challenging assignment: to make a large, three-dimensional representation of an artifact important to this time period.

The students were asked to consider the following questions when deciding what to build: What might have the first French missionaries needed to survive the wilderness? Did French voyagers need tools to make a living? What might one find in an early British settlement? What transportation did all of these travelers use and in what types of buildings did they live?

Mr. Clor instructed the students that the "sky is the limit for what materials you may use." His only stipulation was that artifacts should be large enough to display in class but small enough to fit through the doorway. They also needed to include a written paragraph describing the artifact and its importance to Michigan's history.

Pictured is a cannon created by Ryan Murphy. All projects are on display in the corridor outside Mr. Clor's classroom.

item.title: Bee Spells Success for Sixth Grader

The other finalists in addition to Spencer and Jack were fourth graders Harry Durno, Maria Fields, Claire Sheeren and Isabella Tomlinson; fifth graders Samantha Savage, Grant Sachs and Henry Whitaker; sixth graders Morgan Connell, Ian Homsy and Tommy Van Pelt; seventh graders Katie Fruehauf, Jacob Mantela, Hailey McDonald and David Scupholm; and eighth graders Alexander Minanov and Lily Patterson.

item.title: Grade 4 Heads to Lansing
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The fourth grade headed to Lansing on Friday, January 27 as part of their study of the government in social studies class. The students had the opportunity to visit with Michigan State Supreme Court Justice Robert Young, a former Academy parent, and even sit in the Justices' chairs! Then they headed to the Capitol building for a tour.

"The highlight was probably lying on the glass floor and looking up at the awesome ceiling in the dome," said fourth grade teacher Didi DeBoer. Following their tour of the Capitol building, the students and teachers enjoyed a delicious lunch and then were off to the Historical Museum for another informative tour.
item.excerpt:encoded: Academy fourth graders headed to Lansing on Friday, January 27 as part of their study of the government in social studies class.

item.title: First Graders Enjoy Medley of Music
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Barbara Karle and her first grade class, accompanied by music teacher Roshell Chuhran, caught an insider's glimpse into the music world during a special field trip on February 8. Carl Craig, father of Caya, gave the students a tour of his music studio, complete with a demonstration on how to use the equipment. The students learned about techno music and the different sounds a synthesizer can make. This was followed by a guided tour of the Motown Museum, where the students learned about the history of Motown music in Detroit. In addition to watching a short movie, the students had the opportunity to show off their own special Motown prowess when they sang songs from their Grandparents'/Special Friends' Day performance!

Go to Flickr to see additional pictures.

item.title: Middle Schoolers Show Their Spirit
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Middle School students showed their school spirit during Spirit Week in mid-February, dressing according to a theme and participating in a variety of fun, challenging and just plain silly competitions. The three days offer a great break in the year right before the long holiday weekend.

On Tuesday, students dressed in their pajamas and tested their mental acumen during the trivia contest. Wednesday was Clash Day, and during homeroom the students challenged their endurance and physical fortitude by scootering, hula hooping, and hopping their way through an obstacle course. The theme for Thursday was Super Heroes. Sixth, seventh and eighth graders battled it out in a lightning basketball contest, and the final activity of the day was the traditional student vs. teacher dodgeball challenge.

A highlight of Super Hero Day was when five seventh grade girls each dressed as their own personal super hero, their teacher (and Spirit Week organizer) Sasha Murphy.

Go to Flickr to see more Spirit Week pictures.

item.title: First Graders Journey Under the Sea
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
As the culminating activity for their study of sea life this winter, the first graders gave a special presentation for parents and Early School students on the morning of Friday, February 16.

Each student selected a sea creature to research and prepare a written report on in class with Mrs. Karle and Mrs. Martin. In art class with Mrs. Baudeloque, they created their sea creatures as three-dimensional puppets using fluorescent paints. In French class with Madame Leslie, they listened to the story, "The Little Mermaid," and learned the vocabulary for the most common animals that live in the ocean and created a book that displays all of the creatures that they studied. They then learned to express sentences with their newly developed vocabulary.

Music teacher Mrs. Chuhran selected “The Aquarium” from French composer Camille Saint-Saëns to accompany the students' presentation. The students learned all about this French composer’s life and his amazing abilities.

All the pieces of this cross-curricular study came together on Friday morning when the first graders stood on stage in the Tracy Fieldhouse to introduce themselves and their sea creatures in French, and then all the sea creatures "swam" together under black light. The overall effect was colorful and magical.
item.excerpt:encoded: As the culminating activity for their study of sea life this winter, the first graders gave a special presentation for parents and Early School students on the morning of Friday, February 16.

item.title: GPA Chess Team Competes in State Tournament
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday, February 4, 17 GPA students from grades 1 through 5 represented our GPA Chess Team at the Michigan Scholastic Chess Championship Tournament held on the MSU campus in East Lansing. Students were divided into four teams with four players per team. Each student played five rounds of chess during this all-day event except for two first grade players who served as alternates and played three games each.

Recalled faculty advisor Cheryl Blau of the day: "The competition was fierce, yet our players were determined to hold their own. Every one of our GPA players remained focused and calm throughout the long and grueling competition, even when games ran over an hour long!" According to Dr. Blau, several of the games lasted 90 minutes or more.

Although the team did not place high enough in the final team standings to bring home a trophy, the members of the 2011-12 GPA Chess Team are to be congratulated for skillful chess playing, respectful behavior, incredible stamina, and outstanding sportsmanship throughout this competition. Congratulations to Bode Neumeister for winning an individual bronze medal.

Members of the chess team are Christa Abar, Griffin Cantin, Isaac Cantin, Alessandro Cavataio, Piero Cavataio, Maria Davis, Adrian Doan, Evelyn Doan, Lachlan Doan, Andrew Jamieson, Adam Kuplicki, Alexander Kuplicki, Bode Neumeister, Jack Nicholson, Claire Sheeren, Thomas Wacker, and Winston Wright.
item.excerpt:encoded: On Saturday, February 4, 17 GPA students from grades 1 through 5 represented our GPA Chess Team at the Michigan Scholastic Chess Championship Tournament held on the MSU campus in East Lansing.

item.title: Eighth Graders Named Essay Contest Winners
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Three eighth graders were named local winners in the 43rd annual America & Me Essay Contest, sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance.

The three students, who earned the first, second and third place awards for their school, are Alexander Minanov, first, Evelyn Woodman, second (not pictured), and Sara Anthony, third. All three received award certificates for their achievement. As the school’s first place winner, Alexander's name will also be engraved on a plaque for permanent display in the school.

The Grosse Pointe Academy’s participation in the America & Me Essay Contest was sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance agent Colleen Dyer of Grosse Pointe Woods.

Alexander's first place essay now advances to the state level competition, from which the top ten essays in Michigan will be selected. The top ten statewide winners, who will be announced in April, will receive plaques, cash, and U.S. savings bonds valued from $500 to $1,000. In addition, the top ten essayists will be honored at a banquet in Lansing, meet with Michigan’s top governmental leaders, and be the featured guests at a Lansing Lugnuts minor league baseball game dedicated in their honor.

A team of finalist judges that includes a top Michigan Government official and the sponsoring teachers of last year’s top two statewide winners will determine the ranking of the top ten statewide winners this year.

Several thousand eighth grade students from over 500 Michigan schools participated in the 2011-2012 America & Me Essay Contest, which was conducted with the help of Farm Bureau Insurance agents across the state.  The topic of the 2011-2012 contest was “My Personal Michigan Hero.”

Started in 1968 and open to all Michigan eighth grade students, the contest encourages Michigan youngsters to explore their roles in America’s future. As sponsor of the contest, Farm Bureau Insurance has earned 11 national awards from the Freedoms Foundation at Valley Forge.

The three students, who earned the first, second and third place awards for their school, are Alexander Minanov, first, Evelyn Woodman, second, and Sara Anthony, third. All three received award certificates for their achievement.

item.title: Third Graders Step into the Past
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
If you happened to be walking along the first floor hallway of The Grosse Pointe Academy on Wednesday, March 14, you might have run into the likes of Albert Einstein, Harriet Tubman, Henry Ford or Amelia Earhart! Each March, Academy third graders step into the past to take a look at some famous figures as part of an ongoing research project. The students spent several weeks researching their chosen subjects. Dressing up in costume and delivering an oral part were the culminating activities of this popular social studies unit.

Walking the halls at GPA this week were, from Mrs. Stepanek's class: George Washington (Gordon Acheson), Albert Einstein (Christian Buhl), Neil Armstrong (Griffin Cantin), Ronald Reagan (William Cooksey), Amelia Earhart (Emmanuelle Cubba), Walt Disney (Ava Daudert), Henry Ford (Jack Fauster), Laura Ingalls Wilder (Kaitlyn Gray), Cleopatra (Ariana Herman), Thomas Edison (Alex Kelly), Sacagawea (Courtney Mecke), Jane Goodall (May Savage), and Mae Jemison (Christina Thomas).

From Mrs. Wolney's classroom were: Helen Keller (Elizabeth Becker), Harriet Tubman (Lexi Belyue), Henry Ford (Alessandro Cavataio), Abigail Adams (Meggie Demkowicz), Suleiman (Lachlan Doan), John Kennedy (Dane Dryer), Sacagawea (Angel Jones), Amelia Earhart (Elizabeth Kendrick), Albert Einstein (Oscar McWood), Mozart (Lilly Parrish), Theodore Roosevelt (Danielle Patterson), Thomas Edison (Thomas Smith), and Douglas MacArthur (Ryan Warezak).

item.title: Seventh Grade Team Wins Trophy at China Quiz Bowl
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday, April 14, Academy middle school students participated in the fourth annual Michigan China Quiz Bowl, sponsored by The Confucius Institute at Wayne State University.

The competition features quiz bowl style questions that pertain to Mandarin language learning and Chinese geography. The six divisions comprised for non-heritage learners include first, second and third year middle-school divisions and first, second and third year high-school divisions.

The Grosse Pointe Academy was represented by a sixth and seventh grade team competing in the middle school division. The seventh grade team ended up winning first place in their division and bringing home a trophy.

Members of the seventh grade China Quiz Bowl team are (pictured above with Chinese teacher Lucia Hu, from left): Hailey McDonald, Gabriela Cavataio, Carly Demkowicz, Jyen-ai Jones, RaeAnne Woodman and Megan McCarren,

“The Michigan China Quiz Bowl is offered as an enjoyable incentive for students of Chinese language and culture to realize their accomplishments,” said John Brender, Director of the Wayne State University Confucius Institute. “Learning a foreign language – and especially Chinese – will bring many future rewards, but the initial thrill of putting together sentences and communicating in a foreign language is a milestone that we are extremely happy to acknowledge with this event.”
item.excerpt:encoded: On Saturday, April 14, Academy middle school students, along with Chinese teacher, Lucia Wu, participated in the fourth annual Michigan China Quiz Bowl, sponsored by The Confucius Institute at Wayne State University.

item.title: GPA Students Participate in National Spanish Exam
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations to middle school Spanish students who participated in the National Spanish Exam and achieved tremendous results. According to Spanish teacher Veronica Weber, "All of the students showed a lot of improvement, and in many cases the improvement was remarkable." Results for the Academy yielded one gold medal winner, one silver medal winner, and nine honor roll awards.

Seventh grader David Scupholm received a gold medal and eighth grader Lily Patterson received a silver medal. Named to the Honor Roll were seventh graders Virginia Cinnamond, Sam Durno, Jacob Mantela and Kevin Mazur, and eighth graders Grayson Cieszkowski, J.D. Gray, Hannah Homsy, Kendall McConico, and Ryan McWood.

“Attaining a medal or honorable mention for any student on the National Spanish Examinations is very prestigious,” said Kevin Cessna-Buscemi, National Director of the Exams, “because the exams are the largest of their kind in the United States with 143,641 students participating in 2012.”

The National Spanish Examinations are administered each year in grades 6 through 12, and are sponsored by the American Association of Teachers of Spanish and Portuguese.

item.title: GPA Celebrates Earth Week!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
In recognition of its “Green School” status, the Academy once again expanded Earth Day on Monday, April 23 to a week-long celebration. During the kick-off on Monday, each student and faculty member received an Earth Week sticker, and librarian Jane Baetens began the “GPA Green Reads” program during library class. First graders were given an Earth Week packet to work on throughout the week and each morning’s bulletin included a "green" riddle of the day. (Example: How did  Benjamin Franklin feel when he discovered electricity? He was shocked!) A highlight for grades 1-3 was a special morning visit from the Arts and Scraps truck.

Tuesday was bike, walk or carpool to school day. Mrs. Baetens continued the “GPA Green Reads” program in library classes, and first through eighth graders figured out their carbon footprints in science class.

On Waste Free Wednesday, first through eighth grade students and faculty weighed any waste left over from lunch. Sixth graders paid their weekly visits to classrooms and school offices to empty paper recycle bins.

There was no school on Thursday due to parent/teacher conferences, but on Friday the seventh grade led an all-school paper drive, greeting parents at their cars and collecting their paper goods for recycling.

item.title: GPA Hosts 4-5 Science Fair
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy fourth and fifth graders participated in the annual grade 4/5 Science Fair this spring, the culmination of which was a parent evening on Wednesday, May 2 during which attendees had the opportunity to view all the display boards in the library while the young scientists were on hand to explain their methods and procedures.

Didi DeBoer, who teaches fifth grade science, and Katy Klimczuk, who teaches fourth grade science, led the project during science classes. They began by teaching the scientific method (stating the problem, forming a hypothesis, listing the materials and procedures, recording observations, and forming a conclusion). Working under the guidance of their teachers, students conducted some of the work for their projects in class and the remainder at home to meet specific deadlines throughout the process.

Fifth grade projects were entered into a competition, with middle school science teachers serving as judges. Special certificates of recognition and ribbons were awarded to the top five fifth grade projects.

Congratulations go to grand prize winner Adrian Doan and to the following students who received ribbons for outstanding achievement: Errington Belyue, William Kendrick, Brandon Murphy and Blake Weaver.

item.title: Fifth Graders Travel to Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The fifth grade enjoyed a non-stop tour of Washington, D.C., taking all the knowledge they gained about the government in social studies class and making it come alive while enjoying the sights and monuments of the nation's capital.


Before leaving for the trip, the Academy fifth graders were responsible for researching and presenting a location that they would visit during the trip. Upon arriving at each location, the tour guide handed the microphone to the students to take over. One tour guide even said that the Academy group was the most prepared group she had ever had. Says fifth grade teacher Trevor Clor, she "claimed we were more knowledgeable than her eighth grade groups, specifically the one she had last week from Saginaw."

The first day the group walked the National Mall in a light drizzle, which was actually perfect weather, recalls Trevor, to view the sobering Vietnam, Korean, and World War II memorials. The second day students and teachers were up bright and early to make their appointment at Ford's Theater, where a park ranger provided an overview of the site and the history of the building. They also visited the White House and Capitol Building.

Says Trevor: "A highlight for the students was our trip to the National Zoo. The kids absolutely lost their minds at the site of the Panda Bears. It was hilarious. It was as if they were seeing the Beatles or something."

The third day included a moving viewing of the changing of the guard at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. "The kids were blown away by the guards' absolute precision," recalls Trevor. Other treats included witnessing the Presidential motorcade whiz by just off the mall, seeing the Hope Diamond at the Natural History museum, being shocked at the damage a recent earthquake caused to the National Cathedral, and wonderful meals.
item.excerpt:encoded: The fifth grade enjoyed a non-stop tour of Washington, D.C., taking all the knowledge they gained about the government in social studies class and making it come alive while enjoying the sights and monuments of the nation's capital.

item.title: GPA Students Excel in National French Exam
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the sixth consecutive year, Grosse Pointe Academy middle school students, pictured with Middle School French teacher Amal El-Hosni, participated in the National French Contest Exam, with ten students receiving medals for their high scores and achievements. This 60-minute national examination is developed and managed by the American Association of Teachers of French. Its purpose is to help stimulate further interest in the teaching and learning of French as well as to help identify and reward student achievement.

Competing against middle school and high school students, the following Academy middle school students placed in the top 10 ranks both nationally and in the Metro Detroit Chapter: eighth grader and silver medal winner Abby Kuplicki (#2 national ranking and #1 local ranking), eighth grader and bronze medal winner Alexander Minanov (#4 national ranking and #2 local ranking), eighth grader and bronze medal winner Grace Drettmann (#4 national ranking and #2 local ranking), and seventh grader and silver medal winner Katie Fruehauf (#3 national ranking and #1 local ranking), Sixth graders were ranked only at the national level and the following students received bronze medals: Mira Hallock (#4 ranking); Karina Minanov (#5 ranking); Grace Andreasen (#5 ranking); Sophie Leslie (#6 ranking); Tommy Van Pelt (#6 ranking); and Tristan Shogren (#6 ranking).

Sara, who was nominated by her tennis coach, played at #3 singles and was the GPA Bulldog for the team. She is a scholar athlete, received high academic honors, and is on the citizenship and head of school honor rolls.

Robert, a two-year veteran on the varsity basketball and varsity lacrosse teams, was nominated by the coaches of both sports. Robert was co-captain and MVP of the lacrosse team. item.title: Fourth Graders Become Engineers
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Fourth grade students became engineers as part of a Force and Motion unit in science class. Their task was to create a blueprint, and they then had 20 minutes to build a vehicle that could move at least 100cm. They learned to work together and share ideas with one another. If their vehicle did not work, the class discussed what might have gone wrong and went back to the "drawing board" to try again. According to their teacher, Holly Willson, "All students were able to complete the task by the end of the period!"

Click here to see pictures.

item.title: Book Fair a Success!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
This year's Scholastic Book Fair, under the direction of co-chairs Heather Brundage and Kelley Smith, enjoyed sales of approximately $16,000 due to the generosity of our many parents, grandparents and special guests. Of this revenue, the school earned approximately $3,000 and increased sales by over 5% - a significant enough accomplishment that Scholastic awarded The Grosse Pointe Academy a sales growth bonus of $661. Also, thanks to the One for One Books program, in which Scholastic donated one book for every dollar that a student donated to the Book Fair, Scholastic will donate 750 books to a charity. Due to the program, the school also received an allowance of $750 for librarian Jane Baetens to purchase new books for the library, resulting in 45 new hard cover, high quality books for our students to enjoy in the years to come.

Volunteers came out in droves to help the hard-working co-chairs. "From set-up to tear-down and everything in between, we couldn't have done it without them!" said Heather. Many volunteers were present on multiple days. Thanks go to Alison Arkison, Debbie Bagby, Dorota Bamford, Michelle Becker, Karrie Bixler, Jen Bojarczyk, Elizabeth Bonev, Randi Brink, Mary Cantin, Carol Cinnamond, Nancy Cotton, Hagi Craig, Molly Donaldson, Jen Fauster, Jenny Fruehauf, Melissa Gray, Laura Gupte, Liz Homsy, Kim Kendrick, Yvette Korte, Amy Koskinen, Vesna Larrea, Wendy Maltby, Mary Alice Mecke, Carrie Paolucci, Susie Rahaim, Angela Randazzo, Julie Sheeren, Anita Valente, Celia Wade, Kelly Walsh and Karla Wortman.

item.title: Grade 3 Tours Historic Grosse Pointe
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Last Tuesday, the third graders embarked on a neighborhood historical tour. They explored the history of the Grosse Pointe area, beginning with the first inhabitants, the Native Americans. In addition, they discussed the development of the French and British, and finally the establishment of Michigan as a state and the village of Grosse Pointe. Highlighted among their discussions were Native American tribes, ribbon farms, the heritage of The Grosse Pointe Academy, and business development of the Grosse Pointes. The tour concluded at St. Paul's Cemetery.

The lion won in Mrs. Ahee's class and the zebra won in Ms. Baratta's class.

item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy students in grades 3-8 have the opportunity to join the Detroit Children's Choir. GPA's own Lauri Hogle, Grade 6-7 music teacher, has been named the Artistic Director of this new choir, which will meet from 1-2 p.m. Saturday afternoons at the DSO's Orchestra Hall, beginning December 8. Vocal development and tone, repertoire and music notation learning will be the key focus for this non-auditioned choir. The choir will combine with other DCC choirs in a mass choral spring concert on April 27, following workshop and rehearsal with Kris Johnson, a Kresge Fellow who is composing a commissioned work for the children to perform along with his renowned jazz ensemble.

In addition, the choir will be participating in a full-day workshop on January 19, being taught by four choral teachers from Singers of United Lands. Students will learn folk music from four countries. Students will learn folk music from four countries, which will be performed as a mass choir in the evening at the DSO prior to their concert.

The organization’s mission is to use the power and discipline of singing to bring together Detroit’s children in grades 3-8 – from urban and suburban communities, representing a wide range of ethnicities, religions and socio-economic levels – in a way that strengthens team building, creativity, social interaction, understanding, and connection.

For more information or to register for the new choir, please contact Lauri Hogle at lhogle@gpacademy.org.

item.title: GPA Grads Named AP Scholars
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe South High School announced its 2012 Advanced Placement Scholar Award winners. Among the 147 students recognized by The College Board for exceptional achievements on AP exams are eight Grosse Pointe Academy alumni.

Awards were based on several levels of achievement: National AP Scholars, AP Scholars with Distinction, AP Scholars with Honor and AP Scholars.

Receiving AP Scholar with Distinction honors, granted to students who receive an average score of at least 3.5 on all AP exams and score 3 or higher on five or more exams, are Somers Brush, Christopher Fowler, Conor Tily and Jeffrey Woolstrum.

Receiving AP Scholar with Honor Awards, available to students how receive an average score of at least 3.25 on all AP exams and score 30 or higher on four or more exams, is Alex Parker.

Receiving AP Scholar honors, awarded to students who receive scores of 3 or higher on three or more AP exams, are Henry Brophy, Elizabeth DiMauro and Giovanna Posselius.

item.title: Athletes of the Season Named
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The coaching staff at The Grosse Pointe Academy named Jyen-ai Jones, David Scupholm and Hannah Lemanski the Athletes of the Season for the fall of 2012. This award is based on athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship.

Eighth grader Jyen-ai Jones is a two-year veteran of the girls' varsity volleyball team and this year's Most Valuable Player. She also received awards as best digger (with an all-time record of 76 digs over two seasons) and best passer, and was named Team Bulldog.

Eighth grader David Scupholm was co-captain and Team Bulldog for the boys’ tennis team. A two-year veteran of the team, David played at #2 singles.

Seventh grader Hannah Lemanski, a three-year veteran on the cross country team, was co-captain and Most Valuable Runner. Her first place finish in the girls' race during the GPA cross country invitational on October 11 contributed to the team coming in second place overall.

item.title: Let Freedom Ring
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
A special assembly for grades 1-8 on Friday, January 18  opened with first grader Reggie Sharpe reciting Martin Luther King, Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech, at the end of which his fellow students leaped to their feet in a spontaneous standing ovation. Early and Lower School Principal Jen Kendall then introduced the morning's special guest, Dr. William G. Anderson, who has held many positions in hospitals and businesses and was the president of the American Osteopathic Association. Dr. Anderson, who is perhaps best known for his work in the civil rights movement, regaled the students, faculty and parents in the audience with stories of his days growing up in rural Georgia, his encounters and growing friendship with Dr. King, and his own role in the civil rights movement, from peaceful protests against discrimination and segregation to fighting for the right to vote.

Dr, Anderson is active in organizing a speaker series hosted by Michigan State University College of Osteopathic Medicine entitled: "Slavery to Freedom: An American Odyssey." Interested parents should click here for more information.

item.title: GPA Alumni Named Finalists in Math Competition
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Three Grosse Pointe Academy alumni were among twenty-one students from Grosse Pointe South High School who qualified as finalists in the 56th Annual Michigan Mathematics Prize Competition, an activity of the Michigan Section of the Mathematical Association of America.

Seniors Christopher Fowler, Conor Tily and Jeffrey Woolstrum were among the top 1,300 students in a pool of more than 6,400 from the 148 Michigan high schools who competed in Part I of the competition on October 2.

Finalists will now advance to Part II of the competition, which will take place on December 12. Part II consists of an exam with five problems, of which students provide written explanations for their claims and mathematical proofs of their results. From there, the top 100 combined scores from both parts are invited to an awards program on Saturday, March 2 at Hope College in Holland, Michigan, where approximately $20,000 in scholarships are awarded. Scholarships range from bronze awards ($250) to the gold medalist ($2,500).

item.title: Ringing in the Season
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Academy community gathered on the evening of December 4 to kick off the holiday season. The annual celebration began in the Tracy Fieldhouse with a performance by the Eighth Grade Bell Choir under the direction of music teacher Lauri Hogle, followed by a Christmas carol sing-a-long. The crowd then convened at the front of the school - a new venue this year - for the countdown to the lighting of two trees, one in front of the fieldhouse and the other in front of the Early School. Read more about the event in Mr. Kuelling's reflections.

On Thursday, Kindergarten students, with the help of Head of School Lars Kuelling, added a personal touch by trimming the Early School tree.

Other Christmas events over the week included the third grade's vocal performance at the Grosse Pointe War Memorial during the Ladies Christmas Luncheon, and the second grade Breakfast Club, during which students made gingerbread houses with their parents (see pictures on Flickr).

Twenty students from first through sixth grade, placed in teams of four, competed in three divisions, with each team completing five rounds of play. The GPA team placed in two of the three divisions, with the team of Evelyn Doan (grade 2), Alexander Kuplicki (grade 2), Alexandra Larrea (grade 1) and Bode Neumeister (grade 3) winning fifth place in the K-3 division, and the team of sixth graders Piero Cavataio, Adrian Doan, Adam Kuplicki and Thomas Wacker winning seventh place in the K-6 division.

There's no business like snow business, and in spite of snow, rain or sleet, the show must go on! Fourth and fifth graders presented their snow stopping musical, “Snow Biz” on Thursday night. item.title: First Graders Journey Under the Sea
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: As the culminating activity for their study of sea life this winter, the first graders gave a special performance for parents and Early School students on February 12. Each student selected a sea creature to research and prepare a written report. During the presentation, the students displayed the three-dimensional sea creatures they had made in art class with Mrs. Baudeloque. They introduced themselves and their creatures in French using the vocabulary they learned in class with Mme Leslie, then created an underwater effect with the creatures “swimming” under black light to the music of “The Aquarium,” by French composer Camille Saint Saens. item.title: Eighth Grader Named Michigan National Geo Bee Semifinalist
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the second consecutive year, eighth grader Sam Durno was named one of the semifinalists eligible to compete in the 2013 Michigan National Geographic Bee, sponsored by Google and Plum Creek. This is the 25th anniversary of the Bee.

Bees were held in schools with fourth through eighth grade students throughout the state to determine each school's Bee winner. School-level winners then took a qualifying test, which they submitted to the National Geographic Society. In each of the 50 states, as well as the District of Columbia, the Department of Defense Dependents Schools, and the U.S. territories, the National Geographic Society invited the students with the top 100 scores to compete at the state level.

The 2013 Michigan National Geographic Bee will be held at the Fetzer Center at Western Michigan University on Friday, April 5, 2013.

The state winner will receive $100, the "Complete National Geographic on DVD," and a trip to Washington, D.C., where he or she will represent Michigan in the national finals at National Geographic Society headquarters, May 20-22, 2013. The first-place national winner will receive a $25,000 college scholarship and lifetime membership in the Society. The national winner will also travel (along with one parent or guardian), all expenses paid, to the Galapagos Islands to experience geography firsthand through up-close encounters with the wildlife and landscape of Galapagos.

National Geographic Channel and Nat Geo Wild will air the final round of the 2013 National Geographic Bee, moderated by Alex Trebek, on Thursday, May 23 (to be followed on public television stations).

Over 1,500 students from schools in Macomb, Oakland and Wayne Counties competed. The students submitted their projects in the Junior Division (for sixth, seventh and eighth grade) within one of 13 categories based on scientific discipline. Once again, the efforts of the GPA students yielded tremendous results, with eighteen GPA students awarded sixth place or higher.

Receiving a gold ribbon for second place were Lindsey Martin and Karina Minanov. Receiving a gold ribbon for third place were Ian Homsy and Sophie Leslie.  Blue ribbons for outstanding projects were awarded to Brittinie Hughes, Spencer Warezak and Kennedi Cosma.  Recognized with green ribbons for excellent projects were Brad Bixler, Morgan Connell, Nicholas Connell, Alex Johnson, Tate Kuelling, Hannah Lemanski, James McCuish, Tristan Shogren, and Joseph Spica. Charlie Fruehauf and Cameron Turner each received an honorable mention.

Grace Andreasen and Tommy Van Pelt are competing in the Google Science Fair in April.

Pictured with Mrs. Jerome are the top four winners, from left: Sophie Leslie (third place), Lindsay Martin (second place), Ian Homsy (third place), and Karina Minanov (second place).

item.title: GPA Art Teacher Named Diversity Champion
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Art teacher Rosi Triano was named Diversity Champion by the Race Relations Diversity Task Force of Metropolitan Detroit. Rosi's enormous heart and open mind are legendary at The Grosse Pointe Academy. She has championed the Diversity Committee for GPA for many years and was the Chairwoman for the Association of Independent Michigan Schools Diversity Committee for two years. She remains a vital member of that committee, and was instrumental in bringing the Middle School Diversity Symposium, hosted every year by the Southeast Michigan Diversity Committee, to The Grosse Pointe Academy on April 16.

Additionally, Rosi volunteers her time in the Junior League of Detroit, Metropolitan Detroit Teen Conference, now called Giant Step, and serves as a school board member for Legacy Academy in Detroit. Rosi is committed to widening the artistic opportunities for minority youth throughout the metropolitan area.

Rosi will be honored along with other champions at a breakfast hosted at the Birmingham Community House at 8 a.m. on April 25.

item.title: Academy Students Bring Home Trophies in China Quiz Bowl
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday, April 13, fifteen Academy middle school students, along with GPA Chinese teacher, Shanyi Chen, headed to L’Anse Creuse High School North in Macomb to participate in the fifth annual Michigan China Quiz Bowl, sponsored by The Confucius Institute at Wayne State University.

The competition featured quiz bowl style questions that pertain to Mandarin language learning and Chinese geography. Non-heritage Chinese language learners competed in first- through third-year middle school divisions and first- through fourth-year high school divisions.

The Grosse Pointe Academy was represented by four teams competing in the middle school division. Winning first place in the third year middle school division were eighth graders Carly Demkowicz (team captain), Jyen-ai Jones and Rae Anne Woodman.

Winning second place in the third year division were Gabby Cavataio (team captain), Megan McCarren and Hailey McDonald. Winning second place in the second year division were Nicholas Connell (team captain), Ian Homsy, James McCuish and Spencer Warezak. Earning third place honors in the first year division were sixth graders Adam Kuplicki (captain), Piero Cavataio, Adrian Doan, Brandon Murphy and Winston Wright.
 
“The Michigan China Quiz Bowl has served as an enjoyable venue to motivate, recognize and celebrate Michigan students and their accomplishments,” said John Brender, director of Wayne State’s Confucius Institute. “Last year, we hosted 262 students from 17 schools, more than tripling the number of participants who joined us five years ago.”

Pictured with Grosse Pointe Academy Chinese teacher Shanyi Chen are, from left, first place winners Jyen-ai Jones, Carly Demkowicz (team captain), and Rae Anne Woodman.

item.title: GPA Hosts Middle School Diversity Symposium
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy hosted the Southeast Michigan Diversity Committee's Middle School Diversity Symposium, "Initiatives in Diversity: Facing and Finding Yourself in a Digital World," on Tuesday, April 16. A total of 67 students from GPA, Academy of the Sacred Heart, Eton Academy, Roeper and Cranbrook attended. Representing the Academy at the symposium were sixth graders Adrian Doan, Johnnae Curry, Brandon Murphy, and Emma Wujek, and seventh graders Grace Andreasen, Sophie Leslie, Tristan Shogren and Tommy Van Pelt.

Two of the sessions were run by high school students from Roeper and Cranbrook. Following registration and an icebreaker at 9 a.m., participants were assigned to a group to rotate through the following sessions: Session 1 - Looking Inward - What makes you unique? Session 2 - Influence and the Media: How does media shape and influence your identity? Session 3 - Citizenship and Community: How can you make a difference in your community? and Session 4 - Expression: Fishbowl and Evaluations.

GPA art teacher Rosi Triano is a member of the SEMDC and served as its chair for two years. She was instrumental in bringing the symposium to GPA.

The Association of Independent Michigan Schools (AIMS) is a non-profit organization of primary, elementary, and secondary schools whose purpose is to support and advance independent education in Michigan. The AIMS Southeast Michigan Diversity Committee (SEMDC) is a consortium of representatives from member schools whose focus it to promote professional development and education for faculty, staff, administrators and students in the area of equity, justice, multicultural education and diversity. The SEMDC plans and offers workshops and symposiums to faculty, staff and student constituents.

item.title: All the Places You'll Go!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Tracy Fieldhouse will be transformed over the weekend and early next week as final preparations are underway for this year's annual Action Auction, which takes place on Wednesday, May 8 and Saturday, May 11.

Working with the theme "All the Places You'll Go!" - a take-off on the Dr. Seuss book of similar name - Auction chairs Michelle and Chuck Becker and Sandra and Peter Cavataio have built a wonderful catalog of items for the Auction. This theme not only represents the wide range of opportunities available to Academy students while at the school and throughout their journey to adulthood, but also the fantastic places you can go from the Auction.

Fabulous trips are really the center point of this year’s offerings. All the places you will go include Paris, Hawaii, Bay Harbor, Orlando, Mackinac Island, Nashville, Germany and more. Although, with hundreds of items up for bidding, such as parties, home accessories, toys, student projects, and cultural and sporting event tickets, there is a wide variety of items available each night of the event to appeal to many tastes, interests, and budgets.

The paddle raising during the Live Auction will raise funds to support student innovation programs. The creation of an innovation and design center will focus on developing students’ interest and excitement in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). These programs will extend our current classroom experience to encourage new discovery and creativity

Back by popular demand, Neiman Marcus Club Action Auction will round out the evening on Saturday with a night-club atmosphere right in the Fieldhouse. Guests will dance the night away with music from DJ Prevu and world percussionist Jared Sykes.

All of the Academy and Metro Detroit community is invited to join us for Action Auction 2013 to help us support The Grosse Pointe Academy. Reservations are being taken online and at the door. For more information about Action Auction or to reserve your tickets, please go to www.academyactionauction.org or call 313.886.1221 ext. 182.

item.title: Discover Summer Camps at the Academy
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy is offering an array of camps this summer that are open to the community, from cooking to robotics to a variety of sports camps.

For the very youngest campers (ages 3-8), there is arts and crafts and a Junior Chefs Cooking Camp. Older campers ages 9-12 who enjoy art may choose “Art at the Academy,” an arts camp with a different focus (clay, jewelry or drawing) each week.

Students entering grades 4-8 may select “Eat Your Words,” a two-week class that focuses on writing and cooking, or the GPA LEGO Mindstorms Robotics Camp, a one-week camp that introduces campers to the LEGO Mindstorms NXT robotics system and NXT programming language. After creating basic robots, teams will be challenged to design new robots of their own design and creativity.

Also for this age group is the No Code Web Design and Video Movie Making camp taught by GPA’s Technology and Learning Specialist, Megan Black.

For Francophiles ages 5-8, there is a French Language Camp taught by GPA’s French teacher, Madame Leslie. In this week-long camp, children will experience Francophone culture and speak French. Class activities include storytelling, singing, dancing, drawing, crafts, counting, and playing interactive games with other children.

Studies indicate that learning to play chess can have a positive effect on a child's academic achievement by helping students organize their thoughts, plan ahead, think strategically and stay focused. In the week-long GPA chess camp, instructors from All the King’s Men will teach children strategies to improve their game.

Camp Invention is a weeklong summer adventure of fun and exciting real world challenges led by qualified educators. Students entering grades 1-6 will discover creativity and inventiveness through hands-on, creative problem-solving activities. Go to campinvention.org to register.

Math Camp under director Wendy Jerome, GPA’s middle school math teacher, is a two week math review to prepare students for the upcoming year. Students can expect to review material, strengthen skills, and extend themselves. Students who take this class come into the first days of school confident and ready for new material.

Sports camps at GPA include tennis clinics for children ages 5-14 with certified USPTA instructor Cheryl Carroll. The Little Stars/Future Stars program is designed for the beginner to intermediate player ages 5-10. The Junior Development program is geared toward the intermediate to advanced player ages 11 and older.

J&J Summer Basketball Camp with directors Jaye Hill and Jesse Jamerson offers instruction for the most advanced middle school player to the player who is just learning the game. This camp will include leadership workshops and quality instruction in all aspects of the game. Ray Scott, former Detroit Pistons player, will make a special appearance.

313 Lacrosse Camp for boys grades 2-8, under director Ken Brubaker (“Coach B”), will be an intense training experience for players looking to challenge themselves and learn cutting edge techniques and skills through concentrated training on the field. A highly qualified staff of professional, college and high school coaches will use the 313 MPDS (modern player development system) to train and coach all players.

Private, semi-private and group tennis lessons and lacrosse instruction will also be available. Contact the individual instructors for details.

Click here for or a detailed brochure that includes a schedule of dates and times and a registration form or call 313.886.1221.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Grosse Pointe Academy is offering an array of camps this summer that are open to the community, from cooking to robotics to a variety of sports camps.

item.title: Butterflies Fly Free!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The rain held off this morning just long enough for Mrs. Varty and Miss Kate's Early School students to release the butterflies they have been raising for the past ten days. After the larvae arrived, the children were able to observe them as they made their metamorphosis from larva to chrysalis to butterfly.

"None of them came at the same time, which was exciting," said Peggy Varty. "One came out yesterday morning when we arrived at school, then one came out during morning work, one at lunchtime, one in afternoon kindergarten, and the last one we discovered when we got to school this morning."

The students were thrilled to see their butterflies take flight! "It is such an exciting process for all of the students to be a part of," said Kate Kingsley.

Click here to see pictures on Flickr.

item.title: Sixth Grade Hosts Medieval Banquet
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The sixth grade's annual study of the middle ages in social studies class culminated this week with two events. On Thursday, the students simulated the life of a monk during Monk Day, spending half the day in the Lakeshore Boardroom and the Chapel. Activities included taking a vow of silence, praying, and illuminating the manuscript of poetry they had written in language arts class. During the second half of the school day, students recited their poetry manuscripts during a Poetry Cafe held in the lower gym.

On Friday, the class hosted the annual Medieval Banquet in the Lakeshore Parlor decorated with family crests and other artwork. The grand entrance of the royal court and guests was followed up with a knighthood ceremony, judgments, and a variety of entertainment. Between events parent volunteers served courses of bread and soup; chicken, roast potatoes, corn and baby carrots; and a final course of dessert. Entertainers included musicians, dancers, jesters, comedians, magicians and a dream-minstrel.

A visiting delegation from China enlightened attendees with stories and myths from their faraway land while the French delegation delighted guests with a dance and song titled Jean Petit. The banquet concluded with a performance by the royal dance troupe.

Click to see pictures of Monk Day and the Medieval Banquet.

item.title: GPA Alumna Selected as Challenge Detroit Fellow
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy alumna Sarah Somes is enjoying the opportunity of a lifetime. She has been selected by Challenge Detroit, a leadership and professional program, as one of 33 Fellows invited to live, work, play and give in and around the greater Detroit area for one year. Sarah was hired by Edw. C. Levy Co., a conglomerate whose focus is to help preserve our world through an advanced practice of environmental stewardship, recycling materials, employee safety, and customer satisfaction.

In addition to being hired by one of the participating companies, each Challenge Detroit Fellow has the opportunity to participate in monthly team challenges designed to positively impact the city and region. In addition, each Friday participants work in teams organized to generate innovative and impactful solutions to pressing needs faced by partner non-profit organizations.

Over 700 applications from across the country were narrowed down to 70 finalists. Finalists attended a two-day event to interview with the companies, participate in a mini team challenge, and experience the city.

Sarah said she applied for Challenge Detroit because she knew throughout her college years that she wanted to become a part of the efforts that are currently creating a momentum towards a better future for Detroit. She also felt that the program would help her discover the best way for her to understand and give back to the communities within the city that have endured.

“My favorite part about applying for Challenge Detroit was the final interview process,” Sarah said. “The energy and enthusiasm among all of the people present was contagious. I met many motivational and exciting people in those two days whom I look forward to working with and sharing our excitement about the city. There was an undeniable positive energy among everyone that left us all excited to call Detroit our home.”

Sarah graduated from the College of Charleston in the spring of 2013 with a Bachelor of Arts in Urban Studies with a concentration in Urban Planning. She was a 2013 Scholar, School of the Humanities and Social Science, 2013 Outstanding Minor, School of Business, and three-time recipient of a Scholar Athlete Award. As captain of the College of Charleston Sailing Team, she was a Finalist for the J. Stuart Walker Trophy for outstanding athletic, academic and leadership achievements in both 2012 and 2013 and was the 2011 Sailing MVP.

A 2009 graduate of Grosse Pointe South, where she was a member of the cross country team for two years and the sailing team for four years as well as team captain, Sarah attributes much of her academic and athletic success to the foundation she received at The Grosse Pointe Academy.

“One of the greatest things the Academy did for me was rebuild my confidence and enhance my learning skills,” Sarah said. “After I struggled for my first three years of grade school, my parents transferred me for fourth grade to the Academy, where they knew I would be given the extra care and help I needed to improve. Through tutoring and extra guidance I strengthened my academic abilities. Not only did the Academy offer me the opportunity to catch up and excel, but my teachers were incredibly supportive and instrumental in reviving my confidence and skills.”

Sarah’s involvement in Academy athletics contributed to her later successes in high school and college and played a major role in developing her team bonding and leadership skills as well as goal-oriented drive for success.

“I participated in every sport available at the Academy and over the years it has helped me better communicate with my peers as well as create a well-rounded understanding of teamwork, dedication, time management, organizational skills and leadership.”

These are all skills that Sarah is sure to apply to her work at Edward C. Levy Co. and her year-long contributions to Challenge Detroit. As for her future beyond the Fellowship, Sarah envisions continuing to live downtown and work in the city.

“I want to be more involved in urban development and planning as well as to volunteer within the communities,” she said. “ I grew up loving Detroit and now I’d like to call it my home.”

item.title: Middle School Students Excel in National French Exam
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the seventh consecutive year, Grosse Pointe Academy middle school students participated in the National French Exam (also known as Le Grand Concours), with 14 students receiving medals for their high scores and achievements. This 60-minute national examination is developed and managed by the American Association of Teachers of French. Its purpose is to help stimulate further interest in the teaching and learning of French as well as to help identify and reward student achievement.

The exam is a multiple-choice test of approximately 70 items covering listening comprehension, vocabulary, grammar and reading comprehension. Students took the test that was appropriate for the French curriculum in which they are enrolled. Their scores were then ranked against students locally as well as nationally who are enrolled in similar curricula.

"I was exceptionally pleased this year with the accomplishments of all of my students," said middle school French teacher Amal El-Hosni. "I was also happy to see that many of our graduates have gone on to excel in the test in their respective high schools."

Competing against middle school and high school students, eighth grader Katie Fruehauf received a gold medal and #1 ranking both nationally and locally. The following eighth graders received bronze medals: Stephanie Vermet (#4 national ranking and #2 local ranking), Therese Drettmann (#5 ranking both nationally and locally), Markus Minanov (#5 ranking both nationally and locally), and Antonina Cinnamond (#6 ranking both nationally and locally).

Seventh grader Karina Minanov, who was ranked #1 in metro Detroit and 3rd nationally, received a silver medal. The following seventh graders received bronze medals: Grace Andreasen (#5 nationally and #3 locally), Tommy Van Pelt (#5 nationally and #3 locally), Charlie Fruehauf (#6 nationally and #4 locally), Tristan Shogren (#7 nationally and #5 locally), and Sophie Leslie (#8 nationally and #6 locally).

Sixth graders were ranked only at the national level and the following students received bronze medals: Samantha Savage (#4 nationally), Henry Whitaker (#5 nationally), and Thomas Wacker (#7 nationally).

item.title: How Do You Say
