item.title: Students Catch the Spirit of Service
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the thirteenth consecutive year, Academy first through fifth graders participated in the CATCH Fun Run to benefit the CATCH (Caring Athletes Team for Children's and Henry Ford Hospitals) organization. Click here for photos!


"This is a great way for our children to participate in a fun and healthy event while learning the spirit of giving back to the community," said Sasha Murphy, Community Service Coordinator.

This year the students raised $4,485, a record amount due to matching gifts by generous donors in the community. Judge Lisa Neilson and Jeffrey T. Neilson, Dr. Robert Beck, Jeffery Parsigian and Truckspring.com all stepped up to match the students' contributions. Special thanks go to the Warezak family for their efforts on behalf of GPA and CATCH.

Present to receive the ceremonial check, signed by each of the students, was Jim Hughes, Executive Director of CATCH, who has attended GPA's fun run for over a dozen years.

Middle School students Spencer Warezak and Tai Daniels will both serve as emcees at this year's CATCH Night of Champions event.

Since 1987, CATCH dollars from special events and donations have facilitated a steady stream of items and services that help improve the quality of life for thousands of needy children, as well as growing the charity's "board-designated endowment fun" to ensure assistance for future generations. The charity "catches" children whose special needs might otherwise fall through the cracks.

These special humanitarian items and services, which would otherwise not be funded, include speech language therapy for children with autism and developmental disorders, vision exams and glasses, adaptive toys for children with limited use of limbs, wheelchair lifts, tutors and computers for children who have had prolonged hospitalizations, interpreters and home-based therapy equipment.

item.title: A New Perspective on Art
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Art teacher Holly Kristan presented her eighth grade students with a challenge in art class on October 1. Given six works of art to examine, they were to rank them for the following: which they would like to have in their own homes, which was most likely to sell for a lot of money, which took the longest to paint, which was most likely to win a prize, which was their favorite, and which they did not like at all. They then compared their total scores to the reality of the paintings, which challenged their perceptions of art. For example, the painting the students liked least won England's Turner prize; and a work of art by Willem de Kooning the students thought looked like a scribble was the third highest selling artwork at auction.
item.excerpt:encoded: Art teacher Holly Kristan presented her eighth grade students with a challenge in art class on October 1.

item.title: GPA Breaks Ground for Garden Classroom
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy community gathered on Monday morning for a ceremonial groundbreaking of the garden classroom. All students from Early School through grade 8 were present to listen to remarks by Head of School Lars Kuelling and Board President John Murphy. Student Council President Kennedi Cosma gave the dedication. Students representing each grade level participated in the groundbreaking. The ceremony concluded with an all-school photo.

The groundbreaking was followed by a ribbon-cutting ceremony for the Innovation Design Center. All Intermediate School (Grades 4-5) students were present along with their teachers, Mr. Kuelling and Intermediate and Middle School Principal Lawrence DeLuca. Fourth grader Charlie Janovsky did the honors of cutting the ribbon.

All students went home at the end of the day with a seed packet as a reminder of the special growth that will take place not just in the garden classroom, but with each individual GPA child this year. The seed packet contained a special message in remembrance of the day: "to nurture... to inspire... to challenge" that is particularly meaningful to the Academy experience.

Click here to see pictures from these two very special events.

item.title: A Second Grade Whodunnit
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Second graders in Mrs. Ahee's classroom were charged with investigating a crime when they discovered candy was missing in their classroom. First they identified four likely suspects who had been seen in the vicinity during the time frame the crime took place. They asked all the right questions they had learned in class: Who, What, Where and Why. They helped Detective Rosati and Officer Puckett, special visitors from the Grosse Pointe Farms Safety Department, dust for fingerprints to see if they could find a match. The students also questioned each of the suspects. Finally, they identified the perpetrator! Click here to solve the mystery.

item.title: McMillan Lecturer Offers Tips for Technology
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy had the pleasure of hosting this year's McMillan Lecturer, Dr. Larry Rosen, on the evening of November 12. Prior to his talk on "Understanding Our Obsession with Technology and Protecting Our Humanware," Dr. Rosen met with teachers to discuss strategies for the successful implementation of technology as an instructional tool within a classroom setting.

 


“Dr. Rosen’s studies and insights on our fast changing world are important for us to ponder,” said third grade teacher Jeanette Stepanek. “It is crucial to realize how technology can change our family and friend relationships. As we recognize what is happening, we can better the learning environment and social relationships in education and the world. Making the world a better place to live is what it is all about.”

Dr. Rosen touched upon the importance of resting the mind, citing one way to do so by going outdoors and enjoying nature. Said Jeanette: "It is reassuring to confirm that going outside and being surrounded by nature can calm and reset us to charge ahead. The GPA's beautiful campus is the ideal setting for educating!"

Dr. Rosen (center) is pictured above with Thayer McMillan (on left) and Head of School Lars Kuelling.

* * *

The William Charles McMillan III Lecture Series is a gift from Thayer and Gioconda McMillan given in memory of William in the interest of emphasizing the importance of elementary education.

item.title: Middle School Electives Kick Off
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Friday, December 13, Middle School students experienced their first taste of electives, which will meet once a month from now through the spring for a total of five sessions. Students chose from a variety of options, many of which will include visits out in the field for real world experiences.

In Application Design with Mr. Rochte, students designed and created their own application for use on tablets and smartphones. Students will learn programming and visit programmers in the field.



Mrs. Hogle will take her students to a classical concert at the Detroit Symphony Orchestra as part of the Marketing Program Design elective. Students will create a marketing plan to develop a specific marketing program for classical music for the target audience of middle and high school students.

In CSI with Mrs. Jerome and Mrs. Roberts, students will learn crime scene analysis techniques. In the first session, for example, students learned about finger printing and examined their own fingerprints! Students will meet with a crime lab scientist and may even visit an active crime lab.


In Moot Court with Madame El-Hosni, Mrs. Kristan and Mrs. Whitaker, students will learn the art of debate, rules of presenting arguments, rebuttal, problem-solving and impromptu response. They will debate their own issue and visit a courthouse.

Leadership is the focus of two electives. In Team Leadership in the 21st Century with Mr. Cowan, students will examine the varied elements of leadership, including qualities of leadership, listening, conflict management and risk taking. Students will create leadership opportunities for their peers and visit local government offices.

In Service Discovery with Mrs. Patton, students will research and visit local and national non-profit organizations in detail, ultimately selecting a community based organization and devising and implementing a community based service project.

Students may also explore their social conscience in Teach Green with Sasha Murphy. The students will research topics such as water pollution, air pollution and recycling in order to create and implement "green" lessons for the school. They will also visit a green company.

Mr. DeLuca began his Investigative Reporting/Video Production elective with a visit from M.L. Elrick, a Pulitzer Prize and Emmy Award winning investigative reporter with Fox 2 News. Mr. Elrick talked about the importance of reporting to create awareness and then effect a change. He distinguished investigative reporting from other news types not as "negative news," but as a positive step in bringing awareness to an issue that needs to be resolved.


"When I look for a story, I look for something that's broken," he said to the students. By reporting the story, he gives people "the opportunity to make changes, to make improvements."

"Our job is simple," Mr. Elrick explained. "We ask questions, we get answers, and then we let you guys decide."

item.title: Students Demonstrate Use of iPads
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Parents of students in grades 4-8 were invited to learn more about uses of the iPad in classrooms as part of the Middle School’s implementation of GPA's one-to-one iPad program. The informative night on Thursday, January 16 featured a variety of student presentations.


Middle school students demonstrated to parents features of technology that have been particularly beneficial to them, resulting in a personalized approach to instruction, increased engagement, integration of subjects across a variety of disciplines, and ease of collaboration through Google docs.

For example, according to one student, use of the program Wordly Wise makes learning vocabulary and diagramming grammar "fun". Google docs allows students to share documents, and other apps help with organization and note-taking. A presentation for language arts class on The Outsiders using Pic Collage showed how students incorporate creativity into their presentations. In addition, completing the sixth grade leaf project on the iPad allowed the students to collect more than just leaves as they included pictures of the bark as well as the entire tree itself, serving as a much more effective reference guide.

Other highlights included sixth grade students showing their interactive biology ebook, Josh Roberts and Brandon Murphy "demo-ing" the apps they created in Mr. Rochte's elective, and Samantha Savage demonstrating examples from her Educreations App where she made a video with her voice-over explaining various grammar rules.

Discussion ensued on the "flipped classroom" in mathematics classes, with some students mentioning use of the Khan Academy's on-line classes and others discussing math teacher Wendy Jerome's pre-recorded video lectures. Students observed that the “flipped” approach allowed them to watch lectures at home, then practice at school, versus the traditional approach of hearing lectures at school and practicing (i.e., doing homework) at home without the benefit of the teacher's presence when encountering obstacles.

Said Lars Kuelling about this innovative approach: "This is a bit like an NFL quarterback watching game film and studying that week's offensive playbook, then coming to practice ready to play. Now the teacher gets to coach the student in real time, and students can only benefit from the personalized practice."

The use of iPads has also been beneficial as an assessment tool with the use of the "Socratic Classroom" app, allowing teachers to engage every student, assess his or her understanding, and give immediate feedback. Mike Cowan, Social Studies and English faculty member, described his joy at seeing every student in the class engaged in learning and praised the approach for allowing him to solicit an answer from each student in class, not just those industrious students who are quick to raise a hand in response to a question.

Special thanks go to middle school students (pictured above from left): Josh Roberts, Brandon Murphy, Maria Fields, Samantha Savage, Hannah Lemanski, and Tate Kuelling for their participation, and to Megan Black, Mike Cowan, and Lawrence DeLuca for leading the presentation.
item.excerpt:encoded: Parents of students in grades 4-8 were invited to learn more about uses of the iPad in classrooms as part of GPA's one-to-one iPad program. The informative night on Thursday, January 16 featured a variety of student presentations.

item.title: The Benefits of a K-8 School
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Does it benefit my child to keep them at GPA through eighth grade? YES. A study reported in Ed: The Magazine of the Harvard Graduate School of Education makes a convincing argument for the benefits of a K-8 school versus a stand-alone middle school. Their research found that students who left elementary schools for middle schools in grades 6 or 7 "lose ground in both reading and math compared to their peers who attend K-8 schools."

Clinical psychologist and author Michael Thompson supports this study in his book Best Friends, Worst Enemies: Understanding the Social Lives of Children. He states: "If I could design psychologically safe schools, every elementary school in America would go from K-grade 8 and would be no larger than 400 children."

GPA's middle school principal Lawrence DeLuca is in full agreement. "A K-8 environment provides many advantages beyond improving academic performance. Students experience fewer transitions, they develop long-term relationships with teachers and other students, and there is an opportunity for cross-age tutoring and role modeling under one roof. For example, our buddy program helps the first graders feel comfortable in their new environment while giving the eighth graders the opportunity to act as leaders and role models."

Click here to find out more about the Academy's middle school.

item.title: GPA Students Earn Scholastic Art Awards

item.content:encoded:
When eighth grader Grace Andreasen went to the 2014 Southeastern Michigan Scholastic Art & Writing Awards Ceremony on Wednesday, February 12, she did not expect to run into her big buddy from GPA. Four years ago, when Grace Andreasen was in fourth grade, she was matched up with Carmella Goree '11 as her seventh grade buddy. The two reunited at the Detroit Film Theater at the DIA, where they each received Scholastic Art awards. Grace received an Honorable Mention in Printmaking, and Carmella received a Gold Key in Photography.

Receiving a Silver Key in Printmaking was eighth grader Hannah Lemanski. Hannah's Quilt Reduction Print was featured in GPA's art show invitation. The art show is scheduled for Tuesday, March 4 from 3:30 to 8:00 p.m.


Also receiving awards were former GPA art students and alumni Kate Krueger '10 and Kate Van Pelt '10. Kate Krueger received an Honorable Mention in Painting and Kate Van Pelt received a Gold Key in Digital Art. One of Kate Van Pelt's pieces featured a gingko leaf - of particular interest to anyone who remembers the sixth grade leaf project!

Hannah and Grace are pictured above with their art teacher, Holly Kristan.

item.title: Electives Bring Real World Experiences
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Middle School electives continue to bring real world experience and applied learning to sixth, seventh and eighth graders at The Grosse Pointe Academy. On Friday students attended their third session of electives.

In Mr. Cowan's team leadership elective, Grosse Pointe Farms Mayor Jim Farquar spoke about the role of the mayor and city council.

In Sasha Murphy's Teach Green Time elective, students taught the second graders different ways to be more energy efficient. The second graders were divided into two groups. They learned how to make a garden out of used plastic bottles, they listed ways they can be less wasteful, read a story about the life of a plastic bottle, and played a memory card game with pictures of animals.

In CSI with Mrs. Jerome and Mrs. Roberts, students prepared for their DNA analysis on the new electrophoresis machine by learning how to pipette, and in Application Design with Mr. Rochte, students continued work on creating their own computer apps. For example, eighth grader Brad Bixler created an app for the computer called Unique Turtle, which is programmed to create unique designs (see example below).


Students in the moot court elective were fortunate to have two parents lawyers visit. Mrs. Fields (mother of Maria, grade 6) and Mrs. Johnson (mother of Alex, grade 8) listened, guided and helped students prepare their arguments on oppositing sides of the debate.

Said Amal El-Hosni: "The students were excited to have real life professionals in the field share their time and expertise with the group." Next month, the moot court team will visit an appellate court in downtown Detroit and have a chance to meet and talk with Judge Murray in his chambers.

Click here to view pictures.

item.title: R.E.A.L. Classes Offer Real World Experiences
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
This month's R.E.A.L. (Real-World Experiences and Applied Learning) classes for middle school students got the students and teachers out of their classrooms and into the field for real life exposure to their chosen areas of interest.


In Investigative Reporting and Video Production, Mr. DeLuca and his students visited WDIV Channel 4, where executive producer and GPA graduate Tim French gave them a tour of the Newsroom, Studio, Control Room and Master Control. One of the highlights was meeting Emmy award winning meteorologist Andrew Humphrey, who explained how he produces his weather reports and spoke with the students about the importance of finding a career about which you are passionate.


The Moot Court R.E.A.L class travelled with Madame El-Hosni, Mrs. Kristan and Mrs. Whitaker to the District I location of the Michigan Court of Appeals and met with Judge Christopher Murray, husband of GPA third grade teacher Bridgette Murray. Judge Murray discussed how the Court of Appeals functions, accompanied the students to view the Court of Appeals in session, and graciously answered student questions. The students especially enjoyed hearing live arguments regarding two criminal cases and one civil case. Said Holly Kristan about the experience: "This was quite a privilege for our students, and we sincerely thank Judge Murray for this wonderful opportunity."


Mrs. Patton's Service Discovery group, along with GPA fourth graders, packed 300 food bags for children at Gleaner's.

Back at GPA, the Teach Green group built a hamster house, submarine, Frisbee,  cars and ships out of recycled items., Mr. Cowan's Leadership team, having already enjoyed a visit from a military leader and a government leader, learned about unconventional leaders, and students in Mr. Rochte's Application Design continued to design apps for use on tablets and smartphones.

item.title: GPA EdCamp
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Teachers at GPA are constantly learning and improving, and who better for them to learn from than other teachers? After school on Wednesday afternoon, teachers led or attended a series of mini-clinics on technology. A total of 17 presentations ranged from the "Flipped Classroom" by middle school math and science teacher Wendy Jerome to the use of Evernote for student portfolios on the iPad and computer by Early School teacher Peggy Varty.


"I don't know of another K-8 school that is doing this sort of thing," said Technology and Learning Specialist Megan Black, who organized this cutting-edge professional development session. "We will definitely be able to serve as a model for some of our fellow AIMS schools as they look to implement their own tablet programs or follow our lead in moving to a 1-to-1 iPad program. It shows how far we have come in less than two years."

Pictured above: Given the proliferation of infographics, visual literacy is one of the most prized skills needed in the current market place. Fourth grade teacher Didi DeBoer shows fifth grade teacher Holly Willson (and middle school teacher Michelle Roberts, not pictured) how students can create charts and graphs on the iPad in a jiffy.

item.title: Class size matters... a lot
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
With student-teacher ratios ranging from 8:1 in the Early School to 10:1 in Grades 1 through 8, The Grosse Pointe Academy boasts some of southeast Michigan’s smallest class sizes for elementary-school students. 

And for good reason. Research shows that class size is an important determinant of student outcomes.

In fact, a study released in 2014 and published by the University of Colorado Boulder noted that just a few years ago the average United States class size for public primary school teachers in self-contained classes was 21.6 and that the “evidence suggests that increasing class size will harm not only children’s test scores in the short run but also their long-term human capital formation.”

An article first published in The Washington Post and available below summarized and discussed the findings of this research from UCB's National Education Policy Center.

The actual study, published as a policy brief, is available here in its entirety.

To request an appointment or for further information on the Academy’s academic offerings, please fill out our Online Admissions Inquiry form or contact Admissions Director Molly McDermott at 313-886-1221, ext. 146. E-mail: mmcdermott@gpacademy.org. 

Class size matters a lot, research shows

By Valerie Strauss, The Washington Post 

Every now and then someone in education policy (Arne Duncan) or education philanthropy (Bill Gates) or the media (Malcolm Gladwell) will say something about why class size isn’t really very important because a great teacher can handle a boatload of kids.

Not really.

A review of the major research that has been conducted on class size by Northwestern University Associate Professor Diane Whitmore Schanzenbach and published by the National Education Policy Center at the University of Colorado Boulder makes clear that class size matters, and it matters a lot. Schanzanbach, an associate professor of human development and social policy at Northwestern and chair of the Institute for Policy Research’s Program on Child, Adolescent, and Family Studies, writes in the review:

Considering the body of research as a whole, the following policy recommendations emerge:

• Class size is an important determinant of student outcomes, and one that can be directly determined by policy. All else being equal, increasing class sizes will harm student outcomes.

• The evidence suggests that increasing class size will harm not only children’s test scores in the short run, but also their long-run human capital formation. Money saved today by increasing class sizes will result in more substantial social and educational costs in the future.

• The payoff from class-size reduction is greater for low-income and minority children, while any increases in class size will likely be most harmful to these populations.

• Policymakers should carefully weigh the efficacy of class-size policy against other potential uses of funds. While lower class size has a demonstrable cost, it may prove the more cost-effective policy overall.

Why do small classes work? She writes:

The mechanisms at work linking small classes to higher achievement include a mixture of higher levels of student engagement, increased time on task, and the opportunity small classes provide for high-quality teachers to better tailor their instruction to the students in the class.

The research is there. Class size matters. Even the finest teachers are limited in what they can do when they have large classes.

So can we stop pretending that class size doesn’t matter?

Valerie Strauss covers education for The Washington Post and runs The Answer Sheet blog.   

About The Grosse Pointe Academy
The Grosse Pointe Academy is an independent, coeducational day school serving children age 2-1/2 through Grade 8. We foster an inclusive environment that respects all cultures and religious beliefs. We seek to remain faithful to our heritage as a former Academy of the Sacred Heart and to those who through their Catholic faith and perseverance sought to preserve and enhance the legacy of this past for generations. Incorporated as a non-profit institution, The Grosse Pointe Academy is directed by a Board of Trustees working together to serve the Southeastern Michigan community.

item.title: School Essay Contest Winners Named
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Three eighth graders from The Grosse Pointe Academy have been named local winners in the 45th annual America & Me Essay Contest, sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance.

The three students, who earned first, second and third place awards for their school, are, from left, Toriano Spencer (second place), Sophie Leslie (first place), and Tate Kuelling, (third place). They are pictured with language arts teacher Lynn Patton and Farm Bureau Insurance agent Colleen Dyer.

All three contest winners received award certificates for their achievement. As the school’s first place winner, Sophie's name will also be engraved on a plaque for permanent display in the school. Sophie wrote about her paternal grandfather, who was an engineer/top turret gunner on a B24 liberator bomber during World War II.

The Grosse Pointe Academy’s participation in the America & Me Essay Contest was sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance agent Colleen Dyer of Grosse Pointe Woods.

Sophie's first place essay now advances to the state level competition, from which the top ten essays in Michigan will be selected. The top ten statewide winners will receive plaques, cash, and U.S. savings bonds valued from $500 to $1,000. In addition, the top ten essayists will be honored at a banquet in Lansing, meet with Michigan’s top governmental leaders, and be the featured guests at a Lansing Lugnuts minor league baseball game dedicated in their honor.

A team of finalist judges that includes a top Michigan Government official and the sponsoring teachers of last year’s top two statewide winners will determine the ranking of the top ten statewide winners this year.

Several thousand eighth grade students from over 500 Michigan schools participated in the 2013-2014 America & Me Essay Contest, which was conducted with the help of Farm Bureau Insurance agents across the state.  The topic of the 2013-2014 contest was “My Personal Michigan Hero.”

Started in 1968 and open to all Michigan eighth grade students, the contest encourages Michigan youngsters to explore their roles in America’s future. As sponsor of the contest, Farm Bureau Insurance has earned 11 national awards from the Freedoms Foundation at Valley Forge.
item.excerpt:encoded: Three eighth graders from The Grosse Pointe Academy have been named local winners in the 45th annual America & Me Essay Contest, sponsored by Farm Bureau Insurance.

item.title: It's Been R.E.A.L.!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Eighth grade R.E.A.L. (Real-world Experiences and Applied Learning) elective classes wrapped up on Friday, May 2 with a final session. One of the goals of the program was for each class to have the opportunity to go in the field and experience a taste of the real world, whether it was visiting a courthouse for the Moot Court elective or touring a television station as part of the Investigate Reporting and Video Production elective.


During the last session, Mrs. Patton's Service Discovery R.E.A.L. group visited Grosse Pointe Animal Adoption Society after collecting donations for this non-profit organization.


Mrs. Hogle's Marketing Program Design class attended a classical concert at the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on April 25, and for their finale on May 2, they presented their marketing plan for a new concert teen series for the DSO. In attendance at the students' presentation were Executive Vice President Paul Hogle, marketing executives Chris Harrington and Scott Harrison, and education director Emily Lamoreaux.


Mrs. Jerome and Mrs. Roberts' CSI class visited the Grosse Pointe Farms police station and courthouse. After practicing crime scene investigation techniques such as blood splatter patterns and analyzing DNA on an electrophoresis machine, students learned about the actual process from a Grosse Pointe Farms detective.

Finally, Mr. Cowan's Leadership class, having enjoyed in-class visits from representatives from local government, business and the military, experienced the world of community non-profit leadership with a visit to Habitat for Humanity.

item.title: Sasha Murphy Recognized as Diversity Champion
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
GPA teacher Sasha Murphy was honored as The Grosse Pointe Academy's Diversity Champion by the Race Relations Task Force of Metropolitan Detroit on Thursday, May 8.


Sasha, who is an alumna of the school, wears many hats at GPA. In addition to serving as a P.E. teacher, she is the Community Service Coordinator and advisor for the National Junior Honor Society and Student Council. She also volunteers time before and after school every day to work with students with learning challenges.

"Sasha is the unofficial adult advocate and advisor for students of color," said Megan Black, who put together the media show for the event. "She maintains relationships and remains a role model for many young women well after they leave the Academy. She is remembered by students for her open mind, kind heart and immense patience."

Sasha Murphy is pictured above during the Honorees' Breakfast with her husband, Dave.

item.title: Academy Students Excel in National French Exam
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
For the eighth consecutive year, Grosse Pointe Academy middle school students participated in the National French Exam (also known as Le Grand Concours). Eighth grader Karina Minanov, who achieved a perfect score, earned the first rank both locally and nationally. In addition to a gold medal, she will receive a plaque engraved with her name. This is the second consecutive year the Academy has had a student receive a first place ranking both nationally and locally.


Other eighth graders receiving recognition were silver medalist Tommy Van Pelt (#3 nationally, #2 Detroit Chapter); and bronze medalists Grace Andreasen (#4 nationally, #3 Detroit Chapter), Sophie Leslie (#7 nationally, #4 Detroit Chapter) and Tate Kuelling (#9 nationally, #6 Detroit Chapter).

Seventh graders Samantha Savage and Henry Whitaker were also bronze medalists. Both placed in the first rank in the metro Detroit chapter and in rank 5 at the national level.

All sixth graders enrolled in French at The Grosse Pointe Academy were ranked in the top ten nationally and received bronze medals. They are: Bryce Bixler (rank 4), Maria Fields (rank 4), Brooke Popadich (rank 5), Nafi Sall (rank 5), Christa Abar (rank 6), Aiden Kuelling (rank 6), Dakota Jones (rank 7), Blake Pradko (rank 8), Sade Shaw (rank 8), Molly Woods (rank 9), and Megan Driver (rank 10).

This 60-minute national examination is developed and managed by the American Association of Teachers of French. Its purpose is to help stimulate further interest in the teaching and learning of French as well as to help identify and reward student achievement.

The exam is a multiple-choice test of approximately 70 items covering listening comprehension, vocabulary, grammar and reading comprehension. Students took the test that was appropriate for the French curriculum in which they are enrolled. Their scores were then ranked against students locally as well as nationally who are enrolled in similar curricula.

item.title: Grade 5 Goes to Washington
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy fifth graders, accompanied by their teachers, Trevor Clor and Holly Willson and school nurse Rosemary Barker, traveled to Washington, D.C. this week as part of their study of the United States government. Over their three-day trip, they took 37,118 steps (according to Mrs. Willson's pedometer) and visited 23 sites. Day one of the trip included a photo stop at the White House and visits to the American History Museum (where students were impressed with the size of the Star Spangled Banner), the Capitol Building, Library of Congress, Supreme Court, National Archives and the Washington Monument. On day two they visited the Air and Space Museum and the Natural History Museum along with the Mount Vernon, World War II, Lincoln, Vietnam, Korean, Martin Luther King, Jr. Thomas Jefferson, and Franklin D. Roosevelt monuments. Day three included a visit to Arlington National Cemetery, the Iwo Jima Memorial, U.S. Air Force Memorial, National Zoo and Naitonal Cathedral. "Not only did the students learn a lot, but so did I!" said Holly Willson after the trip.


According to Trevor Clor, the students made a great impression wherever they went. "In fact, we even had a fellow passenger on the airplane call the school to congratulate us on such wonderful students," said Trevor.

Click on the link for pictures and a video!
item.excerpt:encoded: Academy fifth graders, accompanied by their teachers, Trevor Clor and Holly Willson and school nurse Rosemary Barker, traveled to Washington, D.C. this week as part of their study of the United States government.

item.title: Spring Has Sprung at GPA!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
After a long, difficult winter and an exceptionally cold and rainy spring, The Grosse Pointe Academy’s Garden Classroom is finally beginning to sprout.

Our foundation is in place. We have beautiful, gravel pathways snaking through rich soil beds. Our patio, with four picnic tables, has been hosting lunch for happy classroom customers in sunny weather. We have a well stocked tool shed. The gazebo is gorgeous, and makes a perfect place for a class to spend time together, as demonstrated above by students in Kate Kingsley's Early School class. Kevin Alt and the GPA Maintenance Staff are to be commended for their hard work.

With the assistance of Master Gardener and parent volunteer, Mollie Donaldson, many grades have already planted. Some of the seedlings already growing are sunflowers, cosmos, herbs, salad greens, marigolds, and more. Each class designed a garden to complement their curriculum and if these gardens haven’t already been established, they will be sown in the remaining days of school. Before the Early School departs for summer, Peggy Varty’s class will install their spectacular sundial and beautiful bird house hand made by the five and under apprentice carpenters.

Didi DeBoer and Megan Black have been named Co-Coordinators of the STEM/STEAM initiative and Garden Classroom. Both of these educators share a passion for gardening, all things STEAM related, and are enthusiastic in their determination to see both programs flourish.

Click here to view pictures.
item.excerpt:encoded: After a long, difficult winter and an exceptionally cold and rainy spring, The Grosse Pointe Academys Garden Classroom is finally beginning to sprout.

item.title: Fete des Amis: Together We Flourished!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
A beautiful spring evening greeted over 400 guests to a sold out Action Auction, our school’s largest fundraiser, on May 10. Parents, grandparents, Legends, friends, and community members gathered for fun, folly, and furious bidding as we raised our paddles to directly support educational programming while honoring the Legends of the Academy.

The evening began with a wonderful silent auction and cocktail reception in the Fisher Library, followed by a lovely sit down meal in our magically transformed Tracy Fieldhouse. Guests were entertained by our student and staff reenactment of Pharrell’s “Happy” video and a sentimental video tribute to the Legends. A very successful and exciting live auction was conducted by the DuMouchelles and emceed by our very own Legend, Joe DiMauro. After the live portion of the auction, party revelers danced the night away to the Motown sounds of the Prolifics.

This important annual event raised well over a half million dollars in support of educational programming and our STEM to STEAM innovations. These funds will be channeled into school operations, creativity and design, the arts and professional development. In conjunction with the Auction, a group of donors graciously funded the installation of a permanent garden and sculpture at our school entrance in honor of the Fete des Amis and to further improve our beautiful campus.

A huge thank you to our wonderful and generous community for all of your support for the Academy and our students. If you missed out on the "Action," make sure you sign up to volunteer or come next year. It is an event not to be missed!

item.title: GPA Partners with the DSO
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy is proud to announce a partnership with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra for the 2014-2015 school year as a sponsoring school of the DSO’s Wu Family Academy of Education and Engagement.

“This opportunity is a key component of our initiative to bring arts and creativity to our science, technology, engineering, and mathematics efforts,” said Head of School Lars Kuelling. “We are so pleased the DSO is partnering with us to provide a unique opportunity for our students to extend their performing arts learning beyond the daily classroom while also making the Academy a destination for the arts.”

The DSO offerings will include two opportunities for students: The Suzuki String Training program and the Academy Chorus. Staffed by DSO and Detroit Children’s Choir instructors, these optional programs will allow students to participate in convenient lessons on-campus before and after school, with the possibility of classes during the school day if scheduling permits.

The partnership follows on the heels of the school’s successful paddle-raising to support the inclusion of arts, creativity and design in its recent science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) initiative. The goal was $100,000 and, thanks to the generosity of the community, the Academy raised $160,000, bringing a three-year total in support of technology, STEM and the arts to nearly $600,000.

item.title: Is Your Child Ready for Preschool?
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Your two and a half or three-year-old is almost out of diapers, is curious about everything, and seems ready to explore the world. But is he or she ready to start preschool?
 
“When I meet with parents of preschool aged children, they often ask me how they know if their child is ready for preschool,” said Jennifer Kendall, Director of Early School Education at The Grosse Pointe Academy. “Signs that your child is ready for preschool include an interest in being independent, a desire to play with other children, and the ability to follow directions.”
 
One of the benefits of a Montessori environment for a toddler or preschooler, according to Kendall, is the individualized nature of the program within a full classroom setting.
 
“The teachers introduce the materials to the children and then the children have the ability to choose work that is of interest to them,” said Kendall. “We call this self-directed work, and it is ideal for children who are new to a school setting. It provides just the right comfort level for children to explore and take risks under the guidance of their teacher.”
 
The classrooms have a Practical Life area, where children develop fine motor skills through a care for their environment, a Sensorial area, where children learn color, size, texture, and weight through their work, and the Academic areas of language arts, math, science, and geography.
 
An environment that builds independence and perseverance, while fostering creativity and critical thinking skills, has other benefits as well. Said Lars Kuelling, the Academy’s Head of School: “Montessori has produced some of the greatest entrepreneurs since Thomas Edison and Henry Ford, with the founders of Google, Amazon, and Wikipedia all having attended Montessori schools.”
 
Other attributes of a Montessori preschool include small class sizes, highly experienced teachers with Montessori certification, a program that supports key mechanics necessary for reading, writing and math, and weekly meetings with specialists in art, French, physical education, creative movement and library.
 
At The Grosse Pointe Academy, a child’s curiosity and desire to explore are met in a safe, nurturing environment. For more information or to arrange a tour, contact Molly McDermott at 313.886.1221 ormmcdermott@gpacademy.org.

item.title: GPA Hosts First Garden Day
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
"It's like going on a treasure hunt!" "There are a gazillion beans here!" "This is so much fun!" "I can't believe how tall our sunflowers are!"


These were a few of the comments from children who participated in GPA's first Garden Day on Monday, August 4. Students and parents enjoyed picking vegetables, weeding, deadheading flowers, staking tomatoes and cucumbers, watering, fertilizing, eating popsicles, and more. The vegetables picked were tomatoes, cucumbers, basil, green beans, green peppers, hot peppers, zucchini, and summer squash.

This innovative programming, an outgrowth of GPA's STEM program, ties to the school's roots as a self-sustaining farm back in its Academy of the Sacred Heart days.

The carefully planned garden, which students and teachers refer to as a classroom in spite of its outdoor location, enjoys a bit of whimsy in its organization – a butterfly garden by the gazebo, a pizza lover’s delight garden with several varieties of tomatoes and basil surrounded by marigolds, pumpkins and gourds planted by Early School children in The Great Pumpkin Patch – but there is meaning behind the playfulness.

Each grade level, from the preschoolers and kindergarteners in the Montessori Early School to eighth graders in the middle school, is responsible for a garden plot, and each plot has its own unique theme. Many of the themes are related to that grade level’s curriculum. For example, The Storybook Garden contains flowers one would find in several children’s stories, such as snapdragons, zinnias, lamb’s ear, and dahlias. Mr. McGregor and Peter Rabbit’s Gardens, named after the popular Beatrix Potter storybook characters, contain produce that any rabbit would risk sneaking into the garden for, such as cucumber, zucchini, summer squash and peppers.

The fourth grade created the “What thyme is it?” garden, which is a biorhythmic garden that features flowers that open in relation to the time of day or location of sun, such as morning glory, Mexican daisies, evening primrose, thyme, 4 o’clock flowers and moonflowers, with stepping stones representing the hours of the day. George and Martha’s Garden is the fifth grade’s representation of their study of the U.S. Constitution. Finally, middle school students will be conducting experiments in Mendel’s Hypothesis Garden, which includes pea plants, a nod to Mendel’s famous benchmark genetic studies involving peas.

Future plans for when school is back in session include a flower bed behind the gazebo where middle school students will study soil acidity and how hydrangeas react to various changes.

“The garden is a work in progress,” said fourth grade teacher Didi DeBoer, who is garden coordinator along with Technology and Learning Specialist Megan Black. “It has endless possibilities and we are looking forward to seeing what it yields for the coming year."

item.title: Is Your Child in the Right Preschool?
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Choosing a preschool for your child is one of the most important decisions you will make as a parent. Schools are as individual as each child, and finding the right fit is the key to igniting a lifelong love of learning and laying a foundation for future success.
“Parents today are searching for more than just day care,” said Jennifer Kendall, Director of Early School Education at The Grosse Pointe Academy. “They want more than just play-based activities. First and foremost, they want their child to be safe and happy. They also want an environment where their child will be academically enriched and prepared for the next step of their journey.”
That is where The Grosse Pointe Academy comes in. Since 1962, as Michigan's first Montessori school, the Academy has remained true to Maria Montessori's philosophy and methodologies, enrolling children from age 2 1/2 to 5. 
Attributes of the Academy's Montessori preschool include small class sizes, master teachers with Montessori certification, a program that supports the key mechanics necessary for reading, writing and math, and weekly classes in art, French, physical education, creative movement and library.
The Grosse Pointe Academy advantage extends through grade 8, providing a continuum of educational excellence in an environment that builds independence and perseverance, while fostering creativity and critical thinking. A college preparatory curriculum, Christian values, and a warm, safe environment where every child is known round out the Academy experience. 
 
"All parents understand that saving money for college is an important part of the plan," said Lars Kuelling, Head of School. "We believe your investment begins here, where our graduates go on to attend the finest high schools and colleges in the nation."
For more information or to arrange a tour, contact Molly McDermott at 313.886.1221 or mmcdermott@gpacademy.org.

item.title: Getting the Most from Your Child's Preschool
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
So your child has started preschool. Does it feel like there isn't enough structure and there is too much play time? Do you worry about the lack of personal attention your child receives? Is it all about cutesy songs like the Itsy Bitsy Spider? Or should you be looking for a preschool where your child is guided to discover, to explore, and to acquire the knowledge and skills necessary for future success?

At The Grosse Pointe Academy Montessori Early School, students begin formal learning at an early age - as young as 2 1/2. The best learning at this ages comes from engaged teachers and a purposeful classroom environment. The Practical Life area, the Sensorial area, and the Academic areas - including reading, math, science, and geography - are all part of the carefully structured learning plan.
 

"Our very youngest children are taught to make individual choices based on their abilities and interests, to take Montessori materials from the child height shelves, and to develop budding interests," said Jennifer Kendall, Director of the Academy's Early School Education. "Teachers foster this process by assessing the children's readiness for a learning activity, demonstrating a skill, and guiding a child's work as necessary."
 
Technology may have its place in learning, but at this early age, sensorial engagement with the pink tower, the thousand chain, the smelling jars, the sound boxes, bells, the geometric solids, and the sandpaper letters are more important for early childhood development. All of the senses are engaged in this total immersion in learning, with the tablet taking a back seat to the moveable alphabet - where 4 and 5 year olds, and even some 3 years olds, start to spell, to read, and to build numeracy skills.
 

And there's more: GPA students learn French from age 3. They are immersed 
in music, art, physical education, and creative movement classes, with extended day options available. Throughout it all, parents remain connected to their children's education through personal interaction, regular communication, and formal conferences with the teacher.
 
"Parents must observe our students in action to truly gain an appreciation for what happens on a daily basis," said Head of School Lars Kuelling. "The environment is creative, adventurous and spontaneous, and children are encouraged to make decisions for themselves, take risks, and solve problems on their own."
 
For information about how your child can get more out of preschool, contact Molly McDermott, Admissions Director, at 313.886.1221 or mmcdermott@gpacademy.org.

item.title: GPA Awards Faculty Innovation Grants
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Head of School Lars Kuelling announced the recipients of an Innovation Grant Award during the opening faculty and staff meetings for The Grosse Pointe Academy on Monday, August 25. These grants were made possible by the successful STEM to STEAM paddle-raising held at the Fête des Amis Action Auction on May 10, 2014, which, among other initiatives, will fund faculty and staff professional development.

Innovation Grants are intended to provide faculty and staff with the opportunity to visit and learn from cutting edge programs at other independent schools across the country, stimulating faculty members to use the spirit of innovation to further challenge and inspire Academy students.

Beth Ahee, second grade teacher, will visit Kingsley Montessori in Boston, Massachusetts to observe the transition from Montessori Kindergarten to Lower School and ways to implement Montessori teachings into the Lower School.

Trevor Clor, fifth grade teacher, will visit Chadwick School in Palos Verdes, California to explore student exposure of visual and performing arts on a daily basis, outdoor excursion trips, student produced science films, and the success of robotics labs.

Didi DeBoer, fourth grade teacher, will visit Brimmer & May School in Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts to observe the inquiry based science program for grades 4/5 in search of ideas for incorporating STEM/STEAM. In addition, she will observe a certified wildlife habitat.

Bridgette Murray, third grade teacher, will observe the service learning program at Hillbrook School in Los Gatos, California along with the school's 1:1 iPad program and thematic approach to teaching.

Lynn Patton, Grade 8 language arts teacher, will visit Mt. Vernon Presbyterian to explore a model of inspiring and challenging students as 21st century learners. She will also meet with a local school to investigate a Film Festival concept for grade 7/8 year end performances.

Peggy Varty, Early School teacher, will visit Hathaway Brown in Shaker Heights, Ohio, observing their Storyline Project for ways to implement it into the Academy's three, four and five year old classroom, specifically using this concept to study the Great Lakes.

"The range of schools and variety of interests reflected on the proposals we received is a testament to the energy and creative spirit of the Academy's teachers," said Lars Kuelling. "They are always seeking innovative ideas to make their classrooms more vibrant for their students. We are so fortunate this year to have had this additional funding to support new ways, from Early School to Grade 8, to make The Grosse Pointe Academy the best learning environment possible. I can't wait to see what these teachers bring back to GPA!"

item.title: Team Leaders Make Dynamic Duo
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
One needs to spend only a few minutes with second grade teacher Beth Ahee and fourth grade teacher Didi DeBoer to feel the positive energy between them. And no wonder - the two have known each other for 21 years, having met on the T-ball diamond when their sons played on the same team and their husbands were both coaches. They were part of a winning team then and they are part of a winning team now.

Beth and Didi have been appointed Lower School (grades 1-3) Team Leader and Intermediate (grades 4-5) Team Leader, respectively. In this new role, they will assist Lawrence DeLuca, the Assistant Head of School for Instruction, Grades 1-8 Principal, in analyzing curricula, programs and assessments with the Lower and Intermediate School teams. Beth and Didi will serve as positive role models and mentors to foster a high level of morale and to support, encourage and guide teachers.

The two have dedicated a good part of their summer to making sure they will hit the ground running at the start of the school year. They began the benchmarking process by looking at what other independent schools in the region and around the country are doing in all areas of the curriculum. They looked specifically for schools with forward thinking, hands on and exploratory programs, with an eye on programs that would enhance the Academy’s science, technology, engineering, arts and math (STEAM) initiatives.

For example, as part of the science curriculum, work in the classrooms will be enhanced in the Innovation Design Center. Didi and Megan Black, STEAM Co-Coordinators, will work together to create exploration activities for the students to perform in the lab that will expand upon what teachers are teaching in class. The result will be project-based learning that is experiential and hands-on.

“There is always that moment in class or the Innovation Design Center when that innovative child steps up and does something we as teachers would never have even thought of,” said Didi. “Then there is that child who hangs back, looking for more direction. We want every child to have the skills and tools they need so that they are comfortable and not afraid to try. At the same time we want them to do more than follow directions and spit something back, but to be critical thinkers and problem solvers.” 

In addition to reviewing the curriculum at each grade level, Beth and Didi will look at the yearly transitions in subject areas, ensuring that teachers build on students’ knowledge from grade to grade. 

“We want to make sure we’re at the cutting edge as we transition from year to year,” said Beth. “The focus is on building on skills to make sure we are aligned rather than overlapping, and ensuring a smooth transition so that each student is receiving the best education possible.”

The process of building over the years is beneficial not just to the students but to teachers as well. “We will be looking at the big picture,” said Beth. “All the first through fifth grade teachers will see what we are trying to accomplish and how they are each part of the process.” The goal in these first five years will be to ensure a seamless transition to middle school in which students will continue to build on the skills they have acquired in grades 1-5, preparing them for the next step, high school, and, ultimately, college.

Beth and Didi’s new responsibilities as Team Leaders will be particularly beneficial to Lawrence DeLuca as he himself transitions into his expanded role as Principal for Grades 1-8.

“I am very exited to work with both Didi and Beth,” said Lawrence. “They are master teachers and experts in their fields, as well as dynamic individuals who bring a great energy to their class.” In a letter sent to parents over the summer he cited their ability to lead amongst their peers, knowledge of the curriculum, work ethic, love of teaching, and ability to work with families.

For Beth and Didi, it is all about teamwork. It is the synergy between the teachers at all grade levels and the spirit of innovation and collaboration that will make their new roles as Team Leaders most rewarding.

"One of the best parts about working at the Academy is that all the teachers really get along,” said Beth.

Echoed Didi: “It’s such a pleasure to work collaboratively with people who all share a vision.”

“I am confident that with Lawrence in his new position as Principal for Grades 1-8, and with Didi and Beth serving as Team Leaders, we have all the right elements in place for an extremely successful school year," said Head of School Lars Kuelling. "I can't wait to get started.”

item.title: Providing an Uncommon Education
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
PROVIDING AN UNCOMMON EDUCATION

I love the start of a new school year! Having worked in education my entire adult life, I have witnessed the opening of many school years, and I never grow tired of it. That first day makes me think of the sound of the starter’s gun in a road race…the nerves, the excitement, the readiness to get out and get started already after the months of meticulous preparation. Let’s get going already!

The excitement is palpable as we greet students and parents each year, whether someone is returning to school and greeting a friend or teacher, or whether they are new to the school and meeting classmates and teachers for the first time. This was definitely the case during Tuesday’s orientation sessions when I had the privilege of welcoming parents and students to the 2014-15 school year. I began each session with the same message, the same advice that I’ve used as a classroom teacher, middle school principal, and now as a head of school.

My message to students was to keep three things in mind to ensure a great school year. The first is to respect self, others, and property. Respect is key to everything we do here at The Grosse Pointe Academy.

Second is to be kind. Kindness goes a long way in life, and I encouraged students to seek out different ways to be kind, whether welcoming a new student, making space for someone at the lunch table, or inviting someone new to play at recess.

Third was to have fun – to do something new, to try something, and to make the most of what you have been given. Nobody likes to hang out with you if you have a big rain cloud trailing behind you, I told them. And the good news is that the teachers at GPA like to have fun too!

My message to the parents was to remind them they have made the right choice by selecting The Grosse Pointe Academy. Over the summer I followed closely the national conversation about educational standards and what the state of Michigan plans to do with mandated testing, and what I have concluded is that those standards are about being average.

The sad reality is that too many teachers are having to focus on the one or two students who may make the difference between a 72 and 74% pass rate, rather than on all of the students. What about the students at the top end, who are not being pushed or challenged? What about the students who need a little extra attention so that they, too, can be successful? Or those who could be inspired to pursue a passion, if only teachers could focus on the joy of learning and what is best for kids?

In my summer letter I referenced my friend Mick Gee, Head of School at Allendale Columbia School, who observed that independent schools such as ours are “the cure for the Common Core.” I really like Mick’s idea, as I believe he has captured the heart of fine independent school education in his witticism, and I’d make my own observation that we provide an uncommon education for our students and that our parents have made an uncommon choice in a world of average educations.

What makes us the uncommon choice, the better than average option for students? We focus on every student. We inspire students academically, in the arts, and athletically. We challenge them to learn and nurture them when they need a little extra care, and since we know each student so well, we endeavor to bring out the best in each student.

Perhaps most uniquely, we partner with parents, and we respond to parent insights. For example, two years ago during our ISACS survey, we asked parents what they would like to see in The Grosse Pointe Academy of the future. Parents responded that they would like to see problem solving, creativity, innovation, and real world applications. What you see today at GPA is quite different from what you may have seen two years ago, and a lot of that is because we responded to parents.

Today you see cutting-edge technology in every classroom, STEM activities in the Innovation & Design Center, the integration of the arts across the curriculum as we take STEM to STEAM, the R.E.A.L. (Real-World Experiences and Applied Learning) electives program in the middle school, and a garden classroom. Our esteemed McMillan Lecturer, Yong Zhao, who is visiting us in November, will speak to the difference entrepreneurship, creativity and problem solving can make in a child’s educational experience.

We are certainly proud of what we have accomplished, but we wouldn’t have made any of these strides without parent input. As a parent at The Grosse Pointe Academy, you have made the uncommon choice. It is by partnering together that we are able to create the very best educational environment for each of our students, and we thank you for making the choice to join with us in providing a first-rate experience for each and every student.

item.title: Celebrating International Dot Day
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
On Monday, September 15, second and third graders celebrated International Dot Day. This celebration is based on a book by Peter Reynolds entitled The Dot. It began in 2009 and each year participants have grown globally. It is a story about a teacher who dares a doubting student to trust in her own abilities by being brave enough to "make her mark." She begins with a small dot on a piece of paper that becomes a breakthrough in confidence and courage. Her creativity blooms and she encourages other to "make thier mark." Basically, it's about embracing one's own creativity and inspiring creativity in others.


The students made their mark by making a dot and signing their names. Said second grade teacher Beth Ahee: "They were all quite curious as to what they were doing. We then read the story and discussed ways to 'make our mark.'" In the afternoon, students made a dot that came to life with an iPad app called CoLar Mix. They also made a collaborative dot collage that will be hanging outside in the hallway and made dot paintings in art class with Mrs. Baudeloque. Said one student to Mrs. Baudeloque: "This is dot-tastic!"

They finished the day's festivities by enjoying "dot" pancakes.


"The children had a ball and hopefully took home an excellent message about trusting their abilities and creativity!" said Mrs. Ahee.

item.title: Monarch Butterflies, Sunflowers and More
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
According to STEAM co-coordinator Megan Black, The Grosse Pointe Academy is "definitely on the Monarch migratory route. We had swarms of Monarch butterflies over the previous few days and classes at all levels enjoyed watching them on the butterfly bushes in the main school circle as well as the garden where they stopped by for some nectar." Mrs. Sturm's Early school classes took advantage of the moment to draw pictures.


Also, the giant sunflowers that graced the garden have gone to seed. Said Megan: "We removed them from the stalks and donated them to each Montessori room so that they could tweeze the seeds out as a fine motor skill activity. The kids in the big school remembered fondly doing this so we had a few extra flowers and Mrs. DeBoer's science classes also began to harvest the seeds." Mrs. Sturm's class also draw the sunflowers. 

Students regularly pick vegetables and tomatoes galore and donate them to the Plum Market Kitchen staff, who make tasty salads and dishes. Herbs from the garden have created delicious pestos and sauces. Whenever vegetables from the garden are used at lunch, the chefs place signs on the salad bar.

View pictures on Flickr.

item.title: Buddy Trip to the Apple Orchard
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Eighth graders accompanied their first grade buddies to Miller's Big Red Apple Orchard on Friday, September 19 - a great way for the students to get to know each other! Students, first grade teachers and eighth grade advisors were treated to an informative tour of the orchard in addition to a fun hayride. The tractor driver shared some fun facts about apples and taught the students how to properly pick out the best, ripe apples. Everyone got to pick out their very own bag of apples and also got to do some sampling! Lunch under the pavilion - with donuts and cider for dessert - was followed by a trip to the farm to see pigs, goats, sheep, chickens, hens, llamas and a pony.

A favorite part of the trip for the students was climbing the huge stacks of hay and playing with their friends and buddy. Everyone - including the teachers - climbed to the top of the hay stack for a group shot.


Afterwards the group went inside to learn about how apple cider is made. They got to see the giant machine and hear all about how the process works. Then they went into a very warm "greenhouse" room and learned about Aquaponics and how tilapia fish and plants help each other grow. They also got to taste some fresh cilantro that was grown in the greenhouse.

Said first grade teacher Lindsey Furgal: "All day, the students stuck with their buddies. The eighth graders did a fantastic job of watching over the first graders the whole time, and made sure they were safe and having fun!"

The apple orchard trip is one of many activities the first and eighth grade buddies do together throughout the school year.

Click here to view pictures on Flickr.

The voters have placed their ballots and the results are in! Congratulations to Student Council officers Will Kendrick (President), Samantha Savage (Vice President), Ryan Murphy (Treasurer), and Maria Fields (Secretary).


The election process for middle school candidates begins with nomination speeches. The candidates then make posters and write their own speeches outlining why they think they can make a difference at their school.

"I have to commend all the candidates for running," said Student Council Advisor Sasha Murphy. "Getting up in front of the entire middle school to present your speech is a great experience for everyone who participates. Whether they win or not, students are still demonstrating leadership and initiative."

item.title: Fourth and Fifth Graders Test Tulips
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Mrs. DeBoer's fourth and fifth grade science classes started their Red Emperor Tulip experiment last week. The students are participating in the Tulip Test Garden from Journey North, the same web site that tracks butterfly migration. They weighed, measured circumferences, cut bulbs apart to see the insides, and made predictions based on what they saw. Then they planted one bulb per person and marked its location.

Next, the scientist/gardeners planted larger groupings following careful test garden instructions. The planting date is logged with the website, as is the date they see the first peek of life and also the first bloom.

Said Mrs. DeBoer: "Our results are recorded with others from around the world as we look for signs of spring. The students also planted a winter crop to provide necessary nutrients for the soil so we can plant our gardens again with the vegetables that we so loved picking this year." 

Click here for pictures.

item.title: Meet Kelsey, Member of the DCC

item.content:encoded: Kelsey just joined the Detroit Children’s Choir through The Grosse Pointe Academy’s Chapter. So far she is loving it. You can also hear Kelsey perform with the DCC!

item.title: 7/8 Forensics Team Earns 16 First Place Awards
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy hosted this year’s 7/8 Eastside Catholic Forensics League meet on Saturday, December 13 and the Academy placed fourth among the eight schools competing. Grosse Pointe Academy students earned a total of sixteen first place awards, with three students winning overall first place plaques and two students earning overall second place plaques.

Receiving first place plaques were Maria Fields in the Declamation category and Samantha Savaga and Adam Kuplicki in Duo Interpretation. Receiving a second place plaque was the Duo Interpretation team of Imani White and Tai Daniels.

Other standout performances were given by Nafi Sall (one first place and two second place awards in Prose); Karmella Williams (one first place, one second place and one third place award in Prose); and Josh Roberts (one first place award in Declamation).

Receiving second place awards were Megan Driver (two in Drama), the Duo Interpretation teams of Imani White and Tai Daniels and Johnnae Curry and Henry Whitaker (one each), and Kendall Adams (Drama). Shekinah Aho received two second places and one third place in Poetry, Isabella Tomlinson received two third place awards, and Brooke Popadich and Haleigh Howard each received a third place award in Drama and Storytelling, respectively.

Academy teacher Harriett Whitaker served as the faculty advisor for the 7/8 team as well as organizer for the event. Other faculty members and administrators who helped with the meet include Beth Ahee, Amal El-Hosni, Sasha Murphy, Michelle Roberts, Lawrence DeLuca, Lars Kuelling, Didi DeBoer, and Bridgette Murray. The judges who represented our school were Michelle Roberts, Ellen Krease, Mary Alice Mecke, and Kimberly Jackson. There were almost 30 middle school students who volunteered to help as well. Special thanks go to alumnus Luke Roberts for his volunteer assistance.

This is the third time GPA has hosted an Eastside Catholic Forensics Meet.

item.title: R.E.A.L. Classes Begin!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Middle School R.E.A.L. (Real Experiences and Applied Learning) program provides opportunities for students to engage in real-world tasks that extend classroom learning, employ cross-disciplinary thinking, make connections to the world outside of their classroom walls, and create innovative solutions and products as a result of their work.

The classes will meet after the ERB tests on January 13, 14, 22, and 23 from approximately 11 a.m. until the end of the school day.

This year's R.E.A.L. classes include CSI, where students learn crime scene analysis techniques; Greening GPA, which focuses on how students can help keep their school and community environmentally healthy; 8 Mile Zone (8MZ), a journalism course exposing students to a variety of media; Moot Court, where students will debate their own issue and visit a live courthouse; Travel to Techno, for students to explore music through technology; Near-Space Exploration, for students to learn about lighter-than-air flight, radio and GPS technology, the near-space environment, scientific ballooning and its application to meteorology; and GPA Productions, in which students will learn how to make PSA announcements as well as write, film and edit videos with the opportunity to publish their finished products.

item.title: R.E.A.L. Classes Wrap Up
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
This week represented the conclusion of ERB testing along with the final R.E.A.L. (Real-world Experiences and Applied Learning) classes. A major component of each class was an on-site visit. Last week the Moot Court class, led by teachers Amal El-Hosni, Holly Kristan and Harriett Whitaker, visited the Grosse Pointe Park Municipal Court and Department of Public Safety. Students toured the facilities and viewed the court in session as Judge Carl F. Jarboe presided over criminal and civil matters. 

This week the CSI class with Mrs. Jerome and Mrs. Roberts (a.k.a. Cagney and Lacy) went to the Grosse Pointe Farms police station where detectives gave the students a hands-on experience in fingerprinting, preserving chain of evidence, crime scene photography, and deductive reasoning.

Students in Mrs. Chuhran's Travel to Techno class met with Carl Craig, an Academy parent and owner of Planet E Studio. Mr. Craig is a world renowned producer, composer, and D.J. His musical talent is technology or music made through synthesized sound. He shared with the students that he is a native to this area, yet gets to travel the world because of his success in a career that is considered unconventional to most. He said it all has to do with creativity and imagination.

After hearing an explanation of how the equipment works, students were able to experiment with the equipment themselves to explore their own creativity.

Students also presented a piece they worked on in class using nothing more than the synthesized sounds they found using their personal iPads. Student recreated the instrumentation to the Taylor Swift song, "Shake It Off," and formed their own iPad band.

8 Mile Zone, a journalism class with Mr. Cowan and Mrs. Patton, visited radio station WDET. "It was such a great experience to be in the studio while Sandra Svoboda and J. Carlisle Larsen reported the news," said Mr. Cowan. Greening GPA, with Sasha Murphy, took a trip to Nextek where students were treated to a tour by GPA parents Paul and Fay Savage and a presentation by employee and GPA alumna Anna Basse '04.

On campus, students in Mr. Rochte's Near-Space Explorations prepared for their upcoming balloon launch. The GPA Productions class with Mr. DeLuca and Ms. Black continued work on their PSA's. Plans are underway for a "screening party" for parents in February. "It should be a real red carpet event!" said Mr. DeLuca.

item.title: Up, Up and Away!
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
It's a bird... it's a plane... no, it's a high altitude balloon!

Middle School students in Mr. Rochte's R.E.A.L. class embarked on a near space journey on Thursday, January 29 with the launching of the 30' balloon they built. Although the balloon was launched with helium due to the weather conditions, it was designed to fly throughout the day as a "solar Montgolfiere" or solar hot-air balloon.

The balloon was equipped with a payload box containing a GPS tracker (which unfortunately malfunctioned) and a mini digital camcorder that was running when it took off. The hope was that the students would be able to witness its journey if the balloon was ever found. A label on the box included instructions for its safe return to GPA.

"All of our predictions suggested it would land sometime on Wednesday night, probably around 8 p.m., in northwestern Ohio," said Director of Technology Robert Rochte, who teaches mathematics and computer science in addition to the Near Space Explorations elective. The elective is part of GPA's R.E.A.L. (Real-world Experiences and Applied Learning) program, which provides opportunities for students to engage in real-world tasks that extend classroom learning, employ cross-disciplinary thinking, make connections to the world outside of their classroom walls, and create innovative solutions and products as a result of their hard work.

The balloon, having completed its descent in the middle of a field, was found by a gentleman from Foster Farms outside of Roanoke, Virginia.

"We never dreamed it would somehow make it all the way to Virginia!" said Mr. Rochte. "Mr. Foster's call on Friday morning was the talk of the school all day."

One early speculation for the balloon's unexpected voyage is that the helium diffusion rate was not as high as expected; with some left-over gas in the balloon, the descent was extremely slow. According to Mr. Rochte, this would have allowed the balloon to travel much farther with the jet stream. He estimates the balloon traveled approximately 400 miles. "Our farthest ever GPA balloon flight was 933 miles, back in March of 2007. That one almost landed in the Atlantic!"

While the balloon will be returned, it enjoyed a brief detour to Shawsville Middle School in Montgomery County. Before shipping it back to GPA, Drema Foster, the wife of the man who found the balloon, took it to the school for the students to see how it was constructed. She also sent pictures of the area in which it was found. 

"You will get an idea of how many mountains surround the area the balloon was found in," Mrs. Foster wrote to Mr. Rochte in an email. "It's really quite amazing it landed in the middle of a field and not in the woods."

Mr. Rochte will download and process the video as soon as he receives the payload back. "It should be fascinating for the students to see it," he said. "Although I doubt it will include the landing. Oh, how I'd love to see the cows' faces as the balloon touched down!"

Click here to see pictures of the launch.
