item.title: Demystifying Montessori
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
In an article published this past spring in the Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), a number of parents and educators endeavor to better explain and "demystify" this very innovative approach to education called Montessori.

Grosse Pointe Academy directress Peggy Varty, above, with one of her students, has been on staff at the Grosse Pointe Farms school since 1995.

MONTESSORI ADVOCATES WANT TO DEMYSTIFY THE METHOD

April 10, 2015 

BY KELLY ST. JOHN REGIER / CONTRIBUTING WRITER

Two decades ago, Stacey Constantian discovered Montessori education.

Back then, Constantian was the mother of a bright 4-year-old girl who had taught herself to read. Her daughter didn’t fit in at the parent-participation preschool she attended, nor did the program provide enough of an educational challenge.

“The teacher couldn’t believe she was going to have to find special work for her,” recalled Constantian. “They asked us not to come back.”

Constantian began to research other options, and she soon found what she called a perfect fit – the educational approach created in the early 1900s by Maria Montessori, an Italian physician. Montessori’s methodology stems from the belief that children learn best at their own pace while learning independently through the use of sensory materials in mixed-age classrooms.

Programs are available from infant to high school level, although the highest level offered in Orange County is eighth grade, at LePort Schools in Fountain Valley and Irvine.

“I chose Montessori because I read a lot about brain development,” Constantian said. “There are sensitive periods in a child’s life, times when the child’s brain is growing quickly, and the brain is interested in learning something right then.”

Constantian is such a believer in the value of Montessori education that – after becoming a Montessori educator – she recently founded her own preschool, Kensington Montessori in Laguna Niguel.

A growing number of schools in Orange County and across the United States are turning to Montessori teaching programs, but many parents still are not familiar with the “Montessori way” and what it looks like in a classroom.

To understand Montessori’s approach to learning, it helps to get some background.

Montessori was the first woman to receive a medical degree in Italy. She believed that all human beings have unique potential that needs to be discovered, developed and applied at an early age. She put those progressive theories into practice in Rome in 1907, when she opened a school for impoverished children.

COMING HOME, STAYING HOME: EARLY SCHOOL TEACHER WITH DEEP GROSSE POINTE ACADEMY ROOTS IS RIGHT WHERE SHE BELONGS; SAYS THE MOST IMPORTANT PART OF HER JOB IS HAVING A SAFE, SECURE, AND WELCOMING CLASSROOM

Within two years, the children who had been written off as mentally deficient were passing Italy’s public school exams.

Montessori designed her classroom to center on the children, not the adult teacher. Everything in a Montessori room is child-size, from tables and chairs to sinks and toilets. She also grouped her students in mixed-age classes, so that older children could act as role models and teachers to younger children.

Unlike in traditional classrooms, students did not sit through group lessons in Montessori’s classes. Instead, they taught themselves by working independently with instructional materials she personally designed, such as wooden letters and numbers, puzzles, beads and household items.

The Academy is hosting a Monterssori Information Night on Wednesday, Nov. 11.

During preschool and the early elementary grades, students are free to move around the room and choose their own “work” from shelves at their level, and they are not under deadlines to complete certain tasks.

“Every material is designed to step-by-step teach a new concept or skill,” said Lindsay Journo, vice president of academics at LePort Montessori. The Montessori system emphasizes using natural materials, not plastic, including breakable materials such as glass pitchers or porcelain cups.

“We believe children can learn how to handle these materials. There is a real level of trust when they are allowed to,” Journo said.

During upper elementary grades through high school, Montessori teachers act as guides for their students, working with each child or presenting cultural lessons to the class. Rather than sitting through lectures, students are encouraged to pursue their interests. Some students may be placed in small reading groups while others work independently on math skills in class.

“One of the biggest misconceptions about Montessori is that it is very strict,” said Carla Hofland, director of member services at the American Montessori Society. “Yes, the classroom is very structured in that you won’t see Disney characters or oddball things. But within that structure, there’s a tremendous amount of freedom.”

A child in preschool who is interested in starting her day by washing a doll, for example, is allowed to do that.

Hofland explains that self-directed activities enable children to find comfort and satisfaction in completing familiar tasks.

“The child is allowed to do that work again and again until they are finished with it,” said Constantian. “A 3-year-old might enjoy pouring water from a pitcher to a glass repeatedly. Then, one day, she’s done.”

MORE INFORMATION ON THE GROSSE POINTE ACADEMY MONTESSORI PROGRAM

Montessori boasts some very famous alumni. Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, chef Julia Child, video game pioneer Will Wright, author Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, actor George Clooney, rap star and music mogul Sean “P. Diddy” Combs and Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales all attended Montessori schools as children.

In 2004, Page was quoted as telling ABC’s Barbara Walters that a Montessori education was the key to his and Brin’s success with Google.

“I think it was part of that training of not following rules and orders, and being self-motivated, questioning what’s going on in the world and doing things a little bit differently,” Page told Walters.

Some research suggests that children who attend Montessori schools reap benefits in academic and social development.

Angeline Lillard, author of “Montessori: The Science Behind the Genius,” cited a 2006 study that found that Montessori students leaving kindergarten scored higher than their peers in public and private schools in standardized math and reading tests.

According the study, Montessori students also wrote essays with more imagination and depth than their peers did after elementary school.

But not all the research supports Montessori’s superiority. A 2005 study found that although Montessori may provide unique benefits that extend beyond academics, the program is not associated with higher academic achievement. The study published in the Journal of Childhood Education compared the academic achievement of urban fourth- and eighth-graders in Montessori programs with students in traditional education programs, including magnet and non-magnet public schools.

Additionally, some parents question whether Montessori provides enough opportunities for group socialization and imaginative play, or worry that it is too academic of an approach for small children.

MONTESSORI DIRECTRESS BRINGS INTERNATIONAL ACUITY TO HER PEACEFUL CLASSROOM

Shelling out the extra cash needed to support a private education can also have a huge effect on a family’s decision to forgo free public education.

The U.S. Department of Education reported in 2012 that the average private school tuition for elementary school was $7,700 annually. Because schools are operated independently, full-time Montessori tuition can range anywhere from $999 to $14,000 per year.

There are two reasons Montessori programs can cost more than traditional programs, said Constantian. Materials alone for a preschool class cost about $11,000 versus just several thousand for a traditional preschool, she said. Also, the training to become a Montessori teacher is more extensive, which means qualified Montessori educators can command higher salaries.

Although the initial cost may be high, most Montessori schools do offer financial aid and scholarship programs. Moreover, more than 400 public schools offer Montessori programs, according to The American Montessori Society. Springbook and Santiago Hills elementary schools in Irvine both offer Montessori programs.

“We are seeing growth, particularly in public and charter schools,” said Hofland, of the American Montessori Society. The society was formed in 1960 by Nancy Rambusch to bring the Montessori approach to the American school system. It has 1,400 member schools today and certifies more than 2,000 new teachers every year.

Determining the exact number of Montessori schools in the United States is difficult because the name and method were never formally licensed or trademarked. (Montessori reportedly wanted to make sure her methods were widely available to anyone.) That means anyone can open a Montessori-based school without having to follow specific standards.

That Montessori schools are all independently run can make it difficult for parents trying to determine which Montessori school is right for their family. About 60 schools in Orange County identify as Montessori.

“Go on a tour and see the school,” advised Journo. “It should be clean, beautiful and warm. It should have a productive hum of activity in a peaceful atmosphere.”

Journo also recommends that parents ask where its teachers received their credentials. LePort, for example, hires teachers credentialed by the Association Montessori Internationale, which was founded by Maria Montessori herself.

Other marks of a quality Montessori program can include affiliation with the American Montessori Society and accreditation by the National Association for the Education of Young Children, which both require advanced teaching qualifications and higher program standards than state licensing.

“To some families, Montessori is still a bit of a secret,” said Journo. “We want to change that.”

item.title: An educational institution like no other
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Visitors typically marvel at the architectural splendor that is The Grosse Pointe Academy. Whether its the schools historic Gothic-inspired exterior or its bright and modern educational facilities inside, the combination of such a solid foundation with academicsand technology designed for the 21st century has the Academy occupying a very unique position in elementary education in Michigan. After The Grosse Pointe Academy's last extensive renovation of its main school building, which brought about many of the campus improvements students still enjoy today, the project (completed in August 2007) earned a number of accolades, including being selected by School Planning & Management magazine as a winner of its 2008 Impact on Learning Award. We revisit the award below with excerpts and photos from the original article in the April 2009 edition of School Planning & Management magazine.
(Information on school tours is available at 313-886-1221 or online here.) Grosse Pointe Academy Lower/Middle School (Moran Building) Fanning/Howey Associates, Inc. - Michigan City, Ind. Project of Distinction Winner 2008 Education Design Showcase Project Fact Sheet (2007-08) Facility Use: K-12 Elementary Project Type: Renovation/Modernization Category: Whole Building/Campus Design Location: Grosse Pointe Farms, MI District/Inst.: Grosse Pointe Academy Completion Date: August 2007 Design Capacity: 375 students Enrollment: 345 students Gross Area: 55,000 sq.ft. Space per pupil: 220 sq.ft. Site size: 22 acres Cost per student: $41,452 Cost per sq.ft.: $188.00 Total project cost: $10,363,100 Building construction cost: $7,738,960 Site development cost: $351,500 Furniture & equipment cost: $20,657 Fees and other: $2,087,000 The Grosse Pointe Academy - Grosse Pointe Farms, Michigan From outside, The Grosse Pointe Academy looks the same as it has for the past 78 years. Its stone-accented brick walls and quintessential Gothic architecture evoke a sense of tradition and pride. But on the inside, this historic school can now offer students a modern learning environment complete with 21st Century technology, larger and more functional classrooms, and inspiring special program areas. A Rich Tradition (Visions/Goals) The history of The Grosse Pointe Academy dates back to 1885, when the Religious of the Sacred Heart founded a school for young ladies. In the late 1920s, the renowned architect Charles Donagh Maginnis designed the Moran Building, a striking Gothic structure that became a symbol of the Academys rich tradition and pursuit of excellence. At the beginning of the 21st Century, The Grosse Pointe Academy began to address shortcomings at the Moran Building. While rich in history, the building did not support a 21st Century learning environment. Classrooms were underutilized and were too small to support current educational programs. Students and teachers didnt have access to the latest in technology. It was time for a change. Tradition and Tomorrow (Educational Needs/Planning) In 2004, the school embarked on a comprehensive building initiative that they dubbed Tradition and Tomorrow. The journey began with a comprehensive feasibility study and campus master plan that focused on ways to preserve the building while creating the best possible learning environment.  
  Administrators, teachers, and support staff participated in a three-month planning process which examined multiple schemes and explored the needs of each program area. When they were finished, the team had created a series of exciting goals: Provide high performance learning environments to support educational programs for grades 1-8; Respect and enhance the interior historic qualities of the Moran Building; Increase overall safety by reintegrating the reception and administrative areas into the Lower Middle School wing; Provide ADA access throughout all levels of the building. Unlocking Potential (Challenges/Solutions) Throughout the planning process, administrators and staff expressed a strong desire to preserve the historic character of The Grosse Pointe Academy. This meant accomplishing all renovations within the existing building footprint. A creative phasing plan took advantage of a recent performing arts addition to unlock the building and provide the necessary room for renovations. The phasing plan involved: Moving the performing arts program from the existing auditorium, located on the second floor, to the recently completed performing arts addition in the Tracy Field House Wing of the Academy; Renovating the former auditorium to serve as a library; Demolishing the former library and reclaiming it for use as educational space. As a result of these renovations, the educational environment at The Grosse Pointe Academy is completely reborn. If you drive up to the school, you dont know anything is different. But when you walk inside youre just blown away, says Phil Demartini, Head of School at the time. Classrooms on the first floor house grades 1-5 and are 200 to 250 square feet larger than before the remodel. Computers provide a technology-rich environment and encourage personal and small group research. Plasma televisions act as interactive white boards. New lighting systems with motion detectors reduce energy usage and overall operating costs. Students also enjoy running water and drinking fountains in the classroom for the first time. Teachers have ample storage and new or historically restored millwork and cabinetry. The attention to detail is something that people marvel at, comments Demartini. They say, how did you get all that stuff to match?  
  On the second floor, middle school teachers and students enjoy the same types of amenities. Six newly expanded classrooms combine with two state-of-the-art science labs to support team teaching and collaboration. A new computer lab, located near the middle school commons, acts as a large-group instruction room and exploration center. A Signature Space / A Discovered World (Unique features/Innovations) The Grosse Pointe Academy wanted a building that would add to their rich history. The design team responded with the creation of a new second-floor library and a dramatic art loft, located in a converted attic on the third floor.  
  Located in the schools old auditorium, the library is the signature space within the building. The barrel vaulted ceiling features restored ornamental wood arches and detailed paneling. Historic windows, sills, wainscot, and trim are also restored. Custom-designed new millwork blends seamlessly with the existing woodwork. Refurbished pendant lighting, along with additional discrete, supplemental, and task lighting, gives the library a sense of warmth and brings out the luster in the restored wood. The design arranges reference desks, study areas, and stack areas in a simple and efficient manner. A bank of six computers allows students to conduct on-line research in small groups or individually. On the third floor, the former attic is home to a discovered world. Once a collection of cramped classrooms and storage spaces, the third floor now features a bright, airy art loft and expanded classrooms for foreign language and Christian Life. Classroom walls are now arranged parallel to the ceiling trusses, freeing the learning environment from its former constraints. The art loft supports an open studio environment with sloped walls that are reminiscent of a French garrett. Existing windows andskylights infuse the studios with natural light. A gallery wall provides a place for students to display their work.     Preserving History (Materials) As he walks the halls, Phil Demartini is constantly impressed by how restoration efforts allow him to experience the school in new ways. Its brought new life to the whole building. There are windows that I never saw before. There are spots that I never paid attention to because they werent accentuated the way they are now. While restoration efforts are most noticeable in the library and main corridors, they impact the entire building. Refurbished windows and doors give the building a new luster. The original Welsh tile located in the main lobby shines thanks to a thorough restoration, waxing, and polishing. In classrooms, many of the original cabinets are restored in place. When restoration was not possible or additional storage space was required, new cabinets were designed to match the schools historic character and maintain a consistent image. Safe & Secure (Safety and Security) A new glass wall system creates an enclosed reception office within the main lobby, allowing staff to fully supervise visitor access to the main entrance. The entire building features a sprinkler system, as well as a new elevator that is capable of transporting an entire class to any floor, including the previously inaccessible third floor art loft. In the science labs, new hoods, eyewash stations, and enhanced fire separations create a safe learning environment. A newly reoriented main drive makes it easier for parents to drop off and pick up their children. At the same time, the drives meandering form adds to the beauty of the overall campus.  
  A Dramatic Rebirth According to Phil Demartini, renovations have created a new sense of excitement within the student body. One of the things you notice right away is the pride the kids have in the building, he says. They walk around with their chests out saying, this is my school. We have the finest art rooms youre ever going to see. We have high school kids coming back saying that they dont have the kind of science labs we do. Its like a transfusion. This was a great school and now its more than that its an incredible place. Teachers echo Demartinis enthusiasm. I have so much space in my room for children to work in groups and on projects, says Barbara Karle, a first grade teacher. I have lots of storage space. The lighting in the rooms and hallways is so pleasant and calming. I love our new old school building. For Marsha Thomas, an Academy teacher for over 29 years, the project is the best of both worlds. After the completion of the renovation I was awestruck by the beautiful blending of the traditional and updated features. Michael McCuish, an eighth grade student and president of the student council, says the larger classrooms have added to the learning experience. It is much easier for the teachers to teach, and the students to be taught because of the extra space. I believe that the renovations to our school building have made the students more eager to learn. Phil Demartini credits the renovation project with revitalizing The Grosse Pointe Academy. In the past year, enrollment is already up, and student and community interest is at a high point. What weve done is launch the rebirth of a school that was looking for identity, he says. This is something that is going to keep The Grosse Pointe Academy alive for the next 100 years. item.title: The Academy Fund provides critical support to teachers, students
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The initial launch phase of The Grosse Pointe Academy Academy Fund has been completed. In fact, Academy Fund Director Kristen Van Pelt discussed progress of the launch in a video posted a couple of weeks ago. But even though the Academy Fund is in its quiet phase, Van Pelt said, the need for ongoing support and contributions continues unabated. The Academy Fund is an annual appeal to support The Grosse Pointe Academy, she said. As such, it is the most important fundraising effort of the year in that it provides ongoing support to the operating budget, allowing GPA to offer competitive salaries, professional development and and southeast Michigans most unique educational experience to our students. Technology at the Academy also benefits from contributions made to the school's annual fund. Among specific areas within the Academy that benefit from AF support, according to Van Pelt, are ongoing enhancements to Montessori classroom materials, competitive athletic programs with travel opportunities throughout metropolitan Detroit and middle school Real-World experiences. Through this annual appeal, we also provide our students with Applied Learning (R.E.A.L.) electives classes, dedicated reading and math specialists for all students in grade 1 through 3, a dedicated technology and learning specialist, and a full-time school nurse, a benefit for students that is increasingly rare today in primary schools, public or private.
The Academy Fund provides ongoing support to GPA's Montessori activities, part of what is now Michigan's longest continuously running Montessori program. Van Pelt said it's easy to donate by going to the schools website at gpacademy.org. And if you have any questions about the fund or about the Academy in general, she said. please give me a call at 313-886-1221, ext. 182, or e-mail me at kvanpelt@gpacademy.org. Also, you can mail your gift to:The Grosse Pointe Academy,Lake Shore Road,Grosse Pointe Farms, MI, 48236 ATTN: Academy Fund E-mail your pledge to mwestwood@gpacademy.org Phone the development office at 313-886-1221, Ext 180.

item.title: Former Academy student is in Paris this week to work on climate change
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Pathway to Paris organizers Rebecca Foon, left, and Jesse Paris Smith say the December 4 and 5 concerts will go on as planned. Former Grosse Pointe Academy student Jesse Paris Smith is in Paris currently to prepare for the Pathways to Paris concerts, which will be held December 4 and 5. Smith and co-organizer Rebecca Foon says the concerts will "bring our voices together in solidarity, offering our love and commitment to a sustainable world." Billed as a series of musical performances and talks to unite around our climate and a sustainable future for our planet, the Pathway to Paris is an initiative founded by musicians/activists Smith and Foon in partnership with 350.org that brings together musicians, artists, activists, academics, politicians and innovators to participate in a series of concert events to help raise consciousness around the urgency of climate action and the importance of establishing an ambitious, global, legally binding agreement at the UN Climate Change Conference in Paris in December 2015. Pathway to Paris kicked off a year ago with an intimate evening of music and speakers at Le Poisson Rouge immediately following the Peoples Climate March in New York City in September 2014. An intimate series of similar events have been unfolding in New York and Montreal since then. The Pathway to Paris concert series culminates in Paris this week during the UN Climate Change Conference.
Smith said the upcoming climate change talks offer an enormous opportunity to send a clear signal that the world is moving away from fossil fuels and toward a renewable energy future, while listening and problem solving with voices from around the world.
Read more about Smith and her brother Jackson, who attended the Academy in the 1990s.
Former GPA studentJesse Paris Smith visited the Academy this past summer. Scheduled musicians, artists and activists in Paris this week include Bill McKibben, Naomi Klein, Vandanna Shiva, Patti Smith, Thom York, Flea, Dhani Harrison, Tenzin Choegyal, Jesse Paris Smith and Rebecca Foon. All participants donate their time, skills and talents; while the primary aim of P2P is consciousness-raising and call-to-action, the events also raise funds, with all proceeds going to 350.org. Pathway to Paris is supported by Ben & Jerrys, in collaboration with 350.org, with additional support from the United Nations Development Program, Tree Laboratory, Sustainability Solutions Group, NextGen Climate America and Modo Yoga NYC.

item.title: From head of school: ES students give lesson on thankfulness
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academy's Head of School Lars Kuelling recounts a special gathering held recently at the Early School. . . So what are you thankful for?" asked Miss Kate to the gathered Pilgrims and Indians.
Around the feast table, set with items from the fall harvest and the bounty of the hard work of the room moms, sat the students from Mrs. Varty and Miss Kate's classes. Dressed in their Thanksgiving regalia, legs criss-crossed applesauce style, they patiently waited for their moment to share.
One by one they took their turns answering the question; some loud, some quiet, but every one sharing their thanks.
"I am thankful for
mom and dad, turkey, family, video games, jumping on the bed, and sharks! they said, with every one paying quiet attention, and no one laughing at some of the more whimsical answers coming from those assembled around a very long feast table.
After giving thanks, we prayed together, singing the Johnny Appleseed grace, before carving up the popcorn turkey." Each student received a serving of white meat (regular popcorn) and of dark meat (caramel popcorn) for their meal before digging in to the feast.
As I watched the children, I was struck by the depth of their gratitude. They all had something special to be thankful for, whether it was family, food, or fun, and they all shared it.
How nice that we were able to join together to remember the special message that Thanksgiving reminds us of...that on this special day we celebrate a time for family, our appreciation for the bounties set before us, and the community that unites us.
Thank you, Early School students, for reminding us of their importance in our lives. I hope you all have a wonderful Thanksgiving!
Lars Kuelling,Head of School

item.title: Parents of Early School students say GPA well worth sacrifice
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Pictured above are the Shallas: from left, Margot (19 mos.), Kristine, Elizabeth (3), Ryan (4), and Ryan. Margot will join her brother and sister at the Academy next year. It didnt take long for Grosse Pointe Woods residents Kristine (Armaly) and Ryan Shalla to know that the Academy was the best place for their two children. After all, Kristine was already quite familiar with the school and with Montessori, especially since her sister, Katherine Armaly Pfeifer, graduated from GPA in 2000 and taught Montessori for a number of years in South Carolina. But it took only a few months of her now four-year-old son Ryan in Montessori school at the Academy for the Shallas to be completely confident that they made the right decision. Three months into his first school year, Ryan was reciting all the continents, writing and sounding all the letters of the alphabet, successfully learning numbers, including adding and subtracting and knew all his complex shapes, just to name a few amazing accomplishments, Kristine Shalla said. Additionally, the interaction these Montessori children at GPA display is astounding at such a young age. They assist each other, teach each other and they empathize with each other. Shallas said she has no doubt her three-year-old daughter Elizabeth, also in the Early School, will continue to excel as Ryan has. There truly is no place like it, she said. And the Montessori education is phenomenal. Sacrifice worth it Like most parents who send their children to private schools, the Shallas believe the financial burden is well worth it. They have no qualms about telling others that they sacrifice for all the right reasons. Our children and their education are all that matters right now for us, Kristine said. They are pretty smart kids to begin with, so why would we want to keep them from such an accelerated atmosphere? It is what they know.
Elizabeth and Ryan Shalla pose at the special Academy street sign earned by their parents at the most recent Action Auction held by GPA in May. Kristine Shalla, who grew up in the Grosse Pointe area and attended Our Lady Star of the Sea in Grosse Pointe Woods, added that from the headmaster to the maintenance crew, the Academy staff is by far the most engaged group of people she has ever had the pleasure of knowing. They take the time to know everyone, she said. They dont judge and they welcome all your thoughts and ideas for the institution. It really is nice that you have all of that camaraderie in one place. Tuition not enough The ShallasRyan, who is an MSU alum working at a Farmington Hills-based company called Digital Image Studios, and Kristine, a University of Phoenix alum and national sales manager for Armaly Brands, a Walled Lake-based distributor and manufacturer of Brillo Brand productsare well aware that The Grosse Pointe Academy wouldnt be the school that it is today if it just relied on tuition. As a privately funded school, all these resources that GPA makes available to help our children achieve so much are made possible by the incredible generosity of Academy families, Kristine said. The Action Auction and Academy Fund has helped to support and will continue to support the growth of our children for years. And through our own annual-giving initiative, we have the ability to more fully support the programs at GPA. We believe that we should further help our childrens generation as well as the next one with all the great opportunities the Academy provides. For more information on all of the academic programs at The Grosse Pointe Academy or to set up a visit and tour,call 313-886-1221 or e-mail:jkendall@gpacademy.org.

item.title: Alum and university professor presents important research at prestigious conference
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Brad Murg, a university professor in Seattle, Washington, graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy in 1993. Dr. Bradley J. Murg, a Grosse Pointe Academy alum (93) and assistant professor of political science and director of global development studies at Seattle Pacific University in Seattle, Washington, presented a paper recently at a prestigious conference in Washington, DC. Titled "A Different Type of Resource Curse: Foreign Direct Investment and the Political Economy of Civil Court Reform in Kazakhstan, the paper was introduced October 16 at the Central Eurasian Studies Society annual conference at George Washington University in DC. A member of SPUs School of Business, Government, and Economics, Murgs research is supported by grants from the Social Science Research Council and the International Research and Exchanges Board, and focuses on legal reform, the political economy of foreign aid, and economic development in China and the former Soviet Union. Find out more about GPA's many talented alums in the latest edition of "The Academic" magazine. Murg has been busy of late as he spent the past summer in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, researching Chinese aid policy in the region. He also works regularly as a consultant/adviser to the Asian Development Bank on development issues in East Asia. In addition to these areas, Murg is an active member of the American Catholic Philosophical Association and he is currently working on a series of articles exploring the conceptualization of poverty in contemporary Catholic social thought. Murg graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Emory University, where he also completed his master's degree, focusing on the moral philosophy of St. Thomas Aquinas. He is a recipient of the Henry Luce, William Fulbright, Morris Udall, and Henry M. Jackson fellowships and holds a M.Sc. in Economic History from the London School of Economics. His doctoral dissertation was on legal reform and economic development in China, Russia, and Kazakhstan at the University of Washington. He is fluent in French, Russian, and Mandarin Chinese with proficiency in German, Dutch, Uighur, Tagalog and Latin. When not on campus, Murg says he generally can be found indulging his passion for kayaking off of his houseboat on Lake Union, or adding to the list of the 78 countries he has visited thus farmost recently, Ecuador. In a further update for the Academy, Murg says his brother, Cameron, also a GPA grad, is an investment banker in Los Angeles, and sister, Stephanie (GPA alum), is a writer covering contemporary art and design in New York City.

item.title: Back to basics: Montessori education
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
IIn an article published recently in "Smile Politely," an independent, online, culture magazine based in Champaign-Urbana, Illinois, the author talk about how Montessori students are "given the tools to teach themselves," and that this innovative method of teaching developed by Maria Montessori is less alternative and more essential, especially for early childhood education. Back to basics: Montessori education Smile Politely / November 18, 2015 / By Ashley Huddson
  It is not uncommon for students and parents to become unsatisfied with traditional public education, for those individuals there is a widely popular and successful education alternative: Montessori. According to Christine Krupp and Danielle McFarland, two of the Directresses at the Montessori School of Champaign-Urbana (MSCU), Montessori is not alternative. Described to me by McFarland, the Lead Directress of Elementary education, Montessori is a, modern approach to the way human children were meant to learn. Maria Montessori (1870-1952), the creator of this educational method, developed the system of education used at Montessori schools all around the world today through observation. She observed that children are curious and eager to learn, and that when a child is put into an environment where they are free to work, that child can thrive intellectually and socially, Krupp explained. item.title: The Academy's early legacy preserved in video
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Many in The Grosse Pointe Academy community today still retain strong ties to its past, including its roots as the Academy of the Sacred Heart. But likely many more in the communityespecially parents of our younger studentsknow very little of the history of 171 Lake Shore Road prior to its 1969 transition from The Academy of the Sacred Heart to The Grosse Pointe Academy. Students of The Academy of the Sacred Heart, now The Grosse Pointe Academy, walk through the school's front quad toward the main front entrance. Rosalie Posselius, who is an alum, former parent and GPAs alumni association president, has deep ties to the school from both a Sacred Heart and Grosse Pointe Academy perspective. In fact, one of her latest projects, which involved interviewing ASH alumnae for a video called The Legacy Project, was featured in the most recent edition of The Academy of the Sacred Hearts main alumni publication, Esprit de Coeur. The article is republished below with permission of its editor, Lisa Tebbe. (A short bio of Posselius follows this article.) Our Sacred Heart story Sharing The Legacy Project: An interview with Roselie Posselius, creator At the National Conference in Boston last spring, alums were treated to a screening of a video documentary, The Legacy Project. From heartfelt memories to hilarious stories to unforgettable Religious, with smiles, laughter and tears, the film received a resounding trs bien from the audience. The concept evolved as a vehicle to capture and preserve the feelings and impressions of Sacred Heart women and men, young and old. It is intended to be a dynamic, growing archive of how our alumnae and alumni interpret and live the legacy of their Sacred Heart education. Roselie Bellanca Posselius past central regional director, and 1973 alumna of Grosse Pointe and 77 of Bloomfield Hills/Lawrence Ave., stepped up to spearhead the project. Along with her videographer, Roselie began the video conversations at the AMASC Congress last fall in Scottsdale, Ariz. The collection of interviews continued after the conference and is now available on YouTube (see below). We had a chance to chat with Roselie who gives us a behind the scenes look. EdeC: How did you become interested in filmmaking? RP: My experience in video came as a natural progression from my work in theatre production. I have been producing theatre for over 20 years and had the opportunity to translate some of that work into film. It was a medium in which I could utilize my experience but still learn new ways to communicate. That initial interest resulted in my partner, J.C. Whitelaw, and me starting a video production company about five years ago. What interests me most and consistently is telling a story. The nuances of the mediums that one can use fascinate me. And, there are an infinite amount of stories to tell. EdeC: Can you tell us how this concept came to be? RP: The idea of The Legacy Project was born out of a perfect storm of events. I had been working for several years in film when I became a member of the AASH Board. I had also been working on the archives of Sacred Heart in Grosse Pointe for many years. When the discussion of AASH archives was brought up at our first Board meeting in St. Charles by Mary (Forsyth), I believe we all felt that we had found a worthy project that we, as a Board, could adopt. I was lucky enough to be there and had the ability to contribute. It reminded me of Paulo Coelhos quote: When you want something, the whole world conspires in helping you achieve it. EdeC: How did you envision the purpose of The Legacy Project? RP: To me the story of the Sacred Heart is an important part of history. It has remained relevant in countless ways. Our founders were brilliant, brave women of faith and strength. Their mission has inspired so many. What better way to tell that story than through the people who have had the experience, those who have lived it the alumnae and alumni. We are the product of the mission. We are the beneficiaries and with that comes the responsibility to carry on that mission. I had been researching St. Madeleine Sophie for a speech I was asked to make for graduation at the school in Grosse Pointe and came across a quote from her that really made an impression on me: We must know how to inspire in our pupils a passion for the beautiful. Let us put history into their souls; without that, memories will fade and we shall have wasted our time. I felt then that ours is a story that must be told. EdeC: What is your process for creating? RP: The interviews are clearly the basis for the process. The AASH Board created a set of questions and we began there. My video partner and I went to Arizona for AMASC and began filming. While asking the questions of each individual themes began to emerge, there was also unique content with each alumna. It wasnt difficult to tell which direction to take once we started talking. The most difficult part of the process was editing the huge amount of information. It always is. We had about 30 interviews and it took hundreds of hours to distill it down to the introductory video that we created. There were so many important messages and experiences that came throughout the interviewing process that could have been included. But, after a while, the pieces fit together like a puzzle. It helped knowing that all of the interviews would be saved in the archives and would remain available for all to examine forever. Our job was just to give a sample of what we had hoped to accomplish.
In 1890, students of The Academy of the Sacred Heart gather behind the Lakeshore building for a field day, which included basketball. EdeC: It must have been so gratifying to experience the reaction from viewers. Can you describe? RP: The reaction to the film has been great. Whenever you produce something like this, you become so close to it that you are not necessarily a good judge of whether or not it will translate from your vision to the audiences perspective. It wasnt really until the luncheon at the Boston Conference where we presented it that we knew we had told the story in an effective way. What a relief! Since then I have had a lot of people share their reactions with me and I am grateful and inspired to keep it going. EdeC: Having created something of such great significance, what are your hopes for it? RP: The truth is that The Legacy Project will preserve our memories, our traditions, our collective and individual stories for the future. It provides insight into the evolution of the Sacred Heart and its mission. I hope that The Legacy Project serves as a means to tell the story of the Sacred Heart. I hope that people will learn the value of our history, the lessons of our founders and the necessity for this type of education to continue and flourish. I hope it serves to inspire our students, their families and the faculty that teach in our schools. I hope it clarifies ours purpose and the significance of the living Mission of the Sacred Heart now and into the future. EdeC: Thank you, Roselie, for helping to share our Sacred Heart story. We are deeply grateful for your time and talent and for helping to connect our alums across generations!
About Roselie Posselius Roselie Posseliuss association with the Academy began nearly fifty years ago, when her parents brought her for an admissions interview to what was then the Academy of the Sacred Heart. She was going into first grade. Four years later she was a part of a major transition in the schools history. I was entering the fifth grade when the school became The Grosse Pointe Academy, Posselius said. It was so exciting! The faculty was for the most part new, and there were boys, which was a major shock to the system. The school had just been saved by a group of parents led by Carole Peabody and Toni Robinson, and there was this incredible energy generated toward making it all work. The group was dedicated to carrying on the mission of the Sacred Heart in a new way." After graduating from the Academy, Posselius attended high school at the Academy of the Sacred Heart in Bloomfield Hills. She received her bachelor's degree from St. Mary's College and an MFA from Pratt Institute in New York City. She reconnected with the Academy in 1987 when her close friend and GPA classmate, Catherine OBrien McCuish, asked her to join the alumni association board, which after six years voted her president of the organization. In 1988, she married another Academy alum, Peter Posselius '72, representing the first marriage of GPA alums. After having served the school for so long on a volunteer basis, Posselius returned in 2000 in a new role as a parent when her daughter, Giovanna, entered kindergarten. In 2003, she rejoined the alumni association board and now serves as president once again. "The Academy gave me a really strong foundation on which to build, Posselius said. I was prepared academically, I felt supported by everyone there, and I am very grateful for the fact that I have always felt that you can accomplish anything you set your mind to. I credit the Academy for that feeling."

item.title: At home with Montessori
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
With the kids home for an extended holiday break and after most of the Christmas presents are finally either broken or ignored, it can be sometimes daunting to keep the little ones occupied and engaged until school starts again on Jan. 4. For parents with younger children—and especially for those whose children attend Montessori schools—a little advice might just be at hand in a blog written earlier this year on POPSUGAR.com, which is a website dedicated not only to parenting but to an “all-embracing lifestyle and cheerful philosophy built around the power of happy.”

In the linked article below from POPSUGAR, blogger Kate Steilen discusses how parents might keep the wee ones occupied at home with many of the same activities inspired and advocated by Maria Montessori herself. Good advice no matter if it’s Christmas-vacation time or “any” time. . .

Bringing Montessori Home: How to Implement the Best Practices at Home

By Kate Steilen (POPSUGAR)

 

When my daughter was accepted into a public Montessori school at age 3, I only knew a few details about what that meant — a mixed-age classroom and special tools that children used that were called "work."

If your kids aren't yet in school, or you haven't encountered it before, the Montessori philosophy may seem opaque. A typical Montessori classroom has a specific layout of tools and materials to allow students to choose what they are interested in. Teachers are referred to as guides and talk about children doing "work" in a "prepared environment," engaging with the "peace curriculum" and "spontaneous self-discipline." None of this sounds like my child. But Maria Montessori's ideas about children's growth — and the successfulness of her program — are interesting in their own right and easily applicable to working and playing with your children at home.

item.title: Perfect fit for transplanted New Yorkers
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Parents of second- and fourth-graders say the Academy has all the right stuff for their children. 

The MacQueen family, above, clockwise from top left, Jason, Tomia, Naomi and Caitlin, is at Caitlin's kindergarten graduation in 2012. Caitlin now is in the fourth grade and Naomi is in the second grade at GPA.

     When Tomia MacQueen stood up to talk about The Grosse Pointe Academy in front of the impressionable young prospective families in attendance at GPA’s recent Montessori Information Night last month, it was clear she was passionate about the school where she and her husband send their two children.

     After all, Naomi and Caitlin MacQueen, in the second and fourth grade, respectively, have been attending the Academy since each was 2-1/2 years old. And the MacQueens themselves didn’t just decide on the Academy willy-nilly. In fact, right after Tomia and her husband, Jason, a financial manager, moved to the Detroit area from New York—when Caitlin was a little more than a year old—they began to search for schools in the area.

     But not just any schools.

     Tomia MacQueen wanted a Christian-based school—that was number one on her rather long list of requirements.

     “Having a school with Christian foundations was very, very important to me personally, but I didn't want just any Christian school,” she said. “Everything else had to be right as well. I wanted a top-notch Christian school. We really liked the combination of small class sizes at the Academy, the curriculum content, flow, and then the transition to a more standard classroom setting after Montessori in the Early School.”  

     MacQueen also wanted a school that would support and underscore all of its students' understanding and appreciation of the differences in other ethnicities and cultures. 
     “Being an interracial family, the continuity and consistency of what our girls are taught at home in that regard was paramount,” she said. “Being in a predominantly Caucasian environment myself as a young child, I knew that our girls would go through the natural and various phases of feeling different, i.e., skin color, hair, etc., and as expected, they did. But I’ve noticed and have been extremely pleased with the level of communication and interest that the teachers at GPA have had in the well-being of not only our children, but all of their students on every level.”
Naomi and Caitlin MacQueen are in London in 2013. 
The coolness factor 
     MacQueen said that faculty and staff clearly care and often find ways to incorporate the uniqueness, or “the coolness” of each of the kids into everyday classroom life.  
     “I even once discovered, after one of my daughters struggled to find a crayon color to match her skin color, that a line of skin-tone colored pencils was available,” she said. “They were readily incorporated without question into the everyday classroom supplies by an Early School teacher who thought they were very cool. It may be a minor thing to adults, but to a child, being able to see him or herself as their own person and represented accurately in family drawings is extremely important and can have a lasting effect on their idea of the normalcy of their own color.” 
     Long story short, she said, is that her expectations of the Academy in that regard were exceeded and that she has a confidence in GPA teachers and administration that she herself never experienced as an African-American child in similar environments.  
Not just about the academics 
The MacQueens also say the education they are providing for their children cannot be measured in dollars or tuition, or even just academic results.  
     For Tomia, who grew up in Detroit and graduated from Hunter College of the City University of New York, The Grosse Pointe Academy is an investment not just in an advanced education, but in having well-rounded children who excel in their own little niches, and are appreciated for who they are, which she says can’t help but spur them into even more growth as students and unique individuals. 
Caitlin is with mom, Tomia, at a Halloween celebration at the Academy in 2013. 
     “As a third-grader, Caitlin was reading at the middle of a fifth-grade level, and as a fourth-grader she has since added about two levels to that,” MacQueen said. “Just to give you an example of how Caitlin has taken to reading, we don't really worry about or see too many electronics at the dinner table,” she said. “But we do often have to make Caitlin put away the book she's hiding under the table.”  
     According to MacQueen, Caitlin gets extra help at GPA from the school’s librarian and teachers in combining her higher reading level with appropriate content that interests her so that she continues to advance.  
     “Still another reason why we think GPA is worth it,” she added.  
Confidence, consistency and math 
It’s also worth it, MacQueen said, because her second-grader, Naomi, is in love with math, which she believes started in Early School Montessori when she began counting things with abandon.  
     “When Naomi was in kindergarten, she would annoy her big sister, who was in the second grade at the time, by doing Caitlin’s homework over her shoulder,” MacQueen said. “The kids were actually multiplying without even knowing it in the Early School, so when they got to a more traditional math methodology in the lower school, they weren't daunted. They were still learning, but not afraid of math at all.” 
     The MacQueens also have noticed an extraordinary amount of general confidence growing in each of their children since matriculating at GPA and it appears that Tomia does not doubt for a minute their decision to send their daughters to the school.  
     “When we see them confidently asking whatever question comes to mind, of anyone, anywhere, we know they are in the right place.”  
     “And when we hear them communicate a thought so clearly, articulately, AND with consideration of others, that is just further confirmation for us,” she said.  
     “It’s also when I ask Caitlin what she wants to be when she grows up, and she says ‘an entrepreneur.’ Or when—as just a 4th grader, she has consistent business plans and acts on them, works towards them, and has the confidence to expect to be backed up in her endeavor, yet is perfectly happy to go at it alone if she needs to—we feel entirely justified in our decision to send them to the Academy.
     “We’re always teaching the girls these kinds of things at home, but we also want our children’s school to reinforce what they learn at home,” she said. “That consistency is another big reason why our kids are here at The Grosse Pointe Academy.”

item.title: Chairs named for 2016 Action Auction
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
From left, above, Bill and Kelley Smith, and Robin and Kim Kendrick were named co-chairs for the 2016 Action Auction, which is slated for May 7 at The Grosse Pointe Academy.

At The Grosse Pointe Academy's Legends Party, which was held on Dec. 1 at the home of Kristi and Jim Penman in Grosse Pointe Farms, school officials announced the chairs for the 2016 edition of the Action Auction. The event, which also honored past auction chairs and former trustees, was a kick-off party for the auction, scheduled for May 7, 2016, on the Academy’s Grosse Pointe Farms campus.

Bill and Kelley Smith, and Robin and Kim Kendrick were named co-chairs for the auction and Connie and Brian Demkowicz were named honorary chairs.

“Although the auction is in May, much of the real action is already happening now,” said Kristen Van Pelt, GPA’s director of development. “Led by our co-chairs, honorary chairs and the many volunteers, plans are going full swing. They currently are gathering hundreds of donations, advertisements and corporate sponsorships as well as planning the decorations and other arrangements that will make the auction the Pointes’ biggest event of the spring.”

Last year’s auction netted more than $450,000 for the Academy’s academic offerings, scholarship and tuition assistance funds, and support for the preservation of its historic campus. 

The auction theme this year is “Fête des Amis – Together We Flourish,” and Van Pelt said the school is bringing together 49 years of community leadership for one spectacular evening.

“The event is a great tribute to the dedication and hard work of so many within our Academy family,” Van Pelt said. “So mark your calendars for Saturday, May 7, and look forward to a great night to support our school.”

item.title: 'Peaceful place'
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded: Current Academy directress discovered the advantage of Montessori and fully embraced it. The Grosse Pointe Academy employs one of the best teaching staffs in the State of Michigan. Highly educated and credentialed, from Early School to eighth grade, GPA staffers are ensuring that all students graduate with every advantage a budding high school "citizen" can possibly have. Those advantages, which the school proudly and collectively tags as "The Academy Advantage," most importantly begin in the longest continuously running Montessori program in the state. Which is where longtime "directress" Mary Jo Carrier educates GPA students--part of her family, she says--who range in age from 2-1/2 to 5. "I always tell the children that we are like a family," Carrier said. "We spend almost everyday of the week together and like a family, we work together, and we need to help each other and be kind to each other. I believe that in this way, the children feel the classroom is their own peaceful place where they play a meaningful role in caring for themselves, each other and their environment." Carrier, who has a B.A. from Marygrove College and is credentialed in A.M.S. Early Childhood, first came to the Academy "environment" in 1994 after spending a couple of years at the Giving Tree Montessori School in Detroit as a directress, and after raising a family once a short career as a medical social worker ended. "As a medical social worker, I was responsible for the placement of patients from hospitals to nursing homes or adult foster care, which needless to say was a pretty sad job," she said. So after leaving the workforce, Carrier and her husband, Mark, raised four children--three sons and a daughter--who she said are now all very active adults. "I was happy to stay home for 13 years raising our kids, keeping active in all their sports, clubs and school activities. But as education had always been a priority in our household, I began to think of returning to the work force in part to help ensure our own children would have choices for their future." Loved the Montessori 'difference' As she was exploring a new career in education, a friend of Carrier, who happened to be a primary directress at Giving Tree, asked her to come and work at Giving Tree and also to bring her daughter to begin school there. Carrier said that since her boys were a little older, it seemed like a perfect opportunity to jump back into the workforce. "I found this was a wonderful place to start working again and it's where I found my love for the Montessori way of teaching," Carrier said. "It was so different from the traditional approach in education. I loved how it stressed independence, order and the freedom to choose work and I began to see that young children were so much more capable of doing things for themselves if we just stepped back and allowed them to do so." She loved the hands-on materials in the Montessori classroom and saw how they made a real difference in each child's learning. FIND OUT MORE ABOUT GPA's MONTESSORI PROGRAM HERE "But most of all I loved to see joy on the children's faces as they took learning into their own hands, treated each other with kindness and respected their environment because they were fully invested in its care," she added. Beginning her Montessori career as a primary assistant at Giving Tree, Carrier worked with 1st through 3rd graders there for about four years after which she decided to check out the possibility of working in Montessori at The Grosse Pointe Academy, which was actually already quite familiar to her. In fact, by that time, she was very heavily involved with the school, serving on various school committees, working as a classroom assistant and even teaching science and Catholic Formation. "All the teachers at GPA were wonderful mentors and wholeheartedly supported me in getting a Montessori certificate," she said. "So after Anne Carson retired, I was lucky enough to get her classroom." Replacing a 35-year veteran, she said, was no easy task, but she jumped in with great gusto, often working from seven in the morning until six at night. "The cleaning staff finally complained that I was at school way too many hours," she said. School is beautiful, staff is friendly, welcoming Asked about first impressions of GPA, Carrier said that since she attended Catholic schools all her life, she had a built-in recognition and understanding of the legacy and traditions of GPA, both past and present. "Also, I quickly gained an appreciation for the property in all its glory of the changing seasons," she said. "The buildings, the trees, the lake--what more beautiful setting could an employee work in?!" "I loved coming to work everyday! The staff was friendly, helpful and welcoming, the children and parents were happy and everyone was glad to be at school everyday." Twenty-one years have passed since Carrier first walked through the doors of GPA. And she still loves coming to work each and every day. "Just like day one, I still believe the most important thing I can do for the children at GPA is to provide a safe, nurturing environment for every one of them," she said. "And this caring, peaceful place makes for such an optimal learning environment, where children can engage alone or cooperatively in meaningful learning experiences that will surely help them can grow socially, emotionally, cognitively and physically." Ireland roots Now that her children are all grown--three are married and all have successful careers, Carrier said--she and her husband are starting to spend more of their free time chasing around the country, visiting her kids and "four beautiful grandchildren." "Our children's interests and jobs have taken them to West Point, New York City, Washington, D.C., Ft. Leavenworth, Kan., and Traverse City," she said. "And we love to travel. In fact, we are looking forward to spending several weeks in Ireland this summer, which will allow us to discover more about our Irish ancestry and lineage that is centered in the village of Puckane in County Tipperary." item.content:encoded: Special skills testing focused on awarding scholarships for middle school The Grosse Pointe Academy is once again hosting its annual "Academy Scholars Challenge," which this year is being held Saturday, Jan. 30, from 9-11 a.m., on the school's Grosse Pointe Farms campus. School official say more than a half a million dollars in need-based scholarships are awarded to those who meet certain testing requirements. As many as three $7,500 ($2,500 per year) scholarships are available toward the Academy's Middle School, which is comprised of Grades 6 - 8. Scholarship money earned as a result of the special testing on Jan. 30 can also be applied in addition to any tuition assistance they may be receiving. Jennifer Kendall, who is the Academy's admissions director, says there will be accommodations for both students and parents during the testing period. "Also, we are encouraging parents to make arrangements to come back to the Academy for a personal interview and experience what our school is all about," she said. item.title: State of the School to feature 2012 graduate
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy alum looking forward to college says GPA prepared him well for prestigious IB school in Troy and beyond; mom agrees James Raudabaugh, a 2012 Academy graduate who will be speaking at Tuesdays GPA State of the School event, is finishing up his last semester at the International Academy, a highly rated school that consistently finishes near the top of U.S. News and World Reports list of the best high schools in Michigan. What actually got him to IA, a school that offers the rigorous International Baccalaureate curriculum to its students, was a well-thought-out written entrance test, a mother who managed to assuage Raudabaughs fears that the school may not be right for him, and eight years at The Grosse Pointe Academy. My time at GPA really helped me gain the confidence and self-awareness I needed to make the choice to go to the IA in the first place, Raudabaugh said. I initially was worried that IA was a school only for future engineers and doctors and Ive always known I wanted to definitely pursue a different path. But the best advice my mom gave me was that I should start at the IA, which begins its school year two weeks before Grosse Pointe South, and if it didn't feel right, since I also was enrolled at South, I could go to plan B and start at South after Labor Day without missing any school days. But at the end of only his first day at IA in mid-August, he told his mom to un-enroll him from South. I knew on day one it was the right place for me, even though getting up at 6:15 a.m. on school days has been hard at times and the carpool across town to Troy made after-school activities a challenge, he said. But my mother always tried to pick me up when I had to stay late for something. Raudabaugh adds that there were a number of students from his GPA class who wrote the entrance exam for IA, three of whom ended up attending the school with him. According to Raudabaughs mother, Susan Gittins, a Toronto native who now works in the Detroit area for a global consulting firm, the transition from GPA to IA for her son was very smooth. His only initial disappointment was not being able to take Mandarin at IA since he studied and enjoyed it at GPA, she said. But he quickly picked up Spanish instead and last year he actually spent time in Spain living with a family and attending a Spanish high school. From Chicago to Grosse Pointe Farms Raudabaugh lived the first six years of his life in Chicago with his family and had been in a Montessori preschool in Wilmette, a suburb of Chicago. When the family moved to the Detroit area, his mom spent a lot of time looking for the right school for him to start first grade. First of all, I wanted James to be with other kids who also had transitioned from a Montessori background into a more conventional academic program, Gittins said. She said her original plan was to move into the Birmingham/Bloomfield area and send her son to either Cranbrook or the Academy of the Sacred Heart.
Raudabaugh as a GPA eighth-grader is with his mother, Susan Gittins, in this photo taken for theschool's Action Auction.   But a redirection to the Grosse Pointe area for the family led to a meeting with then-admissions director Molly McDermott and a tour of GPA. I did research other schools in the Pointes, but GPA was the only one to meet all my requirements, Gittins said. The Academy easily ticked off all my must-have boxes, starting with the first one: having a language class in grade one. Number two was having gym/movement/exercise every day. Three was a Montessori early school so James would transition to the classroom environment alongside other children coming from Montessori; four was early music study, and finally, number five, having all of this in a beautiful and welcoming environment. Gittins said she can't say enough good things about the experience she and James had at The Grosse Pointe Academy. And she said shes always been at the ready to defend the cost of a GPA education. FIND OUT MORE ABOUT THE ACADEMY'S EARLY SCHOOL MONTESSORI PROGRAM My philosophy always has been to invest in the early years of education and then see the ROI in the high school years, she said. By the time kids get to high school, usually habits are already formed, including good and bad ones. I was comfortable sending my child to a public school for high school as I was confident the foundation had already been laid at GPA. It was worth every penny, she said. What I paid for were all the must-haves I mentioned before, she adds. Plus, studies show that language and music, along with regular exercise, are instrumental in developing young minds. Im not saying that DNA doesn't also play into it, but private schools can offer all the stimulants you need to give your child the best possible start in their education career. Focus on film school For James Raudabaugh, even though hes not yet started college, hes already got pretty clear career plans and goals. He wants to make moviesmovies that matterhe said, and when he gets to college in the fall, hes going to pursue a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree and major in film production. Hes been accepted thus far to Emerson College in Boston, University of Michigan, University of Denver, Queens University in Kingston, Ontario, and the University of Windsor. He is awaiting word on Northwestern, Syracuse University, Vassar, Wesleyan, Oberlin and Concordia University in Montreal, all of which should be able to accommodate his expected degree in the arts. Making movies is what makes me the happiest, Raudabaugh said. Ive always had a camera in my hand. I love the creative outlet of putting ideas into a visual format. Although I am not a very good artist in the conventional sense when it comes to drawing or painting, I think I have a strong artistic mindset. So film has been a good outlet for me, combined with music. Raudabaugh established a film club at the International Academy and has acted in a number of the schools drama club productions, including most recently, Shakespeares Twelfth Night. He also plays guitar for IAs jazz band and is the president of his school choir. A busy young man to be sure. But getting back and giving back to The Grosse Pointe Academy also has been a regular feature for Raudabaugh. Each fall for the past several years, hes on the Academys campus quite often as he helps out with the schools cross-country teams. He notes that its a sport that anyone can do and the feeling of accomplishment it leaves you with as you improve your time or even just finish the course is powerful for gaining self confidence. I also love the look of satisfaction on the kids faces as they cross the finish line, he said. Raudabaugh also helps out at the Academy during the summer with its innovative Camp Invention, one of the schools most popular summer camps. An added bonus, he said, is that whenever he comes back to GPA, he gets to hang out with some of the teachers he had at the school. I have fond memories of Mr. Lapadot in grades four and five, he said. And Mr. Cowan, Ms. Jerome, Ms. Roberts, and my Mandarin teacher, Lucia Hu, all were favorites as well. But, really, I can say Ive always had positive teacher experiences the whole time I was at the Academy. item.title: 'Horme' and your child's early education
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
As children move from infancy to toddler and yes, the terrible twos they often are thought of as difficult to control and willfully unruly. But Judi Orion, director of training for Association Montessori Internationale, and director of training for assistants to infancy at the Montessori Institute in Denver, Colo., says, however, that before a toddlers free will fully develops, there is a strong and special energy that is actually directing the childs behavior. Judi Orion is director of training for Association Montessori Internationale, and director of training for assistants to infancy at the Montessori Institute in Denver, Colo. That energy is often referred to as the horme, which is sometimes defined as a life force, she says. And this life force is pushing those young children to become what theyre supposed to become. She says these young children have an extremely active horme (pronounced horm-ay). So children are not being unruly or disobedient to adults, Orion says. They are in fact obeying this internal force.
Dr. Maria Montessori's philosophy advocates the belief that early childhood education should cultivate a child's desire to learn.
Montessori founder Dr. Maria Montessori originally defined this life force as part of the building of character and the formation of personality in young children. She actually borrowed the term horme from Sir Percy Nun, an English philosopher, as her own label for it.
At The Grosse Pointe Academy, children as young as 2-1/2 years old begin this character-building, this developmental journey, in the nurturing environment of the Academys Early School, the longest continuously operating Montessori program in Michigan.  
The Academy is home to Michigan's longest continuous-running Montessori program. Children in the Academys Montessori program are given the freedom to combine this horme, this very strong life force, with the excitement of learning on their own so they can perfect their own individual talents under the guidance of experienced and caring teachers. Experience this Montessori experience yourself as well as metro Detroits most comprehensive elementary-school program on March 2, from 6-8 p.m., when The Grosse Pointe Academy hosts an all-school open house on its beautiful Grosse Pointe Farms campus. In addition, GPAs Valade Art Loft & Gallery will be filled with wall-to-wall artwork that evening as part of the schools annual K-8 Student Art Show. Plus, find out how The Grosse Pointe Academy is changing STEM education to STEAM in its very innovative approach to math, science and the arts in its intermediate and middle-school academic program. item.title: 'Super' grad
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
Academy alums catch helps Broncos along path to Super Bowl Grosse Pointe Academy alum Bennie Fowler breaks free from a tackle during an AFC divisional playoff game vs. the Pittsburgh Steelers. On January 17, former Grosse Pointe Academy student Bennie Fowler came up with arguably the biggest catch of the season up to that point for the Denver Broncos in its AFC divisonal playoff game against Pittsburgh. Quarterback Peyton Manning and the Broncos faced a third-and-12 at their own 33-yard line with 8:40 left, trailing the Steelers 13-12. Denver, to that point, was just 1-of-12 on third-down conversions and Fowler had one catch for four yards. But on this pivotal play, Fowler, who currently is listed third on the Broncos depth chart as wide receiver, lined up in the slot and beat Pittsburgh cornerback Brandon Boykin on an in-route, and then broke a tackle attempt by safety Will Allen to pick up another 13 yards.
Former GPA student Fowler is a wide receiver with the Denver Broncos. Nine plays later, the Broncos scored the go-ahead touchdown that put Denver up for good in a game that took them to the AFC championship game where they beat New England. Fowler and his Broncos teammates now await the Feb. 7th Super Bowl in San Francisco where they face the Carolina Panthers. Fowler, a 2005 graduate of the Academy, who played high school football at Detroit Country Day and then in college at Michigan State University, signed with the Broncos in 2014 as a free agent. He made Denvers active roster this year after spending his first season on the teams practice squad. GPA, DCD and MSU accolades Fowlers on-field and in-classroom prowess began at the Academy, where, in 2005, just before graduating from the eighth grade, he was named Athlete of the Season, an honor given each year to a student-athlete who excels in athletic achievements, leadership abilities, academic performance and citizenship. At GPA, Fowler was the co-captain and leading scorer of the boys varsity basketball team, and set a school record for points in a season, which led to him being named most valuable player by his teammates. Fowler also played on the school's lacrosse team and was listed on the schools prestigious citizenship list. At Detroit Country Day, he was named an honorable mention all-state selection by the Associated Press as a senior all-purpose player (1,478 yards and 15 TDs). He appeared in 44 games (15 starts) during his collegiate career with the Spartans and recorded 93 catches for 1,341 yards (14.4 avg.) with 11 touchdowns in addition to 16 rushes for 102 yards (6.4 avg.) and one score. Fowler, who was an economics major at MSU, also had 15 kickoff returns for 336 yards (22.4 avg.) for the Spartans and led the team in receiving yards (622) and receiving touchdowns (6) on 36 catches (17.3 avg.) as a senior in 2013. For the Broncos in 2015, Fowler has 16 catches for 203 yards, for a 12.7 yards-per-catch average.
Fowler, far right, is with a few of his Broncos teammates on their way to San Francisco for Sunday's Super Bowl 50.

item.title: Music, (Mozart) and the Academy
item.dc:creator: costellodg
item.content:encoded:
GPA students benefiting from a continuum of curriculum in music and the performing arts 

Today, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart would have celebrated his 260th birthday. That is, of course, if he was still with us.

Born January 27, 1756, Mozart left such a legacy of music and composition before his untimely death at the age of 35 that his birthday and musical footprint are heralded with such pop-culture fervor each year that you might think he was a member of the Beatles or Rolling Stones. Well, then again, maybe not the best comparisons. . .

But while it’s unclear yet whether the next Mozart — or Mick Jagger — is currently walking the historic hallways of The Grosse Pointe Academy, a number of notable musicians have attended the Academy over the years and they likely have benefited from one of the most comprehensive music programs found in a primary school in southeast Michigan.

Former students like Jackson Smith, who has toured with the likes of Elton John, Leon Russell and Greg Allman, and who has made a name for himself as one of the Detroit area’s premier session musicians. 

Or Jackson’s sister, Jesse, a composer and multi-instrumentalist who has performed globally in many configurations, collaborating with other musicians and artists, including Soundwalk Collective, Tenzin Choegyal, Tree Laboratory, Shyam Nepali as well as her mother, Patti Smith, and brother, Jackson.

From left, former Grosse Pointe Academy students Jesse Paris Smith and brother, Jackson Smith, are with Jackson’s wife, Lisa, their mother, Patti Smith, and family friend Mike Pigeon.

Or perhaps Regan Chuhran, who was voted "Most Likely to Win a Grammy" by her eighth-grade classmates and who also played in 2008 for First Lady Laura Bush at a prestigious event held at the Grosse Pointe Yacht Club. In addition, Chuhran has been on staff at the Interlochen Center for the Arts and she sits in occasionally as an organist/pianist at St. Mark Lutheran Church in Roseville, Mich.

And we must include guitar phenom R.J. Ronquillo, who graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy in 1990, and has since been all over the world supporting musical stars like Stevie Wonder, Ricky Martin and Thompson Square. 

Noted musician R.J. Ronquillo, above, graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy in 1990. 

Ronquillo, Chuhran and the Smith siblings are just a few of the thousands of former GPA students who have had access to a music and performing arts curriculum that begins with 2-1/2 year olds in Early School Montessori and carries all the way through middle school in a continuum of music education based largely on the nine "national standards of music education" as prescribed by the National Association for Music Education. 
GPA’s Early School curriculum guide says its music program encourages "participation in singing, reciting rhymes, and poetry. Combined with movement, this program will help refine large motor skills and encourages each student to interact as part of a group. Songs, drums, stories, recorded music, finger plays and nursery rhymes all contribute to the child’s introduction to singing and pitch, rhythm, beat and patterns."  

More information on all of the Academy’s music and performing arts curriculum offerings is available online here.
