item.title: Academy students earn medals in prestigious language examination
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Two silver medals and one bronze medal highlight a strong showing by Grosse Pointe Academy students in the most recent edition of the National Spanish Examinations. Shekinah Aho (8), Emma Smith (8) both earned silver medals and Joshua Roberts (8) won a bronze medal in the annual competition sponsored by the American Association of Teachers of Spanish and Portuguese. In addition, honor awards were conferred to six students from GPA. All student participants were honored today at this mornings chapel. Attaining a medal or honorable mention for any student on the National Spanish Examinations is very prestigious, said Kevin Cessna-Buscemi, National Director of the Exams. The exams are the largest of their kind in the United States with tens of thousands of students participating each year. According to Veronica Alatorre, who teaches fifth through eighth grade Spanish, this years competition pitted the Academy students against mostly high school students. This was a great effort by all my students, Alatorre said. Some didn't get a medal or honorable mention, but they all deserve recognition for their very hard work and efforts. Academy students who scored above the national average and earned honor roll acclaim are Alexandria Belyue (7), Alessandro Cavataio (7), Lachlan Doan (7), Kaitlyn Gray (7), Angel Jones (7) and Noah Humphries (8). About the National Spanish Examinations The National Spanish Examinations are administered each year in grades 6 through 12, and are sponsored by the American Association of Teachers of Spanish and Portuguese. They are the most widely used tests of Spanish in the United States. This year, more than 160,000 students participated in the online version of the exam. The National Spanish Examinations are recognized by many administrative and teaching associations and organizations at the local, state and national levels. The National Association of Secondary School Principals has placed this program on the NASSP National Advisory List of Contests and Activities for 2016-2017.

item.title: Why Montessori
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
In a short video produced a few years ago by the Boyd School, a Montessori school in Virginia, and available on this page, we can see what a number of the worlds exceptional doers, thinkers and performers have in common: Montessori. It is proof once again of the central tenet of the Montessori philosophy that says education especially for the very young cultivates a child's intrinsic desire to learn. And do. And explore. And ultimately, to be successful contributors to their world. And like Larry Page, Sergey Brin, Joshua Bell, Jeff Bezos and Yo Yo Ma, who were once very young Montessori students themselves, children in The Grosse Pointe Academys Montessori Early School are given the same freedoms they had. Freedom to explore the excitement of learning at their own pace with carefully chosen materials designed to foster each childs individual talents all under the careful guidance of the Academys Montessori instructors. According to Jennifer Kendall, the Academys assistant head of school for early school education and admissions, children in GPAs Montessori classrooms are are taught to make individual choices based on their abilities and interests, to take Montessori materials from the child height shelves, and to develop budding interests. Our teachers foster this process by assessing the childrens readiness for a learning activity, demonstrating a skill, and guiding a childs work as necessary, Kendall said. The video is availablebelow. . .

item.title: The benefits of Montessori education
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
The American Montessori Society (AMS), which is based in based in New York City with nearly 13,000 members worldwide, is the foremost advocate for quality Montessori education, an innovative, child-centered approach to learning. Among many other resourcesavailable to its members, AMS offers below a "quick sketch" of the advantages of a Montessori education. A short video from AMS on "valuing diversity" also is included below. NOTE: The Grosse Pointe Academy has the longest continuously operating Monterossi program in the State of Michigan. From AMS: Montessori education offers our children opportunities to develop their potential as they step out into the world as engaged, competent, responsible, and respectful citizens with an understanding and appreciation that learning is for life. Each child is valued as a unique individual. Montessori education recognizes that children learn in different ways, and accommodates all learning styles. Students are also free to learn at their own pace, each advancing through the curriculum as he is ready, guided by the teacher and an individualized learning plan. Beginning at an early age, Montessori students develop order, coordination, concentration, and independence. Classroom design, materials, and daily routines support the individuals emerging self-regulation (ability to educate ones self, and to think about what one is learning), toddlers through adolescents. Students are part of a close, caring community. The multi-age classroomtypically spanning 3 yearsre-creates a family structure. Older students enjoy stature as mentors and role models; younger children feel supported and gain confidence about the challenges ahead. Teachers model respect, loving kindness, and a belief in peaceful conflict resolution. Montessori students enjoy freedom within limits. Working within parameters set by their teachers, students are active participants in deciding what their focus of learning will be. Montessorians understand that internal satisfaction drives the childs curiosity and interest and results in joyous learning that is sustainable over a lifetime. Students are supported in becoming active seekers of knowledge. Teachers provide environments where students have the freedom and the tools to pursue answers to their own questions. Self-correction and self-assessment are an integral part of the Montessori classroom approach. As they mature, students learn to look critically at their work, and become adept at recognizing, correcting, and learning from their errors. Given the freedom and support to question, to probe deeply, and to make connections, Montessori students become confident, enthusiastic, self-directed learners. They are able to think critically, work collaboratively, and act boldlya skill set for the 21st century. More about AMS: The American Montessori Society (AMS) is the foremost advocate for quality Montessori education, an innovative, child-centered approach to learning. AMS sets the high professional standards that inform Montessori education as practiced in AMS-accredited schools and taught in AMS-affiliated teacher education programs. A not-for-profit organization based in New York City, with nearly 13,000 members worldwide, AMS is also a hub of all things Montessori: an information center for its members, the media, and the public; a voice in the public policy arena; and a mobilizing force for the global Montessori community, through support services, research, and professional development events.

item.title: Action Auction 2016 proves to be big winner for GPA
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_25875" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] The Grosse Pointe Academys Action Auction in May raised more than $500,000 for the Grosse Pointe Farms school.[/caption] The 2016 edition of The Grosse Pointe Academys Action Auction was an unqualified success, according to organizers of the annual fundraising event. More than $500,000 was raised this year at the Fte des Amis Together We Flourish auction, which was held May 7 on GPAs Grosse Pointe Farms campus. The auction guests, comprised of Academy families, community leaders and corporate sponsors, enjoyed an evening of robust bidding on a selection of fabulous and unique items and experiences in both silent and live auction formats. Of particular note, the $177,000 brought in through the auctions special paddle raise was the second highest amount raised in the 49-year history of the auction. School officials said the paddle raise dollars this year are exclusively going for the benefit of Academy teachers professional development, curriculum materials and learning spaces. The massive success of this years auction and paddle raise is a huge testament to the GPA community's appreciation of the work that our faculty does every day with our students, said Kristen Van Pelt, the schools development director. Head of School Lars Kuellingsaid this years auction exceeded all expectations. I am truly amazed at how everything comes together so beautifully every year, hesaid. "And this years auction was a testament to not only the many, many volunteers and staffers who worked on this event, but it showed once again how much our school community values the work our teachers do for the students. The success of the paddle-raise, in particular, is in so many ways a tribute to our facultys deep care for our students and a recognition by our community of all that they do to provide a top-notch experience for each child, Kuellingadded. [caption id="attachment_25873" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Kim Kendrick, one of this year's auction co-chairs, speaks to guests at the May 7 event, which also raised $177,000 for the benefit of Academy teachers professional development, curriculum materials and learning spaces.[/caption] Van Pelt wanted to point out how especially grateful the Academy is for the amount of time and energy exhibited by this years auction co-chairs. A huge thank you goes to our honorary chairs, Connie and Brian Demkowicz, and to our co-chairs, Bill and Kelley Smith, and Robin and Kim Kendrick, who put in a great deal of voluntary time and energy in order to ensure the success of this years auction, she said. Van Pelt also pointed out that while the Academy has wrapped up the 2016 auction, another one awaits in 2017. In fact, 2017's event will mark the 50th anniversary of Action Auction and work has already begun to help ensure next years Fte des Amis also proves successful. Putting this event together is a year-round effort and a labor of love to support the mission of our school, and we are well on our way in planning for the 2017 auction, which is scheduled for May 13, 2017, she said. "We are looking forward to celebrating 50 years of successful auctions at The Grosse Pointe Academy next spring. More information on the 2017 auction is here.

item.title: A family affair
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Personal attention, focus on values and a top-notch early school program drove family with four children to the Academy (Updated July 29, 2016) When Grosse Pointe Academy parent Sandra Cavataio talks about GPA to prospective parents looking for a quality education for their young children, she never hesitates to say that the personal attention that each student gets is without equal. She also says thespecial attention they get usually results in graduates who are extremely ready for high school, college and beyond. Cavataio should know. She and her husband, Pietro, have had three of their children graduate from the Academy and a fourth, current 7th-grader Alessandro, graduating next spring. I usually tell people that the regular classes at GPA are just like honors classes at the public school, she said. I also talk to them about being so impressed with the Christian values instilled in the children and that the students are very confident and present themselves very well because of all of the many opportunities to shine. In addition, languages are very strong at GPA and many of the students there end up in level-3 languages during their high school freshman year. When Cavataio and her husband first moved to southeast Michigan years ago, education for their children was of primary importance. After all, she holds bachelors and masters degrees in industrial engineering from Louisiana Tech University, and husband, Pietro, is a family-practice physician with an office in Chesterfield, Mich. Cavataio said she originally heard about The Grosse Pointe Academy from another parent at a Gymboree store in metro Detroit and began to ask more questions about GPA to her realtor, which ultimately led to a house in Grosse Pointe Shores and her children at the Pointes premier private school. I attended private primary and secondary school and my husband attended public schools, Cavataio said. But even though the Grosse Pointe public schools had a pretty good reputation, I told him I felt very strongly about private schools and he has come to see the big advantage. She also said they kept hearing that GPA had the best early school program around, which was a definite factor since her family was still quite young when they first moved into the area. Fast forward to 2016, Joseph Cavataio, the oldest of the Cavataio children, is finishing up his first year at the University of Michigan after graduating from Cranbrook-Kingswood a year ago. Joseph is studying physics and engineering at Michigan. He said hes interested in both medicine and engineering and thought those study tracks would be a great way to combine both fields of interest. Students who major in engineering and physics typically score the highest on the MCATs (Medical College Admission Test), so it's a great vehicle to medical school if I chose to go that route. Looking back at his time at the Academy, Joseph wanted to make sure we noted how well-prepared he was for his high school classes. My freshman year at Cranbrook was relatively easy for me since I was so far ahead academically, Joseph said. Ive noticed that many other students from The Grosse Pointe Academy also ended up doing well with some going into leadership positions at Cranbrook, ranging from class president to editor of the school newspaper. Josephs brother, Piero, graduated from GPA last spring and followed his brothers footsteps to Cranbrook, and his sister, Gabriela, matriculated to University Liggetts upper school after the Academy. Summing up The Grosse PointeAcademy experience after many years in the school community, Sandra is quite happy she received such an early tip about the school when she moved to the area. The faculty always has been very dedicated and go well out of their way to help the children, she said. And because of that, I believe, the kids end up excelling in high school and beyond.

item.title: What connected technology and Maria Montessori have in common
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_25916" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Nov. 2, 1946: Maria Montessori visits a classroom in Acton, London. Photo: Kurt Hutton, Kurt Hutton / Picture Post / Getty Images /[/caption] The essenceand some would say the beautyof the Montessori approach to education is its emphasis on a childs need to move, explore and manipulate the world around him or her in order to better understand it. Program founder Maria Montessori said that a childs hands and developing brain are intimately connected. The dilemma facing many Montessori schools now that technology is overtaking all things educationincluding at the earliest levelsis how can the fundamentally hands-on Montessori way of teaching coexist with technology that is available at the touch of a mouse or the swipe on a glass screen? And how can education technology, or EdTech, a now multi-billion dollar industry centered primarily in Silicon Valley, help younger students who most assuredly need the physical stimulus Montessori recommends? In an article originally publishedlast year, author Amanda Rosenburg discusses some of the important developments in educational technology, which is connecting todays youngest students in more productive ways with the decidedly un-technical Montessori method of learning. The Grosse Pointe Academy offers Michigans longest continuously operating Montessori on its Grosse Pointe Farms campus. More information here. What connected technology and Maria Montessori have in common By Amanda Rosenburg The non-touch model of edtech is changing, thanks in part to the century-old theories of early education pioneer Maria Montessori. Ask a child to sit on her hands while she solves a problem, and it will feel like an insurmountable task--for both the educator and the child. But let her pick up an object, hold it, inspect it, experiment with it--and it becomes clear that a childs thinking is grounded in touch and movement. This is the essence of traditional Montessori education, which emphasizes childrens need to move, explore and manipulate the world around them in order to understand it. Montessori believed that a childs hands and developing brain are intimately connected. Her belief can be easily observed in practice by watching any kindergartener try to solve a math equation by counting on his fingers or building a block tower. [caption id="attachment_25915" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Students at The Grosse Pointe Academy work with technology that incorporates both physical and digital sensory activity.[/caption] But what happens when technology becomes a central point of instruction? How do the youngest students engage with the educational content found in apps and games while still feeling and touching the world around them? Traditional Montessorians, for example, have warned that the current influx of technology is developmentally inappropriate for young learners. Today's classroom technology falls short of embracing a young childs senses and skill set. That's because the types of technology early learning classrooms offer their students lack the opportunity for tactile interactivity. Most common are tablets, computers, projectors, or digital cameras, all of which place a high value on output. Few of these technologies require physical manipulatives--things kids can touch and play with--that also connect to the digital realm. But this is changing. Companies are re-imagining and redefining education technology so that classroom computing becomes a more tactile experience for hands-on activities and learning. This approach, called connected technology, involves pairing a physical object the child can hold, such as blocks, with a digital interface, such as a tablet or robot. Sometimes, those objects are used to gather information, as is the case with Tigglys tablet-compatible physical manipulatives, or MaKey MaKeys invention kits. With products like Spheros app-enabled robots, the the physical object is on the receiving end of the data. Why is connected technology so important for a young learner? The simple answer is that it takes the essential aspects of tactile play and builds a bridge to the digital world. While enhancing cognitive learning in young students, connected technology also puts control back into the childs hands--quite literally. Finding a balance between the technology and the tactile is important especially for classrooms that use tablets. Connected technology also offers the immediate and personalized feedback that is unique to a digital learning environment. [caption id="attachment_25914" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Academy students have access to some of the most advanced and balanced age- and grade-appropriate technology in the U.S.[/caption] Multiple studies have shown that integrating connected technology into curriculum leads to higher engagement, greater enjoyment and better collaboration while learning. Going forward, edtech developers need to consider the role of touch when creating technology for early elementary children. And early childhood educators must carefully weigh the pros and cons of each type of technology they add to their classrooms. When teachers first see connected technology being used in the classroom, they usually dont need to hear the why. The potential impact on students learning is obvious. Maria Montessori would be pleased to know her learning theories have not only withstood the test of time, but are being applied in the new wave of connected technology. (Oct 6, 2015)

item.title: Life skills, academic rigor and dedicated teachers
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Current and alum parent says no greater return than on investment in childrens education. [caption id="attachment_25939" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Caleb Williams, left, and Kelsey Williams in a family photo from a few years ago. Caleb graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy in 2013 and Kelsey now is going into 7th grade at the Academy.[/caption] When current parent Latrelle Williams and her husband, Shawn, would drive down Lake Shore Road almost daily on their way to work or on errands beginning around 2008, they noticed the stately looking school near Moran Road, but aside from marveling at its architecture and the beautiful campus on which it sits, nary another thought about The Grosse Pointe Academy would cross their minds. That is until their son, Caleb, started to tell his parents on a regular basis, One day Im going to that school. Finally, his words gave life to his statement and my husband decided to visit a GPA open house, said Latrelle Williams. And then, as they say, the rest is history. Caleb enrolled in the Academy and graduated in 2013, and daughter, Kelsey, is heading into the seventh grade when school starts again in September. And mom says she couldnt be happier with what GPA has brought to her children. GPA is a school where children learn to earn not because they feel entitled to win, or get a good grade or to just show up, Williams said. This is a school where life skills are complemented, academic rigor propels you, strong character leads you, and dedicated teachers educate you way beyond mediocrity. [caption id="attachment_25940" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Shawn Williams, left, and Latrelle Williams were high school sweethearts. They both recognize the value of a good education, especially the one their children are getting from The Grosse Pointe Academy.[/caption] She also said the Academy is a place where not only the teachers are caring and compassionate, but it also flows from the head of school and all staff members. In addition, the strong parental involvement at the Academy shines brightly throughout the community thus proving that it takes a village to raise a child, Williams added. Williams and her husband both graduated from Cass Technical High School in Detroit. We were high school sweethearts, she said. Latrelle went on to the University of Michigan and Shawn to Western Michigan University. They both currently are successful business people with Latrelle making her way through a career in finance and Shawn in marketing and healthcare. So it's clear the Williams both recognize the value of a good education. It's a sacrifice and an investment, she said, but I don't know of any greater return on investment than having your child in a private-school environment like GPA that is so nurturing, challenging, inspiring and that includes a real sense of safety and security. I just wish there was a GPA high school!

item.title: Four more from Maria
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
As we get closer to Maria Montessoris birthday, which is August 31, The Grosse Pointe Academy, home to Michigans longest continuous-running Montessori program, is pleased to offer four more inspiring quotes from this most innovative educator. "The childs conquests of independence are the basic steps in what is called his natural development. In other words, if we observe natural development with sufficient care, we see that it can be defined as the gaining of successive levels of independence." (From The Absorbent Mind, originally published in 1949) "Knowledge can be best given where there is eagerness to learn, so this is the period when the seed of everything can be sown, the childs mind being like a fertile field, ready to receive what will germinate into culture. But if neglected during this period, or frustrated in its vital needs, the mind of the child becomes artificially dulled, henceforth, to resist imparted knowledge. Interest will no longer be there if the seed be sown too late, but at six years of age all items of culture are received enthusiastically, and later these seeds will expand and grow." (From To Educate the Human Potential, originally published in 1947) "Yet a third interesting fact to be observed in the young child is his need to associate himself with others, not merely for the sake of company, but in some sort of organized activity. He likes to mix with others in a group wherein each has a different status. A leader is chosen, and is obeyed, and a strong group is formed. This is a natural tendency, through which mankind becomes organized. " (From To Educate the Human Potential) "Education for the very young is not a direct continuation of that which has gone before, though it is built upon that basis. Psychologically there is a decided change in personality, and we recognize that nature has made this a period for the acquisition of culture, just as the former was for the absorption of the environment." (From To Educate the Human Potential) Learn more about the Academys Early School Montessori program here.

item.title: A bright future
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
New head of school looks to bright, active future at The Grosse Pointe Academy. [caption id="attachment_25987" align="aligncenter" width="1200"] New GPA head Tommy Adams, second from right, is with his wife, Kendall, and sons Colin, Griffin and Logan in Mercersburg, Pa.[/caption] When Thomas Tommy Adams started his tenure as The Grosse Pointe Academys new head of school this summer, he said he wasnt planning to spend too much time sitting back and relaxing. Theres a lot of work to do, he said, and hes looking forward to rolling up his sleeves on July 1 and getting to it. A thoughtful, ambitious and personable leader, Adams, who left a position as assistant head of school for enrollment at Mercersburg Academy in Mercersburg, Pa., said he wants to hit the ground running at GPA. To be sure, my family and I looked forward to arriving this summer and having the opportunity to meet and get to know all members of the GPA family, he said. I also want to quickly build up a level of trust and communication within the community at GPA, both internally and externally, so that we can begin to move this school to the next level in important ways. I plan to work very hard and look forward to working with our faculty and staff, he said. Its going to be a busy summer and fall. Spending a summer and fall in Grosse Pointe also is something Adams is looking forward to. Other than the airport, he said he had never been to the Detroit or Grosse Pointe area before his first GPA interview in February. Although Ive always heard amazing things about the Pointes, its quite different when youre actually here, he said. Its beautiful, and my family and I are excited to become part of the school and local communities. He also said it reminds him a bit of Long Island, New York, where he grew up. [caption id="attachment_25986" align="alignright" width="250"] Adams grew up on Long Island, New York.[/caption] My father was a head of school in an independent school on Long Island, and I had the opportunity to live in a community somewhat similar to Grosse Pointe, he said. Both communities are full of people who take a lot of pride in their towns. For example, at the recent GPA Action Auction, I really sensed that people here parents and staff are very proud of their school and community. I also sensed that many people have been in the area for a lifetime and are really tuned into their community and school roots. Despite his fathers professional experience and his own background as a boarding school student, Adams never planned on a career in education. Instead, as his college graduation approached, he looked toward what he and many of his classmates at Roanoke College thought was their destiny: a career in business. I was teaching tennis during the summers when I was in college, and I hired a young woman to help me with the kids, he said. Her father was headmaster at Northwood School, a boarding school in Lake Placid, New York, and he and I had a number of conversations about the fact that I loved working with and coaching kids. He asked if Id ever thought about becoming a teacher, which I had not, and then asked if I would ever consider applying for a job at his school. I had attended Avon Old Farms School, which is a boarding school in Connecticut, and I loved my experience there. So I thought this might be a great first step. I could do this for a couple of years and then Id go get, quote-unquote, a real job. So, with a bachelors degree from Roanoke College in hand, off he went to Northwood School. By Thanksgiving break, he knew working in schools was his calling and went on to spend the next three years teaching social studies, being a dorm parent, and coaching three seasons of athletics. I loved it. I loved working with kids, loved the fact that I was having an impact on their lives. I felt that this was what I was meant to do. But after those three years at Northwood, he developed a passion for working with families as they considered boarding school. Once he found an opportunity to work in admissions, Adams never looked back. He worked at two small boarding schools before landing at The Gunnery, in Washington, Connecticut and then Mercersburg Academy, the two schools where he would spend the bulk of his career. The familys ties to these schools run deep: eldest son Logan graduated from The Gunnery last year, and son Colin will begin his senior year at Mercersburg this fall. The familys youngest son, Griffin, will start at GPA come fall. Being a parent of a current student has allowed me unique insight into these schools, and Kendall and I look forward to having the same experience at The Grosse Pointe Academy. John Murphy, who is board chair at the Academy and was very involved in the schools head of school search process, said Adams is the perfect choice for the school at this time. Tommy will be a real asset to GPA, he said. He brings a wealth of admissions experience and talent in independent-school administration to our school. But, even more important, he will be bringing a very obvious and infectious enthusiasm to our campus that will be critically important as we are setting some rather ambitious goals for the Academy. Adams tireless work in school administration over the past two decades in school makes him a unique and strategic choice to take the helm at GPA. People may think, and theyre probably right, that I am the unconventional choice for head of school at the Academy. I have been working externally outside the classroom for the last 21 years. But the role of director of admissions is no longer what it used to be thirty years ago. My role has expanded from not only focusing on the external piece of the institution, but understanding the internal piece as well. My career in boarding school has further enabled me to do what I most enjoy: work closely with students as an advisor, dorm parent, and coach. He said admissions professionals need to know and completely comprehend and be able to fully explain the programs, the teaching, the value of all of that is their institution. Because when families are weighing their educational choices, he said, you need to understand the workings of your institution, including the programmatic piece and the teaching piece. You need to believe deeply in the people and philosophies that make up your school. And you need to contribute to its growth in order to meet the evolving expectations of the market. Adams is by nature a leader who challenges those around him to think differently and to work progressively to improve themselves and their institution. His involvement in Mercersburgs all-encompassing program review crystallized for him and for the school just how different todays world is from the one he and most educators grew up in. The way I look at it, said Adams, is that teachers today are less the providers of information, and more the coaches of that information. Think about it. Anything that teachers teach to a child today is available on the Internet with one or two clicks. So I see teachers not in front of the kids, but more behind them, coaching and helping them to learn for themselves and from each other. That to me is a very striking difference between classroom teaching today versus thirty years ago. Adams also thinks that his admissions experience with primarily high school students has given him a rather unique insight into what a successful incoming freshman looks like, and what kind of elementary and middle-school education is necessary to get into quality high schools. I clearly see the difference in the kids coming from an independent school, he said. These kids tend to transition much better to a school like Mercersburg because of their experience in schools like The Grosse Pointe Academy. Independent schools are the best at bringing out the best in kids, he said. And thats how I see our jobs as educators. Teachers in independent schools, I believe, are quite different in that they really feel they have a definite stake in making the kids successful students, athletes, artists, etc. I dont think you get that quite to this extent anywhere else. So what does Adams see as initiatives or needs for the Academy right out of the gate on July 1? For one thing, we need more people coming through these beautiful doors, he said. Plus, I want to strengthen relationships with those constituents from the past, i.e., alumni, alumni parents, previous donors, etc. Inquiry is an endless process yet essential if independent schools want to compete in a expanding market of educational options, Adams continued. Together, we will work thoughtfully to build a school whose graduates are well-prepared to meet head on the challenges of an ever-changing world. Yet as we move forward, we must always remain true to the institutions important and meaningful traditions.

item.title: Open-source success in Mali
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Recentproject by nonprofit run by alum passes remote test with flying colors. [caption id="attachment_26018" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Preparing sand for water-filtration device in Mali.[/caption] Mali is a landlocked country in West Africa where half of its population lives on less than $1.25 per day. Access to clean water is a major problem, particularly in rural areas where 45 percent of the people lack access to clean water. In a blog post published yesterday by OHorizons, a non-profit coalition of technical, social and commercial innovators managed by Grosse Pointe Academy alum Natalie Relich (01), a recentwater project in Mali received critical "off-site" help from her organization, whichpassedthe test of making clean water available and affordable for residents thousands of miles away who desperately need it. Project Profile: Mali + making the OHorizons wood mold construction manual open-source June 30, 2016 Population: 14.5 million Capital: Bamako Official language: French Currency: West African CFA franc; population living on less than $2/day: 90% [caption id="attachment_26016" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Village children in Mali play in and around an empty well. A majority of the population in this West African countrylives on less than two dollars a day.[/caption] In 2014, OHorizons received an urgent email asking for assistance from the Mali Water Project, a nonprofit student organization formed at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign that had developed and was implementing a safe drinking-water project with the help of local community members in the remote village of Konilo-Coura in Mali. The Mali Water Project was started in 2010 when Dr. Osee Sanogo, a postdoctoral research associate at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and a native of Konilo-Coura, decided to create an interdisciplinary student team through the universitys Learning in Community Course. His vision was for this organization to support his home village in the creation of a reliable, economically feasible and sustainable solution to their water shortage and quality problems. Heres what Dr. Osee Sanogo had to say about the situation in Konilo-Coura: There is no running water. People get water from hand-dug wells that are not protected and are often contaminated from above ground sources as demonstrated by our biological water-quality check during the visit. The UI Mali Water Project traveled to Mali twice. The first time was in June 2011 with eight people to do a baseline survey and get a better understanding of the situation. The team returned in June 2014 with five people to actually implement their context-appropriate safe drinking water projects including the implementation of biosand filters. When the second group arrived in Mali in 2014, they realized the steel mold they had contracted to be made by a local welder for their biosand filter project had been made incorrectly. They started searching for an immediate solution to their dilemma. They found OHorizons online, were intrigued by its wood mold innovation, and contacted the organization about the possibility of using its design for their project. [caption id="attachment_26015" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign professor Valeri Werpetinski, at right, with Konilo-Coura community members.[/caption] At this time, OHorizons construction manual wasnt yet open-source and the organization had only been a part of bioSand filter projects in which it had directly facilitated the training's in-country. Through its pilot projects earlier in 2014 in Bangladesh and Ecuador, OHorizons had seen that the trainees had intuitively understood the construction manual and how to make the mold, OHorizons executive director Relich recalled. In those settings, our team actually provided little formal training, she said. We were mainly ensuring that safety precautions were being taken and answering any questions as they came up. Relich said they saw the student group in Mali as an excellent test to see how a project would function without OHorizons being there to supervise. After a phone call with the MWP, to get a better understanding of who theyd be working with and the needs of the community they were working with, Relich sent OHorizons construction manual to their team in Mali. They immediately downloaded our construction manual and purchased the necessary materials, Relich said. Within a matter of days, they had successfully constructed several wood molds and were pouring filters. They did all of this in West Africa with very little instruction from the OHorizons staff and with no electricity! This was a very exciting development for OHorizons, according to Relich. The entire reason behind inventing the wood mold was to reduce as many barriers as possible (financial, technical, etc.) to getting a drinking water project underway, she said. Even though the OHorizons team had seen that our construction manual had the potential to be self-taught, Relich said it was still exceptional to see how smoothly a group of students, who a week before were unaware of the innovation, were able to follow our step-by-step manual and work with illiterate community members to construct the wood molds. Seeing that the mold could be made with little to no input from OHorizons was a big deal to us, Relich said. We realized that we needed to make the manual open-source so more people, like the group from Illinois, could potentially benefit. Horizons then concentrated its next couple of months on making the construction manual shorter, as user-friendly as possible and more visual. Utilizing its in-the-field experience from the in-person trainings, OHorizons was able to cut the manual down from about 180 pages to around 80 pages. [caption id="attachment_26017" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] GPA alum Natalie Relich ('01), far right, on an earlier filter project in Bangladesh after building molds to be used for special water-filtration devices.[/caption] Today, the construction manual and its accompanying appendix are super easy to follow and available to download for free from the OHorizons website. The organization is currently translating its manual and appendix to Spanish, French and Portuguese. These versions of the manual should be available to chose from on OHorizons website by late fall 2016. Since making our construction manual open-source in April of 2015, more than 280 people and organizations from more than 40 different countries have downloaded our wood mold construction manual from our website, Relich said. From OHorizons: We believe access to safe drinking water is a human right and with your support we're working diligently to make it a reality. With a $10 donation to OHorizons, you can give a person clean drinking water, right inside their home, for life! To make a donation to our clean water initiatives, please visit: www.ohorizons.org/donate. More about The Grosse Pointe Academy and its academic offerings is here.

item.title: Academic and career boost aided by GPA
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Nineteen-eighty-eight grad is making a career on screen and stage. [caption id="attachment_26035" align="aligncenter" width="1200"] Grosse Pointe Academy alum Catherine (Worth) Chittick ('88) said both high school and college were made much easier because of GPA.[/caption] When 1988 Grosse Pointe Academy alum Catherine (Worth) Chittick left the Academy, she had her future career already planned out. She said it was partly because of a class she had taken with GPA teacher Mary Lou Fettermann that she wanted to be a forensics pathologist (CSI-style). I was involved in forensics at GPA with Miss Fettermann, Chittick said, but that started my love for acting and storytelling. Plus, I also really think my experience playing Anna in the opening of Ms. (Marion) Chrisners The King and I made me want to continue to pursue acting and musicals in high school. But even at five years old, my involvement in performing was well entrenched. I started playing violin back then along with piano and singing, so I guess the arts were always part of my life. [caption id="attachment_26041" align="aligncenter" width="1200"] Chittick recently acted in a Verizon commercial, which can be viewed below.[/caption] The arts, in fact, and not forensic pathology, are now where Chittick firmly resides.She lives in Los Angeles with her actor husband, David Chittick, and two children and shes been a professional actor in more than nine TV and film roles, including The Proposal and According to Jim. Her stage experience is even more extensive with more than 13 roles, including nine lead roles, in LA, Chicago and Detroit. Chittick also does TV commercials with her most recent work for Verizon and Walmart. SMOOTH TRANSITION A fine and performing arts graduate of Wayne State University, which she attended after four years at Mercy High School (Farmington Hills), Chittick said the transition into both high school and college wasmade much easier because of GPA. [caption id="attachment_26036" align="alignright" width="250"] Chittick also manages a professional photography business in California.[/caption] I loved the small class sizes at GPA, and Mercy, which also had small classes, was a great transition, she said. I felt completely prepared for high school, especially in science. Mr. (Michael) Fultz and Ms. (Sheila) Connolly made science so much fun. As a matter of fact, I attribute my high grades in college science also to them. GPA created my love of science, and I still remember many of it today. Im even still great at classifying trees! As a high school student, Chittick was a member of the National Honor Society, the Whos Who of high school students, and traveled with the People to People International student ambassador program. She also received a half-tuition scholarship to Wayne State. After graduating from college, Chittick moved to Chicago to more fully pursue acting. She performed in quite a lot of theater productions around town, but six months into her stay in Chicago, she got a call to come back to Detroit to audition for The Second City, a comedy theater and training center in the Detroit area. OFF TO LA After performing on the main stage for almost two years (writing and performing in five different shows), my husband (David) was accepted to a UCLA graduate program for theater, Chittick recalled. We moved to California and I started working in theater in Los Angeles. Then I toured with R&B singer Brian McKnight, played violin in his band, and I started booking roles in commercials and television. As an aside, I just recently filmed a commercial for Walmart that actually is airing this summer. Meanwhile, Chittick still has many fond memories of her time at the Academy, which began for her as a fifth grader well, actually, it almost DIDNT begin as a fifth grader. I almost didnt make it to fifth grade at GPA, she said. I had come from a school in my neighborhood and had never taken standardized tests. So when I originally took a test for a different school in Grosse Pointe, they said they would not accept me in fifth grade. Then, when I took the test for GPA, the administration suggested that I repeat fourth grade. But after interviewing me, they decided to let me start in fifth. I was on the high honor role every year that I was at GPA, so I am grateful that the school gave me a chance. I loved Mr. Fultz and all of his trips while at GPA, she said. I still talk to my kids about them. And I loved Mr. Ski (Gary Skwarczynski) and his English class. I can still remember reading The Lottery by Shirley Jackson in his class, which began my love for dystopian literature. French teacher Madame Anne Franco began my love of French and I spent nine years going to French camp because of her. I even went to France with the People to People organization partly because of her, and I still speak Franglais at home with my own children. item.title: New issue of school magazine now available online

item.title: Whats in a Montessori classroom?
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_26115" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Students at The Grosse Pointe Academy begin their educational journey in the nurturing environment of the Academys Early School, the longest continuously operating Montessori program in Michigan.[/caption] In a blog first published on the website buildingthepinktower.org titled Walk into a Montessori Classroom, the Montessori approach to education is discussed as one that offers children intentionally prepared environments that are "full of beauty and order." It also talks about Montessori environments as designed to meet the developmental needs of each child," and alive with movement and sound. Check it out below. . . In addition, take a look at the following short video, which was created as part of the documentary film project, Building the Pink Tower.Itgives a glimpse of a typical Montessori school classroom. More information on The Grosse Pointe Academys Montessori program Michigans longest continuously running Montessori program is here. Walk into a Montessori Classroom Montessori environments are beautiful, full of natural light, wooden beads and blocks, books of all kinds, and flowers in glass vases. Montessori classrooms are alive with movement and sound. Students, whether 5 or 15 years old, move about the classroom to take things off shelves, to discuss a project with a classmate, to put things away. Montessori students are busy. Some are working alone, bent over a mat on the floor or sitting at a small table. Some are gathered around a teacher, in conversation during a lesson. Others are working in groups, their voices and bodies and minds engaged in collaborative work. In a Montessori classroom, order and creativity coexist. Animated conversation and silent observation work together in the same space. In the best environments, children of all races and cultures learn side by side. Through careful observation of how children work and interact, Maria Montessori developed what we think of as the Montessori Method more than 100 years ago. She began her work in the slums of Rome, and her vision has spread throughout the world. The Montessori approach offers children intentionally prepared environments that are full of beauty and order. Materials in the classroom are appealing and designed to meet the developmental needs of each child. Montessori-trained teachers are the bridge between the environment and the student, first through careful observation of each child, and then by providing appropriate instruction and guidance. What do children in a Montessori classroom gain? They learn reading, math, science, history, and geography the subjects they need to know. But they get this knowledge through their own desire to learn, by following their passions and making connections between ideas and subject areas. They seldom learn only by listening to a teacher or reading a text book. Instead, they learn by doing things, working collaboratively, making mistakes, and solving problems. Rather than learning only well enough for the next test, this kind of learning sticks, reaching far beyond tests and becoming a part of each childs identity, helping them to emerge fully in their world. item.title: Understanding other cultures
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
GPA Spanish teacher says to become true community ambassadors, students must learn that culture is as important as learning a second language. [caption id="attachment_26147" align="alignright" width="257"] Spanish teacher Veronica Alatorre has been at The Grosse Pointe Academy since 2011.[/caption] Winning national awards and finishing strong in language competitions are fairly routine for students of The Grosse Pointe Academy. In fact, a number of students brought home top medals late in the last school year from the National Spanish Examination, one of the most competitive tests of Spanish for students living in the United States. Much of the schools success with such competitions can be attributed to GPAs strong emphasis on world languages for all of its students. And perhaps no one personifies that focus more than Veronica Alatorre, who has been teaching fifth through eighth grade Spanish at the Academy since 2011. A graduate of Centro Universitario de la Comunicacion in Mexico City who first came to the United States in 2000, Alatorre has quite a comprehensive and unique approach to the Spanish language for her students. I try to teach the kids to communicate in Spanish by using their own thoughts, feelings and ideas, said Alatorre. I don't want them to memorize and repeat, but to use the tools I give them as a means to express themselves and to be able to use them anytime in the future. Its an approach to teaching foreign language that works best when its used by native speakers who also bring an inherent first-hand cultural experience, according to Alatorre. Culture is as important as language, she said. It helps to minimize mistakes and misunderstandings, it gives a more accurate phonetic pronunciation and promotes tolerance. It also teaches the kids about perspectives of life and that being and thinking different is perfectly okay. [caption id="attachment_26154" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Alatorre loves the outdoors and sports, including kayaking. According to Lawrence DeLuca, who is the principal of grades 1-8 at the Academy, Alatorre is one of the most caring teachers he's ever met. "Her class is always filled with fun ways to teach Spanish, and she does a great job covering high school Spanish I and preparing our students for Spanish II," he said.[/caption] Different might also be a good word to describe the route Alatorre took to becoming a Spanish teacher at the Academy. Currently a single mother with four children of her own, Alatorre was a creative and ambitious child growing up in Mexico. She came from a fairly traditional family where there were certain expectations for the children, especially for the girls. An initial desire by Alatorre to pursue a medical career was met by some resistance in the family. My first choice was to study medicine, but my parents said that career was not for girls and that it would keep you away from home too much, Alatorre recalled. I don't really blame them; it was another culture, another generation and another mentality, where girls were raised only to be a mom and wife. [caption id="attachment_26168" align="alignleft" width="250"] Alatorre has been a competitive runner for many years.[/caption] Her parents apparently were okay with a communications career, however, as she jumped into a university degree program with both feet. Communications was a second career choice for me, but since it required a rather outgoing personality and a creative flair, I actually think it was tailor-made for me. So I went to college and studied for a communications degree. After college and after eventually settling in the states in 2000, Alatorre was offered a job by the popular and ubiquitous Berlitz world language company. It was a job that I thought would keep me occupied as I adjusted to life in the states, she said. I was eventually trained and certified in the Berlitz method, which is an immersion program of language for adults. She quickly began teaching Spanish more and more to people working in the business world and, after her boss told her that he thought she had the personality to teach children, she was offered an opportunity to teach them as well. At first I had my doubts, but I gave it a try, she said. I took the Berlitz Jr. immersion training method for kids and received official certification in it. Then I was sent by Berlitz to different schools in the Detroit metro area, including public, charter and private schools. So it was kind of a happy accident of destiny that I became a teacher. I love it and have stuck with it for the last 16 years! [caption id="attachment_26148" align="alignright" width="300"] Alatorre is with her son Danny and daughter Veronica, who graduated from the University of Michigan.[/caption] Alatorre came to the Academy through a referral from a now-retired first grade teacher at GPA, and arrived with stellar references and experience that included many Berlitz assignments, including some in the Grosse Pointe Public School System as well as at the Neighborhood Club of Grosse Pointe. She also spent some time as an on-call' interpreter assigned mostly to children cases that ranged from juvenile services, protective services, Vista Maria's foster care services to the Department of Immigration and for various courts. According to Alatorre, when she first arrived on the GPA campus, she knew she had found a home. I immediately thought it to be a place where all of the faculty and staff were part of one big family, she said. The families of our students somehow seemed connected as an extended family of the faculty. Most of the teachers and students lived in the same community and the social and academic life was extremely busy during class hours and sometimes outside of the classroom. I remember saying at the time that its the best organized chaos Id ever seen. Scott Tily, who was principal at that time, laughed when I told him. He knew it was true as he had about 40 years himself working with young students. But it was and still is a wonderfully peaceful atmosphere of learning for both teachers and the kids. Outside the peaceful atmosphere of the Academy classrooms, however, this hard-working teacher has been a steady participant in running competitions and marathons for years. Alatorre was a competitive runner at the state level as a master female and also qualified at the national level in 2012 as a master female in the 5K. In 2011, she also won 3rd-place overall in her class in the 30K State Championship in Milford, Michigan. [caption id="attachment_26153" align="alignleft" width="300"] Alatorre's son Roberto is in the Marine Corps stationed in Hawaii. Here he is being formerly promoted to the rank of sergeant.[/caption] I was training 60-85 miles a week for seven years, she said, but I didn't knew that I was overextending myself, and because of my bad natural running-gait mechanics, I ended up with a triple knee fracture that left me out of competitive running for good. She said she still loves outdoors and sports, but now she jog-walks very short distances and it seems shes passed her passion for sports to her kids. They all either run, lift weights, play lacrosse, and one of my youngest did two kids triathlons, she said. And Danny, my youngest, ran for a while with me but now likes biking. I really love outdoor activities and would gladly exchange a week at a 5-star hotel for a backpack hiking trip in the woods or trails. Meanwhile, back at The Grosse Pointe Academy, Alatorre talks more about her approach to the responsibilities of teaching young and impressionable middle school students. I believe that all of us become ambassadors for our country, our school and for the communities in which we live, she said, whether that is in our culture or our language or in different ones. The students experiences with teachers like me who may have come from a different country can be a fulfilling experience that opens doors much wider for them to accept and understand other cultures and to work out any differences together as a team. Along with the regular Spanish lessons, I also try to teach my students about history, geography, climate and how people really live in other countries without any stereotypes. I also want to encourage my students to travel whenever and wherever possible and to fully appreciatetheir role as positive ambassadors for their own local cultures.

item.title: Academy gets ready for new term
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
School makes more progress this summer on maintenance, preservation and beautification plans. [caption id="attachment_26175" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Summer work on The Grosse Pointe Academy's Early School includes tuckpointing, a chimney rebuild and roof repair.[/caption] Keeping up with The Grosse Pointe Academys beautiful and historic campus requires constant attention 12 months a year. But during the summer months when students and most of the faculty and staff are taking a much-deserved break, members of the Academys maintenance crew are working extra hard to get the buildings and grounds ready for Sept. 7, when the schools first through eighth graders arrive, and Sept. 12, when the Early School kicks off. By far it has been the busiest summer of my 22-year career here, said Kevin Alt, who manages GPAs maintenance department. We started the summer off by restoring our lawn sprinkler systems, which included replacing dozens of heads, fixing numerous underground leaks and repairing a number of wiring/timer issues. Alt noted that the front berm along Lake Shore Rd. at the front of the school has never been as green as it is now, especially given this very hot dry summer. Visitors to the school this summer also likely noticed the scaffolding affixed to the outside of the Early School building. Alt said he had contracted with Grosse Pointe-based Madison Maintenance LLC on a big project that included tuckpointing the entire old section of the building, rebuilding its chimney and repairing the stairs. He said Madison will be redoing the Early Schools flat roof next week. [caption id="attachment_26176" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Since 2013, the Academy has been working through an aggressive facilities-improvement plan that prioritized program needs and security as well as the historic preservation and beautification of campus buildings.[/caption] GPAs internal maintenance crew also has been busy with repairing a large section of wall and rotted beams inside the entrance to the new section of the Early School, plus plastering and painting miscellaneous areas throughout the building. In addition, we removed the large overgrown evergreen bushes around the newer building and will be replacing them with smaller boxwoods and fresh mulch, Alt said. The children's garden received improvements as well. As a part of its strategic plan released in 2013, The Grosse Pointe Academy embarked on the first phase of an aggressive facilities-improvement plan that prioritized program needs and security as well as the historic preservation and beautification of campus buildings. Since then, more impressive progress has been made on other campus improvements, including those made this summer, the majorityof which were made possible by the continued generosity of school friends and donors through the Academys annual Action Auction, most notably from the paddle raise at last years auction. Other summer projects this year at the more than 120-year old campus, according to Alt, included moving the schools innovative STEM lab to a different classroom, installing a new 8,000 CFM exhaust fan to provide better ventilation, repairing plaster, painting numerous walls as well as the usual summer work of polishing floors, cleaning carpets, and keeping up with the lawn and landscaping. Alt also noted that the large barn on campus received a new roof during the summer and will geta new red paint job in the fall. In addition, we planted five new pear trees along the nuns walk area and installed metal edging around the garden areas to help control the intruding lawn, Alt said. My crew works very, very hard all year round and takes a lot of pride in what they do, he added. There is a reason they are all in such good shape and wear running shoes to work!

item.title: A hope and a promise for mankind four from Dr. Maria
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
As we recentlypassedthe birthday (Aug. 31) of Dr. Maria Montessori, founder of the Montessori method, one of the worlds most innovative education philosophies, The Grosse Pointe Academy, home to Michigans longest continuous-running Montessori program, is pleased to offer four morequotes from this most innovative educator. The child is capable of developing and giving us tangible proof of the possibility of a better humanity. He has shown us the true process of construction of the human being. We have seen children totally change as they acquire a love for things and as their sense of order, discipline, and self-control develops within them.... The child is both a hope and a promise for mankind. (From Education and Peace, first published in 1949) We recognize the immense power, the unconscious forces existing in the child on the threshold of life. For many years we have been proclaiming that it is necessary to educate the child from the moment of birth. We have traced, through study and practical experience, the ideal path leading to the world of children, of these beings whose social status has as yet not been determined, whose rights have not been recognized and who nevertheless represent the world of tomorrow. (From The San Remo Lectures, 1949) Do we believe and constantly insist that cooperation among the peoples of the world is necessary in order to bring about peace? If so, what is needed first of all is collaboration with children.... All our efforts will come to nothing until we remedy the great injustice done the child, and remedy it by cooperating with him. If we are among the men of good will who yearn for peace, we must lay the foundation for peace ourselves, by working for the social world of the child. (From the Sixth International Montessori Congress in Copenhagen, 1937) Education should not limit itself to seeking new methods for a mostly arid transmission of knowledge: its aim must be to give the necessary aid to human development.... If the formation of man becomes the basis of education, then the coordination of all schools from infancy to maturity, from nursery to university, arises as a first necessity: for man is a unity, an individuality that passes through interdependent phases of development. Each preceding phase prepares the one that follows, forms its base, nurtures the energies that urge towards the succeeding period of life. (From Childhood to Adolescence, first published in 1948) Learn more about the Academys Early School Montessori program here.

item.title: Prepared for high school, college, a business and stressed-out brides
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Alumand business owner says the Academy helped set her up for success with company in Detroit [caption id="attachment_26206" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Grosse Pointe Academy alumCarrie Gentry runs her business, Touch of Elegance Events & Designs, out of Detroit's Renaissance Center.[/caption] The wedding business is a $165-billion industry, with over 2.4 million weddings each year and thats justin the United States. Statistics show that the average wedding takes approximately 250 hours to plan, which is more than six full work weeks. According to the American Association of Certified Wedding Planners (AACWP), preparing for a wedding is one of the most important and stressful tasks a couple will ever do. The AACWP also says that in recent years, there has been an exponential growth in professional wedding planning for these stressed future brides and grooms. And one certified professional wedding and event planner in particular, who is located in Detroit, has been crazy busy with stressed customers and she credits The Grosse Pointe Academy with helping her stay ahead of all the work. GPA not only prepared me for the rigors of high school work but it definitely taught me the priceless skills of time management and perseverance, which one needs in abundance in this business, said Carrie Gentry, who graduated from the Academy in 2003and is owner operator of Touch of Elegance Events & Designs. I love helping couples have a stress-free wedding day and making their dream designs a reality all while staying in their budget. Seeing happy couples on their special day never gets old! Gentry, who has planned weddings held in GPAs chapel, said shes looking to takeher business beyond Detroit and Michigan as well. She currently is based downtown in Detroits Renaissance Center. My goal as a wedding planner/designer and business owner is to continue to provide excellent customer service and designs to our clients in the Detroit area, she said. But I also would like to expand and have Touch of Elegance hubs located in other major cities in the U.S. From fashion design to weddings Gentry originally didnt have wedding planning on her career bucket list when she first set foot on the campus of Savannah College of Art & Design in Georgia. She was working toward a BFA in fashion marketing and management when one of her closest classmates asked her to design and coordinate her outdoor wedding with only found objects and a budget of $300 (including food!). That was quite possibly one of the hardest tasks anyone has ever asked me to do, she recalled. After the wedding concluded, the couple told me how elegant it was and how I really should make wedding planning a career. [caption id="attachment_26207" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Gentry, who has planned weddings held in GPAs chapel, said shes looking to expand her business beyond Detroit and Michigan.[/caption] So, even while continuing to pursue her education and career as a fashion designer, she dipped her toe in wedding and event planning during her senior year at SCAD. But after I graduated, I went back to pursuing a career in the fashion industry in Detroit, she said. However, my mother convinced me that Detroit was making a comeback and that this was the best time to get into wedding planning and design. She told me numerous times that there are always weddings happening in Detroit, but usually everyone has to go far out of the city to find a wedding planner. Of course, mom always knows best and Touch of Elegance Events & Designs was born, Gentry said. I soon began to professionally design and plan weddings as well as make other specialty items for brides, such as veils and boleros, etc. Work ethic from GPA Gentry attended high school at University Liggett. She said that if it wasnt for some timely tutoring from an Academy teacher before getting into GPA, she may not have even attended GPA let alone Liggett. Before my first year at GPA began, which was in the middle school, I had to be tutored by Mrs. (Denise) Phelps all summer long, Gentry said. At first I was apprehensive because I was never very good at math. As the summer went on, I began to understand and actually grow to really like algebra. On the first day of school, I truly felt prepared and comfortable and was able to tackle any problem, math or otherwise. If it wasn't for Mrs. Phelps, I never would have survived! FIND OUT MORE ABOUT THE ACADEMYS MIDDLE SCHOOL PROGRAM HERE. She also had a big shout out to another former GPA teacher (and coach). Mr. (Michael) Fultz, who constantly required the best out of me in school as well as in volleyball and tennis, taught me how to have good work ethic, Gentry said. He is one of the reasons why I also played both sports in high school I actually was captain in both sports and received numerous scholarships to college. item.title: The five key learning areas of Montessori
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
In a recent posting, Australian Kylie D'Alton, operator of the popular blog, How we Montessori, talks about how practical life and sensorial exercises form the foundation for language and maths within the Montessori classroom. The Grosse Pointe Academy offers Michigans longest continuously operating Montessori program to its Early School students. More information on GPAs Early School Montessori, which currentlyhas limited openings available for the fall term, is here. The five key learning areas of Montessori By Kylie DAlton How we Montessori July 27, 2016 It is clear that many parents don't know a lot about what goes on inside the Montessori classroom. There are, of course, parents who are very knowledgeable. So today, parent to parent, I thought I would briefly cover the five key learning areas in early Montessori. In the home, I am aware of these areas and before my children started school full time, I definitely looked over and ensured we covered or touched on all of these areas. It really made me feel like we were delivering a whole range of activities. While on our shelves I kept our materials together, in the classroom there are shelves and spaces for each area. In the classroom, you will find 'Practical Life' shelves and 'Maths' shelves. One of the important things to keep in mind in Montessori is that no area works in isolation. Practical life and sensorial exercises form the foundation for language and maths. Culture can be incorporated into all areas. The five key areas of learning in the Montessori environment include; Practical Life, Sensorial, Language, Mathematics and Culture. 1. Practical life includes life skills to help develop independence, coordination, concentration, self-control, self-awareness, confidence and include: - Care of Self (food preparation, dressing, washing), - Care of Environment (cleaning, gardening, care of pets, environmentalism), - Grace and Courtesy (greetings, manners, social interactions), - Control of Movement (refining movements, walking the line, moving quietly). 2. Sensorial activities allows the child to refine each of their senses: - Sight (visual), - Touch (tactile), - Smell (olfactory), - Taste (gustatory) - Sound (auditory) - Stereognostic (kinaesthetic). Includes the manipulation of specifically designed materials that isolate qualities. Refines fine motor skills, visual and auditory senses and develops coordination and the ability to order and classify. Materials include Pink Tower, Brown Stairs, Knobbed Cylinders, Color Tablets. 3. Language is based on phonetic awareness. Children work through specific hands-on and tactile language materials such as the sandpaper letters to the moveable alphabet. Language is not an isolated topic but runs through the curriculum. The spoken language is the foundation for writing and then reading. 4. Mathematics is developed with the use of concrete learning materials. The sensorial area is the preparation for mathematics. Hands-on materials are used such as number rods, sandpaper numbers, number boards, spindle box, number tiles, beads, and games. Each exercise builds upon another and the child gradually moves to from concrete to abstract areas such as place value, addition, subtraction, multiplication, and fractions. 5. Culture allows the child to explore the natural world around them and includes: - Geography (continents, landforms, earth layers, solar system), - Zoology (classification, physiology of animals), - Botany (ecology, classification, physiology of plants), - History (time lines, using a calendar), - Science. Art and music could be considered cultural activities, however, creativity is encouraged across all curriculum areas. The cultural area is clearly identifiable by globes, puzzle maps, flags and perhaps images or materials from other cultures. Most schools cover these areas with a bit of a description on their websites. While not completely necessary, I believe it helps to know the Montessori basics. When you walk into a Montessori classroom and can identify the areas, it all make sense!

item.title: New research says preschool provides significant benefits
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
A new study by the National Institute for Early Education Research at the Graduate School of Education, Rutgers University, reveals that children who attended Pre-K outperformed those who had no Pre-K experience in every measure. NOTE: Students at The Grosse Pointe Academy begin their educational journey in the nurturing environment of the Academys Pre-Kindergarten Early School, which is the longest continuously operating Montessori program in Michigan.
[caption id="attachment_26296" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] The Grosse Pointe Academy offers the longest continuously operating Montessori program in Michigan.[/caption] New research says Pre-K provides significant benefits Researchers working long-term with WVDE to assess student progress, classroom quality (August 23, 2016) Rutgers University, NJ First-year findings in a long-term National Institute for Early Education Research (NIEER) and Marshall University study of young students and early education classrooms (in West Virginia) reveal performance advantages among children attending Pre-K and provide useful information on classroom quality. Results include: Children who attended Pre-K outperformed those who had no Pre-K experience in every measure Benefits of Pre-K were most profound in print knowledge Classroom quality averages all exceed minimal quality, and several demonstrate higher quality On average, classrooms demonstrated high quality in fostering a nurturing and safe environment The initial West Virginia Universal Pre-K Evaluation showed, on average, children with Pre-K experience outperformed those without Pre-K in every measure. Benefits were large and statistically significant, with the widest margin in print knowledge. We recognize that our states future depends on early investment in our youngest citizens, said State Superintendent of Schools Dr. Michael Martirano. We must ensure that every child has access to high-quality preschool to build the foundation for success. In addition, the study scored both Pre-K and kindergarten classrooms above average for emotional support, such as fostering and nurturing and safe environment, and organization. These findings are detailed in a new report, the first in a series spotlighting Pre-K education in West Virginia. NIEER is proud to partner with Marshall University on behalf of West Virginia Department of Education on this five-year study of how the states Universal Pre-K program affects child outcomes, with a specific focus on reading outcomes. The study, launched in August 2015, includes 599 children starting Pre-K, and 573 children starting kindergarten who had attended Pre-K, in seven counties, Fayette, Greenbrier, Kanawha, Nicholas, Putnam, Roane and Wood. Researchers will follow the progress of these children through completion of third grade. About half the children are girls, more than 90 percent are white and about 73 percent are from low-income households. In upcoming years, additional students and families will be invited to participate. Researchers evaluated skills including language, print knowledge, math, and executive functions such as memory, self-control, and attention. High quality preschool education has been shown to close achievement gaps afflicting American children from minority and low-income familiesand this study shows similar effects in West Virginia. The goal is to provide a comprehensive understanding of childrens development over time, classroom environments and teaching practices across the participating counties, enabling WVDE to develop a data-driven approach to continuous improvement across all classrooms. Researchers also are evaluating the quality of Pre-K and kindergarten classrooms, focusing on Pre-K and kindergarten rooms in the same seven counties. Evaluation includes both environmental factors and teacher-child interactions, measuring Space and Furnishings, Personal Care Routines, Language and Literacy, Learning Activities, Interaction, and Program Structure. Results show a range of classroom quality, demonstrating some classrooms are of good quality and others have room for improvement. Teacher experience also varies, with Pre-K teachers generally having less experience teaching and fewer graduate degrees. We applaud West Virginia for its leadership in providing quality early learning opportunities, said Shannon Ayers, Ph.D., associate research professor at NIEER. We look forward to continuing our work with the West Virginia Department of Education and educators across the state to help achieve the best outcomes for children. More about the NIEER: The National Institute for Early Education Research (www.nieer.org) at the Graduate School of Education, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ, supports early childhood education policy and practice through independent, objective research. ### Learn more about the Academys Early School Montessori program here.
