item.title: Academy alum 'maintains the momentum' for climate change solutions
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_26345" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] GPA alum Jesse Paris Smith is with her mother, Patti Smith, after a recent concert.[/caption] Grosse Pointe Academy alum Jesse Paris Smith continues her advocacy for Pathway to Paris, which is a collaboration between musicians, artists, sustainability consultants, cities and activists to highlight solutions to climate change, and to help turn the Paris Agreement on climate change into real action. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon has called on countries to present their respective instruments of ratification in New York on September 21. In an effort to maintain the momentum for the initiative, Smith, who is the daughter of music legend Patti Smith, helped organize a concert event on September 19 with a number of musicians and leading thinkers to highlight the importance of making the Paris accord real. A video that was put together by Jesse Paris Smith recently in Detroit and publicizes the September event is available below. Smith said next week'sevent in New York will feature musical performances from David Johansen with Mercury Rev, Martha Wainwright, Nicole Atkins, Bill McKibben (350.org), Xylouris White, Lucy Wainwright Roche, Suzzy Roche, Techung, Jesse Paris Smith andRebecca Foon (Pathway to Paris), and will call on world leaders to quickly turn climate commitments into action. item.title: Alum pursues art career in the UK
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
George Spica is studying art in London after attending NYU and completing residency in Iceland. [caption id="attachment_26393" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Grosse Pointe Academy alum George Spica, right, undergoes a portfolio review while at Interlochen Arts Academy in northern Michigan.[/caption] Grosse Pointe Academy alum George Spica (11) is currently pursuing his art education in London where he attends the Slade School of Fine Art at University College, the highest ranked art school in the UK. This after the Interlochen Arts Academy graduate spent a year at New York Universitys prestigious Steinhardt School in Manhattan. I found myself being taught things at NYU that I had already thoroughly covered at Interlochen, an experience I think many Interlochen alums have in college, Spica said. In an effort to step up the level of instruction, Spica received permission to take studio courses for upperclassmen so as to challenge himself further, even though he was only in his first year at NYU. However, he said, it wasnt enough, and the general lack of opportunity for him there led him to look to other schools. I applied for transfer to smaller schools in the U.S., but the institutions that really caught my interest, particularly for their different approach to arts education, were those in the United Kingdom, he said. I was accepted to all the art schools to which I applied in London, and in May, I accepted a place in one of the BFA Fine Art courses at the Slade School at University College in London. University College is the founding college of the University of London, and is one of the most influential institutions in British higher education. I am very pleased with the prospect of studying art here as I find the urban environment vastly different from that of New York much calmer and diverse. Academy academics helped set him up for success in high school and beyond Spica attended The Grosse Pointe Academyfrom preschool to grade eight. He said that what he finally realized upon graduation from Interlochen was that the tradition and rigor that characterizes a GPA education is in fact what enabled him to engage in more unorthodox means of learning in hishigh school years. [caption id="attachment_26390" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Silent Portraits I-VI, 2015. High-definition three-dimensional body scans (George Spica)[/caption] In other words, I was so comfortable and well-versed in my academics after graduating from the Academy, he said, I was far more open to the idea of alternative-learning methods as I matured in the context of an art school. MORE ON THE GROSSE POINTE ACADEMYS ACADEMICPROGRAM IS HERE. After graduating from Interlochen in 2015, Spica had numerous offers for colleges and universities before he finally settled on NYU. He was accepted to the acclaimed Bard College in New Yorks Hudson Valley and the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, where he was offered a substantial scholarship, but he thought New York University was the best fit for him at that time. Now in a much better place at The Slade in London, he said hes looking forward to greater things for his career, which seems to be already flourishing by most any measure. Outside of school, I have a couple of exciting things going on, he said. While in New York, I was accepted to an artist residency called Nes Listamist, which was held in Skagastrnd, a small town in North West Iceland. I spent this past June and July there in my own studio producing a new body of work, predominantly sculpture and video works. [caption id="attachment_26391" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Above, from Spicas work in Iceland. A portion of Spicas artist statement says, My work has always been physical, it was born out of an insular search for the limitations of my own body, but resulted in something far more comprehensive. Capitalizing on the conventional relationships between human consciousness and tactile objects, I have sought to evoke, within those relationships, simply what I perceive to be beautiful.[/caption] At the end of those two months, he curated a show composed of this new work in the residencys gallery. Im really pleased with this new work; it helped me recenter on my sculptural inclinations, something that drives my practice, and certainly something that was encouraged by the space and isolation that Iceland provides. Within the next three years, he said he will also be pursuing more substantial gallery representation in Europe. More on Spica is available here.

item.title: 'Informed, reasoned' citizens
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Academy social studies teacher says most important part of his job is encouraging students to make sounddecisions for the public good. [caption id="attachment_26408" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] GPA social studies teacher Trevor Clor is with his son Benjamin after Ben's graduation from the Academy kindergarten.[/caption] For GPA middle school teacherTrevor Clor, educationwas always his first choice for a professional career. And since hes had a real passion for history and culture as long as he can remember, teaching always seemed like the best way to share his knowledge and learn more himself. When I was growing up, my parents were kind enough to plan our family vacations around visiting Civil War battlefields, said Clor, who has been teaching at The Grosse Pointe Academy since 2009. In fact, Im fairly positive I was the only third grader at my school who dressed up as a Civil War cavalry soldier for Halloween. This former Civil War soldier also is fairly positive he teaches at the best school in southeast Michigan, if not the entire state. When I first came aboard at GPA, I was truly impressed with the community feel among the students, parents and staff here on campus, he said. GPA has a family atmosphere like no school I've ever seen. The Academy was not Clors first stop in his teaching career. He also spent time at Ferry Elementary in Grosse Pointe Woods and Hamtramck Charter Academy in Hamtramck. But without a doubt, along with its amazing academic program, GPA's buildings and grounds are stunningly beautiful, he said. It truly is the whole package and I get excited every day I come to work. Lawrence DeLuca, who is the Academys assistant head of school for instruction and principal for grades 1-8, said Clors enthusiasm is very evident. We are so excited to have Trevor teaching middle school social studies this year, DeLuca said. He truly has a passion for social studies and the excitement he brings to his classroom is almost palpable. Clor, who received his degree from Central Michigan University, also seems laser-focused on what he thinks is his primary responsibility on campus. By far, the most important part of my job at GPA is guiding my students to make informed, reasoned decisions for the public good as citizens of a culturally diverse, democratic society, he said. That's a huge responsibility, but I'm confident that it can be accomplished for each student with the support of my colleagues on staff here as well as the entire school community. [caption id="attachment_26407" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Clor is with his two sons and his parents on a recent trip to Walt Disney World in Florida.[/caption] Since first arriving at the Academy community seven years ago, Clor said the school has seen tremendous improvement in its curriculum and its technology especially its technology. The biggest change I've seen has been our updated technology. Converting to a Mac-based school and supporting 1:1 iPad use for all students was a massive undertaking that Megan Black and Robert Rochte navigated us through extremely well. The addition of the garden classroom also was a welcomed change. It adds life to our school like no other spot on campus. We asked Clor what he thought he might be doing with his life if he wasnt educating children. If I wasn't a teacher, I think I would like to be a travel agent, he said. I absolutely live for adventure and travel. There's no better way to learn and understand people than by going out in the world and experiencing it for yourself. He said hes been extremely fortunate in his relatively young life to have had the opportunity to travel all over the globe. However, there's always an exotic new location waiting just around the corner! When Clor is not on the GPA campus or traveling the world, he and his two sons, Benjamin and Matthew, can be seen snowboarding, eating at National Coney Island or cheering on the Detroit Tigers and Red Wings. Also, my parents have a residence on Higgins Lake in northern Michigan and another in Lakeland, Florida, which are two of my favorite places to visit, he said. Around the Pointes, my kids and I do a lot of playing outside and Im always looking for live music somewhere.

item.title: State of the school address planned for January 31
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Preparing a new generation of learners: State-of-the-school address to feature plans for the Academy. On Tuesday, Jan. 31, at 7 p.m., The Grosse Pointe Academy Head of School Tommy Adams will lay out future plans for the school and how they will positively affect the schools current and future students. One of the things I will discuss for those attending on Jan. 31 will be a perspective on what Ive observed and learned during my first six months as the Academys new head of school, Adams said. I also will talk about the effects of the current educational landscape on independent schools, and the plan to implement changes that will help improve the quality of the learning experience for our students and better position the Academy in the market. During the evenings presentation, which is being called, Preparing A New Generation of Learners at The Grosse Pointe Academy, Adams said he also will present the schools new vision for moving forward at GPA, which resulted from working with a select group of faculty and administrators over the past several weeks. There will be specific and concrete examples of programmatic change and revision to help enhance the learning and teaching that take place in the classroom at the Academy, Adams said. I believe that those attending this event definitely will want to hear about these changes and how it will positively impact their childrens experience at GPA. I look forward to seeing our many parents there. Preparing A New Generation of Learners at The Grosse Pointe Academy The Grosse Pointe Academy State of the School Address Tuesday, Jan. 31, 2017 at 7 p.m. The Grosse Pointe Academy - Tracy Fieldhouse 171 Lake Shore Road, Grosse Pointe Farms Hosted by Tommy Adams, Head of School Parents strongly encouraged to attend; no children please. item.title: Prime foundation
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: Alum twins pursuing doctoral degrees say the Academy prepared them well for the rigors of high school and college. [caption id="attachment_26105" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Christian, left, and Christopher Love graduated from the University of Michigan in 2013.[/caption] Christopher and Christian Love graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy in 2004. Since then, these identical twins have continued to blaze important and consequential trails in both high school and college, and it appears that the world at large also will benefit from their future trailblazing. Christopher is currently pursuing his masters degree in higher education at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. His long-term professional goals include higher education leadership as well as diversity and inclusion work for underrepresented minority students. He also plans to pursue and begin a doctoral program in higher education by 2018. Christian is currently the Leadership in Higher Education M.Ed. program coordinator and a rising second-year doctoral student in higher education at the University of Washington College of Education in Seattle. He said his long-term professional goals include higher education leadership, but he also has a strong passion for teaching and advising students, as well as non-profit management. I often joke with my brother that one day we both will lead a college or university together with Christian serving as president and me serving as vice president for student life and diversity, Christopher said. [caption id="attachment_26104" align="alignright" width="300"] Christopher, at right, makes a strong point to his brother, Christian.[/caption] Both Christopher and Christian received their undergraduate degrees from the University of Michigan. They enrolled at U-M after graduating from University of Detroit Jesuit High School in 2008 and both wanted to study pre-med and attend medical school after four years at Michigan. Unfortunately, we did not have a very strong science background in high school and were not passionate about the course load during our first two years at U-M, said Christopher. So after reflecting and talking with advisors and mentors, we both decided to concentrate in psychology with a minor in Afro-American and African studies. I think its because of our professional, personal and civic engagement experiences that we enjoy learning about people and understanding how the mind works and why individuals interact the way do. Christopher said that he also understood how to read people well and connect with them on an emotional level, which helped him develop good listening skills throughout life. This connection to people at one point got me interested in becoming a psychiatrist, he said, I wanted to support families and communities by helping them process and work through their respective challenges and concerns. In Christians case, he decided to pursue psychology because of his mentoring and peer-support experiences. Having had the opportunity to mentor young people while in high school and serve as a support system for my friends and colleagues, I knew a change of academic scenery was imperative and important for me, he said. Being in a biology or chemistry lab no longer fulfilled my passion, so I decided to enroll in an introductory psychology course with Christopher and was inspired ever since. Both twins said that the Academy was key to getting them off to such a great start in both college and high school. Our transition from GPA to high school was rewarding, first of all, because we were introduced to diversity at such a young age, Christian said. Growing up in Detroit, we did not have much exposure to diverse populations and resources. But the Academy certainly prepared us physically, mentally, and emotionally to have those conversations about race and identity as well as how to interact and engage with diverse individuals through the lens of race, ethnicity, religion and socioeconomic status. [caption id="attachment_26103" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Christopher, left, and Christian said that their educational experiences at the Academy definitely prepared them for high school and beyond.[/caption] He said that during their time at the Academy, they were oftentimes taught to engage in class, support their classmates and seek help from teachers when needed. This certainly was a prime foundation for us once we began our high school tenure, Christopher said. Given our educational experiences at the Academy, we were definitely prepared for the academic rigor at U of D Jesuit because we immediately formulated ideal study skills and positive networks at the beginning of freshman year that carried over year to year. Due to their scholastic, athletic, artistic, and civic experiences at the Academy, the Love twins also were fortunate enough to get involved in numerous extracurricular activities in high school. Such opportunities, they said, included the high school football and track teams, a community service organization (the Christian Service Team), a young man of color organization (BASE-Black Awareness Society for Education) among several other clubs and organizations. BASE was a space for young men of color to pursue and facilitate professional development and community service opportunities as well as engage in dialogue about current events and societal facets affecting young men of color locally and nationally, Christian said. Plus, given our introduction to and ensuing passion for performing arts, we also had the privilege of performing in two high school musical productions, Crazy for You and Guys and Dolls. A big shoutout and much respect and admiration for (GPA teacher) Marion Chrisner for introducing us to such a beautiful art form while we were at the Academy. Besides Chrisner who they said they loved because of her passion and pride in connecting with students through the performing arts the Loves had high praise for all their teachers at the Academy, but they recalled a few more as being especially influential for them. Mr. Lapadot was another, Christian said. He inspired me to find my voice through reading and writing as well as by serving as a leader in the classroom. He also helped me develop an affinity for spelling and motivated me to represent my class in the school spelling bee. He served as a great mentor, leader, friend and support system for not only my brother and me, but for the entire Love family as a whole. Sasha (Ovshinsky) Murphy also was singled out by the twins. Ms. Sasha inspired and motivated both of us to really consider our physical and emotional health while sparking our leadership potential in the gym and on the field, Christopher said. She also pushed us to aim high on our presidential fitness tests every year! [caption id="attachment_26102" align="alignright" width="296"] Christopher, left, and his twin brother, Christian, were born two months early and each weighed two pounds.[/caption] So what was it really like growing up as identical twins? We asked. They said the twins experience has been a phenomenal one and theyve grown to be the best of friends, teammates and confidants. We are each others biggest supporter, critic, and ultimate competitor, said Christopher. Being known as C1 and C2, Love Brothers, Love Twins, Chris and Chris, and the Brothers of Love also has shaped our collective journey in real and profound ways. As we finally embark on establishing our own separate identities, we still will continually uphold the values of twinning and brotherhood. Living as identical twins for the last 26 years has been a rewarding and phenomenal experience for both of us, added Christian. Being born two months premature, weighing only two pounds, and facing a number of adverse challenges along the way have motivated and inspired both of us, he said. I really believe this bond we share has inspired these two Detroit miracle babies to become strong, committed and driven young men aspiring to become great leaders and advocates on a daily basis. So what does the future hold for Chris and Chris? Given their academic and professional experiences at U-M, Christopher and Christian both confirmed that theyve settled on pursuing a career in higher education. They also noted that they both a got a bit of a head start when, after graduating from U-M in 2013, they served with City Year, an AmeriCorps education-based program that aims to support young people along their educational journey. Christian served with City Year - Seattle/King County where he supported 8th-grade students in an English/language arts class for one year before pursuing his masters degree at the University of Washington. Christopher served with City Year - Detroit where he supported 9th-grade students in an English/language arts class for one year before returning as a team leader for his second year with City Year - Detroit. A busy couple of young men, to be sure, and if more proof is needed, we are providing a summary of only a few of the honors and accolades these two have accumulated in such a short time: Christian was a member of the National Honor Society, Cum Laude status (U of D Jesuit) (2009): Both Christian and Christopher were presented with the City of Detroit Emerging Leader Award from Detroit City Council member Alberta Tinsley-Talabi (2008): Christian inducted into National Honor Society, Cum Laude (U of D Jesuit) (2008): Both received full academic scholarships to the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor Additional college scholarships: Michigan Promise Award, Michigan Tradition Award, Big Brothers, Big Sisters of America Scholarship, Anschultz Community Service Scholarship, Wayne County Vision Fund, Archdiocese of Detroit Scholarship and the Unity Baptist Church Education Scholarship (2009): Both featured in the Detroit Free Press for outstanding mentorship (2010): Both inducted into Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc. (Delta Rho Chapter) (2011): Christian received NPHC Neophyte of the Year Award (2012): Co-recipients of NAACP-UM Chapter Community Service Award (2012): Christian received Distinguished Greek Leader Award (2012): Christopher received NPHC Greek Male of Year Award (2012): Christopher received Michigan Difference Rosalie Ginsberg Service Award (2014): Christian received City Year - Seattle/ King County Pride Award (2015): Christian received College of Education Student Leadership Award More about The Grosse Pointe Academy and its academic offerings is here. item.title: Professional development a critical part of Academy's program excellence
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Five GPA teachers get innovation grants for 2016-17 school year. [caption id="attachment_26354" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Claudia Leslie teaches French at The Grosse Pointe Academy and chairs the school's professional development committee.[/caption] The White House announced in Septemberthat more than $25 million in new grants is being awarded immediately by the National Science Foundation (NSF) to expand computer science education for all students. Part of that grant will go to professional development for teachers for instruction. NSF anticipates an additional $100 million investment to this initiative over the next four years. While the NSF grant is focused on professional development for computer science instruction, continuous improvement for teachers in all subjects is a major focus for schools nationwide, public and private. According to Learning Forward, a Dallas-based association advocating for educators, when parents of students are asked what they want for their children, there is overwhelming agreement that they want the best teacher possible in every classroom. The most important factor contributing to a students success in school is the quality of teaching, the organization said in a report titled Why Professional Development Matters. While parents may not be familiar with this research, Learning Forward said they are united in their desire to ensure great teaching for their children every day. And while professional engineers, designers and architects, etc., routinely congregate in seminars and workshops to share best practices, conduct research, and study trends and issues as part of their continuous career improvement, school teachers are no different. Those charged with educating children get together often for professional improvement, and school-sanctioned professional development (PD) days to stay on top of trends and technology that affect the work they do with students are an important part of that activity. That is especially evident at The Grosse Pointe Academy, where a combination of on-campus and off-site PD days, seminars and classes contributes to making its faculty one of the most well-qualified and innovative teaching staffs in the state. Professional development is very important for the school, said Claudia Leslie, a grade 5 French teacher and language specialist at the Academy who also chairs the schools professional development committee. It is crucial for the teachers to keep up-to-date with technology for the classroom, new curriculum resources, and new research on how children learn. Inspired and informed teachers influence students achievement in many positive ways. And that's when exceptional learning takes place. In any given year, The Grosse Pointe Academy typically sponsors one main PD day in the fall and one in the spring. Teachers also use three days for professional development before the students return in the fall and two after they leave at the end of the year. Innovation grants Off-campus, there also areplenty of opportunities for GPA teachers to gain additional knowledge and skills. During the year, a number of our teachers visit schools across the country to gather and share ideas, said Jennifer Kendall, assistant head of school for Early School education and admissions. She said the Academys Innovation Grant program, which is funded in part by the schools annual auction, is integral to the schools success. Its main intent is to provide faculty and staff with opportunities to visit and learn from cutting-edge programs at other independent schools across the country, Kendall said. [caption id="attachment_26372" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] From left, GPA teachers Cheryl Carroll, Bridgette Murray, Trevor Clor, Holly Willson and Claudia Leslie earned Innovation Grants as part of the schools professional development program.[/caption] Leslie agrees that the IG program is critically important. It gives our faculty and staff opportunities for further professional development, she said. After the innovation grant recipients visit these other schools, they share their observations with the faculty and staff. They bring back new programs and instructional techniques that are oftentimes implemented at The Grosse Pointe Academy. This school year, five members of GPAs faculty and staff were awarded innovation grants: Cheryl Carroll, Early Schoolgrade 3 physical education Trevor Clor, grades 68 social studies, grade 6 grammar and composition Claudia Leslie, grade 5 French, language specialist Bridgette Murray, grades 68 language arts Holly Willson, grade 5 Leslie, who is in her fifth year as chair of the PDC, said shes very excited to be able to visit two schools in the San Francisco area this year as a result of her GPA innovation grant. I can't wait to share my observations and ideas with our faculty and staff!

item.title: Academy students once again honored with CATCH assignment
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
For the 9th year in a row, students from the Academys middle school are chosen to emcee prestigious charity event. [caption id="attachment_26467" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Academy students, from left, Lorie Savage, Courtney Mecke and Abby Keane will be emceeing the 2016 CATCH Night of Champions on October 19.[/caption] Abby Keane, Courtney Mecke and Lorie Savage, middle school students at The Grosse Pointe Academy, have been chosen to emcee at the CATCH Night of Champions, which will be held Oct. 19 at The Henry Hotel in Dearborn. Its the ninth year in a row that Academy students have been chosen for the annual event, which this year inducts journalist, author and broadcaster Mitch Albom, TV news anchor Amy Andrews and commercial real estate developer Nathan Forbes into its hall of fame. The Night of Champions helps benefit sick and needy children through the CATCH program, which was initiated in 1987 by former Detroit Tigers manager Sparky Anderson. Specifically, CATCH (Caring Athletes Team for Childrens & Henry Ford Hospitals) raises funds to help pediatric patients at Childrens Hospital of Michigan and Henry Ford Health System. The Academy has been been supporting CATCH since 2000. [caption id="attachment_26465" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Mitch Albom, Amy Andrews and Nathan Forbes will be inducted into the CATCH Hall of Fame at the Oct. 19 event.[/caption] Last year, Megan Driver and May Savage represented GPA as student emcees at the event, which inducted NFL Hall of Famer and Detroit native Jerome Bettis, Detroit Free Press publisher and president Joyce Jenereaux, and retired Ernst & Young managing partner Al Lucarelli into its hall of fame. Since 1987, 89 men and women have been given the organizations hall of fame award. [caption id="attachment_26472" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Last year, GPAs May Savage, left, and Megan Driver (above with former NFL player Jerome Bettis) were honored to serve as special student emcees at the 2015 CATCH Night of Champions.[/caption] At this years event, CATCH also will present the Dr. Livingood Humanitarian Award to Henry Ford Health System's Dr. Tisa Johnson, who is medical director of the Center for Autism and Developmental Disabilities.

item.title: Academy Fund kicks off today with breakfast for more than 200
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Annual fundraising helps to ensureexcellence in schoolprograms, facilities, professional development and technology. [caption id="attachment_26486" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Pancakes, sausage and fresh fruit were on the menu at this morning's Academy Fund kickoff breakfast.[/caption] The Academy Fund campaign kicked off the 2016-17 giving year with its seventh annual All-School Pancake Breakfast. More than 200 on hand this morning in the Tracy Fieldhouse enjoyed stacks of pancakes, sausage and fresh fruit while listening to a few brief messages from Tommy Adams, head of school, and Kristen Van Pelt, who leads the schools development department. According to Van Pelt, attendance was very good today at the kickoff and those on hand, which included many board members, heard that Academy Fund gifts directly support the mission of The Grosse Pointe Academy, which is to nurture, challenge and inspire its students. [caption id="attachment_26488" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] More than 200 people attended the Sept. 30 breakfast in the school's Tracy Fieldhouse.[/caption] She said the schools goal is to get a gift from every parent and reach 100% participation. Each year we rely very much on parent support to provide the transformative experience that is The Grosse Pointe Academy education, she added. A gift to the Academy Fund has an immediate impact on the current and future students of our school, Van Pelt said. When you give, you are helping to ensure excellence in our programs, facilities, professional development and technology. You are investing in our most important product the student who will graduate with the confidence to contribute and lead in our society. Van Pelt noted that a gift to the Academy Fund is also a strong statement to other potential donors that The Grosse Pointe Academy is well worth supporting. [caption id="attachment_26484" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Academy Fund gifts directly support the mission of The Grosse Pointe Academy, which is to nurture, challenge and inspire its students.[/caption] Secure online giving is available by clicking here. Click here to see more pictures from todays kickoff event.

item.title: Academy fun run to benefit CATCH charity
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
On Friday, Oct. 14, first- through eighth-grade students at The Grosse Pointe Academy will be participating in the schools annual CATCH Fun Run. GPAs older students plan torun with their younger buddies from the lower grades at the event, which will be held at 2:30 p.m. on the Academy's soccer field. This year we decided to make the CATCH Fun Run a buddy event, said physical education teacher and middle school dean of students Sasha Murphy, who is coordinating the Academys CATCH effort this year. We sometimes struggle to find buddy time with all of the other school activities, and since the time was already set aside for five grades, we thought a school-wide buddy event would be fun. READ ABOUT THREE GPA STUDENTS WHO WILL BE EMCEEING THIS YEARS CATCH NIGHT OF CHAMPIONS DINNER Murphy said that they are asking each student to bring in a $5 donation forCATCH by Thursday, Oct. 13. She said homeroom teachers will collect donations for first- through fifth-grade students and she herself will collect for sixth- through eighth-grade students. About CATCH: CATCH is dedicated to improving the quality of life for pediatric patients and their families at Children's Hospital of Michigan and Henry Ford Hospital. Through an ongoing series of special fundraising activities, CATCH provides needy children with support where they might otherwise fall through the cracks. CATCH is an acronym for Caring Athletes Team for Childrens and Henry Ford Hospitals and was founded by the late Detroit Tigers manager Sparky Anderson in 1987. Since that time, CATCH dollars from special events and donations have facilitated a steady stream of items and services that help improve the quality of life for thousands of needy children. Whether it be a bed monitor for a child who experiences dangerous seizures during the night or assisting families with utility and rent payments while taking time off work to help care for their sick child, CATCH funds are used in a reactionary manner where no other source of funding exists.

item.title: Academy 'helped form who we are today'
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Alum and mission-driven teacher at GPA says the future of the school she loves depends on the Academy Fund. On a grey and rainy morning one early spring on The Grosse Pointe Academy campus, a decidedly upbeat and cheery figure was welcoming first graders to a special assembly in the big music room. Sasha Murphy, a physical education teacher and middle school dean of students at GPA, brought the kids into the first two rows of chairs set up for a presentation on recycling by Rizzo Environmental Services, whose representative was running a little late. No worries, though, because Murphy kept the students properly engagedshe knows all the younger kids names even though she teaches mostly in the middle school. Rizzos Victoria Czapski eventually shows up and quickly begins leading the kids through the three Rs of environmental stewardship: reduce, reuse and recycle. Murphy coordinated the event because among her many other duties on campus last year she was GPAs Green School coordinator, a position from which shes helped lead the school to seven straight official Green School designations. She obviously knows her way around this Green School and can probably walk blindfolded anywhere on campus without touching a wall. After all, she first set foot on the grounds of GPA in 1986, when she matriculated as a sixth-grade student herself. Giving back Murphy graduated from GPA in 1989 and after finishing high school and college, she said coming back to the Academy to work almost seemed predestined. "When I had the offer to interview for a position at GPA, I jumped on it and was very excited," Murphy said. "I wanted to come back and be a part of the caring teachers and loving family environment that I experienced myself. It also helped that there were other rather strong connections to the Academy. My love for the school is a family affair, she said. My brother, Noah Ovshinsky, graduated in 1993 and my father, Harvey Ovshinsky (Mr. O.), taught creative writing here for 16 years. I am now entering my 19th year as a teacher here at GPA. [caption id="attachment_26513" align="alignright" width="350"] Longtime Grosse Pointe Academy teacher (and alum) Sasha Murphy is with her husband, Dave Murphy. They were married on the grounds of the Academy.[/caption] Now an alumni spokesperson and representative for The Grosse Pointe Academys 2016-17 Academy Fund Drive, Murphy cant think of anything as important as maintaining and sustaining the stellar education she herself received for many other generations of students to come. The Grosse Pointe Academy holds a place in all of our alumni hearts, she said. It helped form who we are today and forged friendships and relationships that have lasted through many years. The Academy Fund provides essential support to GPA, without which the school could not exist. Although it may slip to the back of our minds as time passes, we all smile when we think back to our GPA days and how thankful we are for the experiences and memories our Academy Advantage provided us. MORE INFORMATION ON THE ACADEMY FUND IS AVAILABLE HERE. Murphy noted that because the Academy is a privately funded school, it allows her and the rest of the faculty and staff to educate today's GPA students in an environment that provides to students special and unique academic challenges, a nurturing through faith and ethics, and inspiration enough to sing a solo in the class play, join the soccer team even if theyve never played before, produce an amazing piece of artwork, and spend their school days with teachers who care for them just as her teachers cared for her when she was their age. And giving back to GPA through the Academy Fund helps ensure that a new generation of students experience the same love and care we did as students, she said. This is how you teach children GPA is still the amazing place I remember as a student, Murphy said, and it continues to instill life-changing experiences and relationships in its students and teachers each and every day. When Murphy first started on staff at the school, she loved that the students were immersed in so many thingsart, music, athletics, many other extracurriculars and of course, the academics. "Truly something for every type of student," she said. "To me, this was how you teach children." According to Murphy, teaching children was always part of her life plan. "Believe it or not, I have consciously known since first grade that I wanted to be a teacher, she said. And I started working with children by babysitting in middle school, then became a camp counselor in high school and college, assistant camp director, camp director and then finally a teacher here at GPA." MORE INFORMATION ON THE ACADEMY FUND IS AVAILABLE HERE. In high school, Murphy took child development classes and worked in a day-care center at Grosse Pointe South. In college, she majored in psychology and elementary education and earned a masters in early childhood education. "However, I did not ever think my educational career would be with adolescents," she said. "I always thought I would be an elementary teacher. But after a few months of teaching middle school PE here at GPA in 1998, I fell in love with the older kids and have not looked back." "I really enjoy helping them, teaching them, addressing their struggles and celebrating their triumphs. I love the fact that they seem to always have such a sense of wonder, love of life and excitement." Lawrence DeLuca, GPAs assistant head of school for instruction and principal for grades 1-8, said Murphy is a real advocate for the students. Sasha is one of the most dedicated teachers I have ever met, he said. She is or has been our P.E. teacher, community service coordinator, NJHS faculty advisor, Student Council advisor, 6th-Grade advisor, and now middle school dean. DeLuca said Murphy at times is like a second parent to many of the kids. Every day, she meets with students after school to help them get organized with their homework and get caught up with their work. Driving the mission The mission of The Grosse Pointe Academy and its faculty and staff is based on three central tenets: to nurture, to challenge and to inspire students. In Murphys case, its hard to see where any of that doesnt apply. I am a total cheerleader for my students, she said. I am on their team no matter what. If they get an A+ or fail a test or are having a really crummy day, no matter what, I am there for them. Some kids might just need a hug, she said, some might need help with their homework, or staying organized, or working on improving their citizenship or help remembering to do certain things. You can find Murphy after school three to five days a week, working with those students who need help. She also offers a study hall for middle-school students. And shes a firm believer in practicing what she is preaching to her students. As the schools community service coordinator, it was important to me that the kids know I also did community service in my own free time, that I made it a part of my life as well. And, if Im asking them to speak politely to each other, they needed to see that I do the same with students and other adults. I am always pushing my students, challenging them to get out of their comfort zone. Murphy has herself taken on some challenges of her own with some pretty tough fitness classes and shes working on being a regular runner whenever shes not at school. Psychologist? Its difficult to imagine Sasha Murphy in a different field of work, and when asked what she might be doing if she wasnt in education, she also has kind of a hard time coming up with something at first. But when pressed, she said: In no particular order, private practice or school psychologist, some sort of life coach but more for teens, events coordinator, physical therapist, public relations for a city. . . All noble professions. But the Grosse Pointe Academy and its students and staff certainly are glad Murphy has instead dedicated her career to educating those who, like her, will one day make their own mark in the world. item.title: Hockey hall of famer
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Grosse Pointe Academy alum and first woman to coach high school boys hockey in New Jersey to be inducted into ULS hall of fame. [caption id="attachment_26520" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Now heading into her fourth year of coaching the Montville High School boys hockey team, GPA alum Meghan (Brady) Hishmeh has taken the Mustangsto consecutive winning records.[/caption] The Montville (N.J.) High School Mustangs boys ice hockey team opens its 2016-17 campaign with a non-conference game on Nov. 26 at Sparta High School in Sparta, New Jersey. But the 4th-year head coach of the team and the first woman to ever coach a high school boys hockey team in the state has some personal business to attend to before then. Tonight, October 7, Meghan (Brady) Hishmeh, a 1985 graduate of The Grosse Pointe Academy, will be inducted into the University Liggett Schools Alumni Athletic Hall of Fame in a ceremony to be held at the Grosse Pointe Woods school. Hishmeh will be honored along with three other Knight alums. Even though she drove through the night on Wednesday from her home in New Jersey to get to Michigan for her hall of fame induction, Hishmeh was able to spend a few minutesanswering a couple ofquestions from the Academy. Prepared [caption id="attachment_26521" align="alignright" width="240"] Hishmeh will be inducted into the University Liggett School Alumni Athletic Hall of Fame.[/caption] Shes likely going to be well-prepared to speak and accept her award at tonights event despite the long drive. It seems shes been well-prepared for just about anything thats come her way, including her academic career, which began for her as a three year old in the Early School at the Academy. I started with Ms. Shaw in the Early School and graduated in 1984, said Hishmeh, who also had big shout-outs forsome of her GPA teachers. I loved Mrs. Candler, Mr. Tily, Mrs. Chrisner, Miss Fetterman, Mrs. Ward, Mrs. Connolly, Mrs. Franco and Mr. Lapadot. She said that the Academy prepared its students well to transition to any size or type of high school. Academically, I felt I was extremely prepared, especially in science, French, math and English, she said. Coming into a private high school like Liggett, the academic expectations were high and I felt I was ready. In fact, Hishmeh enrolled in math and French honors-level courses at ULS and handled it comfortably, she said. Also, joining lots of clubs and sports teams in high school was a natural transition for me as the Academy always encouraged you to try multiple activities that may have been new or unfamiliar. Olympics referee As with any athletic hall of fame induction, its fair to wonder why someone is so honored. In Hishmehs case, there is no wonder. Thats because it is plainly obvious why this mother of three, post-op orthopaedic surgery nurse, part-time referee, substitute school nurse and head coach of a high school hockey team is being inducted tonight. A hockey player herself since she was six years old in Grosse Pointe, she played youth hockey before playingthree years at ULS after the school started a girls hockey team during her sophomore year. Hishmeh also played field hockey, soccer and was a member of the Liggetts swim team. She continued her hockey career after high school at the University of Vermont, leading the team in scoring (and penalty minutes) as she earned a nursing degree. After graduating from U-V, Hishmeh moved to Colorado for work. Its also where she began to coach hockey, first with mites, who she taught the very basic fundamentals of the sport. When a job change brought her to New Jersey, she picked up the girls hockey coaching job at Princeton Day, a private high school in Princeton. It was at that time when she also began to referee the sport she loved so much. [caption id="attachment_26522" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Hishmeh graduated from the University of Vermont and when she's not behind the hockey bench, she works as a post-op orthopaedic surgery nurse at St Clares Hospital in Denville, N.J.[/caption] As a coach, Hishmeh figures shes been behind the bench for more than 20 years. But on the other side of the boards, she thinks shes been officiating for nearly the same amount of time, including working a number of games in which her sons were playing and, quite spectacularly, serving as a linesman during the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver. So now, as she looks forward to the upcoming hockey season at Montville, Hishmeh again has very high expectations. Thats because her teams have been winning and performing well since shes been in charge. In fact, before she took over the Mustangs, the team had not had a winning record since the 2008-09 season. Valuable lesson Meanwhile, getting back to her time at The Grosse Pointe Academy, Hishmeh said that besides the wonderful academic start she received at GPA, there is something even more important that she walked away with after graduating from the school. [caption id="attachment_26541" align="alignleft" width="250"] Grosse Pointe Academy alum Hishmeh is with her three sons.[/caption] I believe that GPA has influenced me in many ways in my life and career, but I think what has been most important is that at the Academy, you were always taught to treat everyone as you would like to be treated yourself. That has been huge for me.

item.title: Shared values, football and 171 Lake Shore Rd. come together in Denver
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Alum finds out she works with fellow grad who just happens to be a Super Bowl-winning pro football player. [caption id="attachment_26549" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Fran Williams, left, a 1969 alum, shows 2005 graduate and NFL receiver Bennie Fowler her yearbook at the Denver Broncos' Training Facility near Denver, Colorado.[/caption] An article in the most recent edition of The Academic, The Grosse Pointe Academys biannual magazine for alumni and the school community, got the instant attention of 1969 alum Fran (Fitzgerald) Williams. I work for the Denver Broncos and could hardly believe my eyes when I saw a picture of a very familiar-looking football uniform mid-magazine, said Williams, who was a member of the last class of the Academy of the Sacred Heart before the school transitioned to become GPA. The article she is referring to was about 2005 GPA graduate and Broncos wide receiver Bennie Fowler, who was instrumental in getting his team into the AFC championship game last season. Fowler prepped at Detroit Country Day and played college ball for the Michigan State Spartansafter which hesigned as a free agent withDenver in 2014. The Broncos beat New England in the AFC championship game last season and went on to become Super Bowl champions by defeating the Carolina Panthers. [caption id="attachment_26545" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Fowler had a key reception in the Jan. 17, 2016, AFC divisional playoff game between the Broncos and the Pittsburgh Steelers.[/caption] Williams works for the Broncos Stadium Management Company, LLC (SMC), a subsidiary of the Denver Broncos Football Club. SMC manages all aspects of the teams Sports Authority Stadium, which is where the Broncos play all of its home games. She said she spends most of her time at the stadium and unless its a home game, she rarely sees Fowler since the team practices a few miles away. This week, with the help of the Broncos PR staff, the Academy coordinated a get-together of Williams and Fowler. They met at the team's training facilityand exchanged memories of their shared school and campus on Lake Shore Road. Williams even brought along her 1969 ASH yearbook that Fowler gladly signed. [caption id="attachment_26550" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Fowler '05 (GPA) signs the yearbook of Fran Williams '69 (ASH) after getting together at the Denver Broncos training facility.[/caption] Mine was the last high school graduating class from the Academy of the Sacred Heart in 1969, Williams said. It certainly never occurred to me then, or since then, that a pro football player and I would share the same alumni association! Williams also called out a couple of other alums after reading The Academic magazine. Alumni Association President Roselie Posseliuss article was a welcome reminder of the common roots and value system shared by ASH and GPA alums, she said. Also, the title of the article on 1980 alum James Cargas, Academics, respect and manners, was nearly a complete summation of what began in pre-K and continued through lower and middle school. I would just add the word faith. Reading the magazine was a real walk down memory lane for me and a heartwarming reminder of the values that I learned early and still treasure to this day.

item.title: At the head of the class
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
In an article published by Investors Business Daily, journalist Nancy Gondo discusses education pioneer Maria Montessori and how her innovative academic philosophy has transformed education worldwide and influenced generations of successful Montessori alums, including Thomas Edison, Henry Ford and Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin. The Grosse Pointe Academy offers Michigan's longest continuous-running Montessori program to its Early School students.
Maria Montessori Stands At The Head Of The Class [caption id="attachment_26563" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Maria Montessori, who was born in 1870 and was the first female medical student at the University of Rome, spread her school methods to America and the world. She died in 1952. (Photo: AP)[/caption] By NANCY GONDO, INVESTOR'S BUSINESS DAILY If you think Google (GOOG) co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Amazon.com (AMZN) chief Jeff Bezos and music producer Sean Combs have much in common, you're right. They can all thank Maria Montessori (1870-1952), at least a little, for their success. Montessori's philosophy toward child development and learning lets children pursue their interests as they evolve, instead of forcing them into a strict regime. Given the above examples, it's no surprise this style of teaching is a popular method used in schools around the world. Other Montessori alumni include Julia Child, Thomas Edison and Henry Ford. "Some of these famous people have attributed Montessori to their ability to think outside the box," Kathy Roemer, board president of the American Montessori Society and executive director of a trio of Montessori preschools in New York City, told IBD via email. "Montessori offers environments that are stimulating, safe and nurturing, where children are comfortable taking learning risks. "In addition, mistakes are considered opportunities for learning to take place. Children are able to enhance the abilities they are born with while exploring other areas of challenge." That may be a reason the Montessori method thrives globally. The International Montessori Index, which provides school and training center information, estimates a worldwide presence of 7,000 Montessori institutions. "Montessori remains especially relevant today," Virginia McHugh Goodwin, executive director of the U.S. branch of the International Montessori Association, said via email. "Neuroscience consistently proves this, and science has finally caught up with Montessori. It is a brain-based developmental approach to learning." The Pillar That Maria Montessori discovered a new way of teaching and built it into a viable business was no surprise, given her strong will. Even at elementary school in Rome, she took on a leadership role, finding activities for younger kids to do and making up games. Maria loved math and science. By the time she was 12, she'd decided to become an engineer. Her accountant father, Alessandro, strongly opposed. Girls back then became teachers if they worked at all. But her mother, Renilde, understood Maria wanted to break away from the old-fashioned ideals. And like Maria, she was persistent. "She finally persuaded her husband to allow their headstrong, talented girl to follow her dream," Marie Tennent Shephard wrote in "Maria Montessori: Teacher of Teachers." "Both mother and daughter had the same stubborn streak. Alessandro was no match for them." In 1883, 13-year-old Maria enrolled as one of two female students at a technical school. She graduated three years later, then attended another technical institute for further learning. While there, she changed her aim to medicine. Her father balked. Another hurdle arose when the head of the University of Rome's medical department told Maria a medical school would never admit a woman. She enrolled for premed classes anyway then wrote letters, sent referrals from teachers and asked friends for help to gain acceptance to a med school. IS YOUR CHILD READY FOR PRESCHOOL? Her persistence paid off. That year she became the first female medical student at the University of Rome. She heard grumbling from the male students. But by the second year, she'd won them over with her pluck and drive. On July 10, 1896, 25-year-old Montessori became Italy's first female doctor. The University of Rome hired her as a children's doctor. She also became an assistant doctor at the university's psychiatric clinic, where she observed mentally disabled kids. After researching, she realized they needed special education, not medical treatment. Word spread about Dr. Montessori's findings. Italy's public education minister asked her to give lectures to Rome's teachers about how to educate children with learning disabilities. By 1900 she was a director of the Orthophrenic School, founded to help educate mentally disabled children. She taught pupils via simple motions like using a spoon or walking on a straight line. She also focused on the senses vision, smell and touch to help kids learn to read and write. Within two years, some of them could pass a school exam. In Their Heads The doc thought her methods could help normal children too. She studied philosophy and psychology and sat in elementary school classrooms to observe what the pupils were learning. "Maria Montessori was a scientist who used her uncanny ability of observation to determine how children learn through discovery and doing," Roemer said. When asked if she would take care of 50 preschoolers at a slum in Rome, she jumped at the chance to try her method on normal kids. To help foster independence, she had child-size furniture built. Cupboards, chalkboards, shelves and washstands were placed at children's height. And in 1907, Casa dei Bambini (Children's House) opened, offering free care to working parents of 2- to 6-year-olds living in the tenement. To teach using the senses, she filled bottles with scents (smell and taste) and boxes with sand and stones (sound and touch). "The Montessori method uses the senses, through which all information travels for young children," Roemer said. "Her use of hands-on materials reinforces the discoveries the children are making as they are learning." The kids preferred her creations, such as knobbed cylinders and wooden dressing frames to practice lacing, tying bows and fastening hooks, to traditional toys like dolls and balls. They learned on their own how to build, sort or arrange objects the right way. This helped them gain independence and self-confidence. Montessori let them learn at their own speed. Within a few weeks, they'd blossomed from anti-social, rebellious children into happy, well-behaved students who wanted to learn. Vocabulary Game Next Montessori taught them to read using homemade letters, which they arranged on a mat to form words while learning the sounds of each. "A skillful Montessori teacher is trained to continually assess what stage a child is at in their development and to map out individualized pathways inside the classroom to meet each child's needs," McHugh said. "Children thrive in Montessori because their developmental needs are consistently met and satisfied, enabling them to become joyful and successful learners." THE GROSSE POINTE ACADEMY'S EARLY SCHOOL CURRICULUM GUIDE The school was such a success, another opened in April 1907 in a nearby tenement. More Montessori schools soon sprouted up throughout Rome, then beyond. Queries poured in from around the world, asking about her method. She immersed herself in her work, training teachers and creating classroom materials. Soon she was earning enough money to support herself and her family off her book and course proceeds. The Montessori method became a thriving business. In 1911 McClure's Magazine featured her teaching method, piquing the interest of Americans. A year later telephone inventor Alexander Graham Bell and his wife helped form the Montessori American Committee, which organized the first international training course in Rome. Montessori came to America to promote her method. She gave a lecture to a packed room at New York's Carnegie Hall. She concluded: "The development at which I aim includes the whole child. My greater aim is the eventual perfection of the human race." In 1929 she formed the International Montessori Association in Amsterdam to supervise schools worldwide and maintain control of her method and materials. Montessoridied at age 81 in Noordwijk, Holland, where she was buried.

item.title: The value proposition that is GPA
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Compassion teams up with creativity for 2003 alum: New York writer, poet says the Academys foundation and valuescontinue to be big in her career and life. [caption id="attachment_26577" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Chelsea Baumgarten, a 2003 graduate of The Grosse Pointe Academy, says the foundation she received at the school has been enormously helpful to her in her life and career.[/caption] Chelsea Baumgarten is a successful writer and poet living and working in New York City. Shes been published in numerous prestigious peer-reviewed journals, and her college career has included manyawards and rewards. But this 2003 graduate of The Grosse Pointe Academy sees much of her success thus far rooted in the time she spent on the campus of GPA. [caption id="attachment_26580" align="alignright" width="225"] Baumgarten as a student in the Academy's Early School.[/caption] The Academy certainly prepared me for high school and beyond, said Baumgarten. Academically, of course, across all subjects, GPA is phenomenal. Beyond that, though, the Academy always encouraged creativity and compassion. Theres something magical about the building and the grounds, and the curriculum actively nourished creative thinking. Baumgarten started at the Academy as a preschooler and after graduating, spent four years at University Liggett School. She then enrolled at Kalamazoo College, where she majored in English and psychology, and graduated Magna Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa with honors in both majors. In addition, the psych department at Kalamazoo College gave her awards for excellence in research and excellence in coursework, and the English department awarded her for excellence in critical essay writing. Writing a career With grad school on the horizon, Baumgarten was fairly certain she would continue with her studies in psychology and pursue a career as a clinical psychologist. But writing and literature also was tugging on her arm. I was a teaching assistant for a few psychology courses at KC and also a research assistant in a cognitive psychology lab, she said. I even interned at a psychiatric hospital for a summer. I loved psychology and still do but ultimately couldnt ignore my passion for literature and creative writing, so I decided to pursue a graduate degree in English instead. I think literature and psychology complement each other nicely, though, and Im so happy that Ive studied both. To this day, I think my psych background definitely informs my creative writing. Baumgarten enrolled at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) in 2013 and earned an MA in English literature. While at UIC, she interned in publishing at Chronicle Books, a publisher in San Francisco. After finishing up at UIC, she began in earnest to prioritize her own writing projects, which included turning one of her graduate school term papers about the author Vladimir Nabokovs work into an academic article that eventually was published in The Nabokov Online Journal, a peer-reviewed journal that specializes in Nabokov. At that time, I started to set aside time every day to write poetry and fiction, she said. In the spring of 2015, I was awarded a poetry fellowship to attend the Indiana University Writers Conference, where I was able to study with two of my favorite poets. Finally, in September of 2015, I took the plunge and moved to New York City. [caption id="attachment_26579" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Baumgarten moved to New York City in September of 2015.[/caption] In New York, Baumgarten works primarily as a freelance writer and has published articles about business and literary news. But she continues with her real passion writing fiction and poetry, which ultimately led to her getting two poems published recently in online journal, The Grief Diaries. In many ways, living in New York is a writers dream, Baumgarten said. Theres always something literary going on author readings, talks, writing classes, exhibits at museums and youre in close proximity to so many people from different backgrounds. And Ive become friends with a lot of other writers in various stages of their careers here, too. Currently, she said, shes working on a short story thats set in Michigan. I love to travel and have lived in a variety of places, but my imagination is still very drawn to Michigan and the Great Lakes. Volleyball dynasty Now well-entrenched in one of the worlds epicenters of culture and literature, New York City, Baumgarten nonetheless cannot forget where it all began. I have tons of wonderful GPA memories, said Baumgarten, who grew up in the City of Grosse Pointe and has a brother, Kurt, who also graduated from GPA (2001). The one memory that comes to mind immediately is playing on the middle school volleyball team. To this day, Mr. (Michael) Fultz was one of the best coaches Ive ever had. When I joined varsity in 7th grade, the team had been undefeated for fourteen years or something crazy like that. Mr. Fultz never put pressure on us to win for the sake of maintaining the record, though. He just wanted us to continue to improve and communicate and try our best. It was so much fun to learn to play a new sport from a very talented coach and be part of a program with such a strong history. Baumgarten continued to play volleyball through high school and also at Kalamazoo College during her freshman and sophomore years. She still plays in adult recreation leagues and has even tried her hand in coaching. Right after I graduated from grad school, I coached a middle school volleyball team for a season, she said. I definitely tried to channel Mr. Fultz while I was coaching. Sometimes I would have my team do the same drills that Mr. Fultz had us do, and Id always tell them, I did this drill when I was your age! It works! She said she actually ran into Fultz while she was coaching her own team. He was refereeing one of our games. It was a very happy reunion! Important Academy values Summing up her Grosse Pointe Academy experience, Baumgarten said that doing your own thing and doing it creatively was always encouraged at school with one very important caveat. It had to be done respectfully. Whether it was in creative movement with Ms. Denise, music class with Mrs. Chrisner, or creative writing with Mr. O, I always got the sense that it was okay to do things your own way and use your imagination, as long as you were respectful of others, she said. That was an important value the Academy taught me: you should be respectful and considerate of others and make an effort to understand them. I think that foundation has been enormously helpful to me both in my life and in my writing.

item.title: Four from Montessori
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_26590" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] The Grosse Pointe Academy held its annualMontessori Night on November 16, 2016, in its Early School building.[/caption] One hundred and five years ago this month the first Montessori school in North America opened in Tarrytown, New York. It wasnt long before a second was opened by inventor Alexander Graham Bell and his wife near their home in Canada. Today, there are more than4,500 Montessori schools in the United States and about 20,000 worldwide. The Grosse Pointe Academy, which is home to Michigans longest continuous-running Montessori program, is pleased to offer four quotes from Dr. Maria Montessori, founder of the Montessori method, arguably the worlds most innovative education philosophy. Enjoy! Education should not limit itself to seeking new methods for a mostly arid transmission of knowledge: its aim must be to give the necessary aid to human development.... If the formation of man becomes the basis of education, then the coordination of all schools from infancy to maturity, from nursery to university, arises as a first necessity: for man is a unity, an individuality that passes through interdependent phases of development. Each preceding phase prepares the one that follows, forms its base, nurtures the energies that urge toward the succeeding period of life. (From Childhood to Adolescence, first published in 1948) We must clearly understand that when we give the child freedom and independence, we are giving freedom to a worker already braced for action, who cannot live without working and being active. (From The Absorbent Mind, first published in 1949) "The child must see for himself what he can do, and it is important to give him not only the means of education but also to supply him with indicators which tell him his mistakesThe childs interest in doing better, and his own constant checking and testing, are so important to him that his progress is assured. His very nature tends toward exactitude and the ways of obtaining it appeal to him." (From The Absorbent Mind, first published in 1949) "The child has to acquire physical independence by being self-sufficient; he must become of independent will be using in freedom his own power of choice; he must become capable of independent thought by working alone without interruption. The childs development follows a path of successive stages of independence." (From The Absorbent Mind, first published in 1949) Learn more about the Academys Early School Montessori program here.

item.title: Academy alum named National Merit Scholarship semifinalist
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Less than one percent of all U.S. high school seniors score high enough to be named semifinalists. [caption id="attachment_26630" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Academy alum David Scupholm ('13) earned semifinalist status in the latest National Merit Scholarship competition. (Photo by Mary Montgomery Photography)[/caption] Grosse Pointe Academy alum David Scupholm (13), a senior at Grosse Pointe South High School, has been named a semifinalist in the latest edition of the National Merit Scholarship competition. Scupholm and the three other South students who were named NMSC semifinalists now have an opportunity to continue in the competition for one of the 7,500 National Merit Scholarships worth nearly $33 million that will be offered the this Class of 2017. Scupholm, who graduates from South in the spring, attained semifinalist status by scoring in the top 1 percent of U.S. high school students who took the Preliminary SAT test. He currently has narrowed his college search to a number of small liberal arts schools and plans to major in business or pre-law More than a million juniors Last school year, more than 1.4 million juniors in more than 22,000 high schools entered the 2017 National Merit Scholarship Program by taking the Preliminary SAT/National Merit Scholarship Qualifying Test (PSAT/NMSQT), which served as an initial screening of program entrants. The nationwide pool of semifinalists, representing less than one percent of U.S. high school seniors, includes the highest scoring entrants in each state. The number of semifinalists in a state is proportional to the states percentage of the national total of graduating seniors. [caption id="attachment_26604" align="alignright" width="350"] Scupholm, second from left, is with Grosse Pointe South principal Moussa Hamka and two of his three classmates who also were named NMSC semifinalists. (Photo: GP News)[/caption] About 90 percent of NMSC semifinalists are expected to attain finalist standing and more than half of the finalists will win a National Merit Scholarship, earning the Merit Scholar title. To be considered for the Merit Scholarship, semifinalists must fulfill several additional requirements to advance to the finalist level of the competition. To become a finalist, the semifinalist and his or her high school must submit a detailed scholarship application in which they provide information about the semifinalists academic record, participation in school and community activities, demonstrated leadership abilities, employment, and honors and awards received. A semifinalist must have an outstanding academic record throughout high school, be endorsed and recommended by a high school official, write an essay, and earn SAT scores that confirm the students earlier performance on the qualifying test. More on theNational Merit Scholarship Program: NMSC, a not-for-profit organization that operates without government assistance, was established in 1955 specifically to conduct the annual National Merit Scholarship Program. Scholarships are underwritten by NMSC with its own funds and by approximately 440 business organizations and higher education institutions that share NMSCs goals of honoring the nations scholastic champions and encouraging the pursuit of academic excellence. According to NMSC, the National Merit Scholarship Program honors individual students who show exceptional academic ability and potential for success in rigorous college studies. The program does not measure the quality or effectiveness of education within a school, system or state. For more information about the competition, visit www.nationalmerit.org.

item.title: Students from the Academy a big hit at charity event
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
For the 9th year in a row, students from the Academys middle school emcee prestigious charity event. [caption id="attachment_26611" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Grosse Pointe Academy students, from left, Abby Keane, Lorna Savage and Courtney Mecke are with GPA head of school Tommy Adams at the 2016 CATCH Night of Champions, held October 19 at The Henry hotel in Dearborn. The students served as emcees for the annual event.[/caption] Academy middle school students Courtney Mecke, 8th grade, Lorna Savage and Abby Keane, both 7th grade, were honored to serve October 19 as special student emcees during the 2016 CATCH Night of Champions held at The Henry hotel in Dearborn. This annual dinner and auction includes the CATCH Hall of Fame induction ceremony for community leaders in recognition of their charity work over the past year. Its the ninth year in a row that Academy students were chosen for the annual event, which this year inducted journalist, author and broadcaster Mitch Albom, TV news anchor Amy Andrews and commercial real estate developer Nathan Forbes into its hall of fame. Albom noted in his speech that the three students from the Academy did a great job during the evening. To the girls reading here tonight, he said, "you are fantastic and wonderful examples of what this is all about. [caption id="attachment_26612" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Jim Hughes, executive director of CATCH Charity for Children, is with, from left, GPA students Courtney Mecke, Lorna Savage and Abby Keane at CATCH's Night of Champions event on October 19.[/caption] The Night of Champions helps benefit sick and needy children through the CATCH program, which was initiated in 1987 by former Detroit Tigers manager Sparky Anderson. Specifically, CATCH (Caring Athletes Team for Childrens & Henry Ford Hospitals) raises funds to help pediatric patients at Childrens Hospital of Michigan and Henry Ford Health System. The Academy has been been supporting CATCH since 2000. Also honored at the eventwith the Dr. Clarence S. Livingood Humanitarian Award was Dr. Tisa Johnson, a pediatric physician at the Henry Ford Pediatric Group in Detroit. Last year, Megan Driver and May Savage represented GPA as student emcees at the event, which inducted NFL Hall of Famer and Detroit native Jerome Bettis, Detroit Free Press publisher and president Joyce Jenereaux, and retired Ernst & Young managing partner Al Lucarelli into its hall of fame. Since 1987, 89 men and women have been given the organizations hall of fame award. Last week, first through fifth graders from The Grosse Pointe Academy participated in a "CATCH Fun Run" to raise money for the charity. Students were asked to donate $5 and by race time, they had raised a total of $1,074.44 the largest amount in the schools history of participation and presented a ceremonial check to Jim Hughes, executive director for CATCH. Since 1987, CATCH dollars from special events and donations have facilitated a steady stream of items and services that help improve the quality of life for thousands of needy children. Specifically, CATCH (Caring Athletes Team for Childrens & Henry Ford Hospitals) raises funds to help sick and needy pediatric patients at Childrens Hospital of Michigan and Henry Ford Health System. The Academy is proud to say its been supporting CATCH since 2000.

item.title: 'The surest route to joining the creative elite"
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Erik Brynjolfsson, the author of The Second Machine Age: Work, Progress, and Prosperity in a Time of Brilliant Technologies, says there is a disproportionate number of Montessori-educated people founding and managing many of todays successful tech companies. Googles Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Amazons Jeff Bezos, musician Yo Yo Ma and Wikipedias Jimmy Wales, to name a few, he notes. Brynjolfsson thinks its a direct result of the Montessori classroom environment that emphasizes self-directed learning, hands-on engagement with a wide variety of materials (including plants and animals), typically occurring in a very deliberate sensorial school day. Add Wall Street Journal blogger Peter Sims who says, the Montessori educational approach might be the surest route to joining the creative elite, to the many, many proponents of a education philosophy that is centered in nurturing the uniqueness of each developing child. Interested parents findout more about these advantages when The Grosse Pointe Academy holdsits annual Montessori Information Nights each fallon the Academys campus in Grosse Pointe Farms. During the session, parents observe demonstrations from Academy Early School teachers highlighting the Montessori method's child-centered, individualized approach to education, specifically geared for children 2-1/2 to 5 years old. The event also details the areas of the classroom, learning experiences, and benefits of the Montessori program for those interested in enrolling their children in Michigans longest continuously operating Montessori program. Find out the difference between "classic" Montessori and "supplemented" Montessori. Peaceful place | Current Academy directress discovers the advantage of Montessori and fully embraces it.
