item.title: Is autographed yearbook destined for a future GPA Action Auction?
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
Alumna recalls journey from Grosse Pointe Farms to Denver, getting a Super Bowl ring and a meeting with NFL star; says autographed yearbook also mighttake a starring role in a future Academy auction. [caption id="attachment_26677" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Fran Williams, left, a 1969 alum, and 2005 graduate and NFL receiver Bennie Fowler go over her yearbook at the Denver Broncos Training Facility near Denver, Colorado.[/caption] When 1969 alum Fran (Fitzgerald) Williams was casually thumbing through the most recent edition of The Academic, The Grosse Pointe Academys biannual magazine for alumni and the school community, one article in particular especially caught her attention. I work for the Denver Broncos and could hardly believe my eyes when I saw a picture of a very familiar-looking football uniform mid-magazine, said Williams, who was a member of the last class of the Academy of the Sacred Heart before the school transitioned to become GPA. The article she is referring to was about 2005 GPA graduate and Broncos wide receiver Bennie Fowler, who was instrumental in getting his team into the AFC championship game last season. Fowler prepped at Detroit Country Day and played college ball for the Michigan State Spartans after which he signed as a free agent with Denver in 2014. The Broncos beat New England in the AFC championship game last season and went on to become Super Bowl champions by defeating the Carolina Panthers. Williams works for the Broncos Stadium Management Company, LLC (SMC), a subsidiary of the Denver Broncos Football Club. SMC manages all aspects of the teams Sports Authority Stadium, which is where the Broncos play all of theirhome games. She said she spends most of her work time at the stadium and unless its a home game, she rarely sees Fowler since the team practices a few miles away. Earlier this month, with the help of the Broncos PR staff, the Academy coordinated a get-together of Williams and Fowler. They met at the teams training facility (in Dove Valley, Colo.) and exchanged memories of their shared school and campus on Lake Shore Road. I really had fun meeting Bennie, Williams said. What a nice guy! It was a terrific experience. [caption id="attachment_26675" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Williams and Fowler talk about fond memories of ASH and GPA earlier this month in Denver.[/caption] Williams even brought along her ASH yearbook, the last for the school, to Dove Valley so that she and Fowler could compare notes on similarities and changes over 47 years at the school. She also said Fowler graciously autographed the yearbook with his name, number and his GPA graduation year: 2005. Someday, that might be a fun auction item for GPA, noted Williams, whose journey to Colorado began after graduating from ASH, which at that time was operating as a high school. MORE ON ACTION AUCTION 2017 Fell in love with a Texan In the fall of 1969, I left home for Boulder to attend the University of Colorado, Williams recalled. She said her parents had a couple of rules about college that she and her sisters were obligated to observe. We had to leave the state of Michigan and we had to graduate in four years, she said. I applied to three schools and got accepted to one, thereby making my decision very easy. I was not one of those people who would fall in love with Colorado and then never want to leave, but I did fall in love with a Texan who never wanted to leave. So we got married, and have been here permanently since the spring of 1974. Fast forward 28 years to 2002 and after seeing an ad that Invesco Field at Mile High, the stadium where the Broncos play, was interviewing for guest relations staff, Williams thought shed apply. Having been raised as an unwilling football television viewer and then growing into a football enthusiast, and assuming that this would be an easy and profitable means of seeing the games in person, I went for an interview and was hired, she said. At the interview, it was made very clear to me that my assumption about seeing the games was completely invalid. That was disappointing, but true! Williams nonetheless happily worked full time in guest relations at the stadium until this season. She said that although the average fan probably has no idea what the job actually entails, game days are long, grueling affairs. I love the people I worked with and many of the fans became friends, but I decided that once I hit Medicare, I had earned watching the games with my feet up, she said. Williams still keeps her feet involved with the stadium, however, but now only as a part-time receptionist. I had already been acting in that capacity for about eight years and have a ball doing it, she said. I should have kept better notes because the questions and comments that we get cover a gamut you cannot imagine and would make for a very entertaining book! Super Bowl ring Williams said that besides football games, the stadium is used year-round for a huge variety of events: weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, business meetings, proms, and one Democratic Convention assemblage in 2008 when President Obama made his acceptance speech. But it was my part-time receptionist job that earned me a trip to Super Bowl 50 in San Francisco and a Super Bowl ring, she said. The Broncos really are a wonderful organization. Williams notes that her younger sisters, Karen Fitzgerald Hutchinson and Ellen Fitzgerald, also graduated from the University of Colorado and live in Denver. They attended and graduated from what was then Grosse Pointe University School, now called University-Liggett School, after ASH closed in 1969, she said. Even though shes not working full-time at the stadium any more, Williams does keep its welfare and success uppermost in her mind. The stadium where the Broncos play is the same stadium where I applied, but it is now called Sports Authority Field at Mile High, she said. That name will change again as the Sports Authority chain of sporting goods stores has declared bankruptcy. Maybe one of your readers would like to explore naming rights at the stadium where the reigning Super Bowl champions compete!

item.title: Museums, Miles Davis and scarves
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
(Updated: Feb. 9, 2017) In a blog published in 2016by hipster-friendlyhotel company, Ace Hotel, 2004 Grosse Pointe Academy alum Paige Russell, now living in Austin, Texas, talks about her art and the scarves that take shape from that art as well as one special scarf she made to celebrate Aces latest hotel in New Orleans. Enjoy. . . March 25, 2016 (acehotel.com) Paige Russells Eloi scarves come into the world as construction paper compositions. Unwilling to sentence these creations to a two-dimensional life, Paige transposes her work onto silk, allowing them an infinite number of transcendent new realities worn around a collar, as a crown or tied tooth-ache around the head of a cayenne-colored hound dog. Paige made the Eloi Le Grande Zombi Scarf for our new home in New Orleans, a celebratory homage to the cultural richness of New Orleans Voodoo and the city itself. We were lucky enough to catch a minute with Paige to talk about her life and work in Austin, what shes listening to and how to find inspiration in everyday moments. Hi Paige. Ive been thinking about your scarves. I can only imagine what it feels like to make a thing and then have it suddenly exist folded up around someones neck. Its such an intimate place. Suddenly your art is just out in the world, so close to someone. They probably get their perfume on it and the crumbs from their croissant. Its so different than hanging something in a gallery where its just ogled from a distance. What does that feel like? I think its awesome. I love that idea. Ive always been a person that just wants to surround myself with beautiful objects. Thats just very important to me, to look at pretty things. For someone to choose to bring an object into their life that I made, its so cool. Youre right. A scarf is such a classic, utilitarian item. Its used in so many different ways. Its an intimate thing, and the fact that people would want to use something everyday with my work on it feels really special. [caption id="attachment_26721" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] GPA alum Paige Russell (04) says with art nothing needs to be real. It doesnt need to be serious or based in reality at all. It just needs to make people feel something.[/caption] How does music influence your work? I read somewhere that a lot of your scarves are based on songs. I listen to a lot of music in my studio, and Ive always loved music and finding new music. I go on these kicks where I just listen to things over and over and over again, and it somehow informs my work. I dont realize it until afterwards. And then I think, Well I have to name it after that song. Like, the Miles Davis scarf, I just think it looks like jazz. Yeah, I couldnt deny it. Most of them I just cant deny it so Im like, Okay. Yeah. That one was given to me by that person or song. These are the things Ive been listening to lately. Talk a little bit about your process and the Le Grande Zombi scarf you made for Ace New Orleans. With all of my scarves, I begin by making a construction paper cutout piece on wood panel. I layer and layer and layer then photograph the finished product and trace each shape in Illustrator. More on GPA alum Paige Russell ishere. My thoughts of New Orleans revolve mostly around celebration (drinking, dancing, parades) and the eyes and figures were born out of this. The background needed to feel crazy and festive, confetti-ish without looking gaudy. Something wasnt sticking with the parade thing so I got on a more narrative trajectory. I needed it to feel like New Orleans without getting esoteric. I did some research on Voodoo culture in New Orleans and the symbols used. I went through a few different comps and found the story of Li Grand Zombi, the sacred serpent of Nola voodoo culture: Li Grande Zombi is the major serpent spirit of worship among New Orleans Voodooists. In New Orleans Voodoo, snakes are not seen as symbols of evil as in the story of Adam and Eve. Snakes are considered to be the holders of intuitive knowledge knowing that which cannot be spoken. Women often dance with serpents to represent the spiritual balance between the genders. Voodoo rituals in New Orleans almost always include a snake dance to celebrate the link to this sacred and ancient knowledge. Do you feel like you go into a lucid state when youre working? Yeah, for sure. I think a lot of the reason why I started doing the cut outs is because its super melodic. You cant do it unless youre zoned out because its just a repetitive motion. Im working on something right now thats a four foot by five feet and Im covering it in these tiny one centimeter dots. Ive been cutting these for three weeks. Its driving me nuts but its also the most meditative thing that I could do. I think it really eases my anxiety. I have crazy anxiety. Doing this it just so good for me. Like meditation. More on GPA's academic program, which includes a robust art curriculum, is here. Where does the inspiration for the scarves come from? Do you start out with an idea? Are you making a story up? Or do you feel more like you just start cutting and see what happens? Its more, I just start cutting and see what happens. I think that a lot of them are inspired by whats around. Sometimes music, too. Its kind of just something thats permeating my head and my space so [the work] just comes out of that. If Im going through something in my life, it just comes out in that lucid kind of state that we were talking about. If I go to a museum and see someones work and its really inspiring to me and then thats in my head its definitely inspired by that. For the Ace New Orleans scarf specifically, it was William Hawkins, the outsider artist. I love his work. I had him in mind the entire time. How do you get to that lucid place? Do you have a ritual that gets you there? Or is it just a matter of sitting down and being disciplined in the space? Its like 75% procrastination and excuses. Then, when I can finally sit down and just zone out, I can get somewhere. I feel like all art or all creation, creating anything, is mostly thought and anxiety and just putting it off. Then you just have to get it out. You just jump off that ledge. It takes a while but once Im there I just force myself to sit down and start. Then thats when good things can actually happen. I always compare it to throwing up. You feel awful and youre like, I just want to vomit. I just want to get it over with. Its all this build up. Then you do it and its like, Ah. Where was I? You know? Its all better. Thats what my creative process it like at least. Its like torture. Yeah, Carl Sagan always said this thing: In the Universe, nothing is the rule. Something is the exception. Whole solar systems are created only when something is out of balance in the universe. Its like art, right? If there is an anxiety or tension theres a catharsis that comes when a physical thing is made to balance it. I dont know, kind of a stoney thought. Does making art feel spiritual at all to you? Yeah. When I make something that Im very proud of, theres this fleeting feeling of inner success with a piece that is very spiritual. I set up the piece right in front of my bed so I can wake up and look at it and be proud of myself and then its immediately back to the anxiety of having to start over and continue on. Its very spiritual. More on GPA's academic program. What is your life like in Austin? I love Austin. The weathers great. It doesnt get too cold. Im kind of a hermit but I have a dog that Im obsessed with and we go to a bunch of places. We go to all the swimming holes and, you know how Austin is. Theres so many cool nature places throughout the city. Its like dog heaven. I usually just go places in nature with my dog. Just make work, honestly. Ive only been here for almost two years, a year and a half. Im still kind of adjusting to it all. Ive moved three times in that year and half. Have you had your dog since she was a puppy? Yeah. She was actually born on my kitchen floor. It was the worst situation. I was in Savannah and living with my boyfriend at the time and four other guys and three cats and a pregnant dog. And the dog had ten puppies. Then we had to keep them for the eight weeks. It was a pretty rough. But she was the only girl and I needed her. Dogs are very powerful. I feel like theyve evolved psychologically with humans in an emotionally intelligent way. Scientists should be studying this. Yes! They communicate so well without talking. Dogs are humans. Dogs are humans. Do you think there are different strengths in different colors? What colors can you not get enough of? I get really attached to specific pieces of paper. Which is really weird. I have this one thats a poppy reddish orange and I use it, I think, in every single thing I make. I cant stop. I tried to. But I love it too much. There are some colors that I cant really get into. Purple. I dont know why. I think my mom had something to do with it. What other peoples art do you like? Lately Ive been really into Rousseau. Lee Krasner, Ive been looking at a lot of her work lately. She was Jackson Pollocks wife. Who else? This guy that went to SCAD, Tim Wirth. His work is so insane. I have one of his paintings. Im trying to collect more but Im broke. His work is really inspiring. What other things inspire you? I dont know. Music, I think. Other peoples art. Philosophy. The way other peoples minds work. Psychology is really inspiring to me. I think just pushing that whole surrealist view of what is as opposed to what we know. Flipping that on its head. Which is kind of a psychedelic view too. Im really into surrealism. I think when [surrealism] started it was the idea of putting two things together that would not go together in conventional art or ideas or poetry. Putting unlike things together in word play and color play. It appeals to me because I dont think that everything is as it seems. Theres so much more. Yeah. Sometimes you can put two things together that have never been next to each other before and somehow thats more reflective of a true thing. Exactly. In art nothing needs to be real. It doesnt need to be serious or based in reality at all. It just needs to make people feel something. More on GPA's academic program, including curriculum guides, is here. item.title: Prestigious lecture at the Academy rescheduled for May 22
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_26264" align="alignright" width="351"] Jessica Lahey, who is the author of the New York Times bestselling book, The Gift of Failure: How the Best Parents Learn to Let Go So Their Children Can Succeed, is currently on a book tour around the U.S.[/caption] McMillan Lecture Series event rescheduled afterGrosse Pointe Farms power outage. The McMillan Lecture originally scheduled for Nov. 7 has been rescheduled for Monday, May 22, 2017. Officials at The Grosse Pointe Academy in Grosse Pointe Farms were forced to cancel its Nov. 7 William Charles McMillan III Lecture Series event featuring Jessica Lahey due to a utility failure that knocked out power to the school and surrounding area. Electrical service to GPA, which is located at Moran Road and Lake Shore Road, was interrupted completely beginning around 6 p.m. on Nov. 7 following an accident Monday afternoon at Fisher Road and Grosse Pointe Boulevard that caused power lines to fall in the area. The rescheduled event with educator, writer and New York Times columnist Lahey willfeature among other things the current research on autonomy-supportive parenting and teaching, including Laheys take on competence, rewards, praise, and, most importantly, failure, when it comes to raising children. Lahey, who also is the author of the New York Times bestselling book, The Gift of Failure: How the Best Parents Learn to Let Go So Their Children Can Succeed, is currently on a book tour around the U.S. More on Lahey, including an exclusive interview, is here. More on the William Charles McMillan III Lecture Series William Charles McMillan III was a student at The Grosse Pointe Academy from 1973 until 1981 where, receiving love and encouragement, he learned to reach beyond his limitations. Although weak physically, McMillan was intellectually gifted and his passion for life, his love and concern for all living things, and his enthusiastic use of verbal skills changed the lives of those who were closest to him and left a lasting impression on all with whom he came in contact. Never at a loss for words, McMillan was bursting with impressions, questions and insights which came pouring out in a dazzling, dizzying torrent. It was rare to have a brief, superficial conversation with McMillan. A friend commented, I sometimes felt like I needed a seat belt when William was talking to me, because he would take us into outer space, back into primeval history, and then into a universe of his own imagining. "McMillan believed that anyone could make a significant and lasting impact on the world no matter what ones age, size or circumstance." The William Charles McMillan III Lecture Series focuses on elementary education and is dedicated to the proposition that every child can reach beyond his or her own limitation, that each child makes the world a better place. It is the goal of these lectures to take your mind where it has never been before.

item.title: Classic Montessori? It makes a difference
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: Montessori programs can be classified as classic or supplemented. Find out why The Grosse Pointe Academy offers the classic variation. Education pioneer Maria Montessori once declared, An education capable of saving humanity is no small undertaking; it involves the spiritual development of man, the enhancement of his value as an individual and the preparation of young people to understand the times in which they live. Yes, education is a monumental undertaking and Dr. Montessori certainly speaks truth to power. And yes, perhaps it goes without saying that the power to educate begins, most importantly, in the very young. For children in The Grosse Pointe Academys Early School Montessori program, its not just the fact that they are receiving the benefit of one of the worlds most innovative method of teaching. Or that its being delivered by Michigans longest continuous-running Montessori school. Or even that GPAs Montessori preschool includes small class sizes and master teachers with consistently updated Montessori certifications. Its what happens after Early School that shows the true benefit of a Montessori early education. A study of creativity published by The British Psychological Society in 2013 (Educational & Child Psychology Vol. 30, No. 2: Maud Besanon, Todd Lubart, Baptiste Barbot) showed that young school-age children who had attended a Montessori program exhibited better creative performance later in their academic careers than children schooled in traditional academic programs. This was true for all children at all initial creative ability levels for both integrative tasks (drawing and story) and divergent thinking tasks (unusual uses for a cardboard box, improvement of a toy and parallel lines, for example) (Besanon, M., Lubart T., 2008). But it isnt just about creativity. Angeline Lillard, in her book, Montessori: The Science Behind the Genius, cited a 2006 study that found that Montessori students leaving kindergarten scored much higher than their peers in public and private schools in standardized math and reading tests. Susan Gittins, whose son James Raudabaugh, after graduating from GPA in 2012, attended the prestigious International Academy in Troy, Mich., said it was critical that as young student, her son would have the benefit of a school with preschool Montessori as well as can effective transition to its lower through middle schools. I did research other schools in the Pointes, but GPA was the only one to meet all my requirements, Gittins said. The Academy easily ticked off all my must-have boxes, starting with the first one: having a language class in grade one. Number two was having gym/movement/exercise every day. Three was a Montessori early school so James would transition to the classroom environment alongside other children coming from Montessori; four was early music study, and finally, number five, having all of this in a beautiful and welcoming environment. A family affair When current Grosse Pointe Academy parent Sandra Cavataio talks about GPA to prospective parents, she often recalls her own experience in seeking an education for her four children. When she and her husband first moved to southeast Michigan, education for their children was of paramount importance. After all, she holds bachelors and masters degrees in industrial engineering from Louisiana Tech University, and husband, Pietro, is a family-practice physician with an office in Chesterfield, Mich. Cavataio recalls when she just happened to hear about The Grosse Pointe Academy from another parent at a store in metro Detroit and began to ask more questions about the school to her realtor. This led directly to a house in Grosse Pointe Shores and her children enrolled at the Academy. I attended private primary and secondary school and my husband attended public schools, Cavataio said. But even though the Grosse Pointe public schools had a pretty good reputation, I told him I felt very strongly about private schools and he has come to see the big advantage. She also said they kept hearing that GPA had the best early-school program around, which was a definite factor since her family was still quite young when they first moved into the area. Fast forward to 2016, Joseph Cavataio, the oldest of the Cavataio children, is in his second year at the University of Michigan after graduating from Cranbrook-Kingswood. Josephs brother, Piero, graduated from GPA in 2015 and followed his brothers footsteps to Cranbrook, and his sister, Gabriela, matriculated to University Liggetts upper school and will graduate next spring. The youngest Cavataio child, Alessandro, will finish at GPA in the spring of 2017. Joseph Cavataio said his first year at Cranbrook was relatively easy for him since he was so far ahead academically. Ive noticed that many other students from The Grosse Pointe Academy also ended up doing well with some going into leadership positions at Cranbrook, ranging from class president to editor of the school newspaper, he said. Is it classic? Author Lillard, who is a professor of psychology at the University of Virginia, said that just as the Cavataios found out, it is extremely important for parents to do plenty of their own homework when researching Montessori schools. Thoroughly interrogate the schools credentials, she recommends. Parents should look at whichorganizations have certified the school, and where and how the teachers [often called directresses] were trained. They can also look at whether the school has a complete set of Montessori materials and whether the children are concentrating deeply as they use the materials. In an authentic Montessori classroom, she added, parents should expect to see all children, including the youngest ones, working independently or in small groups by choice, and happily. Lillard noted that even within the world of Montessori, there are significant variations in programming at Montessori schools. She said its important to differentiate whether a school that calls itself Montessori is a classic Montessori school or is it one offering a supplemented Montessori program. Classic Montessori is the rarer form, according to Lillard. In fact, a recent survey of Montessori schools in the United States showed that only 28% of school heads strongly agreed with the statement, Our school implements [its education program] according to the original vision of Maria Montessori. (Murray & Peyton, 2009, p. 28). So, as with any alternative educational program, fidelity is an important consideration, Lillard said. Children in classic Montessori programs as compared with children in supplemented Montessori, which means the program is supplemented with more conventional early-school activities, and Conventional programs show significantly greater school-year gains on outcome measures of executive function, reading, math, vocabulary and social problem-solving, according to Lillard. She said it shows that high-fidelity Montessori implementation is associated with better outcomes than lower-fidelity Montessori programs or conventional programs. Jennifer Kendall, who is GPAs assistant head of school for Early School education and admissions, said the Academys early childhood/preschool definitely is classic Montessori. As an example, just as Maria Montessori prescribed, children in our Montessori classrooms are introduced to different materials throughout their Montessori years, and each of the materials presented by the teacher has a definite purpose, Kendall said. While both conventional play-based and Montessori classrooms have something resembling block objects in the room, a classic Montessori classroom has the pink tower of ten varying shaped block units, she said. This tower is a Montessori material that is used to help develop coordination, set a basis for the number system and increase awareness of dimension. Another Montessori prescription from Dr. Montessori is having children of different ages in the same classroom. Maria Montessori believed that younger children would benefit from a classroom community formed with the older children, Kendall said. The multi-age classroom allows younger children to learn from the older students and model their behaviors. It also allows the older students a chance to reinforce their own knowledge by helping the younger students. Peaceful place | Current Academy directress discovers the advantage of Montessori and fully embraces it. Story here. More information on GPAs Montessori Early School program is here. item.title: Pushing traditional boundaries in art class
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: GPA art teacher says inspiring students withdesign-thinking leads directly to creative and innovative solutions in class. [caption id="attachment_26814" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Grosse Pointe Academy teacher Erin Brott studied art at Detroit's prestigious College for Creative Studies and holds an art education degree from the University of Michigan.[/caption] (Updated March 12, 2017) Grosse Pointe Academy art teacher Erin Brott said shes singularly focused on making sure her students remain excited about what they are learning. I encourage all of our students to try and push their own boundaries, she said. I try to guide and support them to gain the skills and knowledge it takes to be a confident artist or designer, but more importantly, I also believe it is important to allow them room to make mistakes and urge them to learn through the process. Brott, who is in her secondyear on staff at the Academy, also said motivation remains uppermost in her approach to her art students. She said keeping kids inspired does wonders for keeping them engaged. In fact, it was Brotts own art teachers who inspired her own path to art and art education. I became an art teacher because I was totally inspired by the amazing art teachers that I myself had in school, Brott said. I was kind of an average student academically, but when I got to high school, I found my true passion in art. And that pushed me to achieve higher goals. She said art propelled her through high school because she was more of a visual learner and that she learned best by seeing and doing. [caption id="attachment_26813" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] An accomplished painter herself, Academy art teacher Brott recently completed this piece called "Modest Magic."[/caption] Through my interests in art, I was able to excel in all of my other core subjects in school and it really made me think differently about the very real art concepts that also exist in math, science, and yes, language, history and culture, she said. The arts also made me more creative when I problem-solve and gave me the confidence to express my ideas in any capacity. Brott took the same approach to her first teaching job at Detroits Henry Ford Academy: Elementary School, where she taught for three years. She said design-thinking was an established process at HFA, where you creatively guided students to solve complex problems to create unique and innovative solutions. I really loved working in a solution-focused and action-oriented environment, she said. All of the lessons I learned there are ingrained in my philosophy of education and they highly influence my current pedagogy here at GPA. Lawrence DeLuca, the Academys assistant head of school for instruction and grades 1-8 principal, agrees that Brott definitely is focused on new ways to engage GPAs student body. Everytime I walk down the hallways, I am astounded by the amazing artwork our students produce with Ms. Brott, from kindergarten to grade 8. he said. Not only does she inspire our students to create great pieces, but she often incorporates interdisciplinary projects as well. DeLuca recalls that recently Brott organized a glass-blowing project where middle school students learned the science behind glass blowing and then created molten glass in the science lab. Then the students blew the glass and sculpted it in the art loft. It was a very fun and authentic learning experience for the students that they will likely remember for a long time, he said. Photos from the glass art project arehere. From CCS to U-M to GPA Brotts undergrad work began for her at the prestigious College for Creative Studies in Detroit where she majored in fine arts with a focus on painting. Immediately after starting at CCS, she developed a real urge to share all of the exciting new concepts she was learning with younger students. She then added art education as her second major. As I was learning more and more about education, it quickly became my singular focus, she said and so I then transferred to the University of Michigan-Flint and enrolled in their visual arts education program. [caption id="attachment_26812" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Brott recently had her students learn about glass art and glass-blowing. From left, 7th-graders Bode Neumeister, Ava Said, Abby Keane and Jacob Tomlinson hold up their glass creations.[/caption] Immediately upon graduation from U-M, she got a job at The Ann Arbor Art Center, a nonprofit arts organization located in downtown Ann Arbor that offers workshops and classes for artists of all ages. This gave her the opportunity to inspire a very diverse group of kids and young adults on a weekly basis. Working there gave me a sense of purpose as well as validation that I had in fact chosen the right career path, she said. Meanwhile, back at GPA, Brott said her own career goals strongly align with GPAs mission to nurture, challenge, and inspire each child's potential. GPA does an excellent job of allowing students to find their unique and individual strengths and its my job to individualize my art curriculum to fit each childs needs, said Brott, who is a resident of Ferndale. I do this by incorporating their individual strengths into each project so they find their own success. Going above and beyond Now only about halfway through her secondyear of teaching at GPA, Brott nonetheless said its more than enough time to confirm what she thought of the school and its community when she first visited. My first impression of GPA was that the buildings were architecturally beautiful and the people were completely focused on their work with the kids, she said. Each day I am excited to come to work and see the countless examples of how our teachers go above and beyond to help students realize their potential and reach their goals. Plus, I am constantly impressed by the genuine love of learning that our students show. It is a true testament to the great history of our school and it also shows how dedicated GPA teachers and staff really are. [caption id="attachment_26810" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Brott was in Burano, Italy, this past summer. Burano is the most colorful place Ive ever seen, she said.[/caption] It appears that Erin Brott has found a home at GPA. But, just as a for instance, we wondered what kind of career she might have if it wasnt teaching. If I wasnt a teacher in the traditional sense, I would probably go back to school to be a licensed art therapist, she said. With that kind of job, I would be able to work in a children's hospital to support and help patients get through recovery and rehabilitation with the expressive use of visual arts. [caption id="attachment_26811" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Kaitlyn Gray, an 8th-grader at GPA, holds up her glass art to the light. Jennifer Kendall, GPAs assistant head of school for Early School education and admissions, said Brott has been a wonderful addition to The Grosse Pointe Academy family. She is not only a great artist herself, but she allows each child to develop their own artistic talent. It is a pleasure watching the art develop grade after grade. Erin is able to reach all children from kindergarten through grade 8, which is a true gift."[/caption] About The Grosse Pointe Academy The Grosse Pointe Academy is an independent, coeducational day school serving children age 2 1/2 through Grade 8. item.title: GPA and the 'nations report card' on science
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
The Grosse Pointe Academys unique approach to science and math education is making a difference for its students. In late October 2016,the results of the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) test in science, more commonly called the nations report card, were released and while there has been some improvement over previous results, the report found that only about a third of fourth and eighth graders in public schools nationwide showed strong academic performance in the sciences. "We still are not at a place as a country where we are preparing the future STEM workforce that we need," Education Secretary John B. King Jr. said after assessing the results. "We think there's significant work still to do, but we are heartened by the progress that we see in these results." The National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), first administered in 1969, is the largest continuing and nationally representative assessment of what our nations students know and can do in subjects such as mathematics, reading, science and writing. Standard administration practices are implemented to provide a common measure of student achievement. The NAEP science exam, which was given to 237,300 students in 46 states and U.S. Defense Department schools, tested participants in physical science, life science and earth and space sciences. Nationally, the test results showed that 38 percent of fourth-grade students were considered proficient or above in science. In eighth grade, 34 percent were proficient or above. The rest were at or below the basic level. In 2011, the last time NAEP tested for science, only 32 percent nationwide performed at or above what is considered proficient. Michigan's fourth- and eighth-graders ranked in the middle of the pack nationally on the test, which is given to a representative sample of students in each state, according to data released yesterday. Asked what improvements those states that are below the national average can make to improve science achievement, education secretary King said, "We know some things from research about what makes a difference for long-term success in the STEM fields. He said investing in early learning opportunities, specifically high-quality pre-kindergarten, where young students are exposed to science through play and developmentally appropriate learning experiences has shown to improve outcomes. GPA math and science making a difference With all that as background, a general look at private school science and math programming vs. public programming paints a picture with great contrast. In a 2006 comparison made for mathematics in Grade 8 by the U.S. Department of Education, where all private schools in the nation were compared to all public schools, the average private school mean mathematics score was 12.3 points higher than the average public school mean mathematics score. It is perhaps unfair to compare public school student performance with private and independent school students and its not always an apples-to-apples comparison since testing can be wildly divergent. And class size is likely a big factor when looking at public vs. private. Joseph Cavataio, a 2015 graduate of Cranbrook-Kingswood School in Bloomfield Hills and The Grosse Pointe Academy (2011) who now is at the University of Michigan studying engineering, says hes definitely noticed a difference in fellow students from public vs. private schools. He says in calculus class, for example, when he started at U-M, he was already four college credits ahead of his peers. Cavataio gives a big shout-out to GPA and to its chemistry class, saying that it definitely prepared him well for high school chemistrywhich he says directly led to him placing out of all of his required U-M chemistry classeseven though he only took one honors chemistry class at Cranbrook. [caption id="attachment_26656" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Michelle Roberts, who teaches math and science in the Academys middle school, says GPA students in general are very well-prepared for high school, including the science courses they take.[/caption] Also, the Academy definitely prepared me to be a leader, he said. Because of the small class sizes at GPA, we had the opportunity to be in the limelight quite often and that gave me the confidence to pursue leadership opportunities in high school. He recalled that his freshman year at Cranbrook was relatively easy for him since he was so far ahead academically. And I noticed that many other students from the Academy also ended up in leadership positions at Cranbrook, he said. STEAM-powered science The Grosse Pointe Academys fourth- and fifth-grade science program has been designed to engage students in a variety of hands-on experiences through labs and simulations using the scientific method, according to school officials. Cooperation and collaboration are encouraged as students problem-solve in pairs or small groups, which leads generally to higher achievements within the curriculum. The Academys STEAM program also plays a big role in the schools focus on science. Didi DiBoer, assistant head of school for grades 4-8 and the Academy's former 4th grade teacher, says Academy students have the rather unique opportunity at a young age to focus on real-world challenges. While utilizing an engineering-design process in our STEAM lab and garden classroom settings, students are engaging in science lessons that are completely relevant to them, she said. And allows them to work collaboratively to solve problems while being immersed in hands-on inquiry. Our STEAM lessons not only integrate science, technology, engineering, art and mathematics, our students are also becoming engaged and open-ended in their discussions, which leads to multiple correct answers and surprisingly creative solutions. Another Academy alum, George Spica (11), who attended Interlochen Arts Academy and is currently pursuing his arts education in London where he attends the Slade School of Fine Art at University College, has a more novel perspective of how the time he spent at GPA gave him a head start. I attended GPA from preschool to grade eight and what I now realize is that the tradition and rigor that characterizes a GPA education is in fact what enabled me to engage in more unorthodox means of learning in my high school years, Spica said. In other words, I was so comfortable and well-versed in my academics after graduating from the Academy, I was far more open to the idea of alternative-learning methods as I matured in the context of an art school. ERBs at GPA Michelle Roberts, who teaches math and science in the Academys middle school, says GPA students in general are very well-prepared for high school, including the science courses they take. Our alums in local public school chemistry classes say they are doing well and some of our high school freshmen even tell me that they do not really see any new material in class until the spring semester, Roberts said. Students from the Academy generally have a much better background in chemistry than their peers who attended school either at another independent school or at a public school. For math, especially when it comes to testing, Roberts says its hard to compare GPA student performance with other schools. We test students in mathematics using the ERBs, which is a tool for us to make sure we are hitting the standards for local, state and national assessments, she said. ERB (Educational Records Bureau) testing was designed to provide highly regarded admission assessments for students applying to independent schools and/or specialized public schools that require entrance exams in the United States and in other countries of the world. Academy officials say that since GPA students take the ERB tests, they are at distinct advantage when competing for high school admissions or scholarships to more elite independent schools. At GPA, students in grades 2-7 take the test and the school receives national norms for grades 4-7. Of those benchmarked results, two thirds of Academy students scored in the 90th percentile or higher on the national norms in at least one subtest of the ERB CTP 4. This means that when looking at GPA students compared with the entire nation, the majority of them rank in the top 10% in at least one academic area. Roberts said GPA middle-schoolers dont use ERB for science, however, though some take it in high school, depending on the school they attend. Stand-alone middle school vs. K through 8 Another factor perhaps in the overall success of The Grosse Pointe Academys math and science programs can be attributed to the fact that students at GPA are enrolled in a continuum of curriculum that for many begins in early school Montessori. Roberts, who shares middle school math teaching duties at GPA with Wendy Jerome, Julie Anderson, and Robert Rochte, says by the time Academy students get to their classes, they are very well-prepared. I think its how we integrate the Montessori foundation with traditional methods of math education that provides these kids with the readiness necessary for middle school and beyond, she said. [caption id="attachment_26658" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Students from the Academy generally have a much better background in chemistry than most of their peers who attended school either at another independent school or at a public school.[/caption] A number of studies back up this assertion by Roberts. Research has found a significant drop in test scores for students who attend stand-alone middle schools while scores for students in K-through-8 programs tend to stay constant or increase during middle school years. Over 75 percent of GPAs 6th-grade students and 65 percent of its 7th-grade students last year ranked in the top 10 percent nationally in math on the ERB CTP4 area tests, qualifying them for the Northwestern University Midwest Academic Talent Search (NUMATS), a gifted and talented identification program. Roughly 80 percent of Academy graduates take AP and Honors courses in high school vs. 46 percent overall at Grosse Pointe South and 32 percent nationally who take AP courses.   Personalized yet methodical and technological While students who matriculate through GPA from Montessori early school to middle school benefit from a fully integrated academic program, the math and science curricula at the middle school level has been designed to take students methodically and purposely from one subject to another. Middle school mathematics, for example, begins in 6th grade with the preparation for more advanced mathematics, such as algebra and geometry, while at the same time reinforcing general arithmetic skills. Mathematical modeling, the use of manipulatives, and real life problems allow students to understand the increasingly abstract concepts presented. And while algebra per se is not in the 6th-grade math program at GPA, students do study algebraic reasoning, pre-algebra and algebraic thinking. By 7th grade, students are fully into algebra and then get a very healthy dose of geometry along with more advanced algebra in grade 8. Middle school math and science teacher Roberts says that as she takes her students through the rigorous academics, its not always all about books and no.-2 pencils, though. Wendy (Jerome) and I definitely have used technology as another way to improve the math program for our kids, she said. We use many computer applications to flip the classroom. Which means that students see lectures and teacher presentations at home or on their own time and then use classroom time to work out problems and get more individualized help. We make our own videos for flipped instruction as well as for students who are not in class for some reason, Roberts said. Student-centered The idea of individualized help, it appears, also is central to the high performance of Academy students, especially in mathematics. Teachers work directly with students to develop personalized roadmaps for success. Throughout the years at GPA, teachers remain in close contact with parents and families to provide progress updates and to set goals.

item.title: 'The barn gets a new coat of red
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: The big barn on The Grosse Pointe Academy campus is looking a lot snazzierthese days. Thats because its received a new coat of bright red paint, thanks to the schools maintenance staff. [caption id="attachment_26914" align="alignright" width="240"] Sasha Murphy, GPA's dean of students and physical ed teacher for grades 4-8, gives students a quick history lesson of "the barn."[/caption] The project took about two weeks because we had to fit it into our normally very busy schedule, said Keven Alt, who manages GPAs maintenance crew. He said the last time it was painted was approximately 10 to 15 years ago. Molly McDermott is GPAs former longtime admissions director and now assists the schools development office. She recalls that years ago, the facility waspainted by different means and painting crew. Actually, back in the 70s, school parents helped paint the building whenever it needed a coat. The Barn, as it is officially called, was built in 1860 and is included in the National Register of Historic Places by the U.S. Department of the Interior. Alt said he believes the buildingwas originally built as a carriage house, andeven though it currently just houses all of his groundskeeping equipment, it nonetheless needed a facelift since its such a prominent part of the schools look and feel. We just collectively decided maintenance staff, board members, administration that we could use some additional color to brighten up the campus, he said. item.title: Lucky find
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: Nurturing, caring teacher finds a home at a nurturing, caring school. [caption id="attachment_26928" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Lindsey Furgal, a 1st-grade teacher at The Grosse Pointe Academy, says her goal every day of every school year is "to make sure my students feel comfortable and safe in their learning spaces, so that they can strive to be the very best versions of themselves.[/caption] The Grosse Pointe Academys mission is to nurture, challenge and inspire its students. Head of School Tommy Adams says the Academy prides itself on its warm and nurturing environment where each child is known and respected. For Lindsey Frugal, a 1st-grade teacher in GPAs lower school, she cant believe how lucky she was to find a job in such an environment that fits her so well. I dont think I couldve ever found a more meaningful, rewarding job for myself than the one I have now, she said. I think my own nurturing and caring personality has allowed me to create a warm, comfortable and safe learning environment for my students. They always seem happy and excited to come to school every day to learn. Thats probably because she loves to make school and learning fun for her students, which is blatantly obvious once you enter her classroom. I really try to keep my classroom full of laughs and smiles, she said. I can truly say that I have found my gift and passion in life and that is teaching children. Teaching children seemingly has been on Furgals radar for a while. She grew up in Grosse Pointe Woods, attended Mason Elementary School, Parcells Middle School and Grosse Pointe North High School, graduating in 2003. Ive always wanted to be a teacher as far back as I can remember, she said. Growing up I had some amazing teachers in my life and I thought it would be totally rewarding to be that same kind of leader and mentor for students of my own. I was a babysitter/nanny for children all through high school, and I think I shared a special bond with many kids and families throughout those years. So nurturing children was always something she was good at, she thought. But upon entering Michigan State University for college, there was still some uncertainty in what she wanted to pursue and what career direction she wanted to take. In fact, she ended up graduating with a bachelors degree in communication (in 2007) and went on to work in marketing and advertising at jobs in the Metro Detroit area and in Chicago for about four years. It was inevitable However, it was about that time when she couldnt forestall the inevitable any longer. At that point in my life, I just didnt see myself wanting to excel in any other career path, she said. It was clear that my heart was with teaching. So she moved back home to Grosse Pointe and started school full-time again, this time at Oakland University where she earned a second bachelors degree in elementary education, which she completed in December of 2013. While at OU, since I already had a bachelors from MSU, I was lucky enough to be able to substitute teach in a wide-variety of public schools while taking classes, Furgal said. I gained so much classroom experience while subbing and was able to directly apply what I was learning about in school in an actual classroom setting. [caption id="attachment_26931" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Furgal, shown here with boyfriend, Peter, cant believe how lucky she was to find a teaching job in such an environment that fits her so well.[/caption] She completed her student-teaching at Shawnee Elementary in the Chippewa Valley Public School District (in a 2nd-grade classroom). Following her OU graduation, she picked up a two-month, long-term substitute position in another 2nd-grade classroom at that same school, and later completed an additional long-term substitute position at another Chippewa Valley school (in a 1st-grade classroom). My growth and experience throughout my elementary education program at Oakland has definitely molded me into the teacher I am today Furgal said. I am so grateful for those opportunities and for the guidance I received from numerous mentors and role models along the way. Furgal hired on at the Academy in the fall of 2014, which makes this her third year at GPA. Every day during those two-and-a-half years, she said, shes reminded of why she chose to switch career paths to become a teacher: Its because of the kids. And its because of the kids that gets her up every school-day morning with a singular focus and goal. Celebrating individuality I feel that my number-one job as a teacher is to make sure each one of my students genuinely wants to come to school, she said. So my goal every day of every school year is to make sure my students feel comfortable and safe in their learning spaces, so that they can strive to be the very best versions of themselves. She also said that because GPA offers such a wide-range of special classes and extracurricular activities, its students have more opportunities than those at most other schools to become well-rounded, cultured and confident students. Plus, I strongly believe that all the teachers at GPA do an excellent job of encouraging our students to celebrate their individuality and unique qualities, she said. In my case, I feel that my nurturing, supportive and dedicated teaching style inspires my students to learn and grow in a way that best fits them. But across the board, Grosse Pointe Academy teachers make it a priority to provide each and every student with all the support and encouragement they need in order to succeed. item.title: Motivated midshipman
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: GPA alumnus in the U.S. Naval Academy wants to make an impact for good. [caption id="attachment_26944" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] U.S. Naval Academy student and GPA alum Josh Gray ('10), center, is with fellow midshipmen in Annapolis, Maryland.[/caption] Grosse Pointe Academy graduate Josh Gray spent the better part of yesterday morning on his former schools campus talking to middle schoolers about the U.S. Navy and the United States Naval Academy. He knows what hes talking about because he is well into his own commission at the Naval Academy. I expect to finish up at the Naval Academy in 2018, said Gray, who graduated from GPA in 2010, and was home for a long weekend. Gray signed on with the USNA in Annapolis, Maryland, after high school at Grosse Pointe South because he thought it was the best way for him to make a real difference in the world. I chose to go to the Naval Academy because it was an opportunity to be part of something greater than myself, he said. Also, I believe the Naval Academy stands for things I believe in. Plus, it will give me an opportunity to make a tangible impact for good in the world. [caption id="attachment_26942" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Gray speaks to GPA middle-school students about the U.S. Navy at a special assembly on November 21, 2016.[/caption] According to the U.S. Naval Academy, even though midshipmen technically are college students, all are still considered on active duty in the U.S. Navy. Gray said midshipmen typically attend the academy for four years, graduating with bachelor of science degrees with commissions as either ensigns in the Navy or second lieutenants in the Marine Corps. USNA graduates usually go on to serve at least five years in the Navy or Marine Corps. Gray has a couple of career goals in mind after graduation. Id like to serve in the Navys special warfare unit or as a member of the U.S. Marine Corps, he said. Even though hes well-focused on serving his country in thefuture, Gray nonetheless recalled the eight years he served at The Grosse Pointe Academy, which, he said, gave him a real foundation for his own definite expectations for excellence. [caption id="attachment_26943" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Josh Gray is with his two sisters, Anna, left, who is in the 4th grade, and Kaitlyn, an 8th grader at The Grosse Pointe Academy.[/caption] Ive got many good memories at GPA, especially of the many teachers I had, he said. In particular, remember Mr. (Bob) Lapadot's WEN (Write Every Night) assignments in 5th grade. That's when I really learned to enjoy writing and thinking creatively. Lawrence DeLuca, GPAs assistant head of school for instruction and grades 1-8 principal, said Grays success so far in his young career doesnt surprise him. Josh was an excellent student and a natural leader, DeLuca said. His hard work and strong moral character have served him well, and we are very proud to see him excelling at the Naval Academy. item.title: Acting 'the truth'
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded: 2014 alum and budding thespian says herAcademy experience helps herto stay ahead in high school. [caption id="attachment_26978" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Grace Andreasen, a 2014 graduate of The Grosse Pointe Academy, plays character Nettie in the University Liggett Schools production of Orphan Train, which was performed Nov. 3-6. ("Orphan Train" photos by Holland McClinton, ULS)[/caption] Grace Andreasen recently finished a run as the character Nettie MacClearyin the University Liggett Schools production of Orphan Train. The drama tells the riveting story of nine orphans on a train that leaves New York Citys Grand Central Station, circa 1914, and travels west to towns in search of homes, any homes, anywhere for the orphaned and unwanted children. Andreasens Nettie is a young Kansas farm wife who suffers a terrible loss of her own baby. Its a heart-rending story with enough ups and downs to test even the most experienced actor. My role in Orphan Train was definitely a challenge, said Andreasen, who graduated from The Grosse Pointe Academy in 2014. But it was a very enjoyable challenge and one that I truly embraced. She said it is definitely more fun and interesting to play a character that is so multifaceted and complex rather than one that is of a singledimension, and though the part of Nettie was emotionally draining, she really loved it because it was a challenge. Acting is feeling things truthfully and conveying that truth to an audience and to your scene partners, and that honesty and vulnerability is what I love about acting, Andreasen said. It was quite scary to be emotionally vulnerable onstage for a bunch of people to see, but what made it all worthwhile was the beautiful story we were telling and the emotions we felt while telling it. It goes without saying that a story like Orphan Train demands so much from its actors. I got asked a lot about how I could cry so easily onstage, which is kind of a funny question because it's not about crying on command, it's about telling the story and immersing oneself into the world of the play and feeling what that character would truthfully be feeling. That's what I think acting is, or at least that's what it is to me: standing on stage and telling the truth! Telling the truth on stage is not new for Andreasen, now a junior at ULS. In fact, shes been performing on stage since her days at GPA I performed in all of the productions at GPA, and I greatly enjoyed them and shes been onstage many times at Liggett and beyond even though at first she wasnt 100% sold on acting. I started out freshmen year at ULS not really knowing if I wanted to get into theater that much, she recalled. I had always loved going to see shows, but I didn't know if the whole acting thing was for me. I helped out here and there with the drama department at Liggett, but didn't really do much. That all changed during her sophomore year, after she tried her hand at acting for the first time at ULS. [caption id="attachment_26980" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] The 2014 GPA alum said that the honesty and sheer vulnerability is what she loves about acting.[/caption] I auditioned for a fall show and got a significant supporting role as Elaine in Arsenic and Old Lace. I had an absolutely wonderful time over the course of rehearsing and performing that show and learned so much. We actually ended up taking that show to the State Thespian Festival at Saginaw Valley State University and got to perform for a significantly large audience filled with people who really appreciated theater. It was truly an amazing experience! That, she said, was the moment when she realized that she wanted to be involved with theater for the rest of her life, including pursuing it professionally. After Old Lace, she performed as Amanda in Liggetts production of Tennessee Williams' The Glass Menagerie in the spring. That was a taxing role to say the least, shesaid. Then this year, as Nettie in Orphan Train (by playwright Dennis North), it was even more challenging. In addition to her acting roles, Andreasen is the director of operations for the University Liggett Players organization, which means that she assists the schools director in running the theater program and making sure that everything runs smoothly. In addition to this, shewas named one of only 12 state thespian officers in Michigan. Whew! Lots to do for a high school junior in addition to a rather rigorous academic schedule, which, she said, has not been as challenging as it could have been had she not attended the Academy. [caption id="attachment_26981" align="alignright" width="250"] Andreasen said NYU is on her radar for college.[/caption] I felt so prepared coming from GPA to Liggett in terms of my ability to manage my workload and also my ability to thoughtfully contribute to class discussions, she said. I remember during freshmen year at Liggett that a lot of students (non-GPA kids) were complaining about the amount of homework, and that all of the GPA grads could easily handle it. Also, all of the GPA students seemed in a way more thoughtful and even more mature, and could easily hold meaningful discussions in class. Andreasen also had high praise for the GPA faculty. In terms of teachers, I really loved all of my teachers at GPA; they were the best, she said. In fact, Mrs. (Barbara) Karle and Mrs. (Michelle) Roberts came to see me in Orphan Train and I cannot even express how happy it made me to see them and to know that they were supporting me. As far as college plans, Andreasen has not arrived at a final choice, although NYU is high on her list. Ive been thinking about college a lot lately and I've been doing some research, but I'm still not completely sure because there are so many choices and factors that go into it, she said. However, in a perfect world, I would go to NYU because that has been my dream school for a while now. I'm very interested in the Tisch School of the Arts at NYU and would like to pursue acting and possibly playwriting there. Its not a pie-in-the-sky pursuit for Andreasen even though she knows that theater as a career might be a risky choice. She has no illusions, but also offers a bit of advice. . . It will take a lot of hard work; however, it's what I love and am passionate about. And if I could give other students any piece of advice, it would be to follow and pursue your passion because doing what you love and what makes you happy is extremely important. item.title: Middle school and nurturing potential at the Academy
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
(Updated 02/03/17) To nurture is perhaps the most commonly referenced component of The Grosse Pointe Academys triumvirate of a mission statement. Along with to challenge and to inspire, the Academys unique quality of nurturing the potential of each child and allowing its students to discover their unique strengths in a caring and comforting environment is what many parents cite when talking about their childrens education at GPA, especially those with very young students at the school. But while a nurturing environment is a critical foundation for 2-1/2-year old to kindergarten-age children in GPAs Montessori Early School, it nonetheless also proves to be just as important for students facing the transition to high school. Middle school is a notoriously difficult time for students, as it serves as the transition from the usually well-structured elementary grades to a more independent and demanding high school. Whether its ensuring they feel safe and cared-for in the classroom, or keeping tabs on the wavering assessment of their own abilities to compete and succeed, or maybe just staying out of the way of the many swirling and raging hormones, teaching pre-teen students is usually a pretty tough row to hoe. In fact, its been said that those who teach middle school are most likely to take up bungee-jumping as a way to relax after their work day ends. One Stanford University professor took on the middle-school mindset recently in order to better define some of these issues, especially as it relates to a students confidence in his or her own ability to learn and grow. In research led by Carol Dweck, a professor of psychology at Stanford, the difference between a fixed and a growth mindset in school-aged children, specifically children in middle school, was examined. Dweck defined a fixed mindset basically as a belief by a student that intelligence is nearly always innate. In other words, either youre born with smarts and the ability to achieve great things or youre not. A growth mindset, according to Dweck after surveying 373 middle-school students, means that the student believes that achievement is variable and that problem-solving ability is something to be developed over time. [caption id="attachment_27026" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] A Stanford University study concludedthat to nurture a growth mindset in students, its important to encourage themby specificallypraising their efforts to solve problems themselves.[/caption] Dweck said that kids with a fixed mindset were more likely to be bored in school because they were less apt to try new things or new ways to solve problems. If they werent getting it, it probably was the teacher or the schools fault or they think they just dont have it. Growth-minded students, on the other hand, looked at school work as a series of puzzles and challenges to tackle, which made them less likely to complain that any external factor was causing their difficulties. Dweck concludes that to nurture a growth mindset, its important to encourage students by praising their efforts to solve problems rather than focusing on praise for how smart they are. For The Grosse Pointe Academy, in addition to academic excellence, shaping young people and preparing them for lifes challenges is one of the school's strengths. Acknowledging achievements is important, but setting goals and creating leadership opportunities is essential to building student confidence, according to school officials. This enables them to set and achieve their own goals and become more growth-minded students versus fixed. Lawrence DeLuca, GPAs assistant head of school for instruction and principal of grades 1-8, said it comes down to individual attention. Small class sizes at the Academy give teachers the opportunity to know their students on a much more personal level and to better recognize and encourage more individual growth, DeLuca said. Research shows that K-8 schools of fewer than 400 students are the best social environments for middle school children, he added. The Grosse Pointe Academy middle school program provides an academic, artistic, spiritual, physical, and social environment that promotes the education of the whole child. He said that because of small classes, middle school students at GPA have daily access to an advisor, which means they are more easily creating bonds not only with fellow students but with an engaging and caring faculty and staff that nurtures and advocates for students in and out of the classroom. We also provide high school counseling that offers individualized assistance in placing students in over a dozen of the top high schools in our area to ensure our students and families find the right high school fit, he said. [caption id="attachment_27027" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] Lawrence DeLuca, center, GPAs assistant head of school for instruction and principal of grades 1 through 8, said research shows that K-8 schools of fewer than 400 students are the best social environments for middle school children.[/caption] DeLuca noted that while studies have found a significant drop in test scores for students who attend stand-alone middle schools, scores for students in K-8 programs similar to the one at the Academy tend to stay constant or increase during middle school years. The proof is in the pudding. Roughly 70% of our students in grades five through eight rank in the top 10% nationally on the ERB CTP4 area tests and qualify for NUMATS, DeLuca said. NUMATS, or Northwestern University Midwest Academic Talent Search (NUMATS), is a gifted- and talented-student identification program. He said that not only does GPA provide a rigorous academic program that prepares middle schoolers according to their abilities and interests, the schools welcoming and encouraging environment makes them comfortable enough to participate in high school classes, some even while still at GPA. Plus, after graduating from GPA, roughly 80% of our graduates take AP and Honors courses in high school, he said. That is versus 46% at Grosse Pointe South and 32% of students nationally who take AP courses. For Grosse Pointe Academy's Amal El-Hosni, who teaches world language in the middle school, shes also a big believer in the nurturing part of the schools central mission as it applies to middle-schoolers, and how it helps to shape them in both academics and life. I make sure my students always know they are in a safe environment, and that its okay to fall and make mistakes, as long as they are willing to get up and try again, she said. "Some students might be afraid or reticent with such an approach, but in the end they usually rise up to the challenge and realize why I was pushing them. After all, this school is all about nurturing potential, and allowing students to discover their own strengths. For more information on the Academy's middle schoolas well as all of itsacademic programs or to set up a visit and tour, call 313-886-1221 or e-mail: jkendall@gpacademy.org.

item.title: Four more from Maria
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.content:encoded:
One hundred and three years this past December, Dr. Maria Montessori first traveled to the United States on a three-week lecture tour that included films of her European classrooms and a number of assemblies. Everywhere she went in America, she was met by large, enthusiastic crowds, even though at that time only about 100 Montessori schools had been established in the country. Today, there are more than 4,500 Montessori schools in the United States and about 20,000 worldwide. The Grosse Pointe Academy, which is home to Michigans longest continuous-running Montessori program, is pleased to offer four quotes from Maria Montessori, founder of the Montessori method, arguably the worlds most innovative education philosophy. Enjoy! "The child has a different relation to his environment from ours... the child absorbs it. The things he sees are not just remembered; they form part of his soul. He incarnates in himself all in the world about him that his eyes see and his ears hear." (from The Absorbent Mind, first published 1949) [caption id="attachment_27040" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] The Grosse Pointe Academy is home to Michigans longest continuous-running Montessori program.[/caption] "A three-year-old educated according to Montessori pedagogy, becomes a master of his hand and undertakes with a joy a variety of human activities. These activities allow him to develop the power of concentration." (from the San Remo Lectures, released in 1949) Under the urge of nature and according to the laws of development, though not understood by the adult, the child is obliged to be serious about two fundamental things the first is the love of activity The second fundamental thing is independence. (from What You Should Know About Your Child, first published in 1948) "The child's development follows a path of successive stages of independence, and our knowledge of this must guide us in our behavior towards him. We have to help the child to act, will and think for himself. This is the art of serving the spirit, an art which can be practiced to perfection only when working among children." (from The Absorbent Mind) Learn more about the Academys Early School Montessori program here.
